data: b"If ever a movie needed English subtitles, this is one of them. Her songs were beautiful and the story is great, but a lot is lost because I do not understand what they're saying. But it was a most refreshing movie out there now. Good acting and history."

b"`` Just Married '' is a painfully extravagant movie that is almost very light and cute. Ashton Kutcher and Brittany Murphy play a couple of Romeo and Juliet that has been repeated in so many films, it's revolting - he's the classic sports fan and the son of middle-income parents, and she's the daughter of a few billionaires. whose profession we never learned. Her parents preferred to marry her with the snobby Peter Prentice, a boring antagonist who is more of a hindrance than a real character. Anyway, the cute couple get married and travel to Europe, where their lies and unbelievable circumstances (they are expelled from a hotel after they spoil the circuitry trying to connect some kind of sex toy) hinder their fun. perfect honeymoon. The film was compounded by bad jokes, boring characters and clich & egrave; stories. I think I thought I'd laugh once. The terrible thing about this movie was how everything was unbelievable. Each character was able to pull a beautiful and comforting monologue from the air. Most of the speeches did not even fit the personality of the character, for example, Kutcher's character gave at least two of these monologues, and each one was one of the best parts of the script. Too bad they came out sounding awkward and clumsy, since the character was not supposed to be the brightest lamp in the box. Finally, the characters were painfully underdeveloped. We do not know whether Murphy's character likes to be rich or not, nor can we really discern whether she's a rich girl or an art-loving intellectual. We never find out what Murphy's father does, and although a good, strong relationship between father and son is suggested between Kutcher's character and his father, we never know for sure. Finally, an attractive blonde was constantly around the character of Murphy ... she was a sister? friends ? cousin ? That bothered me throughout the movie. So why not a star instead of two? Well, Murphy and Kutcher proved to be excellent actors with amazing chemistry together. Murphy especially brightened up the screen with his dazzling personality and soft, scratchy voice. Kutcher will forever be typified as the dumb face, but it's a character that matches well with him. I found them to be the only highlights of the movie. Bottom line: This movie kept me awake. It was quick and moderately pleasant, but something new or different was missing. See if you like fliks teen chick, not if your idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8ba movie is one that will keep you thinking."

b'I may not be able to add much to the comments, whose compliments I entirely agree with the content of this magnificent film, but I still felt compelled to offer my two cents on BluRay, which is equally fantastic. With the full measure of the glorious winner of the background of this now legitimately restored story in HiDef, the plot\'s inherent drama finally finally finally has a screen equally worthy of being presented - a fact Perpetually lost in every other presentation of video I\'ve seen before. It\'s actually an awe-inspiring revaluation as to the intended impact of this movie and, from any and all previous video issues of it, in fact a transformation from a first-class adventure of acceptably good scale to a first-class and global adventure. a remarkable spectacle! I daresay I do not approach myself looking so good when I remember seeing him at my local theater all those years ago. By the way, it looks so good, I do not think anybody would dream, with their appearance here, that this movie is actually wrapping its 50th anniversary. Of the opening credits, I see that the film was originally filmed in 70mm, so in much more detail than the most common 35mm films have. You can expect a similar performance on HiDef with other 65 or 70mm films, like 2001: A Space Odessy or Lawrence of Arabia - IF the disc transfer is good - and here it certainly is. The image inside the frame on this disc is always, and absolutely, as firm as the Rock of Gibralter. There was only the slightest amount of jitter, as seen in my setup, but again only rarely and almost imperceptibly when it was seen - still not sure if the disc was actually at fault or not. Not a hint of moir\xc3\xa9, anywhere. The sound is very good and much better than I had any reason to wait. Although John Barry\'s great soundtrack originally appeared in mono, it\'s by far the best I\'ve heard of it - it even has a better impression than the original (mono) soundtrack available on CD if my memory serves. However, the range of sound effects on this disc is either real stereo or, more likely, derived from various elements of isolated sound effects and then "panned" during post-production. There are also some interesting extras: more than two documentaries about the film\'s production, movie reviews, theatrical trailer and even a brief but interesting interview with John Barry himself about the origins of his ideas for the soundtrack. But, after all, I love it when such a majestic and monumental film like this gets the real treatment it does here. Sometimes the presentation is everything! Highly recommended! !'

b'I\'ve been a 3D nut for many decades. I pre-ordered this from amazon and man, what a disappointment! The quality of the video is just slightly better than the 3D bootleg of the 90\'s shutterglass (and at least the 3D DVD was FULL SCREEN) that was made from a Japanese VHD 3D disk. Even the 3D "red / blue" trailer for this movie (from the 3D Film Expo at the Egyptian Theater here in Hollywood) was full-screen. If you use Google in this title, you will find some sites with photo comparisons (PAL, NTSC, DVD, Blu-ray, etc ...) and you can clearly see that this 3D Blu-ray cuts the movie from ALL FOUR SIDES. Just a little bit is cut from the left / right, but it lacks a bit of the top and bottom to create that ratio of 1.85 in full screen. Part of 3D perception is lost because of this, and it\'s probably what others here meant with certain scenes looking like `` flat \'\' or `` 2D \'\'. One of the most remarkable scenes is the one in which Margot and Mark are talking in the livigroom. This wonderful photo is obviously set to 3D effect. Margot\'s hand rests on the final table in the extreme foreground, displaying that beautiful diamond ring. Guess what ? In this Blu-ray 3D version, your ENTIRE hand is completely cut! I watched these cut scenes throughout the movie ... characters cut through the trash, bits of cut-out lamps, etc. Yes, it\'s great to see that red dress look really red, but unfortunately the colors are severely overrated. I think I\'ll grab hold of `` House of Wax \'\' or `` Creature FTBL \'\' until criticism comes from other guinea pigs out there, LOL! I\'m sure others will agree that the black ink printed on the Blu-ray disc itself looks awful. I\'ve seen better labels on pirated DVDs! Anyway, just my 2 cents.'

b"This review is to emphasize that this version (Westlake Entertainment) of Escape from Sobibor (which is a great docudrama) is not the 143-minute uncut version as indicated in the Amazon listing and also indicated on the cover of the DVD. I have the TGG / Diamond version (also 120 minutes) which is a much better transfer."

b'If you look closely at the fine print of this DVD, you will see that it is not approved by the Wayne Foundation. And the boy shows it. The picture quality of this DVD has all the signs of being a DVD recording of a VHS copy of the movie. They did not even bother to use a new VHS tape - judging by the grainy texture and annoying glitches (flickering, "hair" on the screen, etc.), it was captured from an old copy of the tape. I have a VHS tape that has a better picture than this DVD. Everyone please write to the Wayne Foundation and tell them about the poor quality release of this movie! If we do, we\'ll be able to convince them to release widescreen, quality releases from Criterion from John Wayne\'s less famous films.UPDATE: OBSERVE! This comment DOES NOT APPLY NECESSARILY TO THE SPECIAL EDITION. Amazon is mixing all McLintock! comments in a bag. I do not know what the quality of the special edition (released in October 2005) is, but it is not necessarily the same as the previous editions.'

b'This movie is based on a true story, and I saw the original story of "A Haunting". "I was hoping the movie version would give me a more frightening version of the original story, but all I got was a bad acting, a dull plot and terrible effects. It seemed the director had a great idea in his head, but he could not project it properly. They have tried a lot to make the story "better". "As a result, the story came out as tacky and over. If you want to get a better and more accurate version of the story, check out the "A Haunting" version.'

b'... but a terrible DVD. The sound is simply old Dolby Surround and the movie is full screen. I find this very annoying. I always liked Joshua Tree and waited for the DVD release. I imagined widescreen, Dolby 5.1, trailers, comments and motion menus. But none of this happened. Artisan disappointed me so much with this poor and unimaginative release. I would like to start a campaign to get Artisan to change his mind. To get them to relaunch this amazing movie into widescreen. They should do this like this movie totally rocks. Even the current cover is painfully horrible. A grumpy photo of a Joshua Tree would be better. One last thing. Amazon and the back of the DVD claim that the runtime is 102 minutes when it is actually the unrated version 106. This version should remain intact in future widescreen release.'

b"If you want to be alone while watching Alone In The Dark, there is good news and bad news. The good news is that you will have your desire. The bad news is that misery loves company. Being hung by incarnated nipple clusters over a well of cacti and scorpions would be less painful than sitting through this garbage menage about aliens, monsters, nefarious scientists, abducted children, a paranormal and Tara. Reid as curator of museums. Pinch me, I must be dreaming. Better than a pinch of what a slap in the face, that's what this crap a movie provides. Alone in the Dark is supposedly based on an old Atari game, which I've never heard of. What I remember about the old Atari games were their rudimentary graphics and stories. I doubt the story of the film is even a consideration. So in order to fill in the blanks, writers Elan Mastai, Michael Roesch and Peter Scheerer lend and steal from other films. Best movies. Movies that make you realize that you're not just watching an imitation, but a really bad imitation, like Chuck Norris doing his homage to Judy Garland. I admit that his version of the Easter Parade left me in tears, but only because he was kicking me in the face. That was what it seemed like to see Alone in the Dark. I do not care about stupid and stupid horror movies, but I hate stupid, stupid horror movies that refuse to acknowledge this fact. Alone in the Dark comes with a poker face impossible to know if we should take this seriously. We are, but we are not, or more precisely, we can not. There is no room for maneuver in the script, direction or performance. Government conspiracies abound in Alone in the Dark, which meets paranormal investigator Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) joining an elite group of government agents to defeat an ancient evil. As an orphan, Edward escaped the clutches of the unscrupulous government agent / scientist Lionel Hudgens (Matthew Walker), whose depraved experiments turned children into half-blooded zombies. Now that Hudgens has found the final key to open the portal between darkness and light, it is up to Edward, former lover and healer Aline Cedrac (Reid) and command leader Burke (Stephen Dorff) to save mankind. whom I would call when definitive evil decides to attack humanity: two actors riding that straight path to the video and an actress better known for shimmering paparazzi. Was that a selection or return decision? Director Uwe Boll (The House of the Dead) does not help much, never allowing actors to step out of the thin paper box or express any emotion beyond the written word. If everyone in front of or behind the camera just recognized the obvious, Alone in the Dark would have been a joke. Computer generated monsters that never seem to be in the same frame as the actors, happy trigger commands, a complicated plot that does not make sense, paper doll characters, all the ornaments of a good goofy time. Too bad the guys behind Alone in the Dark did not fall into this trap."

b"I do not know who I'm feeling anymore, Stephen Dorff or Christian Slater. Dorff, who is a great actor, although you never know about the movies he is in, has not been anything but remote since the original Blade in 1998. Slater's career has declined over the years, practically taking part in some flop projects . Both actors walk peacefully through their roles in this latest video game for the film adaptation of director Uwe Boll, the same guy who brought us another video game adaptation, the incredibly bad House of the Dead. Alone in the dark is not much better, with a story so non-existent you'll be scratching your head wondering what's going on before you pray for all to be killed. Tara Reid is also on board as the smart girl, and as previous reviewers have mentioned, we know she's smart because she wears glasses. There is no redeeming factor about Alone in the Dark, and if you have been subjected to the House of the Dead farce, then you know what to expect here."

b'This DVD attempt to cram in about an hour the entire history of North American exploration. Given its purpose, I believe it does a pretty decent job. It summed up five hundred years of history and many dozens of expeditions and explorers in brief bits of information. I do not think this is a good educational tool, as it would probably be a little uninteresting - it does not have very interesting stories, just a stream of information. On the contrary, this is a good starting point for someone who wants to research the North American exploration and would like an introduction to the major events and people in their history. Not really something to excite people about the story, people seeing this should already be excited.'

b'Before watching this, do not make the mistake of including this movie in idiot comedies like "Tootsie" and "Mrs". Doubtfire. Although based on a true story, director Greenwald eschews many western (and Hollywood) conventions of bringing one of the best westerns of the 1990s. Suzy Amis plays Jo, a woman who trusts a few bad men too much. After escaping to the west and leaving her son out of wedlock, she is nearly raped by two soldiers. To hide from them, she wears men\'s clothing and heals her face, eventually using her new facade to get what she needs in the West to survive. Ian McKellen plays a woman who plays her, believing her to be a young man. She finally befriends Bo Hopkins, who has her best role in years, and starts a sheep ranch. She falls in love with a Chinese she has been forced to hire as a cook, and must eventually fight with a clump of cattle trying to steady herself and drive out the sheep farmers. Amis remembers Eric Stoltz in his scenes as a man, and is totally believable. McKellan and Rene Auberjonois have small but important roles, such as older paternal figures, whom Amis trusts, but they turn against her. Bo Hopkins is great as the neighbor Amis tolerates, befriends and tolerates. David Chung plays the Chinese man nicknamed Tin Man as a junk addict addicted to opium. It looks perfect for paper, life scars and everything. Heather Graham also has a small role as Amis\'s lover, and does her best with it. The most amazing aspects of this movie is what the film is not. There are no cute scenes of `` Yentl, \'\' in which Amis falls in love with a man as a man. The cattle company\'s war, a standard point of Western plot, never dominates history, or comes to a trivial conclusion. The final scenes, with Jo\'s unmasking, seem almost a farce, but when thought later, they play with great sincerity and excitement, especially Hopkins\' reaction. Greenwald\'s camera turns a small movie into an epic, with a beautiful Montana scenery. His screenplay is also very clever, never going for cheap laughs or the kind of exploration that a male director may have sought. I strongly recommend `` The Ballad of Little Jo. `` This is assessed (R) for physical violence, strong armed violence, some sexual violence, gore, some profanity, some nudity, sexual content, sexual references, drug abuse, and adult situations.'

b'I bought this DVD without having seen it in the movies or in the video. I bought it based on the strong comments I saw on the top ten lists at the end of the year. This is one of the few (just?) Great animated works that do not work like a musical. It depends solely on the strength of its characters to tell the compelling story of the young "Hogarth" (yes, Hogarth!) Who befriends a giant robot that fell to Earth during the 1950s. Of course, the military and other adults are suspicious of giant apparently benign. The real strength of this movie is that both adults and kids will enjoy it because it works on many levels. It\'s an astute commentary on the paranoia of the 1950s (without being heavy), an exciting adventure film and a comedy that has humor for adults and children. Both will fall in love with "Iron Giant" (voiced by Vin Diesal, from "The Rescue of Private Ryan"), who eventually teaches humans one or two things about loyalty and sacrifice. A word of warning for those with very young children: there are some "damn" and "hell" (3 or 4) throughout the film; therefore, its PG rating.'

b"It was the franchise's slugfest that fans thought would never happen except in the form of comic books. After years and years of failed attempts and false beginnings, the powers that finally came together. Hoping to capitalize on the surprise success of the merger of two successful horror franchises with Freddy vs. Jaso, two of the most popular science fiction creatures go all the way in Alien Vs. Predator with those pesky humans caught in the middle. It's not a clich\xc3\xa9; that this movie does not like. Disposable characters are broadly outlined. For example, a bottle cap worn around a character's neck is considered a defining feature. The film even manages to include the old chestnut where the characters surpass the fireball blast. Fans who expect the two alien races to start waiting for over an hour until the first battle, but it is quite impressive when they play around. like something out of a comic book. Of course, the fight scenes are pretty cool in all their CGI-assisted glory, but that's hardly an endorsement. Poor Lance Henriksen is playing here as a selfish businessman who provides the only human connection with the other Alien movies (it is hinted that he is the inspiration for the android bishop in Aliens). It is in only a quarter of the movie before being shipped quickly. There is an audio commentary by screenwriter / director Paul W.S. Anderson and the actors Lance Henriksen and Sanaa Lathan. They connect at the same time seemingly oblivious to the narrative mess that is this movie. Also includes an audio commentary by visual effects supervisor John Bruno and creator effects creators Alec Gillis and Tom Woodruff Jr. Anyone who likes to hear these details will find this track informative. There are three deleted scenes totaling two minutes and include a bit of Predator humor that was properly cut. Also included are two trailers and a gallery of comic book covers. for Alien from Dark Horse Vs. Series Predator.Alien vs. Predator was not worth waiting for and comic book fans will feel cheated. The movie begins slowly but once the Aliens and Predators start hitting each other, the weak script and awkward plot mercifully become the background. It's a shame because both alien races are poised for countless story ideas that subsequent sequences have not been able to capitalize on effectively. All we have left is a beautiful, numbered movie."

b"If you've never seen the EXORCIST, or have not seen it for a long time, this is a great opportunity to add this classic horror movie to your library! The acting, directing, cinematography, soundtrack and special effects stand up well to the test of time. Of note is that both the special effects and the music of the Tubular Bells are still wonderful, and not at all. Max von Sydow is also particularly memorable as Father Merrin. b'The third installment of the popular & quot; Beverly Hills Cop & quot; series is like a distant relative who comes to stay with you. At first, you are happy to see them and get refreshed in the old days, but they certainly tire quickly. This movie gets to that point after about fifteen minutes. Eddie Murphy is back as Alex Foley, the increasingly unlikely fish detective out of Detroit. Once again, Axel is fighting against the law enforcement, the Beverly Hills Police Department and the bad guys who killed his friend. Sound familiar? Even Serge (Bronson Pinchot) is back in a desperate and painful scene that seems to last forever. The direction of veteran John Landis, of Murphy, is acceptable, showing the usual talent of Landis to stroll and to do acrobatics. The script of the normally trusted Steven deSouza, regrettably, is kind of overcooked. It is never clear what the tone of the image is. The action scenes are very unlikely and often played for laughter, while the comedy scenes are forced and bland. History never builds the sense of risk and conflict that is essential for such a film. It is not a riot of laughter, nor is it remotely suspenseful. Also, any movie that makes Hector Elizondo - one of the best character actors around - looking bad has some serious problems. There are two good things about & quot; Cop III. & quot; One is an excellent action sequence set in an amusement park Ferris wheel. This is the only exciting part of the movie. The other thing I liked was the special guest series from several famous movie directors (like George Lucas), a typical Landis joke. At least it gives you something to look for in some pretty boring scenes.'

b"Great Milestones is an exploration of the breeding habits and mating rituals of various types of animals. Interesting aspects of this subject are how the moon and the tides regulate and synchronize certain elements of reproduction and how the weather also play a role. Not only are terrestrial animals studied, but some types of underwater creatures are also shown. In the second half of this documentary, parents who protect and feed their newborns are touched. Finish is a look at the young animals leaving the house or nest in the fight to join the circle of life. With just 60 minutes in duration, this feature can leave you wishing for more. The sound, the narration and the video are very well done in my opinion. No bonus is offered, except for some trailers from other programs. The chapters are a bit short due to the time limit, but what is presented is fun and enjoyable, however. As diverse as the animal kingdom is, we hope Reader's Digest will make more of these kinds of documentaries. If you are a fan of this type of subject, we recommend viewing."

b"The good news about this DVD is that it focuses more on Big Brother as a band, rather than exclusively on Janis Joplin, like other documentaries. Unfortunately, the sound quality is generally very poor, and the images are usually erased. This is especially noticeable because many of the same images have been used in other films like JANIS, MONTEREY POP, BIG BROTHER: BALL AND CHAIN, and various TV specials (A & E, Biography, VH1 and so on), so comparisons are very easy to do . I have re-editions of 78rpm vinyl records on CDs that have been digitally restored to provide a clearer sound than this DVD, and I have seen silent movie images restored in the same way, so I can only assume that this documentary was rushed with a eye fast buck and not much concern about the quality of production. That said, the DVD offers a fascinating insight into the band members at the time and right now. Some of them recall the Psychedelic Era with nostalgic fondness, while others have obviously clung and rehearsed their resentments for the last 40 years. If they had never met Janis Joplin, the Big Brother story could have been very different - if no one had ever heard of them, or if they would have become great on their own terms blues, we'll never know. But this DVD offers tempting glimpses not only of what it was, but of what it could have been."

b"I bought this DVD as a stocking stuffer for my husband. We watched together in preparation for an upcoming trip to Amsterdam. The film, which chronicles the life and struggles of the Dutch painter Vincent Van Gogh, was very well done and one of Kirk Douglas's best performances. At times, it was disturbing due to a moving description of Van Gogh's serious mental illness. Other strong performances by Anthony Quinn, who played the painter Paul Gauguin, and James Donald, who played the brother of Van Gogh, increased the pleasure of the film. The film was visually stunning and it was possible to see the evolution of Van Gogh's art. I look forward to my trip to see Van Gogh's art in person."

b'Flash Gordon is as cheesy and fun as half a century ago, but the people who put this package together were lazy. There are a dozen individual episodes of Flash Gordon on each disc, but there are no "interruptions" between them. If you watch three a night and want to continue from where you left off the next day, you will have to restart the disc again. There is no way to go straight to the next episode. You have to repeat the episodes that preceded it. This is simply lazy or slopy by the people who put the package together. They do not deserve your business.'

b"Hellboy 2 continues the story of Hellboy and his work with a paranormal agency. He is still surrounded by friends and a new leader who reminds me of Doctor Who's Brain of Morbius. What happens during the film is an Earth battle between Humans and Elves / Goblins / Ogres / Trolls, and Humans are almost exterminated by Elves of the Golden Army of giant robots. But in a moment of compassion, the King of the Elves decides not to wipe out the remaining humans and calls a truce that humans can build their cities but leave the forests to the Elves and Trolls. The years passed and humans forgot the truce and took over most of the land of the Elves and Trolls. The Prince of the Elves has decided that his father is weak to do anything about humans and decides it's time to wake up the Golden Army again. Brimming with tons of action and a twist in what it's like to be different, Hellboy 2 delivers the goods. Also included are the following special features: 6 deleted scenes, Troll Market Tour, Comments, set visits and an animated comic epilogue."

b'Hollywood werewolves have been characterized as serious creatures who walk behind their victims as a Groucho Marx hirsuit. The image of this lopant werewolf was originally recorded by Lon Chaney and successive generations of actors just continued their style. But with John Werewolf in London, director John Landis not only pushed the werewolf back down so that he resembled nothing less than a mobile tank lycan, but also added a touch of humor needed to force viewers to move away momentarily of the blood to contemplate what they had just seen. David Naughton and Griffin Dunne are two Americans walking through a dark swamp in English, rising from the heights of Heathcliffe, WUTHERING HEIGHTS. They are attacked by a howling werewolf who kills Dunne, but only bites Naughton before he himself is killed by villagers. This introductory scene in which Naughton and Dunne are banned by a hostile group of pub drinkers is a haunting mix of frightening fear fermented with mordazity. It is precisely this mixture of horror and humor that suggests that the viewer engages in extremes of emotions ranging from laughter to gagging, with the viewer sometimes not sure which to choose. Jenny Agutter is a very underrated actress who shines like a nurse who falls in love with Naughton, and can not understand a radical change in her eating habits, since he increasingly prefers her extra rare flesh. Agutter adds an unexpected dimension to a role that, in the hands of another, less competent director, could have relegated her to little more than an attractive piece of eye candy for English eyes. Griffin Dunne provides visceral humor like a corpse that keeps popping up, like the ghost of Hamlet\'s father, at appropriate times to remind Naughton that the price to pay to get rid of the lycanthropy may be a little too high. And then there\'s the song, played in the same vein as Simon & amp; Garfunkle\'s letter from THE GRADUATE, but here the "crucible" of Credence Clearwater Revival Bad Moon Rising & quot; punctuates the scenes of transformation that a bad moon leads to bad vibrations. Finally, Rick Baker\'s special effects are impressive, as you can see bones lengthening, skin growth and nostrils lengthening, as Naughton is seen scaring himself as much as the audience. Ultimately, WEREWOLF AN AMERICAN IN LONDON is an innovator in the werewolf genre in that vision and sound combine to present creatures as helpless in their own way as their victims are on their own.'

b'Amazon to its complete discredit is posting comments from two totally different movies as one! There are two versions of The Big Trail - a 35mm shot and 110 minute duration and released in 2003, and a new widescreen version released in 2008 with a duration of 122 minutes and shot in Grandeur 70mm and completely different in scale and impact. The important version, to add further confusion, comes with the first as a box set. Potential buyers need to be aware of this! `` Full Screen Edition \'\' will confuse many buyers - in fact, it\'s nothing like that, so I rate it the lowest rating. The film in its historical format deserves five FIVE STARS! and can be purchased from the set titled `` The Big Two Disc Special Edition \'\' which not only includes this lower version DVD but also the most important and immensely historic version of the movie\'s `` WIDESCREEN EDITION \'\'. was shown for the first time. Again, I would easily rate this widescreen editing DVD with five stars! The widescreen version is 122 minutes long and is taken directly from the original 70mm. The `` Full Screen Edition \'\' masked here as what it is not is not a jagged version of the widescreen image, but it\'s actually a shorter version (110 minutes) 35mm at the same time from Fox to most theaters in the world. day that could not turn the huge film. Yes, it\'s a real movie and certainly good - until you see the 70mm. My low rating is to draw attention to all these important details that are not mentioned in most of the positive reviews. Most of what makes this epic movie in scale is much better appreciated in a widescreen format, and not the totally confusing full-screen edition as offered here. I am usually tolerant of these awards in the television medium - watching the widescreen "Lawrence of Arabia \'\' into anything smaller than a 60-inch screen is like peeking out a colored ribbon stretched out in the middle of the television. Faced with such a tiny image, it\'s understandable that many people opt for cut or \'full\' screen versions instead of but the main point of `` The Big Trail \'\' is the magnificent GRANDEUR format, a monstrous 70mm image offering breathtaking detailing of the vast panoramas that make up the film\'s settings. with the great black and white landscape photography of the best western photographers of America.If you have a large television screen, just try r "The Big Trail" on Widescreen on Fox `` Two Disc Special Edition \'\'. Once you\'ve seen the movie in its full glory on a good sized screen, you\'ll wonder why Fox launched "The Big Trail" in 2003 in a short and very misleading "Full Screen Edtion." To order the widescreen version of `` The Big Trail \'\' and see a milestone in American filmmaking, something absolutely spectacular as it was planned to be seen. The Big Trail My only complaint is Fox. The insistence on attaching the full-screen DVD to the Widescreen DVD and charging us for two DVDs when most viewers want to see only one version.'

b"Although the 2006 Le Mans DVD looks similar to the previous incarnations, the extremely poor video quality due to a lot of distortion and pixelation definitely makes it the worst of the Le Mans DVDs. It's the same: very test and qualify highlights with just over an hour dedicated to the race itself. However, poor picture quality makes this DVD look almost like a VHS tape. The distortion and pixelation is sometimes hideous and really distances itself from the pleasure of watching the race. If you compare this DVD side-by-side with the Le Mans DVDs covering the 2002 and 2003 races, the 2006 edition is definitely worse. Another complaint is that the DVD covers highlights and qualifications twice - adding a lot of repetition to the DVD. s run time of 140 minutes. This has been a continuing habit for the producers of this series, who have piled themselves up in this featured show that aired on SPEED before their live coverage of Le Mans. This preview, which takes slightly more than an hour to cover tests and qualifications, leads to the actual beginning of the DVD, which then goes back for more tests and qualifications. The lack of special features and cameras in the car is another disappointment. In the 2005 DVD, producers included special cameras in the car for the first time (although the DVD had some pixelation problems). In the 2006 version, there are no special features and filming the camera in the car does not exceed a few seconds for each car that shows. It would have been great if there had been a complete lap in the car on board the Audi R10 Turbo Diesel. Overall I would still recommend this DVD to any Le Mans fan as it is the best disc of a race that saw Audi triumph a diesel car for the first time in the 74 year history of the race. He also does a good job showing all the action of the race and all the drama and glamor that make up the annual festival of resistance in the Circuit de la Sarthe. It is disappointing that the image quality is so poor."
b'I ordered this DVD for my brother, a former Marine. The whole family watched and loved it! It shows fantastic pictures of all the bands and the silent drilling squad. Great dvd!'

b"Finally, I delivered all the advertisement and actually went to watch the Minority Report. The question I have left now that I've seen is: what was all the hype about? Although I have to admit that some of the special effects generated by computer were impressive, the performance lacked any kind of substance. However, what bothered me the most was the incredible amount of product placement throughout the film. Mr. Spielberg was not sure he would make enough money at the box office to announce Aquafina, Pepsi, Gap, Lexus and Nokia throughout the film? Overall, I spent two and a half hours in the movie, during which I wondered more than once if all the people who were walking in the movies during the movie were as bored as I was. The bottom line is, good special effects for free and some interesting scenes like the chase in the car factory, other than that I can watch home commercials on my TV for free."

I can summarize my criticism with this remark from director Petrie because he was interested in directing the film. He says it was because he discovered Kate Hudson was attached to him. Aha So basically, if the film does well at the box office, then it will launch Hudson\'s career and career. Sorry Petrie, but that\'s not good enough for me.'

b'"Ring Around the Rosie" starring Gina Philips ("Jeepers Creepers") and Tom Sizemore ("The Rescue of Private Ryan"). I was interested in their names, but unfortunately the film is terribly annoying, although it takes less than 90 minutes. Gin Philips plays Karen, a young businesswoman who inherits a house in a remote place inland that may or may not be haunted. Near the house lives a caretaker played by Tom Sizemore, who may or may not be possessed by something evil. The premise is very familiar, recently used in films like "The Amityville Horror", and with the right direction, the film would be exciting. But you will soon realize that there are no emotions of any kind, not even a surprise. by a sudden big sound, in "Ring Around the Rosie", which introduces many pieces of recycled images seen in other thrillers - from rudimentary tricks like shadows moving behind the door, a strange reflection in the mirror, strange noise at midnight or not trusted neighbor looking at the protagonist, at the heroine plagued by nightmares and his buried memories of the past. The film also has a lovely boyfriend of Karen (Randall Batinkoff) and her adorable little sister (Jenny Mollen). The first one leaves the house while Karen stays to clean the house; the last one gets there and what Karen sees and hears starts to get weirder. Considering the nature of the conclusion and suggested history of Karen\'s childhood (which I can not reveal here), there may be some psychological explanations about the strange events that terrify Karen, as in other thrillers like "The Others." \'\' That\'s what I thought while trying not to sleep, but no matter how I try, I can not find one in this disconnected story that is confusing and illogical. If you see a character falling from the window and another character catches you in his arms in a cartoon-like way, you realize that this is not a good psychological thriller. Or maybe I\'m thinking too much. Probably this is another poorly written horror movie that you can find at your video store, borrow and regret it later. Whatever it was, I was bored and I can say quite confidently.'

This video was made in 1987 and it is said that Bianchi was on parole in the 1990s, something that Dr. Orne believes has a good chance of getting from Bianchi's tactic of no remorse - none memory was gaining alliances. However, while Toole's face reveals an idiot child amused by his own play, Bianchi is the banality of evil, a soft surface that can not be trusted. The video concludes with survivors of serial killers, including the mother of Sharon Tate, who meet regularly to monitor condemnation murderers' conditional hearings. One can only imagine if they were able to influence Bianchi's release, since Orne predicts that once this form of obsessive / compulsive behavior is exercised, there is no stopping. In Dr. Orne's opinion, no matter how good the prisoner Bianchi had been, once free, he would resume. Some may feel sorry that these men escaped the death penalty because they were in states where it was abolished, and the idea that life imprisonment is a form of punishment worse than execution is diluted by conditional and good behavioral conditions of service. This may sound harsh, but Dr. Orne says there is no civilized method of punishment effective enough to be an impediment - the best that can be done is to keep the perpetrators isolated from the rest of society. There are no parallels between the killers seen here, with no similarities that could explain what triggered their actions. If we are not able to understand their behavior, at least we may be grateful to have been interrupted, at least for a while."

b'About the only thing wrong with this image is the title. Adapted from the novel "Red Dragon" by Thomas Harris, it was decided to change the title. Probably thinking that most American movie goers would think it\'s a Kung Fu movie or something. Probably right. This is also prior to the most acclaimed sequel "The Silence of the Innocents," by the same author. It\'s another great Michael Mann movie, with style and substance. Style can bother some people. It is filmed with various unnatural tones including violet, blue and green. Although they may not be realistic, they always seem to fit the scene. Mann and his photographer put cameras in interesting places. Take for example the austere white cell of Hannibal Lector (Brian Cox). We see both Reader and Will Graham (William Petersen) centered between the same 2 bars, with quick cuts back and forth. Another camera sits above the room. This movie is not really about Dr. Lector however. It\'s about a serial killer known as The Tooth Fairy (Thomas Noonan - really scary). While Petersen struggles with his own sanity, he marries the killer using his ability to enter the killer\'s head. He stole this theme for his TV series "Miami Vice" about the same time. Another great tactic for which Mann is known is the use of music. Here we have an original soundtrack from The Reds and Michel Rubini, not to mention the incredibly cool climactic scene with Iron Butterfly\'s In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida.'

b"Once upon a blue moon, there arises a pleasure for all that uplifts the spirit. `` Strictly Ballroom '' is one of those films. Directed in a delightful high-key style by Baz Luhrmann (WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE'S ROMEO + JULIET, MOULIN ROUGE) in his crazy debut (the first in what would be called Red Curtain Trilogy), the film tells the story of a ballroom dancer who joins an ugly duckling, left-footed, when his independent style gives him the contempt of his more conventional-minded colleagues. Together, they give their all and aim to make the dreams of the National Championship title come true. To say that this movie is incredible would be a euphemism. It is one of the most gloriously entertaining and inspiring films of all time. The cast is simply magnificent and Luhrmann presents his style of direction and editing smart and fast here. He brilliantly uses an opening documentary style and occasional interludes that help better understand the adorable characters. This works wonderfully! This is definitely the feel-good movie of the decade. It's hypnotic, strange, and deeply heartfelt - a delightful delight for the public. A highly recommended must!"

b"I love the first two Anne of Green Gables movies. I saw them for the first time on PBS and had the original VHS tapes released by Disney. Sullivan's first DVD releases had a very low visual and audio quality. This new set - expensive - brings together the four films together, all in widescreen 16x9. I do not like the other two movies, so I'll just comment on the first two. They were originally filmed in 4x3 format, with the television in mind (I read that they may have touched the outside). I'm not an expert, but these new widescreen formats look cropped. Thus, information is lost with these new transfers. Is that so bad? Yes, because I feel that the original proportions of these films should be 4x3 (or 1.33: 1), as they were originally transmitted. Even worse, the image quality looks so digitally erased that many details that were originally visible are no longer visible. The audio looks OK; the default is the original stereo 2.0 mix. Annoyingly, closed captioning seems to have been done by imbeciles. For the first movie, the first disc (fortunately, each movie has two discs) has fairly good subtitles. The second disc has the caption all in IN CHALL CAPS and is full of errors. Very poor quality! ! At this price point, I would not recommend the fans to repurchase these movies if they were already owned. However, as an FYI, I contacted Sullivan Entertainment and they said they have no plans to release the movies on blu-ray."
b'What a waste of money that was. They did not even make Justin sing a song so I could see if I wanted to buy his other dvd.'

b'A sequel to director Ridley Scott\'s "Alien" was inevitable, of course. This traditional horror film set in space simply earned a lot of money for the studio to simply leave it alone. Surprisingly, when director James Cameron took over, he was determined to make a different film rather than just redo the first one. Thus, "Aliens" was adventurous, taking the story in new and exciting directions as a thread of action and adventure rather than another horror film. In fact, several critics think "Aliens" is better than "Alien". `` But now it comes `` `Alien 3` `- as an unnecessary sequence to a great movie as we have seen in a while. First director David Fincher and four writers have created another horror film, trying on existential tones while creating the alien in this movie, Moby Dick, by Ripley. `` But `` Alien 3 `` starts altering the ending of its predecessor and knocking down almost all the characters we care about. Fans will remember that Ripley (Sigourney Weaver), Hicks, Newt and the android bishop escaped in a spaceship at the end of "Aliens". \'\' But this movie begins with its expulsion from the ship and the forced landing on a planet-prison, which kills them all except Ripley! Ripley discovers that the only surviving monster is still with them. Soon, she\'s organizing the prisoners to be alert, but since there are no weapons of any kind all over the planet, they end up playing hide and seek with the creature for most of the film. of problems with this movie, but the worst is his somber dark motive; lack of friendly characters; the dislike of the premise of the film, which has Ripley eventually discovering that she has an alien queen growing inside her; and a long sequence of persecutions so obscure and edited so chaotically that it becomes confused. Those looking for thrills or some enhancement in the early films will be disappointed. Those who seek a headache will have come to the right place. And why is "Alien 3" (rather than simply "Alien 3" or "Alienz" or "Alien: One of These Drooling Monsters Survived After All"? It\'s probably just a trick to getting writers like me to ponder the issue and give the film a little more paint. "It worked.'

b'As some reviews show, if you love this movie, you\'ll love it; if you detest it, you * will * really hate it. Since I\'ve seen it twice, and I\'m ready to see it again, you can put me firmly into the first category - I have not been so transported and moved by a movie since "The Fountain". (which evoked similar responses of love or hate to viewers). This requires the voluntary suspension of cynicism, which I suspect is a point of contention for some ... but if you are willing to open your mind, and your heart even more, you will be amply rewarded. simple, as it should be: a thread that goes through the lives of several characters, which brings them to the main events of the 1960s. Wealth comes in the evocation of the times, in the countless little details revolving around the characters. And most important, when all is said and done, this is a love story, beautifully and poignantly told. If you have felt the intense emotions expressed in these beautiful songs then you will identify with Jude & Lucy, Sadie & JoJo and all your friends. Not only romantic love but also genuine love for others as brothers and sisters, we all together in this confusing and stimulating world. "Are there any weird moments or scenes a little too precious for contemporary tastes?" Of course ! But that does not really matter, because one of the characteristics of the 1960s was the willingness to take ridiculous risks, risking looking foolish or even falling face to face. I\'m glad that Julie Taymor has taken similar risks here because it helps capture the sensitivity of the time, a sensitivity that has led to tremendous creativity and innovation. And it\'s not just this time. The questions of unnecessary war, the demonization of the Other, of intolerance and fear of change, of mistrust of the imagination - are not as potent today as they have always been? But while the film is definitely on the side of the counterculture at its best, Julie Taymor does not hesitate to show how even the best idealistic intentions can get in dark places, as with some demonstrators moving to the bombs. A hymn of peace and love, is also well acquainted with grief and despair. Certainly, the film ends with the anthem, "All You Need Is Love," a song that was rejected by some as an irredeemably naive & dated flower power artifact. But I remember something George Harrison once said, when he was asked if love really * is * all you need - he replied that even if it is not * everything * you need, if you do not have it then how good it is the rest? Yes, it is a bright cloud of sunlit nostalgia in a sense ... but it is also a reminder that there is more to life than fear and darkness, that there is hope even in the midst of madness and chaos. And in that sense, it\'s a very contemporary film with a vital message. Higher, happily recommended!'

b'A story within a story on a cruise ship - the superficial history is of a "seven-year itch". A respectable, childless British couple celebrating this volunteer anniversary is unabashedly warned (in relation to her husband, anyway) by an Indian sage that children are better marital therapy than a cruise to India. Lust takes over the seemingly conservative Brit played perfectly by Hugh Grant and makes him a fool. Yes, this happens to men all the time. On this cruise, the British couple find the sexy French siren and her crippled, older, infectious husband who clings to her British husband to tell his autobiographical novel published in his book. And as for the writer\'s inner story and his French obsession, this shows how "greed" for hedonistic fantasy can lead to obscure, sadistic, or at least lamentable behavior. Suffice it to say that everyone learns this lesson in their own way in the end. A subtle theme here is the portrait of the unsuccessful writer, who buys fantasy with great force and tries to make life imitate art until his life and his art fall short of expectations. any success, (like lust in the seven-year male itch, is another truism - failed artists often go far into fantasy, giving up the realism that ultimately causes frustration and failure) story orally to a mere idiot on a cruise that completely loses its point and is ready to profit from his perfectly respectable life by a brief and scandalous state of sadness, just as he has made the cripple a detestable and abominable loser. Much like the Siren song by Homer (who was also cruising the Mediteranian, was not he?) Great score by Vangelis too, capturing romance and tragedy on a theme.'

b"I would recommend this movie to adults and kids alike. It has something of interest for all age groups. There are beautiful landscapes inspired by the southwest, as the story takes place in the desert of southwestern Arizona in Navajo lands. There is a story too, of two young men who have lost their goat, and they think she wandered into a gorge known as & quot; Cougar Canyon & quot; a place that should be haunted, according to the Navajo legend. They must go in to find the goat, of course, and are surrounded by many dangerous mishaps before successfully fulfilling their mission. The true stars of this film, however, beyond the beautiful landscape, is the superb wildlife photography of the desert in its natural habitat. There is a battle between a badger and a puma, or wild cat, as it is most commonly known, with a surprise ending. The close-ups of a diamond rattlesnake are incredible, and the narration is superb, too. This movie is reminiscent of the old Disney Nature Documentary series that used to appear on television years ago in the 1970s. I enjoyed it immensely, and I am an old citizen, but I can see where it would attract kids too, as they are usually fascinated with wild creatures such as rattle snakes, wild cats, black bears, etc. in their natural environment. In fact, it is very educational, especially for us city dwellers. I can not say enough good things about this movie, you'll just have to see it for yourself."

b"I do not like this movie. It deserves 5 stars for outstanding acting, a horrifying and moving story based on true accounts, dark scenarios and photography, and a mood steeped in despair. A German journalist, Nina Hoss as the mermaid with dark eyes, beaten, unintentional, remains behind in Berlin to document the invasion of the Russians (Soviets). Soon, she finds herself involved in the rape and destruction of the city, and they are defenseless civilians. After repeated attacks against herself, in desperation, she seeks a protector and meets a mysterious Russian officer (Evgeny Sidikhin) with a haunted past. Interested in it, but a bit reluctant, he agrees, and what follows becomes a tale of relationships and commonalities in the midst of hell on earth. Without wishing to justify them, writers to some extent show both sides of the conflict. Russians, in general, yearn for their families, hate the war that dragged them there, and report terrible memories of the atrocities committed by the Germans in their homeland. Paying evil for evil does not settle your actions at all, but I suppose this brings some sort of balance and understanding to the story. Fortunately, the robberies are shown non-gratuitously, and there is a nudity scene to make a point, but this is for graphic footage. But one gets the message. The whole movie is depressing. I think the only sense of hope provided comes from the heroine's desire to survive, to maintain her sanity, and a sense of decency, no matter what. The written epilogue is almost as disturbing. The response of societies is to hide the past instead of dealing with it. A difficult film. I do not watch again."

Of course the animation and the scenes were very beautiful - but that was a departure from what people know about Disney. Disappointed with this.'

The musical highlights are practically every song, but a short list would include 'Trouble', '76 Trombones', 'Marian the Librarian' and 'The Sadder But Wiser Girl'."

b'`` 28 Days Later \'\' is easily the best horror movie I\'ve seen in a long time. What struck me most was how clever it was; that is, the suspension of disbelief was very manageable. Once I got the idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8ba virus affecting someone that way and spreading so quickly, the rest of the plot made perfect sense to me. The few questions I had were easily informed about a beer with my friends. When I heard they were making a sequel, I got really excited and really set my timeline. Opening night, first showing after I left work I was there. Three hours later, I was banging my head on the table and wondering if there was enough beer in the world to understand what I had just seen. "28 Weeks Later" should become a case study in film schools on how to take all that is good about an incredible movie and set it aside for sequel. As mentioned in some other reviews, the plot holes are huge and relentless. My favorites are: 1) the children simply leave the security zone and we even see soldiers in the watchtower just let them go, 2) no one is monitoring or keeping the survivor infected (but not symptomatic), 3) the husband she is dumb enough to kiss her, and 4) no matter how many blocks of the city the boy is frantically impelled, his father "roars" appears quickly and concentrates on attacking him and only him. I was especially eager to see the virus spreading through a crowd, as was reported in the first movie. Do not . When it hits the fan at the train station, what happens? The lights go out and we are given a lot of quick and strobe pictures. Wow, thanks. Unless you\'re epileptic, there\'s nothing scary about it. I give it two stars mainly because I can not give \'Days\'\' seven. Well, let\'s call one for the opening sequence and one for the ending. If it were not for the promise of seeing France get it in the next film, this movie would have totally diverted me to any future "Anything 28".'

b'There are nice surprises in this film: Tori Spelling\'s comedic ability, some original songs, a beautiful cast and a premise full of comedic possibilities - two cute New York guys trying to find a place to have sex. But it would take much better writing and character development to do this in the futile farce that strives so hard to be. Good attempt though, and there are rewards. Gabriel (Christian Campbell), an adorably nerdy and aspiring songwriter with a quirky smile, catches Mark (John Paul Pitok), a darkly seductive and muscular Go-Go dancer (do they really still call them that?), On the subway . This is your fantasy man (rightly) coming to life. The two return to Gabe\'s apartment, where they find their best stand-alone friend (Spelling), an actress, printing 150 resumes. This is planning for a lot of auditions, n\'est-ce pas? It is the first in a series of frustrating attempts to be alone and although there are a few funny moments to be sure, the comic results are questionable. The roommate straight up appears with his own trick and throws away. In their continuing quest for privacy, they find a Broadway Queen, a drag queen, and other characters, each more self-absorbed than the last. And they call the 70\'s "& quot; I & rsquo; s no one notices that Mark and Gabe, hand in hand and fidgeting and insinuating, may want to be alone.Gabe can not blow his horn and just say it. On top of that, after a full night of meeting Mark, with some lovely private moments along the way, Gabe insults him, acting like it\'s still just a trick. a reel, is much more complacent and sweet than a gorgeous piece is capable of being in real life, so it seems that things will work out. four.'

b"Based on a true story, Nigel Cole's CALENDAR GIRLS is a capricious, touching, but sometimes trivial movie. Trivial only in that there are many moments when nothing of real importance happens, and the crisis points are predictably mushy and exaggerated. But a charming cast still manages to entertain. The idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bmore than 50 natural women is difficult to understand, but these women are so elegant and attractive, and the calendar becomes so well done that it can not be avoided when the calendar becomes an international success. Helen Mirren, long-awaited an Oscar, brings her role as Chris, the instigator of the calendar, to a wonderful enjoyment. Ciaran Hinds (Sum of All Fears, Cradle of Life by Lara Croft) is very good, as her husband, whose farewell letter to a sneaky newsboy, causes a breakup in marriage. Julie Walters (Oscar-nominated for years by Educating Rita) does the same with Mirren in her role of widow whose death of the husband inspires the calendar. The other ladies, Annette Crosbie and Penelope Wilton especially, are all very talented in their performances. It's not a shake-earth movie, but an uplifting one in that it proves that beauty is not relegated to the young, perhaps the young at heart ."

b"Before I saw The Girl Next Door, I hoped it was a typical teen sex movie. After watching it, it became one of my favorite movies, if not my favorite. It's a love story and a comedy in just one. Emile Hirsch plays Matthew Kidman, a high school student who is a great student and good kid, but he's kind of nerdy and did not do anything memorable all through high school. This changes when he meets his new neighbor Danielle, played by Elisha Cuthbert. Danielle is beautiful and Matthew instantly falls in love with her. Shortly after sighting her, he sees her undressing by the window and can not help but watch. Danielle catches him watching her and gets angry at first, but then it seems she fell in love with him too. Danielle is a former porn star, whom Matthew does not discover until her friend Eli (played by Chris Marquette) shows her a video of her. To further complicate matters, Danielle's former producer / ex-boyfriend Kelly (played by Timothy Olyphant) appears one day and wants Danielle to return to the adult film market. Kelly and Matthew get on well at first, but that changes when Matthew tries to get Danielle out of the porn industry, which Kelly does not like at all. Eli and Kelly are two characters who really steal the show in this movie. Eli is the nerdy friend of Matthew who gets excited all the time and obsessed with sex and hot women. He had some of the funniest lines in the whole movie. Kelly (the porn director who used to work with Danielle and also used to hang out with her) is the cool, smart guy who caught me in almost every scene he was in. I could not decide whether to love him or hate him - he's a nice and funny guy when he and Matthew are friends, but when Matthew makes him angry, he becomes psychotic and violent. I do not want to give up too much. in this movie, but Danielle makes Matthew do things he never imagined he would do. It really is a case of attraction of opposites: Matthew falls in love with the wild adventurous side of Danielle, and Danielle falls in love with the innocence and purity of Matthew. In several scenes, you can say that Danielle really is a good person, she does not really want to be in the porn business, and she really cares about Matthew. Matthew feels the same about Danielle and puts himself in many risk situations for her. This movie was so touching that I cried in parts, and I do not cry easily. However, there were also such funny parts that I could not stop laughing (especially the scenes with Eli and Kelly). Definitely worth watching and underrated."

b'I do not understand why other countries have all 4 seasons available and the United States does not. This is a great show and should be available here. I have most shows recorded on TV, but I would love to have a box set from this show.'

b"This is still one of my favorite shows to date. I really enjoy reviewing the episodes over and over again. This is the second last season and is one of the best seasons. Obviously, over the years, children are growing and maturing and this brings some interesting situations. In the episode Fast Friends, Steph goes out with children who smoke and make her feel pressured to do the same. I also like the apartment where Steve buys an apartment and DJ sleeps on the couch. Danny finds her (after she arrives late at home) and gets very angry. Full House is a great show that I'm sure today's kids would still like, and older kids like me still like it because I grew up watching it. There's never been a cooler guy (or cuter) than Uncle Jesse, and the love between the whole family is great and fun to watch. This is one of the best seasons and any fan should definitely have this in their collection."

b"You think Hollywood would have no problem making a movie about Hollywood. Think again. It's true there have been some great photos that Hollywood looks at. The oldest I can think of is A Star is Born, 1937, which was remade as an even better film in 1954. 1950 Sunset Boulevard is one of the biggest movies ever made, and a few years later came Singin 'in the Rain, a classical music. However, over the years, the industry has produced more bad films about itself than the good ones. America's Boyfriends are somewhere in between. Its beginning is quite promising, but it hesitates and descends the hill after that. Lee [Billy Crystal] is a Hollywood press agent with big problems. His boss, Dave [Stanley Tucci], needs him to promote the newest movie starring Gwen Harrison and Eddie Thomas [Catherine Zeta-Jones and John Cusack]. The duo used to be the most popular and most popular couple in the United States, and audiences gathered to watch their films. Now that they are on the verge of divorce and can not see each other, they are mailbox poison. Lee must figure out a way to convince the press that Gwen and Eddie are coming back together without letting the two stars know what he's doing. He asks for the help of Gwen's sister, Kiki [Julia Roberts], who not only resents the way Gwen orders her, but is also secretly in love with Eddie. Then there is the problem of the film itself. All the studio saw were the opening credits. Director [Christopher Walken] does not want to show it until he has made some changes. These changes will result in a film quite different from the one the studio paid $ 86 million to make. Reading the above synopsis makes me see just how funny and insightful American boyfriends could have been. The plot leaves ample space for farce and satire, but the writers did not seize the opportunity. Instead of being bright, fragile and insightful, the story is cute, cloying and meek. Most of Hollywood's chances of laughing at herself are wasted. This is Julia Roberts. As much as I've finally come to respect her, I do not think she's right in a normal role. In addition, she made the ugly duckling into a swan routine many times before. The film is basically a vanity project for Billy Crystal, which he also produced, and for director Joe Roth, who used it to launch his new company, Revolution Studios. They were probably afraid of upsetting the Hollywood establishment, of which they are part. If your mind wanders while watching a movie, it usually means that you are not catching you. There are several scenes in America's Sweethearts, where a character says something and everyone in the room chokes. I started to think about it. In all my life, I've never seen anyone say anything that would make all the listeners choke, and I've met some very bold people. This is something that happens only in movies. So I started listing in my head other things you see only on the celluloid. Before I knew it, the movie was over."

b"The hostel garnered much controversy after the release, and spawned a generally uncomfortable set of public reactions. Many responded with hatred of the violent and inflexible nature of the film. My problem with this is not violence. I can not connect to the first half of the movie, which is about regular male fool behavior while traveling through central Europe. All this becomes a long wait to see what you expect in the second half, and provides very little development for what we will eventually have to endure. All the violence in the film is hard, personal and disturbing. It's not fun, but in a broader, very interesting sense. It makes you think about the world, and what dark places can exist where anything or anyone can be bought for the right price. This DVD contains some very good features, and in general a very good set of extras, including a featurette that is almost entirely about the inspiration and reaction of the movie, and how much of it is based on reality. Eli Roth is certainly a smart man, and he's off to tell a message, not just shock, but due to the hard and hard nature of the film, it's hard to digest, and it's too uncomfortable to be really memorable. Maybe there's a bit too much truth for the Hostel."

b'TETSUJIN 28 is a Japanese live-action film based on the Mitsuteru Yokoyama manga series, best known in the West for its 1963 animated black-and-white adaptation, which was aired on US television in 1966 under the title " Gigantor ". "There are some pretty spectacular scenes here of two giant robots, Tetsujin 28 and Black Ox, walking the streets of Tokyo and making a scratch on their horizon, including a harrowing movement where Black Ox lowers at the top of the Tokyo Tower. There is even a great deal where Black Ox launches Tetsujin with disabilities in the Diet Building (Parliament). These sequences are quite exciting and well made, as if the cameras were on the scene and captured the action as it unfolded. Unfortunately, the two subsequent robot battles do not deliver the goods. The punches are very weak and there is not much movement in the fights. Robots never fly and fight each other in the air, although in the final encounter, both really have that power. The original animated series had a much more satisfying giant robot action than the one we have here. Worse still, the young Shotaro, who was assigned to operate the remote device that controls Tetsujin, never seems to want to do so. He is weak and scared for most of the movie. When he finally reaches the plate and accepts his role at the 90-minute mark - long for us to have to wait - he is not particularly effective. While the boy playing Shotaro may be offering a realistic picture of how a ten-year-old would react under the circumstances, I must confess that I was not exactly looking for realism. I wanted the boy to be anxious all the time to control that mighty robot and send him into a furious fight to end Black Ox\'s depredations. Just like Shotaro (or "Jimmy Sparks," as he was known in Gigantor) behaved in the original manga and anime. Or the male heroes in "Johnny Sokko and his flying robot" and the 1960s Gamera movies. These new Japanese heroes are really weak when put to the test (see also Toru in GAMERA THE BRAVE and Tadashi in THE GREAT YOKAI WAR, two films also made in 2005, and both were also reviewed on this site). What does this say about the next generation of Japanese heroes? At least \'Ash\' Pok & mon still knows what to do in the face of a threat. I did as an aspect of the movie, though. I enjoyed seeing two idols of Japanese pop music in the cast. The oldest is Hiroko Yakushimaru, who was popular in the 1980s and starred in a movie I remember called SAILOR SUIT AND MACHINE GUN (1981). She plays Shotaro\'s mother and she is very beautiful. The other is one of my all-time favorite J-pop singers, Yuko Nakazawa, one of the founding members of Morning Musume, here playing a young police detective assigned to the case. They give her short, dark hair and a pretty simple navy blue suit, clearly an attempt to minimize her usual glamor, but she has a lot to do and it\'s always thrilling to see her in action. Another key female character is Mami Tachibana (played by Yu Aoi), an MIT robotics expert recruited to help reform Tetsujin 28 after a disastrous battle from the start. She is young and brave and looks sharp in a uniform and beret as she befriends the young Shotaro. Akira Senju\'s score is nice and melodic and keeps things optimistic when the movie slows down (which it often does). I also have the soundtrack CD. The final song follows a replay of the male chorus singing the theme "Tetsujin 28" from 1963, accompanied by scenes from the original manga, which seems much more action-packed than anything in this film. The Pioneer / Geneon DVD does not offer credits in English anywhere except the one in the DVD case.'

Was often distracted and her five-year-old brother was bored and left the room before the scary parties forced us to turn off the tape. 3) Attempts to make the story appealing to children by adding animal characters further confuse the plot and make the story unrecognizable to anyone who, like me, has read and appreciated the book. END"

b'The four films included in this set - "Disorder on the Block," "Malice in the Palace," "Sing a Six Pants Song" and "Groom Without a Groom" - are in the public domain, meaning anyone with a copy of the movie may release your own video. Often the results are of poor video / audio quality (although the films themselves are very good - \'Brideless Groom\' is one of Stooge\'s funniest comedies of all time). Columbia has just released an \'official\' DVD of the Stooges (with six of the films on a disc) - hopefully the first of many. Stay with Columbia and avoid those cheap imitations.'

b"This was a very interesting film. In fact, it is not banned in Singapore. I saw this movie while living there and it was a great relief. Although the film focuses on street goons, the general theme is Singapore's forgotten people, who can not be a doctor, lawyer or compadre (government). Students are simplified at a very young age and some bad tests mean that you are involved with scum. This movie shows what is happening in Singapore on a side that many Sinagporeans are unaware of. 5 stars for boldness. The cinematography is hard (choppy) in the pieces and the story jumps a little ... but it is still very convincing."

b'If you liked the first, this is your alley. I say this mainly because the tone (darker than many conventional films), the hidden nature and unusual pictures tend to leave some moviegoers off. But if you simply want to see a movie about a demon that was created by humans to fight evil, this is a great movie for you. Guillermo del Toro\'s driving style is very kinetic and fluent. This helps keep the movie going, keeping it from creeping. The scenes flow very well from one to the next (which is also done very well with some wipes and creative overlays). The real attraction for this movie, however, is Hellboy and the staff that was provided to him. Ron Perlman is the absolutely perfect Hellboy. His delivery of the lines is nothing short of perfect in creating a bitter character, but in the end adorable (and also loving). He has an ironic humor about him that makes the character Hellboy something we can all relate to. We all had times when we felt underestimated. We all feel like the outsider outsider. However, despite all the incentives he has to give up defending these humans, he continues to do so because that is what his father taught him to do. Of course Abe and Liz are here too, and Doug Jones and Selma Blair do a wonderful job of portraying their respective characters. But this is not their movie. It is interesting, however, to see one of the elements of the story of the first film turned to portray the other side of it when the team meets the angel of death. In short, as I said above, if you liked the first one, this is just your type of movie. I look forward to seeing what del del Toro has in mind for the third movie. (Of course, we\'ll have to wait for him to finish "The Hobbit" first).'

b'Former government agent Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) must solve the mystery behind events that happened when he was a child, in order to save the planet from being destroyed by monsters of another dimension.OK, I admit, "Alone in the Dark "is not on my list of best movies of all time, but it\'s not on my list of movies either. It may be directed by Uwe Boll, who is considered by many to be the worst director of all time, but if all of Boll\'s other films are so, then Boll has been grossly underestimated because I have seen many movies. which are much worse than this (for example, "The remake of Stepford Wives"). The script is based on a videogame, which gives you that "video game", moving from level to level, I feel that you started with many such movies (like "Resident Evil" or "Doom"), but that did not deter me both of the film made me want to go out and play the game. Not being a player, this was my first encounter with "Alone in the Dark", and I found the story interesting enough to keep my interest in the length of the movie. The performance is uneven in quality. Christian Slater and Stephen Dorff (as another government agent) both perform in decent performances, but Tara Reid is as unconvincing as a scientist that she really contributes to the movie\'s entertainment value. My main criticism is that some of the battle scenes are very long. There is a fight scene at the 1 hour mark which comprises about 15 minutes of people shooting at monsters with very little dialogue, which became tedious after a while. Despite this, I still liked the movie and would be prepared to watch it again.'

b'My son absolutely loves the book I stink! So when I saw this animated version available, I knew it would be your alley. The staff at Schoolastic have a great track record when it comes to animating classic children\'s books, and that\'s no exception. I Stink was animated in a way that perfectly complements the illustrations in the book, and Conan\'s Andy Richter does a fantastic job giving voice to the "all-attitude, all the time" garbage truck. The animated version of I Stink is a hit almost as big with my son as the book. The DVD also includes some other animated adaptations that (more or less) carry the theme of the garbage truck. Trashy Town is the only other story on the subject of trash on the DVD, but with its simple animation and captivating "chorus", it went very well. The others are wrong. Arnie the Donut was funny and a little disturbing (it\'s about a sentient mass conscious of his impending death), but Monsieur Racine\'s Beast was a little too strange. I would absolutely recommend the DVD I Stink to anyone whose son (ren) liked the book. It\'s a fun collection of lively stories and a welcome break from Elmo, the Wiggles, etc.'

b'While for me "Upstairs, Downstairs" remains the best Masterpiece Theater series of all time, this is a close second. Gemma Jones is superb as Louisa Trotter, the Cockney Cook / Hotelier who never loses her manners of common sense nor her strong cockney accent, even after becoming host to the rich and famous Edwardian England. Earlier episodes focus on the rise of Louisa from an assistant cook to lover of the Prince of Wales (later, King Edward VII). But most of the series concerns the activities of the Bentinck Hotel, an exclusive and private London property owned and operated by Louisa. With few exceptions, someone\'s family may have been listed in the Debrett Partnership for at least 100 years before anyone can book a room at Bentinck. And yet, Louisa\'s selectivity is not so much a reflection of her snobbery, but of her passionate commitment to be the Best in everything she does. The entire series is rich in characters and incidents, and in fact Jones / Louisa is deep down in several episodes. But she is unquestionably the dominant and dominant character in this series. You have not seen the unbridled Jura Indignation until you see Louisa, in the last episode of this collection, witnessing at the trial on behalf of her friend, Lord Haslemere, pouring diatribe after diatribe in all its cockney glory. Now that\'s a character! This wonderful series deserves to be much better known than it is. Do not hesitate to purchase this set. I can not wait for the second grade!'
