b'Arguably, this is the funniest of the holiday movies. The real test of a good comedy is to be able to keep yelling at the movie years later, and "Christmas holidays" more than that for me. But this works the other way around: instead of the disaster-prone Griswolds traveling abroad to places like Europe or Wally World, they are anchored in front of the house, while the calendar marks the days until Christmas. Chevy Chase is clearly in its element here reprizing its role as the well-meaning but desperately matriarch Clark, who naturally goes overboard with the creation of "Perfect Christmas." The dependable good Beverly D\'Angelo is also here as Clark\'s supporting wife, who gets her buttons pushed by annoying relatives and crying kids, as well as her willful husband. The late John Hughes fills the script of satires and references, punched with the trademark `` Lampoon \'\' slapstick & lowbrow humor. Granted, sometimes the mood tanks, but it is a nobler effort than the previous uneven `` European Vacation \'\'. This only challenges him not to laugh out of his head, as the Griswolds\' efforts to have "the best Christmas" turn into a long train accident, which can please the funny bone of any "Scrooge." Juliette Lewis & Johnny Galecki (the latter currently on the sitcom "The Big Bang Theory") as the children of Griswold; a pre-Seinfeld Julia Louise-Dreyfuss as half of the neighbors yuppie snobs who suffer at the hands of Clark; and Doris Roberts, Diane Ladd and William Hickey, as some of the troublesome relatives come to visit. But, in fact, it\'s Randy Quaid\'s reaction to the lazy and clumsy cousin Eddie who steals every scene he\'s in. If you want a serious interpretation of a Holiday classic, watch `` It\'s a Wonderful Life \'\'; If you want to laugh too often, then definitely watch this!'

b'After reading the wonderful `` Doc \'\' book for the book club, my husband and I watched `` Tombstone \'\' a few days ago, and `` Wyatt Earp \'\' last night in preparation for next week\'s meeting of the book club. For all those who say there is some controversy about which movie is best, I can put the controversy to rest: `` Tombstone \'\' is better. Watching `` Wyatt Earp \'\' seemed to attend a community theater (with no offense to the community theater)) of the opening scenes with Wyatt (Kevin Costner, with his anachronistic hairstyle), drinking a cup of coffee that is boiling like a witch\'s cauldron, as if the helpers put a piece of dry ice in the cup. With the exception of the good Gene Hackman as Earp\'s father, the male actors\' performance is either caricature, or melodramatic, or wood, or incredibly, all three at the same time. Having just watched Wyatt Earp\'s tightly controlled, uber-masculine portrait of Kevin Costner\'s "Tombstone," Kevin Costner played the same character and reminded me a bit of Forrest Gump, without offending Forrest Gump, crossed with Costner. of "Dances With Wolves" (even hairstyle). I love Dennis Quaid, but having watched Doc Holliday\'s definitive portrait of Val Kilmer in "Tombstone" a few days before seeing Quaid\'s version on "Wyatt Earp" was probably unfair to Dennis Quaid and his cool sunglasses, which They did not even come near me. I love the western movies, but this clich\xc3\xa9 movie - a dose of bottle well before a bullet. explodes, anyone? It made me roll my eyes. To sweeten the deal, it\'s over three hours! Recommendation: Watch `` Tombstone \'\' instead.'

b'Imagine a documentary with a warning that lets the viewer know that they will not hear ANY actual U2 music during the movie. Fortunately, however, I remembered that I was not AUTHORIZED and, at least in this case, it did not mean, neither blunt nor nervous, but empty and empty of content. Discography was the only thing worth looking at.'

b'Having played both games "BloodRayne", I\'m a fan of the series. So when I heard they were making a movie, I was a little interested. But deep down, I knew it would probably suck. I was more than right. Unless you\'re interested in a girl who is so terrible that makes you laugh, DO NOT BUY THIS MOVIE! It\'s a total disaster! The film Rayne is nothing like its equivalent in the video game. The fight scenes were slow, nothing like the fluidity of the game. And do not get me started on the blood ... I\'ve seen better settings in a haunted house. Nothing was done realistically, and the ten-minute recap at the end of the movie (which was made for some reason I\'ll never understand) just shows how sloppy it is. The performance was not great either, and the short sex scene ... let\'s just say I\'ve been laughing for most of this mess. No need for day, the plot was also missing (and this is putting everything lightly). If you want a vampire movie, choose the "Underworld" movies. If you are a fan of BloodRayne looking for something to satisfy your fandom, play the game again. You will have more satisfaction with this than with this awful interpretation.'

b'Italian Job is the best film of all time, without a doubt. Usually I agree with Leonard Maltin, but sometimes he is off the scale and he certainly is in this case. Okay, you may think the characterization is bad - but they are stereotypes. This movie was ironic even before Kevin Williamson and his kind were born. It is worth knowing that the British censors in 1968 would not allow any film to be released, which made it appear that the crime paid, so the end was linked to that condition. If you buy only one video from Amazon (and that would not be good - they have a huge variety of high quality movies - maybe I personally recommend The Quiet Man, for example?) Do this one.'

b"As a lover of ancient history, I was excited to watch yet another movie about Cleopatra's life. This film is extremely fascinating, and seems to follow the script of an ancient novel rather than the life of the last queen of ancient Egypt. The filmmakers obviously did not create this to be a factual account of Cleo's life. The acting of Billy Zane (Antony) and Timothy Dalton (Cesar) was very good, and Lenor Varella (Cleopatra) offers a good show if you like passion and exaggerated drama. If you want to see a televised and modern view of Cleopatra's life, this is her movie, but Cleopatra's film starring Elizabeth Taylor is far superior."

b'Simplifying: Style over substance. There are some excellent sequences, but that\'s all this movie looks like, well planned and executed sequences - but without anything coherent, sticking it all together. The \'near-impact plane and the last-minute rescue\' is extremely impressive and the machine-gun ammunition crashing into Supe\'s chest, followed by the bullet in the eye, is magnificent. My chin was falling and I almost wanted to cheer. That\'s what Superman is about: seeing him defeat the bad guys in new, interesting ways - even fun. But that\'s when the fun ended. As Superman is not, it\'s children\'s love and ridiculous heroic jokes with kryptonite. I think both are so horribly implausible that both should be ridiculed. Like Brodie (skillfully played by Jason Lee in Kevin Smith\'s Mallrats), "It\'s impossible! Lois Lane could never have Superman\'s baby. Do you think your fallopian tubes could handle your sperm? I assure you that when he comes during sex, he probably blows a load like a shotgun blast ... across her back. "So, besides Lois Lane being alive after intercourse, you would have the impossibility of a human being conceiving and bringing the term of an alien\'s son to the term. Do not forget that just because Clark Kent looks and ostensibly acts like a human, he is an alien. He is a different species entirely. And totally different species can not mate. Just think of the chaos that would ensue in the animal kingdom if a lion falls in love and mates with a crocodile. Or a graffiti. The other issue that makes me shake with rage is the whole crappy concept of Superman being physically able to lift an entire continent of kryptonite into outer space. As the internet blogger dpogue21 speaks so proficiently (much better than I do - so thank you dpogue) in his review of imdb, "my next big complaint is that Superman raises a continent made of kryptonite into outer space. He does not get the Simpsons comic book guy to point out what\'s wrong with that. I do not know how many comic books Bryan Singer has read, but when Superman is exposed to a small amount of kryptonite he barely has the strength to stand. Whoever has had the idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bmaking him fly on a big island, made up of his greatest weakness in space, has no business being associated with any other Superman-related project. The concept is as ridiculous as making a Dracula movie, where the title character has a stake in his heart and still manages to pilot a spaceship made out of garlic in the sun. Why does not only Superman eat kryptonite? He can eat it and then brush his teeth with it and then sleep in kryptonite pajamas. This is no more absurd than having him hoisting a continent of kryptonite into space and then falling helplessly through the atmosphere without burning into re-entry or spreading throughout the central park when it hits the ground. \'\' Do I need to say more? I do not think so. ** [...]'

b"The special effects were good, but the story was weak, silly and predictable. As a kid, I loved the Alien movies. Aliens (the second) is considered a classic in our house as we still laugh about how my mom caused M & M's to rain in the theater after an alien scared her. So with that, I was excited to see this movie and relive some of the memories. What a disappointment. It was not scary at all. The people in the theater were actually *** Sleeping ***. I was jealous of them. I was very happy that this was a short movie. Unfortunately, the scariest thing in this movie was a penguin. I do not see that. If you are a big foreign fan or predator and must catch it, wait for video or HBO."

b"Peter Brooks' Spartan adaptation of William Golding's immortal romance about a group of English students stranded on a dessert island still runs almost four decades after its initial launch. Despite a total lack of star names and limited production values, the film is successful thanks to the performances of children's actors and a general primitivism that makes everything imminently believable. At first, the castaways seem not to be so bad; there is a lot of food, no adult and no predator ... except for maybe one, one & quot; beastie & quot; which can be a strange animal or a ghost or something much worse ... A touching, always poignant accusation of inherent human savagery, Lord of the Flies manages to translate the essence of Golding's tale into the canvas. Like many adults, children think they are good enough to make their own utopia. So much for utopia. So much for childish innocence."

b"Max Beesley is happening. His and Mariah's chemistry was electrical. I smiled, laughed and cried. The first time I saw it was Ok, but sometimes 2-10 I keep seeing something new every time. This has become one of my favorite movies. It all came down to It was a story of romance, success, full of emotion. I recommend this movie as sweet entertainment. You will feel the excitement throughout the movie. Give credit to the actors and do not blame them for a script less than perfect, they did the best with what they were given. Max Beesley is dynamic, throughout the film his eyes tell the underlying story."

b'Poor Bellini! Out of fashion for a century and rescued from near obscurity by the Maria Callas thegenius just to be destroyed by this horror. What should we do about Zimmerman\'s absurd production? Bellini in some kind of big city loft, the characters, the action in total disagreement with the romantic track of bel canto, the opera reduced to almost farce. It may have been saved by a higher corner, but even that is missing. It is almost as if the singers were wondering, "What the hell is this absurdity and why we are here!" Every operatic presentation should be a tribute to the composer, but in this case it is nothing more than a reverence for the director and his obvious need to be seen as outrageous and inventive.We can only shudder at the thought of what she has in store for the future performance of the opera (if any.) Can we wait anxiously for her Norma in Detroit, a metaphor for the collapse of the inner city? I would be surprised.'

b'Okay, so these guys had unlimited access to the most anticipated band reunion, well, never ... and that\'s it? Is that all they do? Do not get me wrong, it\'s cool to see the guys playing again, and watching Kim stand sober along the way, wandering around the cities, and so on. But the main problem with this document is that it is absolutely annoying. And they get in the way of the key issues in all the minds of fans: the reasons for the breakup and the possibility of new music. In fact, the best part of this film (other than the song) is the impromptu fan interviews Kelly does. She starts asking questions! What a concept! This is such a wasted opportunity. The filmmakers were either inept, or very impressed and "honored to be chosen" to make a movie in some depth. We get a lazy love letter. Making movies from the toes. Look, I love all things Pixies. Period. And on a certain level, that\'s cool to see just because I really love this band. And if you\'re a big fan of Pixies, you\'ll probably like that up to a point. But again, from the point of view of the cinema, and what this piece should have been, this is a gigantic disappointment.'

b"Of the trailers and the presence of Julia Roberts in the cast, I joined CLOSER expecting a mild romantic comedy. (My prejudices have not been so destroyed since I saw Bambi's mother being shot by hunters in the matinee on Saturday!) CLOSER opens when Alice (Natalie Portman), a stripper from New York on a visit to London, is hit by a car after that she looked to the left, instead of to the right, coming off the curb. She is taken to the hospital by a stranger, Dan (Jude Law), an aspiring writer with whom she initiates a life relationship. So, Dan sits down to a formal portrait of photographer Anna (Julia Roberts), in whom he beats to no avail. Later, Larry (Clive Owen), a dermatologist, meets Anna, with whom he marries, later divorces after discovering that she had recent sexual relations with Dan, who was once rejected. In rebounding and in need of physical comfort, Larry looks for Alice, now wearing clothes at a London strip club after leaving Dan, and with whom he had already met at one of Anna's photo exhibitions. But Dan still longs for Alice and is emotionally devastated that she has had sex with Larry. Is that confusing or what? (The timeline is obscure, apparently all of this happens over two years.) CLOSER is a painful, watchful, sexually manipulating, obsessive, and haunting film in which the four main characters inflict emotional cruelties on one another. It's not a holiday for an afternoon at the movies with your elderly mother. The language is sexually graphic and, in a sequence of scenes in the London band, visually daring. CLOSER is, however, one of the best films of 2004. Julia Roberts is perhaps the biggest surprise, since it shows that she can radically transcend - even beyond ERIN BROCKOVICH (2000) - her usual cute roles; I was very impressed. It would be difficult to choose the leading role and supporting pieces of this film. All four (Portman, Law, Roberts, Owen) have roughly the same screen time (although I'm not following a timer). Any one of them, or all of them, could win an Oscar nomination. I had started to doze off a quarter of the movie, but then I woke up almost startled when I realized that CLOSER is an exceptional adult movie, not visually explicit. sex or violence, which brutally shows adults in dysfunctional relationships behaving in the worst case. Truly, as indicated by a line in KINSEY: '' Sex is a dangerous game. If you are not careful, you can cut it open wide. ''"

b'WHAT IS THE HOLLYWOOD PROBLEM, ANYWAY? This is the biggest movie ever made. Okay, maybe I honestly do not believe it. Maybe `` The Cable Guy \'\' is a little better. Okay, maybe it\'s a play. I can not decide. Oh, hell, it does not matter! I think what I\'m getting at is that I\'m very sick and tired of hearing people cheat on this movie. I\'m so tired of this, in fact, that I\'m going to lie shamelessly to people who do not like it and say it\'s my favorite movie, even if it\'s not. They are not my favorite Arnold movies, but I still rank him among the top ten. It\'s not even a tenth as bad as they say it is. There were eager fans of Schwarzenegger who actually came to detest Arnold after he made this movie. Why do I ask? BECAUSE ? I demand to know! Is it acting? Is it the script? Is it the story and the premise? Special effects, car chases, what? Okay, the acting is tacky. I\'ll give it to you. The story is exaggerated and the action is exaggerated. I\'ll give you that, too. But guess what, you stupid idiots? It\'s supposed to be like this! This movie was conceived as a social commentary. It\'s satire. It was intended to make fun of the films by example. It points to the most inherent flaw in the entire cinema. Fantasy! That\'s right ! It exposes the film industry for what it is. That is, a circus, a crazy house, a mad dog, a wild beast, a monolithic volcano of glamor, pretension, vanity and and ... And just ... shrill screams - FRAUD - OK, that\'s it. I just answered my own question. The reason Hollywood detests such disdain for this film is simply because it does not like to be the subject of debates like morality and ethics. It\'s not like it\'s a big secret, though, that Hollywood is full of fakes, satanists, ... and demon worshipers. The world knew this years ago. Does not it seem to hurt the grosses, though? People still watch the movies. They keep watching television. They continue to tune into that Oscar-nominated political media circus. Weird Holly is clearly okay. So why did this movie so scare you? Do not ask me. All I can say is that Arnold Schwarzeneger had to have a lot of balls to be in a movie like this. Especially when he was still a newcomer to the profession of actor and America. But hey, it\'s just an action movie, and it has a good plot. Still, there seems to be no end to the contempt that filmmakers and critics have for Arnold. That\'s not what irritates me the most, though. What irritates me the most is that the audience that goes to the movies can be so naive and stupid as to accept whatever Hollywood tells them about a particular movie. Not critical, mind you. No one else pays attention to critics. Especially the stupid rich, with their big thick books and their big thick mustaches. No, I\'m talking about the entertainment industry in general. Usually, if every actor, director, producer, and every type of talk show joins a particular individual, or a particular movie, and shouts at the top of their collective lungs: "THIS WORK IS TERRIBLE. DO NOT SEE THIS MOVIE, \'\' everyone believes in them. What these people should be shouting is "WE HAVE FEAR WE ARE JELOUS WE WANT TO SEE THAT THIS IS A LACK OF PEOPLE" This is all about entertainment It\'s about an artist stabbing another in the back It\'s not about teamwork anymore. Usually, if enough people in the profession report the work of a particular person, the rest of the world will think, "Well, gee! Everyone in Hollywood thinks this movie sucks. Must be true. Well, I\'m not going to waste my money. \'\' That\'s why this movie bombed. Not because of your quality or lack of it, but because of the quantity. That is, amount of people in the business who said it was not good. And the so-called fans, as well as the band of impressionable troglodytes and fingerhunters that they are, fell into this. They stayed away from the mass movie. And what do you think happened? Well, the movie failed of course. It is the most daring attempt of Arnold Scwarzenegger of artistic genius and no one went to see the fuck thing. Well, let me tell you something. I saw the movie, and I liked it! And I\'m not alone! But I\'m tired of feeling like an idiot anytime I play that movie. I\'m sick of people laughing at me when I tell them I\'m a fan of Arnold Schwarzenegger, a fan of Jim Carrey, a fan of Norm Macdonald or a fan of Stephen King. I\'m sick of it, and I will not take it. If anyone here needs to feel ashamed, YOU ARE POEPLE! I do not care what anyone says. So, you all can kiss my $$ and go to hell. I love this movie, and I\'m going to kill someone who tries to change my mind. That said, buy this DVD. It\'s certainly cheap enough (unfortunately for Arnold).'

b"Starting in the late 1950s, there were a number of country music films made, perhaps in reaction to the success of rock and roll movies of the same era. Most of them featured some kind of plot involving rubies getting into all sorts of problems. But these films were not just the crazy, mad luck of hipsters; they were the crazy and crazy misfortune of hipsters who had famous country music stars as friends. In other words, the fragile plots and movie stars disappearing were just an excuse to showcase a huge amount of country music stars of the time. Many of the performances were synchronized, although some were recorded live. The Nashville sound, which was recorded in 1969, was different. Perhaps influenced by the Pennebaker documentaries of the time, this film had no fragile plot or cheeky jokes. Instead, it was a serious look at Nashville and the stars of the reigning country of the day. It is well filmed, complete and fascinating to watch. Much of it was filmed at the Grand Ole Opry, but you also have invaluable footage, like Loretta Lynn's playing for a radio audience and record company staff, Bashful Brother Oswald singing a Mountain Dew chorus off of Ernest Tubb's Record Store. , a rehearsal of Mother Earth (with Tracy Nelson), a performance outside Shelby Singleton's house, a recording session with Doug Kershaw and a young, beardless Charlie Daniels, and more. There are also great filming in Nashville. All performances are excellent, and the film does a great job of capturing the essence of country music of the era - performers, fans and people in the industry. I've been waiting for a long time for this to come out on DVD!"

b'The last Samurai is a very good movie that falls short of being great. You can see why Tom Cruise follows him in his ways. This film is directed very well by the underrated Edward Zwick and Tom Cruise gives a very good performance. The only problem I have with this movie is how important it is. Even movies of this magnitude should not worry so much about epic chords. We understand that this is a great historical epic. There is no need to continue implying this. However, this movie is still worthy of some awards and a good audience.'

b"The action movies remind me of the true beauty of the movies, how a story can be told through visual arrangements and movements through the frame, rather than dead dialogues and two still actors talking. These films are like plays filmed while others are drawn from their silent black and white songs. white roots, telling stories without words. Road Warrior contains one of the best examples of this - such a small moment, a small obstacle overcome, but dancing boldly across the screen like a painter. Here is the magic, shot by shot. Halfway through the final chase sequence, a red hotrod approaches the truck of Max's big rig with intent to kill him. In a scene that has been copied many times, Max emerges from the cab and throws his shotgun at the camera - forced perspective, moving to the right and then to the left, back and forth, zigzagging across the screen. The villain's head explodes like a firework, and we are presented with a cry of joy from Max's wild wolf friend - an animalistic reaction to the violence ironically given by a child raised by animals. Now we have a series of jumps. cuts that tell the little story of the red car losing control and hitting other villain vehicles. This little story is closed by the famous and almost peaceful shot of a man turning upside down in a horizontal fall, again in forced perspective flying toward the camera. Now another series of jumps cuts as we bounce back to the red hotrod and it's struggle to get out underneath the huge wheels of Max. In a nice motion game, the car dances in front of Max's truck, running from one side to the other. another in front of Max and our screens like a hanging carrot, until we have a third view of forced perspective: the camera approaches the grate. of the truck, then climbs up and into the cab at Max, when Max finally ends the misery of the car, nailing him in an explosion of gasoline and bits of metal. Such a sick and distorted beauty ... Did you know that George Miller, director of Road Warrior, also directed Babe?"

b"& quot; The Breakfast Club & quot; is the brat movie that I dare to imagine will be remembered for a long time as a watershed in American cinema - at least as far as teen comedy is concerned. The plot (for those who are not yet familiar with it) revolves around 5 teenagers from various walks of life, forced to sit down together during a detention session on Saturday afternoon. A hilarious, well-crafted and often poignant film about the fundamental truths that make us all human, John Hughes & quot; The Breakfast Club & quot; is perhaps the greatest exploitation of the anguish and confusion that plagued us during the high school years. UNIVERSAL's remastering efforts on this DVD provide some of its own angst. Despite being extended to 16X9 monitors, this newly created DVD offers nothing in terms of video improvement over the previously issued DVD. The colors are dated, unrealistic, often unbalanced with some bleeding and blemishes. Fine details are minimal, even in well-lit scenes. Contrast, shadow, and black levels are extremely poor. Age-related artifacts, including chips, scratches and cuts of spice splashes are all evident. There is a considerable amount of film grain present everywhere for a totally unsatisfactory visual presentation. The audio - remixed to 5.1 in both Dolby and DTS displays a dated feature with muted dialogue and virtually no spatial separation, except in the music tracks.EXTRAS: A theatrical trailer that is heavily used.BOTTOM LINE: & quot; The Breakfast Club & quot; It's a brilliant movie. However, the lack of extras (a documentary would have been good) and the very low processing of the transfer led me to say that this record really is not worth the money."

b"It only takes a few minutes to see how terrible this thing is. The movie begins with some jets involved in a high-speed transcontinental run. It would be kind of dangerous, I suppose. Well, Grant's jet is refueled by another plane while they're on the direct flight path of the other race jets. What happens ? Duh ... there's a horrible collision and three pilots (along with 11 spectators ... huh?) They're dead. Nice personal move. Maybe the funniest, and most pathetic, event in the movie happens a little later. Several years have passed since the tragic jet race incident and we are listening to a network executive who made a live broadcast of the race. The executive says ... are you ready? ... he says footage of the jets colliding during the race was the most highly valued part of the news footage they've shown in the last four years. Unbelievable! ! Talk about a future world in which nothing exciting happens. Must be boring. Other things to look for are a guy who is somehow making a coughing noise while his mouth is not even moving. Also, a scene where a Sabato Jr. shirtless is about to put on a T-shirt. It picks up, but the camera changes angle and now it's nowhere. Then the camera changes the angles again and it is pulling it by the head. Great edition! Everything is bargain basement in this movie, except for the decent acting in the middle of the way. With a fine plot of paper and terrible effects, however, I strongly recommend not wasting your time watching this dreck. One final note ... no nudity and no graphic violence, I have no idea why this is classified as R."

b'This movie almost reminds me of the sitcom Alice TV: set up in a small restaurant, out of the way, run by a weird head chef with a heart of gold, and composed of a trio of waitresses, the impetuous Blondie Southern, the naive and naive, and single mother with upright head (or future mother in this case) along with the typical assortment of crazy and colorful clients. The writer / director Adrienne Shelly can take this model and do something wonderful with it. Far from being a mere remake of Alice, Waitress is a well-conceived and well-executed exploration of a woman\'s struggle for herself and realizing her dreams despite the bad choices and wrong decisions she made along the way. This really distinguishes this movie from most other big screen screenplay options. The dialogue, written by Adrienne Shelly - who also directed and co-starred as Dawn, the coarse waitress who eventually finds true love - shines with humor, charm and humor. It\'s fast and funny, but it always seems totally natural, largely due, of course, to the talents of the actors and actresses charged with handing it over. Unlike the writing in, say, Gilmore Girls, widely praised for its unique character, the dialogue in Waitress never seems forced or unnatural. It\'s brilliant without being intrusive. My only size for this movie is the fact that the message "men are dogs" is a bit heavy. Without exception, all the male characters in Waitress are introduced as, say, Earl (Jeremy Sisto), without principles, like Dr. Pomatter (Nathan Fillion), or simply weird, like Ogie (Eddie Jemison). Even Joe (Andy Griffith), who is really kind and affectionate, is shown throughout much of the film as being arduous and demanding, to the point that Jenna, who suffers a lot, is the only person who can deal with him and is truly true. his only friend. This is obviously a woman-made movie, especially for a female audience, but we can not help thinking that if a man made a movie where all the female characters were nothing more than claws of gold, abusive, whores, it would be a serious reaction, although well deserved. Waitress is a good movie that deserves to be seen. It is tragic that Shelly, who was brutally murdered in November 2006, will not make any more films, as this film will undoubtedly bring awareness of the writer / director\'s impressive talent to a much wider audience than ever before. . Fortunately, the waitress is an appropriate memorial to be remembered.'

b'This is my favorite movie in Bernadette and Lourdes. And now this new remastered version remastered recently released by Ignatius has a great picture quality along with so many bonus additions including the first availability of the French version (original), and the wonderful film and radio interviews with the wonderful Sydney Penny . Now we hope that many, many more people can hear this beautiful song and honor Bernadette with this fabulous Grammy-winning artist. Also has a second beauty sung by Jennifer Warnes on the CD, her song "Prairie Melancholy". Another musical jewel of this heavenly singer. This year of the 150th anniversary of the Lourdes apparitions, this new remastered film, with the audio and music CD, Penny\'s interviews, and the 16-page Collector\'s Booklet is a wonderful way to honor the history of Lourdes. inspirational movie.'

b'The cultural revolution that rocked Paris between 1905 and 1930 is well documented in this mesmerizing two-hour DVD documentary, which includes photographs, film archives, literary excerpts, and analysis. Focus on the arts, from classical music and jazz to sculpture, from poetry to dance, from paintings painted to romances. The rise of Modernism from post-Impressionists to Fauvism, Cubism, Dada and Surrealism and its numerous literary and beaux-arts pioneers is seen as an extraordinary period of free experimentation and interdisciplinary interactions, particularly between poets and artists. Paris was the fermenting pot and the vanguard was strong, sharp, and multiple. Watching this documentary can induce envy. The have lived in such a moment! It is clear that I and many of my generation actually experienced this revolution, although short lived in this accelerating society, when the San Francisco Bay area between 1965 and 1980 was the center of scientific, artistic, artistic, ecological, and other innovations. scientific research. and farms. This brings a small deficiency in documentary: the absence of any mention of developments in science, especially physics, and its influence on the arts, when the concepts of time, space and matter were radically new themes of thought. Otherwise, the research is a wonderful cultural history, from prewar optimism and the engine of cynicism and creative criticism after that carnage. The viewer can delve into many books that cover this exciting period for further study. This DVD is an excellent introduction in the history of art and cultural studies.'

b"We should all congratulate Uwe Boll. He's kind of like a movie cheap. No matter how small talent he has, and no matter how bad these films are, he can continue to do so. I know, he funds all of them himself through some kind of bizarre German fund, but even so, his ability to keep making movies despite absolute and complete failure is one of the great mysteries of the universe. It would not be so bad except that video game developers keep giving their best properties to this guy. I really enjoyed the Alone in the Dark series of games. Even the newest, the New Nightmare, was good for a few hours of gameplay. There was a good movie to be made from the adventures of Edward Carnby, but that's not it. Now Uwe Boll got his hands on Bloodrayne and Hunter: the Reckoning. What comes next, Silent Hill? Doom? I can only imagine the track that this guy will cut through adaptations from game to movie if he is not stopped. Someone needs to take out their line of credit, or these video game publishers need to understand and realize that when they make a bad movie of a game that kills the franchise, no one is more interested in that title. Think about it, is House of the Dead or Alone in the Dark a viable game title anymore? No way . A new House of the Dead game comes out on XBox and no one will mind. The title is dead and all because of Uwe Boll. So if any of you out there working for a game publisher, meeting a game publisher, or having access to a game publisher ... please let them know. This movie itself is not even worth reviewing. I can not separate what I did not like from this dung heap from the rest. Literally, all about it sucks. Writing, acting, music, CG effects, editing. I thought that if I waited until it came out on DVD and then rented with low expectations, I would not be disappointed. Even the $ 5 you spend on this DVD, if you buy it used by one of Amazon's sellers, is too much. You will regret it. This movie is just a bunch of Boll."

b"Well on the money. Do not miss a beat. Creative writing and great performances. Humor and occasional drama come in subtle waves. He enters Grant's life and turns everything upside down and they both learn to be men. Instead of opting for a broad comedy, the script is more subtle, focusing on dilemmas, contradictions, hypocrisies and even finding humor in their tragic failures. It's really a drama that takes everything very seriously. But because it sees the light at the end of the tunnel, it very clearly teaches us that when life brings an end to something, it also offers a beginning to something else. Let's embrace him!"

b'This musical still enchants and enchants us ... more than 40 years after it was made. It wins our old-fashioned applause - with good solid music and dance entertainment. Robert Preston shines like Professor Harold Hill ... an unscrupulous con man who starts deceiving the entire population (about 2,400) of River City, Iowa. He delights his heart (and pocket) and manages to stay one step ahead of the authorities. Along the way, he (Prof. Hill) touches the life of a spinster (Shirley Jones as Marian, the Librarian). and his extremely shy brother Winthrop (played by a very young and lovely Ronnie Howard) and, to his surprise, he finds himself in the unknown territory of a good director. His planned escape paralyzed, he is caught, and must, um, face the music. Along the way, you are given some memorable and fun songs and some delightful dance routines. The filmmakers showed some courage ... using some imagination and risking ... and gave us a lot of entertainment. My favorite places are the opening train sequence and the very excellent dance (and song) scene inside the library. The townsfolk of Rio City are made to be stubborn and narrow minded ... but in reality they are every comedy producer. Virtually all the adult characters in the movie give their share of the workload ... and add humor to the overall fun of the picture. Paul Ford, like confused Mayor George Shinn, is particularly good ... and Hermione Gingold, who plays her wife Eulalie, is also funny (though in a different way). Shirley Jones is very good here. She has always been a great singer, but also does some effective acting and footwork. Pert Kelton, like his Irish mother, is a delight. But the show pretty much belongs to Robert Preston. A more capable artist, he is light on his feet and equally agile (and nimble) while handling his lines. He\'s not a great singer ... he speaks most of the lyrics in his songs ... but they (the songs) work, and they work well. I heard this in the pre-production phase of making the film. , they wanted to replace Robert Preston (the star of the theatrical version of "The Music Man") by someone else. Meredith Willson, the writer of the original story, gave them an ultimatum ... or Robert Preston gets or ... no movie. And, watching him (Preston) perform here, it\'s easy to understand that feeling. He is a delight.'

b"I found this movie very enjoyable. The plot is simple and somewhat unimportant - Camille, a well-known Parisian actress, is returning from Rome to perform in front of her home audience in a play directed by her new lover, Ugo. The play is Come Tu Mi Vuoi, by Pirandello, a classic work (written for her lover Martha Abba) about a woman trapped between the yin and yang forces of reality and illusion. Throughout the film Rivette changes his camera between the game and Camille and Ugo's `` reality '' as if to us, who are the real Camille and Ugo ask. What do they really want? What makes ticks? Can I, the viewer, enter into your universe without a script? Rivette (and his excellent actors) shows us that the delicacy can be robust and inventive, that the desire for another can never be realized and that the realization does not really matter, because in the process of the struggle to achieve it we become alive and creative. What matters is style; style is substance. We are also treated with a brilliant representation of the incestuous relationship between the Italians and the French and there is a delightful succession of nuances, suggestions and plays with the national stereotypes that brought many smiles in my face. I can see why some - those accustomed to Hollywood cliches with their happy endings and predictable plots - may not find the movie so hot. Well, that's too bad ..."

b"Toilet training is part of the parenting process and although it usually begins in the child years, it may take more time with some children than others. Potty Power tries to speed up the process by presenting a DVD that encourages kids to use the potty and give up their diapers or pull-ups for good. Performs his goal through his potty talk, songs, skit and optimistic attitude about the potty's use. Jessica, the narrator of Potty Power, is encouraging and extremely excited. She talks about pee and poop, slang for bodily functions and more, while managing to keep a smile on her face everywhere. She really wants kids to learn how to use the potty, and her enthusiasm will hopefully be passed on to the children watching the DVD. This DVD certainly has its usefulness and I know many people who have had great success showing this training session to their students. young children. But it gets a little tacky and many adults will roll their eyes while listening to the dialogue and the songs. Songs like I am proud to wear my underwear, Wipe Your Bottom and others are certainly captivating for small children, but even some young people will find the stuff too silly to be true. One of my children is already trained to go to the bathroom and she laughs loudly when watching this DVD, due to her silly and often cowardly style. Leaving aside, what matters most is the effectiveness of the DVD and my experience, Potty Power made a difference. My youngest daughter likes to repeat the lines she has heard on this DVD and she likes to sing along with the songs. She has gone alone to the potty, so the DVD seems to be having a positive effect, even if it sometimes becomes annoying. Potent Power, despite its nonsense, is an effective means of weaning children. their diapers and pull-ups. If you can get through the goofiness of the whole experience, the overabundance of the narrator and the weird sketch at the end, Potty Power seems to have something to do with it. Kids will remember the songs and the message, making this DVD a good addition to toilet training."

b'Manny Pontoriero\'s latest set of instructional DVDs includes two DVDs that offer excellent instruction in landscape photography. As with previous Manny instructional DVDs, watching a DVD just once is not enough. Instead, watch a DVD, take multiple pictures, and watch the DVD again. Digital photography allows you to take many shots of a scene, from all angles, using different lenses and filters, with an immediate review of your efforts and without the need for development like in film photography. The first DVD includes several sessions with Manny\'s offer. classroom-style instruction that includes drawings and samples of a topic. So it is for the field to use these principles in action. It\'s in the first DVD that Manny also explains Parallel Thinking. Parallel thinking is "how else can I picture this scene"? Do not just take the picture you first saw. Instead, what other options (different times of day, different seasons, wearing different lenses, etc.) can you use to capture the scenes in one location? The second DVD offers 14 sessions on the field at different locations along the east coast. In each session, Manny provides a detailed description of what he is doing at each location, along with why. Throughout these sessions, there is information that you may lose but are important. For example, if you are stacking filters on a lens, use a lifting ring to be able to use larger filters on a lens and do not vignet your photo. Or, do not change the lenses on the beach if the wind is blowing because you do not want to put sand grains on the lens or camera; and, vacuum the lens and camera when you return home to remove any grains of sand on the outer surfaces. The second DVD contains a 15th bonus session in which Manny moves from the camera to the computer to briefly explain what changes he could make to a specific photo. . It uses the raw Photoshop editor to make these adjustments, along with the neutral density adjustment available in that editor. I highly recommend Manny\'s DVD sets, especially this set of two landscape photographs on DVD.'

b'Former government agent Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) must solve the mystery behind events that happened when he was a child, in order to save the planet from being destroyed by monsters of another dimension.OK, I admit, "Alone in the Dark "is not on my list of best movies of all time, but it\'s not on my list of movies either. It may be directed by Uwe Boll, who is considered by many to be the worst director of all time, but if all of Boll\'s other films are so, then Boll has been grossly underestimated because I have seen many movies. which are much worse than this (for example, "The remake of Stepford Wives"). The script is based on a videogame, which gives you that "video game", moving from level to level, I feel that you started with many such movies (like "Resident Evil" or "Doom"), but that did not deter me both of the film made me want to go out and play the game. Not being a player, this was my first encounter with "Alone in the Dark", and I found the story interesting enough to keep my interest in the length of the movie. The performance is uneven in quality. Christian Slater and Stephen Dorff (as another government agent) both perform in decent performances, but Tara Reid is as unconvincing as a scientist that she really contributes to the movie\'s entertainment value. My main criticism is that some of the battle scenes are very long. There is a fight scene at the 1 hour mark which comprises about 15 minutes of people shooting at monsters with very little dialogue, which became tedious after a while. Despite this, I still liked the movie and would be prepared to watch it again.'

b'This is a masterpiece from an inspirational John Landis movie that does a topic dozens of times before - lycanthropy - and adds a bit of sauce and seasoning to the kettle. Here we have a werewolf movie with adventure, black comedy, a little flesh [both pressed together and torn in pieces of blood], laughter, "oh my gods" and even pathos. This is a great imaginative and inventive film with great special effects that you will never forget, as I have not seen since I saw it on screen at 81. It starts with a couple of young Americans backpacking through the scary European countryside at night. I love the scene where they enter a pub and are welcomed like the plague. Both leave the scene and are quickly attacked by a werewolf with one face being beaten to death and the other, David Naughton, who plays David, surviving only to become a murderous werewolf. All hell breaks loose from then on, when David falls in love during the day, he kills at night and constantly bumps into his backpack mate "with his back to the dead," Jack - with bruised, torn flesh. Great shrinkage and laughter, as with each of Jack\'s post-mortem appearances, he is increasingly deteriorated until, in the end, he is nothing but skull and fascia. The scene in the theater, when Jack introduces David to each of his dead and devoured victims, complete with holes and missing limbs, is a beauty. The transformation scene where David transforms into a werewolf in his living room is absolutely amazing and unforgettable - this is a classic horror scene of all time. Congratulations to the special effects and makeup professionals here. GREAT John Landis cinematographic production with refreshing originality and a wonderful and astute variation of a stereotyped horror theme. Sorry Naughton did not become the star he should have. If you have not seen this you should before the next full moon. Lon Chaney Jr would have been proud of these guys.'

b"We acquired this collection because we wanted to own the 1935 version of A Tale of Two Cities. We just watched and had a wonderful experience. The film is very close to the plot, the performances are excellent. Charles Dickens's book will forever be a testimony to the struggle of humanity between those who have and those who do not. Blanche Yurka's performance as Madame DeFarge is excellent. The citizens of France, seeking to put an end to the tyranny they experience of the oppressive aristocracy, present the endless example that, when rights are trampled, it always ends in revolution and change. The Marquis St. Evremonde, played by Basil Rathbone, offers a vision of the horror it represents for anyone to show that they do not care about those who suffer. Especially when it comes to children; by the horror committed against this family, ignites the fire that leads to events that put an end to the dominant society. Manette's performance as the innocent who has been a prisoner of the Bastille for over 18 years is superb. His daughter, played by Elizabeth Allen, represents the person who inspires great love in two men, one Charles Darnay and the Sydney Carton, superbly interpreted by Ronald Colman. The character of Miss Pross, played by Edna May Oliver, is incredible. We're going to dislike her, to admire her and then to love her for her sacrifice that saves Ms. Manette. In the end, the sacrifice made by Sydney for Lucie's love is one of the most sensitive and touching of all love stories. He finds a purpose for his life, knowing full well that his actions will live forever in the hearts of those for whom he sacrifices himself. I would highly recommend owning this DVD. The other films will be reviewed as we see them."

b"This fun and fun caper of crime has a great cast and a lot of south-frontier flavor that makes it a fun 88 minutes in the movies. William A. Seiter's Borderline is a cool little movie that has more in common with The Big Steal than the noir movie that is often advertised. It's a mix of humor, crime and fun that grows in you over and over until your moody end. It seems both L.A.P.D. and the US Treasury wants to stop a narco-trafficker from bringing narcotics along the border with Mexico. Claire Trevor is the enthusiast of police officer Madeline Haley, ex-O.S.S. agent who talks about the task of going south in an attempt to get information on the distasteful middleman Pete Ritche, hoping this will lead them to Mr. Great. Perry Mason's TV, Raymond Burr, is the heavyweight in the white suit, Ritche, and plays the role with menace. Madeline kind of stumbles on Ritchie, but before she can figure something out, Johnny Mackland, an unknown player working for the LA connection, steals Ritchie's gold so he can make a deal for the next shipment. He ends up taking Madeline with him after the weapons are taken and the pursuit continues. The persecution by Mexico, as they try to avoid Ritchie and deceive the cops, is a lot of fun. Madeline and Johnny start telling each other tall stories and warming each other along the way. When Johnny's friend Miguel is shot, they have a body in their hands to deal with, further complicating the pursuit. Fred MacMurray is good as Johnny, the cop who does not know that Madeline is a cop, who does not know he's a cop! Kind of like a fun pulp movie with more flavor than a habanero pepper, Trevor does a cute performance when he starts liking Johnny, even getting a bit jealous of the cute and pretty daughter of a not-so-clever Mexican cop. Unknowingly, it helps them get a plane to Encinada for the big deal. Like the two near the border, each repents having transformed the other because they fell in love with each other. When they straighten up who they work for, an exciting shootout with Ritchie and his gang culminates in a great ending to this very entertaining movie. A movie that means entertainment, does not take itself too seriously, and you should not either. Genre movie fans like this will like to go south of the border with this."

b"I watched the movie and felt that I was missing pieces, that the scenes were shorter, even that entire scenes were missing, but it had been so long since I watched that I thought I remembered the movie being better than it really was. b'A Faustian tour through the postwar New York and Louisiana, \'Angel Heart\' tells a very old story from a surprisingly original and wonderfully creepy angle. The plot, focusing on the case of a person who is increasingly violent, is fairly simple, but the story that sets it apart is extraordinarily complex. When you go back the pieces in the end, it makes sense, but only just. De Niro is superb as Louis Cyphre, the "entrepreneur" with some assurance to collect, infusing the role with the right balance of sarcastic humor and demonic threat. Mickey Rourke gives what will likely always be his best performance as Harry Angel, a war veteran in shock and disheveled P.I. The support cast is excellent, especially Charlotte Rampling as an occultist, and Lisa Bonet as a teenage voodoo witch. But the real star here is the writer / director Alan Parker. He has an extraordinary talent for the simple yet powerfully disturbing image: a slow zoom on the outer wall of a New York hotel; a New Year\'s Eve crowd in Times Square; a downward lift; a sweeping staircase; the rotating blades of a fan. These images are simple, cold, but positively filled with infernal threats. Trevor Jones\' music is the perfect accompaniment, his saxophones leaning madly on menacing rhythms and the ubiquitous pulsation of a pulsing heart. It\'s a completely disturbing marriage, which will be afraid to close around you with the same somber certainty as the fate of the protagonist.'

b"I bought this DVD from Amazon, remember, although it may not seem like it, because I recently changed my email address and received another account. b'I have to admit with some shame that before this movie, I did not know who Harvey Pekar was. But that did not limit my ability to enjoy this movie, which was one of the most interesting I have seen in a long time. The theme of the film as a whole is brilliantly summed up in the first few seconds of the film. Several boys go to a house on Halloween, all dressed up as Super Heroes, except for a boy, who is dressed just like himself: Harvey Pekar. The film as a whole is about Pekar\'s attempt to tell his mundane, monotonous and disappointing life in a comic book. Instead of a comic book about superheroes, he envisioned a comic book about him, an archivist at Veterans Hospital in Cleveland. The film tells the story of Pekar\'s life in varying degrees of detail, highlighting his encounter with R. Crumb in the 1960s and Crumb inspiring him to start a comic book, despite his inability to draw. By picking up incidents from his own life, involving his friends and colleagues, designing comic books, and then hiring artists to illustrate his stories (many of Crumb\'s own), Pekar manages to create something unique, funny, and in and of itself. Strange, triumphant and beautiful. The movie implies that we can all be the heroes of our own story. Not much happens in the movie, but it manages to be fascinating nonetheless. The big events in the narrative are Pekar\'s encounter with R. Crumb, his decision to write his own magazine, meet his wife, a series of appearances in the late 1980s on the Dave Letterman Show, and his fight against cancer. For all this, there is no attempt to make Pekar look better than he. He is described as physically uninteresting, a little strange, a chronic failure, more than a little neurotic and extremely egocentric. But despite all this, there is an honesty in looking at his life and portraying it as it is, warts and everything else. The way he deals with everything with an indefatigable sense of humor and his determination to do something to give a focus and purpose to his life is heroic in a very real and concrete way, as opposed to the fictitious false heroism of Superman, Batman, or the Green Lantern. It would be difficult to overdo Paul Giamatti by playing Harvey Pekar or Hope Davis by playing Joyce Brabner, the woman who marries Pekar. Both the real Pekar and the real Brabner also appear on the camera, as do most of the real-life models for the Pekar characters. In fact, the way the film\'s narrative flows seamlessly between real-life individuals, actors, and comic book representations is one of the film\'s strengths. In one scene, Paul Giamatti playing Pekar and Judah Friedlander playing Pekar\'s friend (and MTV\'s smallest celebrity) Toby Radloff are onscreen while the real Harvey Pekar and Toby Radloff talk. In another part of the film, Hope Davis and Paul Giamatti are supposedly behind the scenes of Dave Letterman\'s show, but when Giamatti leaves the stage with Letterman, Giamatti cuts to pictures of the real Pekar being interviewed by Letterman. I remembered Margritte\'s famous painting, where he has a painting of a pipe with the words "This is not a pipe" below. By switching from true Pekar to an actor who plays him, it\'s a way of saying "this is not Harvey Pekar" whenever Giamatti is on the screen. In addition, it implies that Giamatti is a cinematographic equivalent of the several Pekars drawn in the comic books. This is a great movie, and I hope you get the attention it deserves. It\'s very different from the CRUMB movie, but I imagine it\'s especially appealing to those who enjoyed that weird but fascinating documentary.'

b"I believe the waitress's excellence is all by herself, but my desire to like it was undoubtedly heightened by the post-production tragedy of the murder of writer / director Adrienne Shelly. I think co-star Cheryl Hines says it's better on the featurette: Shelly's tragic, pointless death drives you to watch the movie through a different prism. She'll miss you."

b"Beverly Hills Cop did not need presentations. It was one of the best action comedies of 1984. It helped bring Eddie Murphy to the mainstream and reigned in 1984. Beverly Hills Cop II was very good. A little over the top but still fun. It complemented Tony Scott's film-making style and also captured the essence of the 1980s. This monstrosity is instantly forgettable from start to finish. A bust is terribly wrong and Inspector Todd (Gilbert R Hill) is killed. Axel (Eddie Murphy) traces the killer known as Ellis De Wald (Timothy Carhart) to a tacky Disney knock-off called Wonderworld, where Ellis De Wald is the supervisor. Where do I start first? Axel Foley does not even feel like Axel Foley (like Big Top Pee Wee is different from Pee Wee of Big Adventure). Eddie spends the entire movie looking like he can not understand what his character should be. Gone is the tenacious but silly cop who angered his target. He is replaced by a guy who is so relaxed in his behavior that it gets annoying to watch after a while. The only characters to return are Inspector Todd (but he is killed in the beginning) and Rosewood (Judge Reinhold). Taggart is gone and so is the sergeant. Bogomil. That was the hint that this movie was DOA. The first two BHC movies had good villains considering the length of time. Victor Maitland and The Alphabet Killer were good villains, but Ellis De Wald is horrible. No disrespect for Timothy Carhart, but he was very weak and his work plan was weak and laziness on behalf of the writers. Using an amusement park to make fake money? The film is rarely funny and bringing back Serge (Bronson Pinochet) was an inexpensive attempt to remind us of the first interaction Serge and Axel Foley had in the first film. There is a moment of redemption in this film: the malfunctioning sequence of the park where Axel saves two children. This scene is the only reason I gave two stars. The mood is most often forced and if you ever listen to this boring theme song for Wonderworld it will be too soon. Who thought it was a fun plot device anyway? In conclusion, this movie killed a promising series. It's a shame that the same director (John Landis) behind Animal House, Blues Brothers, Coming To America and some of my favorite movies are behind this mess. John Landis is a great director, but not a great director for this kind of film. Thumbs down."

b'In movies, as in most other art forms, most works usually come in the smallest of packages. Such is the case of "The Five Senses," an independent Canadian production that chooses for its subject no less than a meditation on what it means to be human. Writer / Director Jeremy Podeswa has created a poetic and insightful work centered on a group of people who share the universal need to find true love and acceptance in a world where hurt and destroyed relationships often result in greater loneliness and despair. Like all of us, each of these characters tends toward the dual goals of intimacy with others and acceptance of self that are essential to human happiness. Some succeed while others fail - just as in life - but none of the characters is left untouched by experience. "The Five Senses", although it has a plot, is more a piece of emotional humor than a narrative drama. Blessed with an excellent cast, Podeswa is able to draw us into the center of his world through the use of sensory images and methodical and deliberate rhythm. In fact, one of the film\'s strongest themes is the examination of the role our senses play in defining our world and character. Podeswa understands that we become insensitive to our senses. As a result, he uses this film to reconnect us to the crucial element of our beings. The quiet, quiet tone, the soft autumnal colors, the sluggish camera, the astonishing soundtrack combine to create an atmosphere in which the audience can become aware of every sight and sound that comes our way. In our effort to establish meaningful intimacy with other human beings, we usually rely on the sense of touch - but this can serve, Podeswa tells us, both to imprison us in false intimacy and to lead us to one that is genuine. and long-lasting. Some of his characters use sex as a substitute for true closeness, while others make a physical connection on a much deeper level. One of the most touching moments in the movie comes when a gay man - probably an AIDS patient - falls apart in tears during a massage session, heartbroken because no one has dared touch him in such a long time. This film recognizes the vital part that sensitive physical contact plays in the totality of a person\'s humanity. Similarly, the film explores the beauty of sound as one of the characters - ironically, an ophthalmologist, a man dedicated to preserving the organ of a sense - faces the prospect of imminent deafness and yearns to create a mental catalog of all sounds of everyday life that he will soon be unable to hear and which we routinely take for granted. However, like all other characters, it is their spiritual emptiness and inability to make a meaningful connection with another human being who brings their greatest obstacles to happiness. Podeswa also examines the part that smell plays in making this vital human connection, as one of the characters - a lonely gay man - revisits his former lovers to smell them in an effort to find out if he can smell "true love" . "Yet` `The Five Senses \'\' is not merely a movie built on an intelligent device. Rather, it breathes in the fullness of humanity, because each of its many characters emerges as a fully developed and instantly recognizable human being. There are adolescents alienated by their own inability to fit into the norm accepted by society and feel guilty for their acts of careless irresponsibility. There are mothers terrified of the loss of their children in one case, literally when their youngster disappears and disappears and, in another case, figuratively, while her teenage daughter seems to be creeping into inexplicable "strangeness." "There are adults unable to comprehend a life filled with failed relationships that attack in desperation for that last chance for happiness, often with the result that they go further than the universally desired goal than ever before. One of the more daring aspects of "The Five Senses" is that he does not succumb to the temptation to provide a "happy" or even conclusive ending for all his characters. The film recognizes that life is a confusing and endless process of changing fortunes and personal growth and remains true to that theme to the end. This brave, haunting and mesmerizing film definitely stands out as one of the real finds of recent movies. a real work of art!'
b'A real tear-jerker, but a great movie. I had the movie in a week and a half'

b'"The Exorcist," along with such films as Rosemary\'s Baby, The Shining and The Ring, stand out as some of the greatest horror films of all time. Not only were they great movies themselves, but they "broke the rules" and opened up new avenues. This DVD contains many deleted scenes and behind the scenes watch the production of the film. I know I heard that after a movie screening a few months before the release, some screen executives thought the movie should not be released. It was very scary. When you really watch the movie for the first time, you will be truly scared ... ... if you take it deeply. Some people remember the "pea soup" incident, but this movie did not use the blood to show what it wanted. Like the other movies listed above, he used clever pictures, dialogues and symbols to make his points. Most people who read this review know that the story was based on a case in 1947 when a 13-year-old boy should have been possessed. . Obviously, some details have been changed for the film. I would like to see a movie from the "true" story of 1947, in which no name is revealed, but the facts of the case are presented. The Exorcist really deserves all 5 stars. Perhaps more writers and filmmakers today should come back and watch it before attempting to make another foolish teen movie that calls itself a horror film.'

b'I liked the special features as much as the episodes. Some of the invited stars that appeared in Bonanza gave comments on the episode they were in. It was interesting how they explained where the episode was filmed and how they did the special effects. Everyone said the Bonanza stars were a pleasure to work with and everyone on set was cool. David Dortort, the creator of Bonanza gave interesting interviews as well. I especially liked his interview called "Remembering Pernell Roberts". The photo gallery contains photos of the stars in their homes. The episodes are uncut with scenes never seen before on TV. I would highly recommend this DVD to any Bonanza fan.'

b'The Enterprise picks up several envoys from various planets to unleash them on a planetoid called Babel. His plans are to discuss Coridan\'s acceptance as a member of the Federation. Some members of the Federation are strongly opposed to accepting them. The reasons ranged from blood feuds to the criminals\' desire to steal Dylithium\'s precious crystals from the planet - Federation protection would do away with such criminal undertakings from other members of the Federation. Among the delegates are Vulcans, Andorians, and a foreign delegation with the face of a pig. which resemble crossings between Bassett Hounds and the Ugnaughts of "Return of the Jedi" with hauntingly empty eyes and a short temper. The makeup on the Andorans was incredibly well made for the time period. When ambassador Vulcan Sarek and his wife Amanda embark on the Enterprise, there is obvious tension and Sarek asks someone other than Spock to be their "tour guide" for the ship. It is then revealed that Sarek and Amanda are Spock\'s parents. Jane Wyatt is the loving wife and mother who has overwhelmed much of her emotions to accommodate Sarek, but still allows them to erupt from time to time. Mark Lenard begins his lifelong career as Sarek, who we continue to see until his death in one of the last seasons of "Star Trek: The Next Generation". `` Sarek has not talked to Spock for four years. Annoyed that his son had refused to study the same subjects he and his father had studied, there are angry, but subjugated, silences among them. Amanda must rush back and forth to calm them down in a gentle way. One of the pig-faced aliens, Gaz, confronts Sarek in the hall and the threat when Sarek declares his intention to vote for acceptance of the case. Coridans. Soon after, Gaz is found, murdered. An autopsy reveals that his neck was broken at a point that would cause instant death. Spock recognizes this as a form of the death penalty used in Vulcan centuries earlier, preferred by his speed and painless delivery. A method called Tal-Shaya, well known to his father. An interesting detail is that the Romulan equivalent of the KGB is called Tal-Shayar in the next generation episodes - the Romulans are distant cousins \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bof the Vulcans and their languages \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bno doubt have common roots ... perhaps the English translation of the Tal-Shayar is `` the murderers of the neck \'\'? Anyhoo, Sarek is thought to be a suspect, but is eliminated when it is obvious that a defective heart valve has been keeping him out of commission. A risky operation requires Spock, the only Vulcan on board with the same T-negative blood type, to deliver almost half of his blood during a transfusion. Why they could not have a beer a day is beyond me. Spock prepares to be the source of blood for his father when Kirk is attacked by an Andorian. The Andorian clearly stabs Kirk on the lower back, near his kidneys in the attack just before Kirk kicks him back and knocks him cold. Kirk reaches to the side and pulls a bloody hand and uses the wall intercom to call for help before losing consciousness. In the infirmary we see Kirk with a bandage around his bare chest. Now we are told that his lung was pierced and that the Andorian barely felt heart failure. Considering he was using a small knife that could not have hit from his butt to his heart, I think they should have re-filmed the fight scene, but that\'s just me. It is as if the lung injury were a later thought of the battle scene and perhaps the writers felt that the public would not "catch" a kidney injury in the same way that they would understand how a lung injury would take their breath away. And that\'s fine. Bad continuity in those scenes, anyway. Spock suddenly refuses to help in his father\'s surgery. He must instead command the Enterprise because there was a murder on board the Enterprise, an assassination attempt, discussions between the delegates, and an unidentified alien vessel chased them, just beyond the reach of their sensors and weapons. Kirk, disoriented, wakes up at Sick Bay, he told the news and needs to find a way to put Spock on the operating table without violating Federation regulations and Vulcan\'s stubborn oath on duty and logic. A subsequent interrogation and a search for the Andorian who attacked Kirk results in some interesting discoveries that will take him to the limit of his seat. Despite being a bit of cheese here and there, this is one of the most exciting episodes of the old series. An excellent show.'

b'Stephen King is best known for his macabre books, but what some people do not know, is that he is also a master of comedy - as is the case with "The Langoliers." complex and hilarious study of the human mind. The film delves deeper, showing how funny people can be when confronted with the imminent destruction. Both the film and the book ask the question, "What would you do if you fell asleep on an airplane, but everyone who was awake died?" and that one of the people on your plane is a psychopath, and another is a blind girl who can sense evil, like Haley Joel Osment in "The Sixth Sense", so you seek shelter at an airport, but all carbonated drinks are flat and the food is spoiled, then you find out that these Pac-Man-like creatures ("the Langoliers") literally consume the past? `` Well, what would you do? It\'s a complicated question, and to be honest with you, I do not know what I would do. But I can say one thing, Bronson Pinchot (in a performance that is quite different from his beloved character Balki Bartokomous in the popular TV show, "Perfect Strangers") also does not know how to answer the question. Dude, he\'s crazy - and I\'m not talking about Riggs in `` Lethal Weapon \'\' - I mean, he really goes crazy. You can say that Pinchot really embraced that role for what it was and took the method to a whole new level. Still not convinced? After all the laughter and clowning routines (the scene where Dean Stockwell drinks the beer at the airport is absolutely brilliant!), You are led into a fantastic, suspenseful chase scene where the Langoliers chase the plane at high speed through escape Just as the plane is preparing to take off the sharp teeth of Langoliers ... Sorry, but you\'re going to have to watch the movie to find out how it ends. That is, if the Langoliers did not reach you first.'

b"This biopic, based on Take Me Home, an autobiography of John Denver, will be enjoyed by hardcore fans (like me), but it's still horrible in many ways. The story begins in the early 1960s, when John (Chad Lowe) begins his career as a folk singer. He meets Annie (Kristin Davis) on a show and falls in love with the place. They marry and move to Aspen, but when John's career takes off, tension increases in marriage. They divorce, he has a short second marriage, and he discovers his love for flying, something that finally earns the respect of his stern father (Gerald McRaney). This movie is a summary of John's life; is poorly written and amateurish and lacks depth or emotion. Lowe (who wears a hideous clown wig that makes him look like Dana Carvey in Waynes World), is shameless all the time, playing an innocent who never seems to grow up. (Actually, although the film covers thirty years, no one gets old.) Davis is very handsome, but the horrible script does not give him much of a chance to develop. McRaney plays the only character that seems real, and he is the villain of the play. The story is shallow and Lowe's Denver is not particularly nice. Her hair is so laughable and distracted that the movie has no chance. Although we hear Denver sing many of his songs, Lowe is lousy at synchronizing his lips. The DVD extras are useless; where are some pictures of the true JD we love?"

b'Wish You Were Here was the follow-up album to Pink Floyds, the massively successful commercial album, Dark Side Of The Moon, which, among other great songs, contained perhaps its signature, "Money." Released in September 1975, Wish You Were Here is the favorite album of many band members as well as fans. When it hit the streets, it went straight to number one on the album charts, both in the UK and the US. In the first four notes - the basis of the song - this invokes a sadness, which was the story of Sy d Barrett. Recorded at Abbey Road Studios in London for several sessions. Although some of these sessions are problematic, it was Roger Waters\' idea to split the centerpiece "Shine On You Crazy Diamond" in two and join each party with three new compositions. "Shine On" was a tribute to Barrett, who, coincidentally, made an impromptu visit to the studio while it was being recorded. Wish You Were Here is Pink Floyd\'s second conceptual album written entirely by Waters. This reflects his sense that the friendship that cemented the band was, at the time, practically absent. Deeply steeped in themes of absence, the greed of the music business and Barrett. The album begins with a long instrumental prelude and follows the lyrics of "Shine On You Crazy Diamond," a tribute to Syd Barrett - whose mental breakdown forced him to leave the band several years earlier. Barrett is fondly remembered with phrases like "Remember when you were young, you shone like the sun" and "You reached the secret too soon, you cried for the moon." This simultaneous release on Blu-Ray and DVD is the authoritative history of the album and was made with the full involvement of the band members. The film is full of new interviews with Roger Waters, David Gilmour and Nick Mason and archives interviews with the late Richard Wright. Also included is cover designer Storm Thorgerson, guest vocalist Roy Harper and cover "Ronnie Rondell" and others involved in the album\'s production. Members of the band discuss the initial difficulties of the initial recordings and how The decision to split "Shine On" became the catalyst. Other interesting insights revealed through interviews are the fact that before Barrett left the band, he virtually gave up or abandoned the desire to make "hit" music. he did not want to make music for `` Top Of The Pops \'\' and, ironically, band members have blamed the greed of the music industry on themselves as the main impetuous for wanting to make music more commercially acceptable, if not exactly " pop ". The movie is also full of excerpts from concerts and performances as well as parts of the band working on the parts.Pink Floyd: The Story of Wish You Were Here is a fascinating and appropriate documentary to honor the band in creating the masterwork album. For casual fans and collectors and musicologists, this is one that you will want to add to your collection. if you\'re an aspiring musician, then you\'ll play it over and over again just to take a look at the creative concept. Syd Barrett has performed in music for only seven years, recording four singles, Pink Floyd\'s debut album The Piper , in the Gates of Dawn (and contributed to the second), in addition to several songs unpublished with Pink Floyd. In 1969, Barrett released a solo single, "Octopus," which prefigured his first solo album, The Madcap Laughs (1970), which was recorded over the course of a year (1968-1969) with four different producers including David Gilmour and Roger Waters. Nearly two months after the release of Madcaps, Barrett began work on his second album, Barrett, produced by Gilmour and Richard Wright, which was to be released in the late 1970s, before entering self-imposed seclusion for more than thirty years. Barrett\'s innovative guitar work and the exploration of experimental techniques such as dissonance, distortion, and feedback had a huge legacy not only in defining the direction that Floyd would take without him, but musicians from David Bowie to Brian Eno and Jimmy Page and more. suffering from diabetes for several years, Barrett died at his Cambridge home on July 7, 2006. He was 60 years old. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. The occupation on his death certificate was given as a "retired musician". `` According to local newspapers, Barrett left about 1.7 million for his two brothers and two sisters. This amount was apparently purchased largely from Pink Floyd\'s royalties for compilations and live recordings with songs he had written while in the band. The Dirty Lowdown'
