b'Louis Malle\'s Lacombe, Lucien still impresses, although he tends to crawl in the third act when you can expect him to tighten control. But it is still a casually powerful reminder of the less heroic side of France under Vichy\'s rule (the Nazis barely seen in the film), since its not very clever does almost accidentally in collaboration with the German Police composed entirely of his compatriots after being rejected by the Resistance. The main achievement of the film is to show, much like Fascism in general, the appeal that the collaboration had to dissatisfied and dissatisfied strangers in the community (only one of the \'cops\' is a true fanatic) and the attraction of undeserved and a power undeserved as Lucien thinks the power he has over people (particularly the implicit threat of surrendering his Jewish "girlfriend" - perhaps a little more symbolically called "France" - to the Germans) is far more intoxicating than killing mere animals. with Melville\'s masterpiece of resistance, L\'Armee des Ombres, there is a worldly sense of reality that adds to the drama. Situated in the quaint little village type that strangers find idyllic, but that is a tedious hell to live for the villagers, it shows how upset and opportunity are so much more a driving force than malice. Certainly far from being glamorous, your employees stay in a local hotel getting drunk and whining when the war news gets worse and worse (as you can tell, you have to listen to both German and British radio reports) and divide the difference \'\' to find the truth) and they are gradually caught up by the embattled locals. The only extra on Criterion\'s album is the imaginative theatrical trailer, so this may be worth catching on Criterion\'s set of boxes which also includes Au Revoir Les Enfants, Heart Murmur and an exclusive disc of extras focusing mainly on Louis Malle and not in the movies themselves.'

b'Paul Verhoeven and Joe Eszterhas open their film with the last oxymoron of love and death: the moment of orgasm coincides with the moment of greatest agony and death. Never before has a movie character been killed at the height of orgasm. Never before has such a creative and controversial opening opened the view of the polarized audience of the first scene. Never before has movie orgasm reached such a scary, cynical, darkly humorous edge with every counter-penetration of the murder weapon. The very concept of ending the victim this way in the first few minutes of the film demonstrates the genius of the creators - and their "poor" taste. But this is just the beginning of a delightfully ironic, even entertaining dance. between life and death that forms the twists and turns of the Wild Instinct. In addition to analyzing a childish and simplistic film of sex and violence, a great film reaches emotional intensity as well with its "looks" carefully photographed and edited. "scenes in which the characters look at each other in non-verbal communication attacks - and Wild Instinct scores 200 percent in this department." Conquered by Verhoeven, cinematographer Jan De Bont and the cast itself, "looks" achieve a particularly good advantage when Curran and Gus meet Roxy for the first time on "his and hers Picassos" scene in the foyer, and then Verhoeven bets again on the scene by the ocean on the deck where Curran, Gus and Trammell meet for the first time. The cut and score score in this area is so beautiful that it hurts. This is certainly the best result of Jerry Goldsmith, whose power in all production is invaluable. Non-verbal looks are key, and it seems mixed with Joe Eszterhas\'s now-famous dialogue to make Wild Instinct such a coherent and vital, so crisp film A delightful friction of character that Wild Instinct is absolutely perfect - at least until the scene of violent sex between Curran and his psychotherapist, which I found unnecessary, but which adds a necessary touch of madness to Curran and Garner\'s relationship. The fact that this relationship is openly discussed in the department provides the final touch of contradiction and astringency. A great film stimulates all parts of the mind simultaneously, from the most intellectual to the most primitive, and Basic Instinct covers the entire spectrum by giving doses. of blood, emotionally satisfying character interaction and intellectually stimulating plot. Instinct is filled with classic and memorable scenes, but most scenes of sex and violence are definitely off the list. Verhoeven has to do it with taste and skill, of course. There are no mistakes here. But who cares how well they can make love or stab each other? It\'s the thing between violence, the fantastic interactions and concise dialogues of one of the best cast ever assembled, which makes the Wild Instinct so good. Particularly striking and satisfying is the scene with Dr. Lamott, Dr. Garner and the entire police team, who discusses the ambiguity and insanity of the film\'s basic themes with a brilliant backing of Goldsmith\'s underscore. Basic Instinct is the culmination of Michael Douglas\'s career - and Sharon Stone\'s career. In addition to Douglas\'s artistically sculpted expressions, let us not forget this fabulous voice. Douglas is simply amazing, and I\'ve never really enjoyed seeing a main character attacked by everyone in the cast, especially his own people. Note a performance particularly underrated by Denis Arndt as Lieutenant Walker, Curran\'s immediate supervisor, who provides a lack of support for Curran\'s ongoing investigation. If characters like Curran and Walker irritate, then Stone as Trammell is the best lubricant, nothing sticks to it, it can easily dodge from any situation. Basic Instinct dares to portray an invincible killer without guilt, without weakness, who as an antagonist overcomes Curran by seduction. I would finally like to touch on the beautiful and smooth movements of Jan De Bont\'s camera, which used in conjunction with long, uninterrupted , multi-character dialogue shots loaded with camera movement, elevate European style and make this one of the most visually pleasing movies to watch ever made, just in terms of pure camera movement. The interaction between camera and actors is electrifying in their vitality. I really liked Verhoeven and De Bont\'s commentary track on Blu Ray. In his craft alone, Wild Instinct goes far beyond the ordinary thriller to become the modern modern whodunit, against which all others must be measured. This movie will surpass the critics - the best film of Verhoeven, by far.'

b'Tom Hanks is the adult man with the 13-year-old mind. As he makes a wish in front of a carnival divination machine to be great, and his desire is granted (physically, but not mentally). He does a search to find the machine to change the desire; In the meantime, he gets a job at a toy company. Basically, the film becomes a long joke about a "child" in the adult world, but also tends to other issues - the loss of innocence and that superficial honesty that is so prevalent in childhood and then disappears into adulthood. Hanks, of course, is a hit in the toy business (what would the 13 year olds not be?). But he falls in love with a co-worker, which makes the decision to go back to 13 again in the end, more moving. Hanks is very good in the role of this child. Worth a watch.'
b"This is a moving story that reminds me of some things that have happened in my life. Two boys in love with each other happen. And that's really a beautiful thing."

b'My seven year old wanted to learn piano, so I bought a traditional piano book for kids - he ended up crying. I was looking for a way to teach him that would not destroy his passion and creativity, or steal his joy of learning. As I walked through the library, the title "Piano for Quitters" caught my eye. In a few days, my son was writing beautiful chord progressions and asking that "musical practice" be added to his work diary so he could play the piano before his other works were finished. Our whole family is now learning to play the piano and worshiping! I\'m a former piano quitter - I\'ve survived a year of traditional piano lessons, and tried several other piano methods, but using Piano for Quitters (and it\'s the sequel: Piano for Life), I\'m learning to play music along with my sons and husband.'

b'Robert Duvall shows some originality in this captivating film. I say captivating, I could not turn it off, the dialouge was very realistic almost with a documentary edge, the action while it was not flashy or excessive had realistic grain, and I had to wonder how this was going to end. Being an artistic end, you really do not know what will happen to our protagonist, killer in the end. I draw the original word in this work for a few reasons. The main character, "John Anderson," played by Duvall (though the same character we\'ve seen him play before) is a killer with a difference, does not use much sexist posture to create this vulnerable, aged and somewhat regretted professional. . He does not repent of the "works" he performed, but which, as he approached the twilight of his life, established no real roots. However, he now has a girlfriend with a ten-year-old daughter, and his love and devotion to that child shines, as well as Duvall\'s love for Tango which is so wonderfully accomplished by the loving camera of very attractive Argentines. Young and old. The assassination plan is second to Tango for much of the film, and when Duvall brings us back to his purpose of being in Argentina, we feel as much as he has to leave that wonderful dance behind. There were a couple of times when Duvall\'s scenes might have been stricter, but I never felt they were too big negatives. All in all, I would recommend this movie to lovers of independent films, dance and Robert Duvall fans.'

b"The Ten Commandments, The Buccaneer, Ben-Hur, The Cid, Planet of the Apes, all the great Charlton Heston movies, for sure. But this film, Heston's performance as the passionate and complex Michelangelo Buonarroti, has no parallel in any of the previous roles or since he played. His portrait as the great artist is imtimate and shows a tender side. In addition, Rex Harrison as Pope Julius II is also extraordinary. The two men create a good chemistry of the rebel artist and stern, but feeling the pontiff who sends Buonarroti to the great task of the Sistine Chapel. This performance reaches its peak when the two men are standing underneath the large and still unfinished fresco late at night and reflect on the images of God and Adam - the classic acting with certainty. Please buy it, rent it, as long as you watch it. If you like art, I'm sure you'll love it."

b'Almost nine years after watching the film for the first time and almost 34 years since the events he inspired took place, the film "Apollo 13" looks even more captivating. The story of Apollo 13, for anyone who has followed the space program and especially those who have witnessed it, is a story as engrossing as it has been told throughout American history. It is filled with drama, intrigue, twists and thrills. What\'s more, everything really happened! In April 1970, the American public was already seeing the incredible landing landing on the Moon as it passed. and could not have cared less about the Apollo 13 mission. Interest was so apathetic that the astronaut conveyed when the ship was about to enter lunar orbit was not even broadcast on television. The fickle public certainly had their interest aroused when, not long after the broadcast, a simple house-cleaning maneuver (stirring in the oxygen tanks) exposed a fatal flaw that led to a tremendous explosion. This explosion caused Apollo 13 to lose control, put an end to hopes of landing on the Moon and left the fate of the three astronauts (Commander Jim Lovell, LM pilot Fred Haise, and command pilot Jack Swigert) in doubt. The heroic efforts made by Mission Control members, as well as the astronauts themselves, bring Apollo 13 back to Earth safely is one of the greatest stories ever told. Acclaimed director, Ron Howard, saw this and, inspired by Lovell. The own account of that mission created one of the truly majestic historical films that already arrived at the screen. "Apollo 13" is a true cinematic achievement. He rekindles the imagination and imagines that the space program happened in the 60s and early 70s. Using cutting-edge special effects in the service of history (as opposed to in place of it), Howard is able to give the public a close-up view of the entire Apollo mission. Using archive footage to create special effects scenes, the director is able to make the release look real, as if the viewer were standing at the top of the tower, watching the rocket about to take off. The scenes in space are well crafted and extraordinarily realistic. When astronauts are forced to shut off much of the lunar module, and the entire command module, to conserve power, the cold abjectness and helplessness that these men were forced to endure is felt by the public. The true mark of the greatness of this film is found in the fact that while we know from the story that the men of Apollo 13 survived, the final moments during re-entry, as depicted in the film, are still incredibly exciting and tense. So the emotional release that comes knowing they have done it is so overwhelming that even the most cynical, hard-hearted viewer will be suffocated by emotion. The narrative and effects of "Apollo 13" are great, but the movie would probably still have fallen if not for the huge cast hired to play those roles. Tom Hanks is solid as the undisturbed Jim Lovell, Bill Paxton (who always seems to find a way in every blockbuster) is good as the trusted but untested debutante Fred Haise, and Kevin Bacon gives a precise picture of last minute Jack replacement Swigert. Gary Sinise plays Ken Mattingly, Swigert the astronaut replaced due to fear of a measles infection, with appropriate melancholy. The other highlight is that of Ed Harris, who plays the rock of a flight director, Gene Kranz. Harris really deserved his Oscar nomination for this performance and there is certainly a strong case to be made for him to have won the award for Supporting Actor winner Kevin Spacey. Apollo 13, by itself, was a strong contender for Best Picture Award, second only to the valuable Braveheart. The only disconcerting question is why Ron Howard was omitted from the nominations for Best Director (he would have to wait another 7 years before receiving his due for "A Brilliant Mind"). "Apollo 13" is not just a big suspense; it is also a lesson in telling history. This allows us to remember those wonderful days of the quest to reach the Moon, as well as the drama of that endangered flight. It is disheartening today to see how the space program has stagnated since those intoxicating days. Apollo 13 proves, beyond a shadow of a doubt, that we still have men with the will, the knowledge and the courage to take this space exploration to places beyond imagination.'

b"In Barbra Walter's interview with Al Pacino several years ago, she said that this was Pacino's favorite role. But this movie stands by itself despite this proclamation. Pacino plays a bandit of Cuban refugees, Tony Montana, who grabs and revolves (leading some lives along the way) to the top of the cocaine world in Miami with the help of his right arm Manny Ray (Steven Bauer). There are memorable moments throughout this movie and some are very graphics but what is probably the highlight of this movie is the great shoot'em up scene at the end; Sosa's assassins infiltrated the Montana estate to kill him because Montana made a big hit for Sosa. When Montana, full of cocaine, finally turns his attention to the killers, he retaliates in complete defiance of them with a machine gun / grenade launcher. & quot; Say hello to my little friend! & quot; is now one of those famous movie lines in the history of cinema. He detonates them as dominoes, resisting the incredible shootout because of the cocaine in his system. This is a true & quot; face 's & quot; scene. It's action fueled by high-octane adrenaline and Pacino plays beyond belief. Your performance is so exciting that you want to grab a machine gun and fight alongside it. Pacino It's Scarface! The DVD comes with great advantages such as theater trailers, production notes, cast and film biographies, the production of SCARFACE (with Pacino) and 10 outtakes of the film. The movie is letterboxed, but it is not digitally enhanced. It would have been nice to see the movie improved, but it does not detract from the experience of watching this movie. Actually, I do not care. IT'S SCARFACE!"

b'In my short list of unmissable titles for 2011, Jos\xc3\xa9 Padilha\'s "Elite Squad: The Inner Enemy" certainly was at the top of the list. The first time I heard about Padilha was with the documentary "Bus 174", 2002, an unforgettable and true story about a bus kidnapping that has spread publicly in the Brazilian media. It was a distressing image that had so much to say about contemporary journalism, rampant crime, local corruption, political maneuvering, and police status as the actual event it represented. I think it\'s fair to say that some of these same themes remained a constant in all future director / writer work. That said, I want to point out that `` Elite Troop: The Internal Enemy \'\' is actually a sequel to the 2007 project titled (you guessed it) `` Elite Troop. "Although the two films are certainly better served as complementary pieces, this has a self-contained story that can be enjoyed on its own merits. If you choose to see this without seeing the first picture, you may lose some of the character\'s stories - but the script makes it faster and more efficient. The film revolves around the character of Captain Nascimento, effectively played by Wagner Moura. Moura is responsible for a special crime unit, and when a prison riot goes awry, squad tactics and decisions are questioned by human rights activists (led spectacularly by her ex-wife\'s new husband). Public opinion, however, side by side with fast and uncompromising performance Moura and pushes him into a position of even more power. Making it a mission to eliminate the rampant drug crisis in Rio, it targets the lower-class favelas where the problem has its strongest point. But by eliminating the obvious enemy, it can make way for a more unexpected enemy. While dirty cops and unscrupulous politicians jockey for new power, Moura begins to realize that he has cut off a monster\'s head to see another (more nefarious) one take its place. Unable to rely on power, he sees new allies in the media and activists who once criticized Moura\'s methods. The turnaround is compelling, believable and undeniably scary. The film is filmed in a gritty documentary style that makes the nasty even more tangible. Although perhaps the narrative depends a little too much on the voice analysis, it keeps Moura\'s point of view in perspective, since the great story leaves him on the fringes of large parts of the action. In essence, this is a morality game disguised as a relentless crime saga - but, in that sense, it is surprisingly underestimated. The character changes are subtle and the action is inexorably real. It\'s hard to imagine that the film can have a happy or satisfying conclusion, but what we have left is certainly appropriate, even if it does not involve everything in a small curve. In the end, the characters distinguish this piece (Moura is fantastic) that has universal relevance in its subjects of corruption and those that fight it. `` Elite Troop: The Internal Enemy \'\' is a rare image that will make you think while having fun. About 4 1/2 stars. KGHarris, 2/12.'

b"Black Sheep (no, not Chris Farley and David Spade starring in the mid-'90s movie) is a movie that has to be seen to be believed. Taking place in New Zealand as a phobic sheep man (Nathan Meister) returns to his old family farm to make amends with his brother (Peter Feeney) who happens to be genetically altering the sheep that populate the land. These sheep do away with a hunger for human flesh, and those they bite become monstrous sheep (yes, they were sheep), and before you know it, they are going crazy. Yes, Black Sheep sounds absolutely ridiculous, and by all means is, but the film is so entertaining that you can not help but admire it. Not to mention the brilliant effects of gore and creature, courtesy of Peter Jackson's WETA workshop staff, while rookie scriptwriter and director Jonathan King plays a visual gag directly at you after another on top of bunches of blood. It does not come close to the irreverent horror / fun of Shaun of the Dead itself, but for what it's worth, Black Sheep is so much fun that comic horror fans should definitely take a look."

b'`` Destination Moon \'\' and `` Rocketship XM \'\' both came out the same year - but that\'s where the similarity ends. I consider "Destination Moon" the father of the modern science fiction movie. The production quality and the wonderful Technicolor give this film a quality that few post-1950 science fiction films would achieve. What helps this movie is the fact that there are no real stars in it - but very competent actors and very recognizable at the very least. `` Rocketship XM \'\', on the other hand, was a fast-paced movie made for `` ... Moon \'\' in theaters. The black and white print quality is stunning, having been restored to its original sharp quality. Lloyd Bridges stars. The special effects for `` XM \'\' were decent for their time, but the effects for `` ... Moon \'\' were ahead of their time. If I were rating these movies, I would give `` .. Moon \'\' a B + and `` XM \'\' a C +. Both films are fun and make nice company pieces.'

b"I love this workout! It's a great program that takes about 45 minutes, and I can do it when I do not feel like going out to the gym. I've danced most of my life, so most low-impact workout exercises I've ever been familiar with, but the repetition is wonderful, and I'm a little sore the next day every time I do the low-impact workout . High impact training is a different story. I've done this once since I had the DVD and could hardly walk the next day! ! This comes from a dancer who is in good shape. The high impact workout is mostly squatting. As soon as I recover from the last time I did this, I'll do it again because it's great and it's so good for you! There is an additional workout for both arms and abs. Each set has Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders demonstrating. Three of the cheerleaders have been selected to perform beginner, intermediate and advanced exercises, so you can choose which one to follow. The only thing I do not care about is that the coach who leads the practice talks a lot. . He is very motivating, however, and especially people who are not very familiar or motivated for the workout, I think they would really benefit from it. I was hesitant to buy a training DVD because of previous disappointment with them and lack of motivation to make them a few more times, but this DVD is an exception. It's a lot of fun, it takes less than an hour of my day, and I can choose exactly how intense or easy I want to take it day by day. Highly recommended ! !"

b"Nothing new happens in this movie. There's a lot of action, mostly in the form of blasts, but nothing in the movie actually moves the Terminator story forward. The viewer leaves where he came from. It is relatively frustrating that the movie insults the viewer's intelligence with lazy plot devices. For example, there are scenes involving the movement of huge and noisy machines, but the characters are not aware of the machines until the machines are on top of them. Or consider that barrels of oil or gasoline or tubes of molten metal or liquid nitrogen are conveniently ubiquitous so that the characters can shoot when needed to make an explosion or melt some machine. The movie is full of such devices. They play out, one after another, for about two hours. Nothing else happens. We have learned nothing new. My recommendation is to skip this terrible addition to the T series."

b'+++++ This film is based on the musical piece "Cabaret" (also called "Goodbye Berlin"). The music and lyrics are from the great John Kander and Fred Ebb, respectively. It was directed by, and the numbers of dance and music were staged by the late Bob Fosse. Personally, I\'m not much into musicals, but this movie is so much more than a great musical. Do not understand that there is just singing and dancing. There is also a good story that plunges into the corruption, decay and false dreams of Berlin in the early 1930s, when Hitler was coming to power. The story follows the life of Sally Bowles (Liza Minnelli) during this turbulent period. She is the so-called star of Kit Kat nightclub who has a master of ceremonies (Joel Gray). Writer Brian Roberts (Michael York) intrudes into Sally\'s world, hoping to take the vacant room opposite her. He soon discovers that she is a ball of fire and energy. It tells us of his dream: \'\' I\'m going to be a big movie star. That is, if drink and sex do not catch me first. `` The movie alternates between real and hard life outside the Kit Kat nightclub and the carefree life inside it, where those who take part can forget their troubles and troubled times. The music and dance routines within Kit Kat Klub provide an acute counterpoint to the real-life drama outside. Five songs from the original Broadway production did not enter the film as "performed," but appear as background music. The music, the costumes, the choreography and the performance are all excellent. Especially impressive is Minnelli\'s performance, impressive on stage and equally compelling. Combining with her is Gray\'s fascinating acting as the Master of Ceremonies that injects humor and excitement as well as effervescence and soundness in procedures. The last scene of music and dance performed by Minnelli is historical and unforgettable! This film won eight Oscars, including Best Actress (Minnelli), Best Supporting Actor (Gray) and Best Director (Fosse). Finally, the DVD itself (released in 2003) is perfect in picture and sound quality. It has a long list of interesting extras. In conclusion, I recommend you to go to this cabaret (old friend). You will never want to leave! ! (1972, 2 hours, wide screen, 32 scenes) +++++'

b"Put me to use. It's what the so-called Ritchie Boys asked the US Army in World War II and got what they wanted. These new recruits, alien refugees - some fresh off the ship from Europe - were sent to Camp Ritchie to learn how the German military did what they could to interrogate prisoners in war zones. It's a WWII story that had not yet been told, and the Ritchie Boys themselves make for watching watching and a wonderful story. These are the soldiers most of us can relate to, people who were not so good at handling firearms, but struggled to enthrall, confuse, and terrorize prisoners of war who appeared and had the information they wanted. in addition to the growing subgenres of Jewish documentaries and World War II, and cleverly uses intuition, music and video archiving. b'Always say, & quot; Everyone here is crazy but me. ? Then you\'ll love this scary, minimalist, low-budget, and very claustrophobic thriller from 1948. Detective Richard Carlson enters an asylum in an attempt to find a crooked judge hiding from justice. But before he can preach the judge, his identity is discovered and he becomes a prisoner of his own scheme. And the only person who can rescue him is the double woman who sent him there! A hard-edged thriller from director Budd Boetticher ("The Killer is Loose," "Comanche Station," "Bullfighter And The Lady") who later earned fame from a series of western existential Westerners ("The Tall T", "Ride Lonesome, "" Seven Men From Now, "etc.) starring the morose and damaged lonely Randolph Scott adrift in an ambiguous amoral environment. Personal note: In the 1970s I met the late Budd Boetticher as a friend. We would stay at Griffith Park with its Andalusians and make several trips to Mexico, where he still practiced his dangerous and beloved art of fighting with bulls on horseback. In life and in movies, he seemed obsessed with playing the role of male antagonist in constant battle with the environment. Boetticher preceded director Sam Peckinpah in themes that made the latter famous. Boetticher was the real thing. It\'s great to see this old gem available on DVD. (Full Screen, B & W, 68 minutes, unclassified).'

b"Stereotyped characters, complicated logic and an abundant absence of intelligence remain in & quot; Domestic Disorder, & quot; a thriller that wants to be disobedient, but ends up playing well. What begins as a somewhat interesting film turns into an endless chasm of unbelievable twists and aggravating characters that make all the wrong choices. Here is a movie that covers familiar terrain, but does not arouse much interest when things go wrong. John Travolta plays Frank Morrison, a boat builder whose ex-wife Susan (Teri Polo) is about to remarry. This, of course, is unacceptable to his 12-year-old son, Danny (Matthew O'Leary), whose explosions against his parents' divorce have led to police seizure on several occasions. Like any good father, Frank advises Danny to accept what he can not change, and give his new stepfather, the rich and popular Rick Barnes (Vince Vaughn), a warm welcome. Now anyone who knows their thrillers can guess that if money is involved then there is usually a tainted past here and there; this movie is no exception. The marriage continues smoothly, despite the presence of Ray Coleman (Steve Buscemi), a former acquaintance of Rick, who is engaged in collecting a large sum of money from his old friend. One thing leads to another, inventions appear, and Rick has a murder in his hands, unaware that Danny witnessed the action of the back seat of the car in which it occurred. This is the first in a series of several scenes that look promising but have little intensity or surprise. Judging from Danny's & quot; Boy who screamed wolf & quot; It is easy to predict that no one will believe him when he reveals what he has seen, except Frank, who must hold a grudge against his son's aggressor if there is any action or energy in the story. There's a bit of cat and mouse going on while Frank searches for Ray's disappearance and possible leads to take to the police, but that's nowhere to be seen. The film seems more interested in showing us how stupid people can be in such situations, however unbelievable. From the beginning, Susan stands by her man, defending him against Danny's accusations. Does it ever occur to you that when a strange event happens, Rick was away from home at the same time? Has she ever stopped to think about how her disbelief in her son's statements is affecting him, rather than the old song and dance about her marriage to Rick? Even the police are completely ignorant, ignoring everything until the end, when that matters little. My big complaint with & quot; Domestic Disruption & quot; is his editor, who reduced the film to just 88 minutes, too short for a thriller and too long for a documentary about vengeful stepfathers. Paramount's ad campaign for the movie hit us with a number of pre-release television commercials as well as a long and revealing theatrical trailer. There are scenes in both, one involving a car chase, the other involving an argument between Rick and Frank in which Rick tries to buy it. These and other glimpses are not even included in the final cut, and may have been more interesting than what we see here. The climax is the standard fodder, but it has the ability to generate more intensity than the rest of the film. Travolta performs well, convincing us of his loving father status; Vaughn can not generate a sense of threat, while Polo does little more than look totally ignorant. For all your attributes (which are few), & quot; Domestic Disruption & quot; adds nothing new to a worn-out genre; his lack of lucid plot could be neglected were it not for his failure to generate any level of suspense. Note: The movie was filmed on the east coast of North Carolina in Southport, but in one scene, Ray mentions that Rick was in a childhood memory of Rick on a family vacation in Maryland. Your thoughts, Mr. McNally?"

However, Manhunter\'s Reader is a creepy but more realistic portrait that surprises me every time I see this in how an evil genius manages to manipulate events out of his cell through the simple apparatus of a telephone. This Reader is surely behind steralized bars - and yet it manages to be a strong presence for TBE told with.I hope every fan and future fan of Manhunter gets to see it the way it first appeared, a beautiful piece of handicraft which was slim and elegant, and yet it flowed elegantly. b"This is the romantic comedy by which all other romantic comedies are now judged. Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan have undeniable chemistry and first-timing timing. And surprisingly also Bruno Kirby and Carrie Fisher, who really have great moments that add fun to the film. This film knows that no one knows how to present Manhattan better than Woody Allen and takes much of its traditions. Including the choice of romantic pop patterns. As in Annie Hall, & quot; It had to be you & quot; is the musical centerpiece for an inevitable coupling. The dialogue is fast and rhythmic, with an ear for the sensibility of New York. And you also know how to display New York's favorite hangouts at their best. Even Billy Crystal is a bit foggy. Yet this film is an original and its style has been imitated numerous times by other films hoping to capture some of its magic. Still, none surpasses that. The icing on the cake was the wonderful choice to interrupt the past seasons of Harry and Sally's relationship with the old couple telling stories of their first date. The way they speak and take on each other's stories is charming and authentic and forces smiles of recognition. When Harry Met Sally is a fun and funny movie that never tires, no matter how many times it's seen. It's a classic. The DVD contains about 7 minutes of additional deleted images. In this case, it is quite apparent because it was deleted. Watch at your own risk. Rob Reiner's audio commentary seems to have been delivered under the gun's sights. Do not look for many joyful anecdotes or insights about where it came from with all these great ideas. The comment track is very slow and dry. & Quot; Making of & quot; the documentary is a little more fun and insightful, so the extras are not a total wash. The sound and image quality is bright and lush, so the most important part of the disc, the movie, is as enjoyable as possible. When Harry Met Sally has a lot of fun with men and women trying to understand each other and makes us laugh a lot and even cry a bit in the process."

b'Although the story involves the Spanish Jesuits building a mission in the desert of South America, true action takes place in the heart. Robert DeNiro gives his best ever performance as a totally depraved and tormenting slave trader who becomes truly repentant. This is a beautiful story of grace, as DeNiro tries to pay for the ransom of his guilt, and begins to discover the mercy and unconditional love of God. At the same time, questions are raised around the motives behind missionary work. They must be inspired by the love of God, but other aspirations have been the impetus for many throughout history. As with the Crusades, there were some very well-meaning Christians, but there were also many who killed and conquered in the name of a loving God. This exemplary historical film will provoke thoughts and leave viewers enriched!'

b'This is not a review of the quality of DVD, cinematography, acting, etc., but rather the essential element of what I consider to be the most intelligent film of the year, although it is not illegible. * Spoiler alert * From what I read, it seems that most of these reviewers did not understand the final ambiguity or, if they did, found this very implausible. The first group (most viewers), not realizing the ambiguity of whether they actually did or did not, seemed to miss the last line that goes back to the conversation with the director, the philosophical core of the film, in which case Leo is resisting accepting which is the nature of man to be violent. If nothing else, the last line suggests that if he really did what they say, he at least has a certain level of self-knowledge about it, is looking for his insanity and refusing to live with it. Or it could be the case that he was always sane, that he really was right about what was happening and refused to accept his suggested memories and vision of the director but realizing that he could never escape and so decide \'die a hero . From what some have said, that this last premise is too incredible, I disagree. Why is it so hard to believe that a country would be incapable of something like that? During the time frame of this film, most US states were still sterilizing the mentally and physically disabled. Would it be such a moral step to go from there to experiment with psychotic criminals, people with no future, for the sake of our national security, our way of life, our dominion in world affairs? Of course, there are problems interpreting the end of the film. It would be a great coincidence if the four names were really anagrams of themselves. He has dreams throughout the film that allude to the end, even before the explanation is suggested by the doctor (although I\'ve only seen it once and may be missing something). On the other hand, if Leo really hallucinated the scene in the cave with Rachel , so why was there a total lack of surrealism, unlike all other sequences? The practical answer, to convince the public to the end, is not credible. The contradictions here seem to derive from the fact that Scorsese is revisiting the same theme he explored at the end of "Comedy King," and in the same style: we\'re guessing if it really happened or if it\'s all in the character\'s mind. I did not read the book, but from what I understood, Scorsese added a layer that was not present in Lehane\'s work, where it\'s definitely only in the character\'s mind, similar to the Machinist (not to beat Lehane). : with his psychological depth and misanthropic vision about human nature, he is the heir of the great Clouzot - though probably more successful in "Mystic River." Adding the ambiguity at the end without changing some plot points to initialize, gaps arise in logic. If that had been cleaned up a bit, I would not hesitate to classify \'SI\' with \'Raging Bull\' and \'Taxi Driver\'. Even so, this is still one of the good ones.'
b'Low quality videos with interviews in between. Best songs are stopped. Some bands are not to be heard live. Overpriced. Do not buy. Rent it first.'

b'I\'ve been a fan of X-Men since I was 9 years old. In recent years, comics have become obsolete and almost impossible to follow (a situation that Marvel Comics has been up to lately), and despite giving the first X-Men movie more than one chance, I did not really think about it very much. . So I tried to keep my expectations low for the X-2 ... The good news is ... it\'s MUCH better than its predecessor! X-2 does not need to bombard viewers with so much information (as this was mostly solved in the first movie), and it may well happen. We took exactly where the first movie stopped: Magneto is in jail, Wolverine is looking for clues about his past, and anti-mutant hysteria is rampant. Enter William Stryker, a government employee fanatic mutant hater, excellently played by Brian Cox. He sends mutant blue-skinned Nightcrawler to tear the White House and overflow the president in the impressive opening sequence, ensuring presidential cooperation with the anti-mutant agenda . Stryker wastes no time in setting up a secret force attack team, and his first target is ... ..to Professor Xavier\'s school. It seems they chose the wrong time to visit, however; The children are alone at home with their "nanny" ... ... Wolverine! Let\'s get ready for RUMMMMBBBLLEEEE! ! ! Before you know it, it\'s a total war between Stryker and the mutant faction assembled; Magneto is released from prison, Xavier and Cyclops are captured and used by Stryker, and the stage is set for a fight between the winner and Alkali Lake, where Wolvie can discover some interesting details about his skeleton and Adamantium claws. The fans disappointed with the lack of action in the first film will be in their glory here, as the number of fights was increased quickly, including an excellent dispute between Wolverine and Deathstrike, interpreted by the adorable Kelly Hu, and the barbaric anger of Wolverine in the mansion . I love the way he dispatches Stryker\'s henchmen ...! Director Bryan Singer has put together an excellent cast and each character takes their moment to shine. The new additions, Cox and Hu, do a great job with their respective roles, and the end sets the stage for X-3. Long-time fans will appreciate the appearances of X-Men artists such as The Beast, Colossus, Siryn, Artie and Kitty Pryde, and will heed the mentions of Gambit and Franklin Richards, among others. Bad news ... ? The film starts strong but gets half dragged at the end; Maybe some tighter edition was needed. In addition, considering how heavily the film draws on characters and situations developed by X-Men comic writer Chris Claremont, including the plot stripped out of his legendary graphic novel "God Loves, Man Kills," I was more than a little appalled to see him not recognized in the credits. The X-2 is not a perfect movie, but it\'s a big step up from the previous X-Men movie, and a great way to start the summer movie season.'

b'So, \'Ally McBeal\' definitely ended now, although this episode compilation reminds us of what was great about it. Focusing around Ally\'s perpetually single, slender and eccentric (Flockhart), the audience is drawn to her hallucinations (brilliantly perceived through a stunning computer animation), her loves, her losses and her work in a law firm that seems to embrace the stranger. What made this show great was that it was so different with David E. Kelley\'s sharp writing bringing a mixture of well-placed observations about modern relationships and absolutely hilarious characters. Who could forget John Cage (McNicol), the diminutive lawyer with a pet frog and a passion for Barry White? Add to that Richard Fish, who seems to wallow in his own male chauvinism, "Subzero" Nelle (diRossi) and the deliciously nasty Ling (Liu) and you have a nice cast that is quite nice, whatever they are doing. Recent episodes have been criticized for not being funny enough, this may seem unfair, although there is always a tendency to be nostalgic about the older episodes that are offered here. It balances very funny, romantic and sad and these previous episodes were genuinely revolutionary, paving the way for more experimental shows. Still, it would be nice to see the stations in their entirety, as they are available in the UK.'

b"Down Argentine Way is a delightful kind of light music from the early 1940s that should delight anyone who loves this kind of movie. We have great performances from great stars like Betty Grable, Don Ameche, Carmen Miranda and the amazing Nicholas Brothers dance! The plot follows a good rhythm and the performance was quite convincing. The action begins when horse-lover Glenda Crawford (Betty Grable) and her mother Binnie Crawford (Charlotte Greenwood) are on track - yet again. It seems the Crawford family has always loved horses and they love them, too. Glenda sees a beautiful racehorse and she wants to buy the horse - the problem is that the horse belongs to Don Diego Quintana (Henry Stephenson), who feeds a long and silly personal grudge against Willis Crawford, the horse's patriarch. the Crawford family. Anyway, Glenda and Binnie go to Argentina after their first attempt to buy horses from Quintana does not go very well. It is not long before Glenda falls in love with Quintana's son, Ricardo Quintana (Don Ameche), who is equally enchanted by Glenda. The young couple tries to pass Glenda Crawford to Don Quintana as Glenda Cunningham in the hope that he will enjoy her and then do not care if she is a Crawford; but this also has its complications. Meanwhile, there's a horse built to compete - will Don Quintana leave the horse race? It's a fragile subframe, but the few horse races we see in this movie increase the action; It's okay with me! Look for excellent numbers of music and dance - remember, these plots were pretty much just excuses for the studio to shoot fabulous numbers of music and dance. It is rumored that after the audience first saw The Nicholas Brothers dance, they celebrated so much that the projectionist had to rewind the movie to show their scene again! Charlotte Greenwood also scored big with her almost unbelievable ability to kick loudly with her legs while she danced cheerfully in another number. Betty Grable also dances very well. In addition, this film marks the cinematographic debut of Carmen Miranda; She sings some songs during the film as well as a brief song at the beginning of the film. Carmen shines even when they were not playing her as much as in later movies! The DVD comes with a superlative extra on the life and times of Betty Grable. She really looked like an especially sweet girl who actually did not want much of life and liked the life of her private family as best she could. The quality of the photos on the extra at Betty Grable is excellent. There is also a running commentary, but optional, for people who want to know what happened behind the scenes while the movie was being filmed. Great ! Overall, Down Argentine Way is a musical that deserves to be seen. I usually book five stars for an MGM musical; but this time Fox really did it right! Fans of classic movie musicals can not miss this!"

b'It seems that no other Broadway musical has ever been transferred so intact to the screen, with every facet of its production shining and gloriously theatrical in its staging. River City, Iowa, of course, does not look more realistic than the Land of Oz, but that\'s the way it should be. It\'s satire, and fortunately the director Morton DaCosta keeps everything in great shape, preserved to play exactly like on stage, even in relation to the opening number aboard a train where all the vendors are singing about a certain rascal posing as a music teacher . Will Smith\'s song has never sounded so good and has received specialist singing and dance from ROBERT PRESTON, SHIRLEY JONES, PAUL FORD and HERMIONE GINGOLD in the lead roles, all helped and encouraged by some of the best musicians. singing and dancing you could ask for in a musical of this type. Gingold is outrageously funny and Paul Ford as her husband, the mayor of River City, is equally violent in a comic role. But it\'s Preston\'s show from start to finish with co-star Shirley Jones, in excellent vocal form, as the skeptical librarian. One of the most cleverly staged numbers is the number "Marian, The Librarian," which takes place in the city library, where sticks and sliding balconies become part of the intricately staged dance routine. All musical numbers are performed with professional charm by a talented group of actors / singers / dancers who are part of the citizenship of River City. Little Ron Howard, the boy with the lisp, who later passed the fame in the direction, is a highlight like Jones\' little brother. In short: Excellent old musical with the heart in the right place - American in the best tradition of the word. In short: It has more charm than the law allows.'

b'Frankly, I watched the movie because of the talent behind it. Unfortunately, I was disappointed with pretty much every aspect of this movie. There are times when the action oscillates between two sets of characters and situations (la Fifth Element), but there is little or no connection between the two situations, which makes me dizzy and confused rather than entertained or stimulated. There is an extreme development of the character, such as the countless times when we see Peggy (Laura Dern) going out to take a sip from her bottle or pouring herself a drink. The idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bher alcoholism hit my conscience to the point of annoying me, and then I discovered that the fact that she has a substance abuse problem has nothing to do with plot, character interaction or anything else. Why was Robert Altman so successful? Filler? The obsession with the Kennedy family by Connie (character of Tara Reid) is another case where a good amount of time is spent trying to show us this side of the character and is never followed by any tangible goal in the film. . Strangely, she is probably one of the most "normal" women in the picture. All of this would have led to a mediocre movie, but the ending really killed me. I have no idea what the ending should mean. In fact, this reinforces the idea that the whole plot was derived by the writers who completed several pages of Mad Libs and then edited them in a script. There is really no other explanation as to why so many aspects of the film seem to be so random (or random at best).'

b"I am a sucker for any movie or piece that is historical, and this definitely fits in the era when women had few rights. Sometimes we need to look back at the story to see how we have progressed from those times. Women have come a long way in their independence and the right to live their lives in their own way. I would suggest to parents to let their children know how lucky they are to be able to choose the man you would like to marry, not what was good for the family. Weddings were organized and most marriages were considered only Bible roommates. Men have always had their lover to turn to when their wife is unavailable (pregnant) and if they were expelled from their wives' bed and considered to be in the doghouse. The film really portrayed the little control women had about their future. Now, about the movie ... is the true story about this duchess and her life. I thank you for putting a real historical piece like the Duchess. I would recommend everyone to watch this movie and know how blessed we are today to make our own choices in life, whether they are good or bad."

b'I really like Lost Highway and have waited years for this DVD release of 2008. I avoided buying the previous version of "import" due to explicit consumer complaints regarding the quality of the transfer. My potential concerns about sound and image quality were dissipated as I visualized this new US release. It looks and sounds great, keeping in mind the source material. The visual style of the film is sparse, simple and high contrast - represented by the aesthetic "American wave" of Lynch. The image maintains its integrity and the deep black employees do not suffer from the noise often seen in older or bad transfers; the colors are also solid for a DVD. The sound design is appropriately moody, moody, dark, evocative, provocative and interweaves a rather eclectic mix of songs with the invaluable contributions of composer Angelo Badalamenti. There may be a slightly irritating difference in volume between the almost whispers of Patricia Arquette and, say, Rammstein - but that\'s not an uncommon problem on DVDs. Otherwise, it sounds pretty cool. I\'m not going to review the film, but I will say that the complete lack of special features is more forgivable for such an unusual, ambiguous and artistic film as Lost Highway than any other film I can imagine now. I often see this film the way I see abstract art: the explanation is not only unjustified, but also largely undesirable. In other words, special features can be intriguing, but I almost do not miss them for a movie like Lost Highway.'

b'The Golden Army - an army made to keep humanity under control because humanity has a problem in consuming everything around them. Elf-thinking and pixie-drawing, it has the power to do things that only the desperate - or crazy - would want. The Elvish type calculates this, divides his toy and lets the army rust. Unfortunately for humanity, rust is an arbitrary word and the Golden Army is something that has never ceased to be a threat. And when powerplay begins to emerge, the BPRD is the only one that has the skills to stop it. When I knew the original footage of the movie, I knew the director / Migola knew what I was doing, but it scared me. a little . b"First I have to say that. Whether you're expecting a story or a hero like Spider-Man, you're in for a shock. The cut of Daredevil directors is one of the best director cuts I've ever seen. Not only does the plot have more substance with the addition of deleted scenes, but it also ties the plot holes as well. There was also a subplot about blind attorney Matt Murdock (Ben Affleck) and Foggy Nelson (Jon Faverou) defending what appears to be a guilty client, played by rapper Coolio of the 1990s. In this cut, you see Matt Murdock more, and you can really see why Mark Steven Johnson chose Affleck to make the blind watcher. When I first saw the original version, I thought Affleck was fine. But after that, I can say that Affleck was the perfect choice for Daredevil / Matt Murdock. But I still have to say that Collin Farrell as Bullseye steals the show. He not only made him a tea, but also made Bullseye a more interesting character than he in the comic book series. The R-rated director's cut also has a darker, darker margin for the film compared to PG. 13 rating as the original version has it. Expect more graphic fighting scenes, and much more profanity for the characters. Overall, I must say that this cut definitely does justice to comic book fans. If you do not have it in your collection, grab it. This DVD also has a good mini documentary on how the directors' cut was made."

b'Whenever a film films for "realism," it usually opens the door to a predictable set of signifiers: portable cameras, real locations, a naturalistic lighting scheme, close dialogues, and tortured theatrics. In just two characteristics, Funny Ha Ha and the new Mutual Appreciation, screenwriter and director Andrew Bujalski reconfigured the language to something much closer to reality. His diy aesthetic and semi-improvisational dialogue earned him a frequent comparison with John Cassavetes, but he did not care so much about the sharp emotion; the characters in his films are clumsy and inexpressive, to the point of not saying what they feel, at least not without getting in the way of it first. Mutual appreciation is not much more than a refinement of Funny Ha Ha, following a similar group of people in their twenties, as they struggle with relationship problems and try to give their lives some strength. And yet, it is equally astonishing to watch, because Bujalski\'s style of stylized dialogue sounds genuinely imminent. The charismatic Justin Rice is a musician who moves to New York soon after his band finishes. It puts him in a strange place, since he must play at the end of the week. When she arrives in the city, Rice reconnects with her friend Bujalski, a good graduate student, and Bujalski\'s girlfriend, Rachel Clift, to whom Rice begins to develop an attraction (and, as it happens, mutual). Meanwhile, Rice meets a champion and more on attractive college radio DJ Seung-min Lee, but gets into trouble when he brings Lee\'s brother as his drummer and tries to distance himself from her romantically. All this intrigue creates a romantic mood. encounter between Rice and Clift, and a serious rupture in its relation with Bujalski, but nothing in Mutual Valor goes according to the usual script. The scene in which Rice and Clift finally vocalize their feelings for each other is the perfect example of what Bujalski does so well: any other romantic melodrama would bubble with passion, but these characters are painfully hesitant and compelling since they are cheating someone with whom they care. What ends up happening between them is completely unexpected, but entirely true to who they are and how the most caring people would act. But such things rarely happen on the screen, and Bujalski\'s willingness to follow him makes him a singular talent.'

b'God this movie really has had my stomach on us for all its duration. As the atmospheric movies go this is certainly a masterpiece. It really is a chiller and it depends on mood and a mysterious atmosphere and not on sudden surprises and violence. The film is set in an old house in Jersey just after WWII. Nicole Kidman plays the owner of the house, living there with her two children all the while waiting for her husband to return home after the war. film three servants arrive to give assistance. These remain to be the only characters that are actually invited in the film. Nicole Kidman is excellent at role as are the two small children. Children suffer from a rare condition in that they ca not be exposed to any strong light. This brings the dark scenes where the film is almost totally set in grim candlelight. To prevent children from being exposed to any lights all doors in each room must be locked and unlocked at the entrance. movie is spent with panic opening and loss of these rooms as there is some strange presence in the house.In many ways, some of these scenes are quite reminiscent of scenes in The Sixth Sense. As the story unfolds the backgrounds for these servo char actors begin to unfold as well. This gives the film an incredibly intriguing feeling that has resulted in me feeling constantly at the limit throughout its duration. You never seem to be sure where all this story is taking - so the sense of mystery is enough. When they leave the house, the outside is covered with this almost surreal haze - again building the atmosphere beautifully. It reminded me of those Basil Rathbone Sherlock Holmes movies that used to scare me as a child. the sun would rise only to raise the atmosphere temporarily to give the viewer a little rest from all this tension. The rhythm really accumulates when the film comes to a very, very dramatic conclusion. Beautifully shot, really gothic, brilliantly represented and worth seeing.'

b'Up there with "Planes, Trains & Automobiles" and "There\'s Something About Mary", there\'s my favorite comedy from Billy Murray. `` Goundhog Day \'\'. Murray (as TV Weatherman Phil Connors) is easily the solitary Hollywood star of the film, as the rest of the cast is much less known in the field. Andie MacDowell was probably best known for her modeling career in 1993, than as an actress ... she does a simply wonderful job as "Rita," the TV producer. Chris Elliot does a great job in a less boring role than that of "Larry" the videographer (he\'s come a long way since it was David Letterman\'s "The Man Under the Stairs"). The other actor who really impressed is the man with the recognizable face, but what is his name (Stephen Tobolowsky as life insurance salesman Ned `` Bing! \'\' Ryerson). Oh, and Scooter, the groundhog. As for the story, Bill Murray is trapped on the same cold day (which happens to be Groundhog Day) in Punxsutawney, PA, covering the now famous festivities. He continues to relive the same day, over and over again. Every day he sees the same things. Every day he meets the same people ... the man in the hall in the early morning, Doris the waitress, the mayor of the city, etc. He decides to get the best out of the situation and do whatever he wants ... just because he knows he\'s going to wake up the next day and will be all over again the same day. While getting tired of reliving the same day, Connors shifts his focus to Rita. First, trying to impress her. So, really trying to take care of her. When he finally passes by it, the spell is broken and the next day it appears. I classify some of Bill Murray\'s films as classics ... that is, `` Caddyshack \'\', `` Stripes \'\', `` Scrooged \'\', `` What About Bob \'\', etc ... but I put ` `Groundhog Day \'\' at the top of the list. Easy choice for my # 1 favorite movie Bill Murray. It\'s also an easy choice for one of my best 4 to 5 comedies of all time. *****'

b'This is a fantastic movie, but please read other comments on acting, camera work, plot, plot, etc. This review is just about the DVD version. The DVD itself is a big disappointment. I am surprised that it is not double sided as the original commercial DVDs were. b'One of the most charming films of recent years, "Calendar Girls," a version of "The Full Monty," is the true story of a group of middle-aged English women who became international celebrities when they projected posed for a fundraising calendar of nude backgrounds that sold millions of copies around the world. Julie Walters and Helen Mirren lead a wonderful cast, with Walters as a woman whose husband dies of leukemia and Mirren as her best friend who comes up with the idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bthe calendar as a way to honor her memory and raise money for the local hospital. . The risk of any "feeling good" comedy is that it will become cloying, timid or funny. Fortunately, the `` Calendar Girls \'\' features an incredibly witty script and top-notch performances by her highly talented cast. Each of the "girls" is given their own unique personality, so that we see them not only as a group, united in this inspiring endeavor, but as individuals working through their own personal demons on the journey until the completion of the project. Women face the expected barriers and confusions in the form of "shocked", disapproving voices in the community, but their belief in the righteousness of their cause dispels all these problems. This charming movie offers more genuine and extravagant laughter than almost any comedy of recent times. The `` Calendar Girls \'\' is exciting, touching, and inspiring - and what more can you ask for a "feel-good" movie than that?'

b"Watching `` The scent of green papaya? it's like listening to harmonious music. There is not much dialogue in this movie, but you will not feel boring. I like the quiet, elegant and graceful mood of the movie. He uses many simple melodies and close-up on the film to reflect the mood of the characters. The visual and auditory beauty brings comfort while watching it. The first part of the film takes place in 1951, when the French authority almost came to an end. French occupied Vietnam more than 30 years before 1954. During the French administration, people in Vietnam were influenced by the French. In the first half of the movie, Mui lived in a traditional family as a child servant. The grandmother lost her husband when she was still a teenager and insisted on praying for her husband every morning and remaining faithful to him. The father left home with another woman and took all the money a few times, but the mother would never blame him. Instead, the grandmother blamed her for not knowing how to please her own husband. In the second half of the movie, Mui moved to the house of a musician also as a servant. The musician, who is also his master, called Khuyen, was influenced by the French and knows how to play the piano. His house was decorated in French style, colorful and bright. Unlike the previous family, simple, antique and everything in wood. Khuyen was hired but later discovered that Mui was actually very attractive after she got dressed. He fell in love with her and then he broke up with her fianc\xc3\xa9? and married Mui. This film shows the difference between a traditional Vietnamese family and a modern Western family. Not only the environment of life has great difference, but also the perception of relationships."

The cast could not have been better; Melissa Leo gives an excellent performance as a guilty housewife punishing herself for a car accident has long since taken the life of her daughter; and James Gandolfini turns into a masterful performance as her husband Doug, who seems to have been unable to overcome her pain and her personal demons. Choreography and cinematography enhance the film, and the soundtrack does a great job of making the film even better. Lois Riley (Melissa Leo) and her husband Doug (James Gandolfini) are even more unhappy, though eight years have passed. years since the death of her daughter in a car accident. Lois has not left the house since the car accident; In fact, Lois was so depressed that she already has tombstones for her and Doug by the side of the grave of her deceased daughter, a fact that gives Doug shiver. Doug also has a longstanding affair with a waitress named Vivian (Eisa Davis). However, when Vivian dies suddenly of a heart attack, Doug is very upset and sad yet; and he suffers in silence because he does not know that Lois already knew about him and Vivian for a long time. Dugo goes to a business convention in New Orleans; and still upset over the death of Vivian (he wanted to take her to her birthday) and also feeling out of place in a very different city from where he lives with his wife, Doug leaves the convention one day and enters a band of striptease where he meets a minor program girl who goes through several different names, including Mallory (Kristen Stewart of Twilight fame). Doug and Mallory start an unconventional relationship; she reminds Doug of her daughter. So, what does Doug do? He calls Lois to say he's in New Orleans indefinitely without giving Lois any reason; he moves in with Mallory paying $ 100 a day to stay with her in his dilapidated apartment in a house that was abandoned after Hurricane Katrina and Doug desperately tries to make Mallory grow up with a combination of love and confrontation that Mallory needs. Meanwhile, Lois finally decides to leave her home after nearly eight years of home - she's determined to drive to New Orleans and find Doug there, calling her cell phone. Of course, the rest of what happens gives us a very solid story and good entertainment. I could tell you more; but there will be no spoilers here, although it may seem like I've told you a lot! Suffice it to say that the rest of the plot should hold your attention very well. In addition, look for very good performances by Tiffany Coty as Tara and Lance E. Nichols in a very brief presentation as Hamilton 'Ham' Watkins, another businessman at the convention. The DVD also comes with an extra about the making of the film. I recommend this movie to anyone interested in family drama or drama in general; and it is clear that fans of the actors in this film would do well to add this to their collections."

b"One Body Too Many A 1944 black and white movie is not a particularly good movie. BUT, it's a fun movie. It's a silly horror / comedy movie that has become the meat and potato of many early studios. I love it . Jack Haley is Albert Tuttle a nose for the insurance man who has a commitment to an old rich recluse. He arrives in his mansion and is seen by the butler (Bela Lugosi). He is taken to his clients' offices and immediately begins his speech on the back of a chair and smoke coming out of a lit cigarette. However, without Tuttle's knowledge, the client is dead and in his coffin in the office. Tuttle puts her briefcase in the closed casket before she notices what's in the room. When he tries to leave, he does not open the door, etc. This film is filled with every conceivable conceivable clich\xc3\xa9. But that's the fun of it. A huge, dark, scary house, a testament to be read, a suspicious butler and cook, a pretty damsel in distress, a grumpy detective, a house full of greedy family members of the deceased, murders, door tricks, screams and noises at night, etc. Of course, a very nervous and reluctant hero. This kind of movie would be nothing without Lyle Talbot and he's here as the family member who thinks the timid Jack Haley has something to hide. I've had this movie for years and every once in a while I screwed up to watch it again because sometimes you need some harmless fun. (~. ~)"

b"This was possibly one of the worst movies I've ever seen, and that's saying quite a lot. b"This stunning flim is situated in Miramont Place, Pimlico (a district in South London). When an unblemished bomb left over from World War II goes out, local shopkeeper Stanley Holloway discovers an ancient treasure, including a mysterious document. An eccentric university professor (Margaret Rutherford) translates the document, and proves that Miramont Place was the site of a palace given to the exiled duke of Burgundy by King Edward IV, making the inhabitants of Miramont Place native to Burgundy rather than British. Locals go crazy, ripping their ration booklets and keeping the local pub open all night, they amuse themselves until the government becomes unpleasant and start attacking them. Enter a dishy Frenchman who turns out to be the current Duke, come claim his inheritance and save his subjects from the iron hand of the beurocracy. Under siege, challenging Burgundians stop the subway trains and make the passengers pass through customs, the government reverses turning off the water supply, who will win in the battle of judgment? If you're a fan of eccentric British comedies, this movie is a classic of its kind."

b"I usually hate anime. I'm the kind of person who complains every time I see a book turned into a movie, just because I do not think adaptations do justice to the original work. I'm a big fan of the manga, so I thought I'd give the anime a try. I was extremely shocked when I started watching. This show is as good as the manga. It follows the story line, with the addition / subtraction of some points of the plot and a different plot of Ouran Fair. Each of the voice actors (in English and Japanese) does justice to each character. The characters themselves are hilarious and diverse. The plot is fun. Do not let the pink cover fool you; this show is not at all feminine / shojo-y. The fact that I actually bought the series actually says something, especially since I watched the entire series twice through a friend before buying it on Amazon (and I'm super frugal). Since I bought it, I watched all the episodes at least two more times, my most favorite. This is a really must have. If I could, I would give this series a higher rating."

b"I am an avid fan of horror movies. My liking in horror movies may not be the best, I'll admit I'm a bit picky, but they still have to be worth watching. This movie has no redeeming qualities. b"After all the hype about this movie I expected something completely different. The documentary was more about the White family and almost did not focus on Jesco. I definitely recommend it completely, however it plays as part of the 'Intervention' episode, part COPS and part Gummo. At times it seemed a little fake, however, the fact that it was a real kind of shock for a second. If that makes sense. It's basically like a car accident. b'CHARLOTTE is sometimes a nocturnal film, a story that passes slowly through the lives of four people and with very few words says much about human relations, about the cocoons we create for security, for protection against fear, for hope the chrysalis metamorphoses into a butterfly or butterfly. Eric Byler should be commended for having the courage to keep this story simple - a tale of four personality "disorders" and how they find the means to exist in this strange world. Michael Idemoto is perhaps the most solitary outwardly, but all four characters seem to beg for connection and simply can not attach. Eugenia Yuan is the idiosyncratic girl, Jacquelyn Kim is the mysterious woman who, with Matt Westmore, is more of a catalytic agent than a character. All four actors are beautiful, sensitive and convincing. The lighting and settings are well chosen. All in all, this little indie movie is quiet fun, dealing more with what\'s not said than with just one screenplay.'

b"With such a talented cast and a semi-decent story, you think it would have been a great movie. Richard Gere plays a gynecologist in a large Texas town. b"After reading MOUSEENEER user review, I'm glad I did not wait for the uncut version, even though I posted it on Laserdisc, I did not feel it added much more space to the movie, the only thing that's different is the scene. murder in the beginning is a little more graphic, the sex scene of Michael Douglas and Sharon Stone is a little more revealing, (he does oral sex in her that is very lively), besides that this movie is the same as the R version, this is a hell of a psychological roller coaster, but it's a good movie, it can be seen as a sex movie, but it's a police thriller that keeps you guessing until the end, and it's still not sure who the killer is, been told in the media that Douglas & Stone hated themselves in this movie (that they could not get along) although you do not know how to say, it would not be hard to believe, given the ego of both Douglas & Stone, despite that, it's a very good cop thriller that should not be ie Sharon Stone looks the best I can not honestly say now, since she has cut off her long blond hair (it's not wise) but here she shines like Catherine Trammel, a role that Julia Roberts rejected, Stone is perfect here and this will always be her best role."

b'I believe that, in a few decades, film school students will study the history of American animation, the Iron Giant will be seen as the last great example of animation films traditionally hand-drawn before moving to computer animation. The thing about this movie is that when it was originally released in theaters, its promotion was so underfunded and simply bad, it was not very successful. Fortunately, it has dedicated followers on VHS and DVD. This film is an example of what animated films routinely perform in Japan, but rarely do here in the US. It\'s well written, visually stunning, and works for all ages, not just for kids. It has been warned that it may not be suitable for very young children. The climactic battle sequence features a potentially frightening transformation of the Iron Giant. Do not get me wrong, this movie is suitable for everyone, but younger viewers and younger children can probably handle it very well. But some children are more sensitive and nightmarish than others, so if you have children under the age of 6, I suggest you preview the movie before you let them see it. Some movies are better rented, others are better bought. This is the last category: it\'s a guardian! If you are an adult who has written animated films like "kid stuff" because they tend to be banal and stereotypical, you owe it to yourself to see this movie. Many reviewers are so easily satisfied that they appear unable to give less than 5 stars, which is a shame because this is a movie that deserves to stand out from the crowd, and absolutely earned it\'s 5 star rating.'

b"I've been watching this animation program for the past 10 years, I'm 20 now. I can honestly say that I still can not find one thing wrong with Gargoyles. b'After I saw this series on the shelves of my local library and saw that it was about an aspiring chef in 1900-1910 London, I picked up all the volumes. This series really surprised me: she has strong writing and attention to the scenery. . Louisa Trotter is a frank and outspoken chef who works in her profession and British society with lots of grease, understanding of human nature and a bit of luck. Gemma Jones is great as Louisa Trotter and the supporting cast is very solid as well. I was not sure if this series was a miniseries or a TV series, but it is somewhat Dickensian in that each episode is based on the previous one. And I can afford a series without a greater complement than saying that conflict resolutions are not trivial or superficial. Many allusions to historically accurate events, politicians, and contemporary culture are embedded in the tangles. I feel that I learned more about English classism and the social customs of the Duchess and the Bentinck Hotel than from my semester in London. If you like period drama (and comedy) and strong and nuanced heroines with lots of battles to fight then you will like "The Duchess of Duke Street." \'\' This series is the test of time. My only complaint is that I did not learn much about the culinary arts, but the writing is so up to standard that my complaint is presented as inconsequential. Although this series began filming in 1976, production figures make placement difficult. The Duchess of Duke Street is comparable in quality to the 1979 Pride and Prejudice of the BBC.'

b'I tore the wrap of this little jewel this morning with the joy of a six-year-old delinquent who was given a one-day pass to a Cadburys candy factory. So I sat down to watch and left two hours later with the smile of a 51-year-old Cheshire cat on Viagra. One such feature is the reissue trailer for the 30th anniversary of 10 years ago, which uses the famous sequence of "... doors off ...". Untouched - it is covered in scratches and has no definition whatsoever - it lets you see how the material in the film looked, as opposed to how beautiful it looks now after the restoration. There are so many scenes that now stand out - like Matt Monro \'. The playful song "On Days Like These" hits and the car passes through the Alps on opening credits - when Charlie gets out of jail as he walks through the gates and Maggie Blye greets him in a car stolen from the Pakistani embassy - when the three Mini Coopers rise to the roof of the football stadium with the Italian police in pursuit - it\'s simply all beautiful.
