Music Video (in HD) 6. The deleted scene with comment by author Matthew Field7. Theatrical Trailer8. Caine was perfect as Charlie Croker, the likely boy, Benny Hill as the coffin computer, the soft, deadly Raf Vallone as the head of the Turin Mafia and Tony Beckley as the elegantly dressed Camp Freddy. But the biggest blow of all was Noel Coward as Bridger - the master criminal serving his Majesty\'s penitentiary service. He has tea and cookies, cares about the British economy and has his cell full of photos of the queen. Coward is simply priceless as he commands the prison deck, "Rule Britannia," played behind him by a string quartet - enough to make you howl with laughter ... You see you forget how funny the Italian is. Job is - the Catholic gay tailor saying that Charlie\'s pre-prison clothes could now be part of a museum exhibition, Coward next to two prison guards as they handed in their two newspapers and a toilet paper. The perplexing look of prison governor John Le Mesurier when Coward complains that "his bathroom was invaded by Michael Caine (flinging the assault on him) - a man\'s bathroom is his castle ... The arrogant garage manager played beautifully John Clive counting the money that Michael Caine just gave him for taking care of his Aston Martin DB - he\'s been in his garage for two years while Caine was out in India.\'\'I was throwing old boy tigers ... \'\' Garage owner counting the fifties, `` there must have been a huge amount of tigers lord ... \'\' The sites of Turin are wonderfully colorful, the mountain scenes as crisp as those in the James Bond reissue and Caine\'s freckles clearer I\'ve reviewed a bunch of oldies on the new format BLU RAY of late - some successful, some pitiful - but that\'s up there with the best.In fact, as a man who loves me dium and believes in his possibilities, I suspect he will please Michael Caine Pink that his films "Zulu" and "The Italian Job" are going a long way towards establishing the BLU. RAY as the format for restoring old movies and preserving them properly. Forward to the boys of David Lean ... As you can tell - and if you will forgive the pun - I was delighted. I loved it, loved it, loved it. Recommended - great time.'

b'Although this is an excellent adaptation of the first 24 chapters of J.K. Rowling\'s book, the first Harry Potter home video releases continue to disappoint with their surprisingly low bonus materials and lack of documentaries. It is obvious that this film, including its current special features, will eventually be released as: 1. An "Ultimate Edition" with new special features, 2. In a `` Complete Movie Collection \'\' with all other movies, and 3. Possibly as an Extended Edition combined with Part 2. So why in the world would I be foolish enough to pay $ 15-25 for it now? If you are an unconditional fan who just can not wait to have this, I suppose I understand but you should just rent it and save your money for later. Otherwise, this is a blatant attempt by Warner Bros. to do away with people with no money. And that\'s not cool with me.'

b'Having seen this movie several times, I definitely have to classify Gigi as one of the most charming musicals ever made. Lerner & Loewe\'s delightful soundtrack includes songs such as "I Remember It Well," "The Night They Invented Champagne," "Thank Heaven For Little Girls," as well as the title track. "Gigi", sung with surprising sincerity and seriousness by Louis Jourdan. The three directors, Leslie Caron, Louis Jourdan and Maurice Chevalier, along with the sites of Paris, help maintain a typically French flavor, especially in the way the characters interact and interact. For all who commented on the political incorrectness of the story, a closer look will reveal the true feminist perspective of Colette\'s work, which was groundbreaking for the time: 1) History is a commentary on the limited social and economic options for history. women out of wedlock (or prostitution) at the turn of the century, 2) Although Gigi (Caron) never fully mastered her lessons and care, she is able to capture the heart of Gaston (Jourdan) precisely because of her imperfections. and 3) more important, it is Gaston instead of Gigi, who is forced to actually transform and challenge the social conventions of the time to bring history to its resolution. Compare this to My Fair Lady, which offers similar social commentary, but solves it in a more standardized way; although Professor Higgins finally notices his love for Eliza in the end, it is Eliza who is forced to submit her will by effecting a reconciliation that does nothing to solve any of the issues raised in the scenes that led to that point. Definitely watch Gigi and judge for yourself. (Be sure to watch only the widescreen version!) The full-screen version is awful, with whole characters cut out of some scenes, like Hermione Gingold\'s for most of the "I Remember It Well" sequel.)'

b"Limey is probably the best work of Soderbergh, he defeats Traffic and Erin Brockovich easily, only Out of Sight and Sex, Lies and Videotape are coming. Limey is one of the only films I've seen where the stylistic odds of the film make the film not just a self-indulgent piece of art to be debated in film class but a moving film that resonates with you. Terence Stamp plays the protagonist Wilson as a tough and sad English criminal who is trying to find out what happened to his daughter. Their search has generic fundamentals, but this movie rises above any gender label. A lot of credit has to go to the Lem Dobbs script, which avoids clich\xc3\xa9 and injects some worthy comedy into the mix. But the editing style of this movie is because I love it, it works on waves as memorys, it's the only movie I've seen that shows precisely how your mind can change from one thing to another. Right now, I'm looking like some jaw-buckled art student jumped on his own importance. But watch the movie and you'll see what I mean. The best part of this movie is that it's sad, the ending is not a big turnaround or some copout, it's just deeply sad, and there are not many movies that evoke that feeling in me today. I finished ."

b"Jerry Lewis is Jerome Littlefield, a nurse from a mental institution who acts more than patients. Since Frank Tashlin directed this film, Jerry is free to focus exclusively on his performance, which he does perfectly. Again Jerry is the lovable loser who was kicked out of medical school because he felt the symptoms of all the patients he diagnosed. This movie features a lot of great visual gags. Jerry fixes a television set in a patient's room that has little reception, also known as snow. When he pulls out the front of the TV, the snow flies off the set and soon fills the room! A patient is full-length, from head to toe, looking like a plastered mummy. Jerry accidentally knocks him down, the patient descends a hill and falls into a tree. There are pieces of broken plaster everywhere, but no body! Jerry states, & quot; I lost a patient! & quot; The film ends with one of the craziest chase scenes in movie history, when a wheeled stretcher with a wounded man emerges from the back of an ambulance and continues downhill, while the first, then two ambulances chase after him. This movie features more LPMs (laughs per minute) than most modern comedies, and is one of Jerry's funniest movies."

b"Where is your house? The place that matters most to you. Where you want to say something to other people. Where, somewhere, means something to you. Mac, who works for the chief of the oil company (Burt Lancaster) - more interested in astronomy than the next big oil field - from Houston, where he makes millions of dollars worth of phone deals before brunch, finds himself sent to a village remote Scottish coast to negotiate a major refinery project. At first, the extremely slow pace of life of local people frustrates him - why does he not close the deal and return home? But then the magic of the place begins to infiltrate itself. The things he thought were important are not that important. And the genuinely important things in life begin to unfold. And Mac finds his true home. Fun, cheerful (everyone gets what they want, no one loses), but deeply touching, this movie is a rare thing - it makes you feel good in every way, indefinitely. Somewhere, there's a phone ringing, someone calling home. Where are you going to call tonight?"

It has the signature De Palma - eroticism, clever cinematography and a movie that moves only by pure style - but in the end you will feel empty and unfortunately coming in the short end by the time you invested The movie begins with a spectacular unlikely stealing of jewelry at the 2001 Cannes Film Festival, in which Rebecca and the team plan to relieve an almost naked actress of her few body linings - a brace of priceless gold and diamond accoutrements. Although visually and musically interesting, the opening scene calls for many oversights of the viewer - how to ignore the fact that much of the plane's cape despite its high-tech setup Mission Impossible depends on guards looking the wrong way and being Rebecca irresistible. Things go wrong and in the end, Rebecca crosses the team, takes the merchandise and looks for another life. She finds one in a couple in search of their runaway daughter, that Rebecca is a woman so dead that the woman's own parents can not tell the difference. It assumes its identity, claims its tickets to America and, through destiny, falls into the romantic embrace of the American ambassador who is on the plane. Life is great until paparazzi photographer Antonio Banderas takes his elusive photo, announcing his presence to the abused bandits. From there, Rebecca looks for the left exit route, which gives her more money at any cost. The story is like a checklist of eroticism - there is voyeurism, a striptease, sad at the Cannes Film Festival. Brian De Palma does it all in style - split screen, sweeping camera angles - and it's fun to watch it in action - but still not enough to plug the holes in the story. The ending tries to pull all the dark themes of the film into a happy silver liner, but will leave you betrayed. Despite the power of the star, I did not like Femme Fatale. It's true that Rebecca was not blue - fans of her role as X-Men would not be disappointed. The character of Antonio Banderas had one or two interesting scenes, but most of the time he did what he was manipulated, with no original solutions out of his situation. Seeing him coming to a clever escape would have been a much better end - but, as it is, instead, the end drew on an exaggerated trick to get out of his somber end. Pass on Femme Fatale - even if you're looking for see Rebecca in a non-X-Men light. Despite all the brightness, it is not worth the investment."

b'Synopsis: John Ritter stars as Roy Knable, a true television addict whose life and marriage are crumbling around his ears while watching TV to get away from it all. The same night that his wife Helen (Pam Dawber) plans to leave him, a mysterious salesman named Spike (Jeffrey Jones) appears to sell Roy a new television set, complete with a gigantic satellite dish that radiates 666 channels direct to Roy \' s living room. However, something goes wrong when Roy and his wife are sucked into the satellite dish and enter the hellish world of TV Satan. From there, it\'s a frantic race to survive before time runs out. About the film: Stay Tuned is probably one of my favorite comic movies. I first saw it in the early 90\'s and when I saw it came out on DVD I jumped at the chance to get it. Stay tuned is filled with slapstick humor, a large number of very twisted comics plays on classic television clich\xc3\xa9; s and TV programs. Among them are Saturday Night Live, Star Trek The Next Generation, Three\'s Company, WWF and classic cartoons. The cartoon is presented in a wonderfully delightful animated sequence that was overseen in production by legendary animator Chuck Jones (who made many of the Bugs and Bugs designs). This is really the best of the movies that John Ritter starred in. Ritter\'s comic timing helps make this movie. Although this film has never been noticed, it is certainly a prime example of why John Ritter\'s comedic career has lasted more than two decades. He was very good as what he did. Comedian comedian Eugene Levy ("SCTV" and "American Pie") also plays a major role in this film as Crowley, a down and out Hell TV Exec that helps the Knables on their journey. He manages to play the adorable charlatan quite amusing. Jeffrey Jones plays the villain, the CEO of Hell TV, Spike. He is a great actor for the villain in a comedy, and he manages to be convincingly wicked and funny at the same time without making the role look stupid, as tends to happen to bad guys in rude comedies these days. With John Ritter With comic timing and Pam Dawber playing the straight man as they fall from the demented channel to the demented channel, this movie is great for many laughs. About the DVD: Stay Tuned comes in a cardboard DVD case, marking it as a budget rate. It is presented in widescreen format with Dolby Digital 5.1 sound. Both the picture and the sound are very good. I did not notice any problems with anyone. The DVD comes translated into French (why not Spanish?) And has subtitles in English, French and Spanish. For special features, the DVD comes with an extended theatrical trailer, cast information and a feature look behind the scenes of the movie. The cast information is simply a list of actors in the film. They do not even provide bios for them, making it a clear case of reinforcing the content with the least effort. The featurette is the kind they used to show on television shortly before the movie\'s release, with cast interviews that are completely ignorant if you watched the movie. It\'s only slightly interesting. The downside is that the music that plays behind the commentator is completely annoying during the first quarter. This DVD release is a very simple and no frills release. Overall, a great movie on a bland DVD release. 4 stars'

b"I'm not as articulate as some of the others reviewing here. All I can say is that we need this kind of entertainment so desperately. b'If I did not say that before saying that again, I\'m a big fan of George A. Romero\'s Night of the Living Dead and its sequels he\'s done for the last forty years. Thanks to him, we really know the horrible world of zombies and the undead in great detail and we know what a scary place might get stuck inside, whether it\'s an old farmhouse, a suburban shopping mall, an underground bunker or anywhere leave it open. an attack of the carnideutas of the living. Of course, once you create a character so popular in Horror, you end up committing an impending copy of your original creation. Oddly enough though, most of these types of films had a varying degrees of success, especially the Italian Zombie filmmakers of the 1980s. Unfortunately, what started it all, the 1968 NOTLD due to copyright error never had this precious right and it soon became clear to everyone that anyone could release it, own it and / or make any version with that plot and title anyway they choose. But first, a bit of history: in 1998 Anchor Bay and John A. Russo (one of the men to help create the original 68 with Romero) decided to release a 30th anniversary version of the classic But instead of just re-releasing the same old impression as all other DVD companies, filmed and added new images to the old, creating a new subframe that not only harms the original movie, but betrays the social commentary that was established in the first place. A real misstep and the fans were not satisfied. However, when it comes to complete remakes, at least someone got it right before that. In 1990, with Romero\'s personal guidance and FX genius Tom Savini at the helm, they made a Night Of The Living Dead that stayed close to the original screenplay, giving the 90\'s audience an update that not only they could be proud of, but better in some aspects of blood values \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8band production. So, after a well-done remake and a learning error on what not to do for a classic, could it be done again? Apparently no . In 2006, with director Jeff "Corman Wanna-Be" Broadstreet in the chair, they decided to try again, of course without the necessary consent of Romero, but this time with a turnaround: Let\'s try to do in 3D! 3D? Same ? Sounds like a curious idea, but it really falls apart. To be honest, NOTLD3D is a farce. Shot on a nonexistent budget, this is the worst "retelling" of a movie since the 2001 Planet of the Apes. Of course, most of your favorite characters are here, but this time mixed up and played by actors who are so tough, it\'s hard to tell them of the real zombies. And the story is so slow and boring that it looks like a 3 AM view of something you\'d expect to see on the Sci-Fi Channel. Also, while the gore factor in the original 68 was minimal at best, 36 years later you still do not see much, if anything, but not for MPAA reasons but financially, and in fact half of me I asked why this was rated "R" in the first place? The new twists were lame, the flat sets and the special participation of the Horror icon, Sid Haig (which in my opinion is not a big deal in the first place) is completely unnecessary, which only helps in establishing that this was the best cash- ins of the cinema. So the main appeal has to be 3D, right? Wrong Instead of using the latest 3D technology of stereoscopic (which is with "grayscale"), they were outdated Anaglyphic type (red / blue), which in turn turns the whole movie into a purple mess . And do not expect anything to "jump" for you. When it works, and it\'s rare, it just gives depth to the backgrounds, which means that your image looks deeper, not closer. It should also be noted, out of the features of the backstage, this entire disc is in 3D, which means that without the glasses, it is unattainable. There is no 2D version on the disc included as it should have been (this version is released separately), so once the glasses go, it is the definitive roller coaster. So to summarize, bad movie, bad 3D, bad idea. It was redone in 1990, and eight years later a trick was given that did not work, either. Even as a film alone, a film like Day Of The Dead 2: Contagium is a better movie. Hard to suggest, even if you\'re a complete one like me, NOTLD3D is a dead movie that should have been buried. (RedSabbath Rating: 3.0 / 10)'

b'Let me start by saying that I\'m not a beginner. So I can say with certainty that this is NOT FOR INITIATORS. Yes, I am screaming :) However, if you are a beginner, you can still use it if you pay close attention to what I am about to say. Women in particular do not use weight or weights of 2 to 3 pounds to the whole workout the first time you complete it. NO MORE THAN 3 POUNDS HIS FIRST TIME PLEASE! ! ! IF YOU WORKED BEFORE, NOT MORE THAN 5 POUNDS! ! ! Watch out for the swimming and butterfly movements. I think it\'s best to use NO weight for these 2 moves at the beginning. I recommend the above because most of the moves are done in speed, so if you\'ve worked before or not, some moves are too fast to keep a good shape particularly for a beginner. Also, too much pressure on the shoulders can overload the neck. After the first time you make this DVD, you can find out what weights you need and if you want to turn it off for some exercises that are a good idea. The coach is a bit annoying because he keeps calling him his first "beginner". \' work out . It is very annoying because it is not technically a beginner workout. Other than that, it can be a good workout for someone who has worked before and will slow down some of the movements and practice good forms. It\'s hard to know how to do this if you\'ve never worked before. Of course "beginner" does not necessarily mean it\'s your first training, but it may be for some. And remember, the BOB instructor insists it\'s your first beginner workout, so apparently he thinks a first timer can do that. With this, he should have advised the use of very light weights and had a modifier. I gave this DVD 2 stars because it is 2012 and there must have been several options on the menu to show modifications and a bit more explanation. In summary, a beginner can do it, but do not use more than 3 pounds your first time. And do not be discouraged if you can not do everything. Most beginners will not be able to do the whole thing the first time. Perhaps the BOB coach should change the name to the begoners because it will be intimidating to most beginners and many will probably get hurt if they do not know how to move and use the proper technique.'

b"Of all the American films of Fritz Lang, SCARLET STREET is my favorite. And now, finally, it's available in a version that I can actually see. This is undoubtedly the best quality edition available. (All other distributors offer variations of the same impression of the grainy, diffuse, dubious-looking public domain that has been circulating for years.) SCARLET STREET is a remake of Jean Renoir's LA CHIENNE (The BITCH), and it would have been great if Kino could have released both titles as a Double Feature. However, I am thrilled to finally have a copy of excellent quality; the disc also features a great audio commentary by historian David Kalat."

The character of Kate Hudson always has the right side, which is good for a while, but after an hour gets tiring. It completely invades every aspect of Ben\'s life; we never see Andie\'s world apart from her two friends and workplace. So while both characters have a similar agenda, there\'s a complete imbalance of weariness, and that to me is the biggest gap in the movie. He fights all her attempts at "losing" him, but all this only produces frustration in Andie - and feeds her to do crazier things. As a spectator, you\'re dying to see her fall on your face just once. But this is an illusion. Ben\'s resistance to Andie\'s antics hardly amuses me, and Andie\'s total disgrace does not please me. Of course both are great, and Hudson smiles positively when she smiles, but man, 112 minutes is a long time to support this game. I can imagine some people thinking that this movie is great. Girl Power and everything. I do not know . But I think we can agree that the film was conceived as a vehicle for Kate Hudson\'s rise to stardom. This film reminds me a little of WHAT WOMEN WANT (with Mel Gibson) for a variety of reasons, but notably because it was written and produced by women - which in the world of male-dominated filmmaking is a much-needed perspective - but Nancy Myers (a producer / director of What Women Want) is definitely much smarter than the "brains" behind How To Lose A Guy in 10 Days. You just have to watch the extras on the DVD to see proof of this. We met two of the producers, who obviously had facelifts. I\'m serious . It is scary . They talk about the material as if it were Shakespeare. Then there\'s director Donald Petrie, who is totally lacking in charisma. MAKING OF with it is so cheap that it\'s probably funnier to watch than most of the movie. While he is there talking, a TV monitor behind him shoots pictures of the movie, and an office worker (with his back to the camera) stares at a static PC screen while biting his nails and shakes his head a lot. She does this throughout the duration of the interviews with Petrie. Oh, and did I mention the background music that accompanies the extras? It\'s department store. Or elevator music. That you always hate more. I did not bother with the comment. Donald is a pain in the ass. There are no outtakes, which is now unusual for a comedy. The deleted scenes are really good, some honest emotions are shown by Andie and we have some quieter moments between the two tracks. Look, it started well. It looked like it would be harmless cute romantic comedy, but the romance lasted about 10 minutes. I can summarize my criticism with this remark from director Petrie because he was interested in directing the film. He says it was because he discovered Kate Hudson was attached to him. Aha So basically, if the film does well at the box office, then it will launch Hudson\'s career and career. Sorry Petrie, but that\'s not good enough for me.'

She discovers that she is pregnant and, therefore, the stakes increase. Ultimately, a desperate CIA man struggles to spread the beans to her. Is he going to do this? She goes? There\'s suspense in this thriller / science fiction film; unfortunately, is not intentional. It\'s about figuring out when the movie will be full of suspense. We know everything from the beginning. b"It would be difficult to formulate a coherent film composed of disparate elements that the director and others obviously felt compelled to include in this scenario, but a worthy attempt is made, only collapsing after the first half. A pre-Columbian ceremonial disk, gold and studded with jewels, was split in half and while one half is displayed in the permanent collection of a New York City museum, the other segment became the subject of a search expedition to a region andean. the aegis of American archaeologist Brooks Willings (David Keith), who is obsessed with bringing his recovery. His wife and daughter stayed in New York, but when young Diana (Camilla Belle) became a disciplinary problem at his school, the two join Brooks in the Andean village where his expedition is based, his wife hopes to correct the behavioral suffering of Diana. , only to be overwhelmed by additional problems arising from your new situation. Continuity falters at that moment, as Diana engages in the mystic rites of the village, Brooks and his wife (skillfully played by Nancy Allen) fall into serious marital discord, a Catholic priest portrayed humorously by John Rhys-Davies, tormented by local cultists. The expedition has developed staff and funding shortages, and much more - many topics to be woven into an accomplished storyline. To solve their many self-imposed conundrums, work decays into insane fantasies, including silly special effects, as a simple resolution. Keith is of wood, manifestly uninspired by his role, but Belle is effective and Rhys-Davies's time is worthy of study, while the laurels of acting go to the superb Eastern Indian Roshan Seth, who easily dominates each of his scenes on the part of a shaman with extraordinary wisdom and magical powers. Filmed in the scenic province of Salta, in the north of Argentina, the scene is benefited by both the cinematography of Maximo Munzi and the faithful ethnicity of Luis Bacalov; if only one way had been seen to strengthen the stuttering scenario."

b'When Conan the Barbarian appeared on video in 1981, I was one of the first to achieve it. The movie has not lost its impact on me when I was 20, and it\'s way ahead of all those witchcraft and witchcraft movies that came in its wake, including the terrible sequel Conan the Destroyer. Why do I hold this? So high in my estimation? Certainly not in acting quality; when you have two bodybuilders, a surfer, a sports star and a dancer like five of the main actors in this movie, then you will not be taking classes - but again, this kind of movie does not need it. . But having said that they did a good job when the script required some excitement to be put into it. Grief, indecision, loyalty, friendship. It was all there. And revenge. Rematch is actually the thread that keeps the story together. To that end, co-writers John Milius (the director) and Oliver Stone should be applauded for not only dare to get out of the way of Robert E. Howard\'s books that gave the Conan world, but also to give us a coherent , neat and pleasant script that does not insult the intelligence (as opposed to the sequence). We have strong characters with whom you can sympathize and thugs that you readily want to get your mere deserts. Arnold Schwarzenegger in his film debut is perfect for the role as well as James Earl Jones as the main antagonist, the utterly evil Thulsa Doom who is so dominated by power that he promptly encourages a loyal follower to commit suicide just to prove a point to Conan . And follow the story is a high quality score written by Basil Polidouris. From the moment the opening credits begin, there is a deep and pulsating percussive sound that can take the viewer to another time and place, and make them believe that this is the song of that era. Mako\'s narration when the story is presented is unforgettable and I remember when I first heard it that it made my jaw drop. BANG! On come theme music. Gutsy, difficult and a delight. For me though, the only outstanding memory is the brilliant cinematography used when Conan is praying to his god, Crom, just before the final battle. He asks for revenge, while the camera runs with the hard cohorts of Thulsa Doom, the music in the background. Fantastic movie set, and one that can not be improved. This should never be redone because they could never do a better job. This has a great story, a great track, strong characters, unforgettable scenes, all sadly absent from the sequel. I\'m not bound by any loyalty to Robert E. Howard\'s fiction, so I do not worry about the fact that this movie strays from Conan\'s "real" world.'

b'This film is a refreshing look at the novel, very European (albeit made American) and with fantastic chemistry. The unique, funny, (pseudo-) intellectual talk practically nonstop through the movie is great and the characters are believable. One would almost think that the actors were not following a script, but were just shaking it, discussing their ideas and real plans. While there may be some kitsch "we\'re all stardust" ... the character\'s reactions quickly correct any slippage in the reality of two young travelers in love with each other and for life. The scenes of Vienna, the Prater amusement park, the clubs and especially the scene in the cafe, are extremely true to life. With so much trash being made by American directors today, it\'s great to see a little gem like that.'

b'My three year old was having a very difficult time using the potty until we bought this DVD. She was stubborn and would refuse to use the potty, so she would intentionally have "accidents" during the day and night. I was completely frustrated and about to "lose it". From the first moment we watched this DVD, she turned a corner. This DVD really caught her eye. She wanted to be a big kid. She wanted to use the potty and she wanted to wear "big kid clothes". I was singing "Hallelujah" praises this DVD. Since we bought this DVD, she only had 3 accidents in about 3 months. Although, we still have to remind her to use the potty, she is using the potty consistently. And, to my surprise, there was an additional benefit of watching this DVD as a family ... my 20 months started wanting to use the potty addition. He was not even 18 months old and he insisted on sitting on the potty and using it. So I\'m saving money on your diapers now too. It does not succeed every time, but it is also on the way to the success of the bathroom. He proudly wears the big boy\'s underwear on top of his diaper, but he would not have it any other way. He loves his underwear! This DVD was a lifesaver and it truly has been my salvation.'

b"It is quite difficult to review these films, for you must consider all the reasons why this film was bound to fail miserably. First of all, this is the continuation of the film Interview with the Vampire (though the third book in the series). As the second book in the series (The Vampire Lestat) was not made into a film, the producers of this film had to pack two books of history into a single film. That's one reason the film left out most of the two books (read the books, by the way). Secondly, this movie was a continuation of the extremely popular and successful Inteview With the Vampire, so of course repeating that formula would have been really impossible. One reason for this is that the previous film was released with some very big stars (Tom Cruise, Brad Pitt, Antonio Banderas, Christian Slater) while the Queen of the Damned was climbed with just one: Aalyiah. The rest of the cast was relatively unknown (Stuart Townsend is not very well known from now on). All these problems aside, the movie itself is pretty awful. If you have read the book, you will be very disappointed, mainly because much of Rice's rich characterization is lost. None of the vampire's stories are revealed, more specifically the Gemini Legend, which is left totally out. The rest of the vampires are only glimpsed near the end of the movie, and are never referred to by name. Unless you have read the book, you will not be able to tell who is who. Another stupid point is that older vampires, for all their short on-screen time, wear the clothes from the time they were made, which is totally false in the book. Something that others might consider less is the disappointing lack of physical similarity that the characters have with their counterparts in the books. For example, Marius is described as a man in his forties, with long gray hair and a handsome face. Jesse is much older in the book, with very prominent red hair, and Armand's brief appearance is very wrong, because he looks more like Lestat. The only correct thing about Armand's physical appearance is his age: he's much younger here than in Vampire Interview because the books claim that Armand was turned vampire when he was 17. The only one that really seemed close to his description is Lestat. Stuart Townsend looked very much like my conception of Lestat, though his voice was too deep. Still, he did not look as good as Tom Cruise in that part. Physical resemblance is important because vampires are described as being very sexy and beautiful, and movies suffer from not accurately bringing these literary characters to the life of the movie. I really do not start with the inaccuracies with the book; there were too many. The main freedoms taken (apart from the absence of the other vampires) were the relationship with Marius and Lestat. Lestat was not made by Marius, as others have pointed out, and Marius as portrayed as an evil vampire, while in the book he is Lestat's mentor and he only kills evil men. The ending is totally different and impossible to compare and contrast here (read the books). The main reason I think it failed is that the film sacrificed a rich history for references to pop culture. More is made from the soundtrack of this film and Lestat's brief career as a nu-metal star than anything else, even history. For the reasons I described at the beginning of this review, I think the filmmakers were doomed to repeat the success of Interview with the Vampire, but that's no excuse to even make an effort. Producers try to make excuses, especially with cut scenes, where they try to explain why they cut more images of other vampires. In conclusion, Queen of the Damned is a miserable failure, mostly for giving up a rich and exciting history for pop culture references. As I said, it would have been impossible to repeat the success of the old vampire movie, but this movie is too horrible to support itself."

b'I loved Saturday Night Fever when I saw it many years ago and it\'s still my favorite movie. A common misconception is that it is a Disco movie or a musical (like Grease). Saturday Night Fever is hard, sometimes rude and violent looks at the world of young working class and club life in the 70s (I was also a bit young at the time of the launch of Fever to join clubs, but was similar in the pre-world -AIDS from the beginning of the 1980s when I started to dance. Violence, sex and curses are REAL ... that\'s how it is (and kind of ... without the bee\'s being !!) for those in Brooklyn (and other places in NY) John Badham did an excellent job of putting the life of a lost 19 year old person who lived for the dance club on Saturday night because everything in his life was frustrating and got nowhere (Remember the lines: "You\'re a clich\xc3\xa9, your place is not on your way, it\'s not a place?") This was the most powerful line and sums up the life of Tony Manero. brutal, tough and great! Up there with Taxi Driver for a raw character portrait!'

b"You'd think a movie with such a star-studded cast would have some redeeming qualities, but that one does not. The characters are flat and provide no reason for the audience to become emotionally attached. Zeta-Jones self-centered starlet character is dreadful and monotonous, depressed John Cusacks and lonely character is unbelievable and impossible to cling to, Billy Crystal's press agent who tries to please everyone's character is not funny nore engaging and character of Julia Robert seems be present only because she has a big smile. The high point, if you can call it, is the foreign lover character of Hank Azaria. His character is horribly stereotyped, but at least he acts a little when speaking in an accent (even though the accent is exaggerated). Even Christopher Walken, who is good at almost everything, is lost in this movie. Your little film role does not even make sense - there's nothing in the movie that gives clues to the end where Walken's character plays a big role. The main point of the film - will be Zeta - Jone's character and the character of John Cusack are back together? - is completely lost because they simply do not have amount of chemistry together on the screen. His performance is completely flat. This movie is disappointing even when compared to all the other more romantic comedies. One last note - the Doberman's gag would be funny and appropriate for third graders if it were not for the fact that Crystal's character seems to enjoy being licked in the groin by a dog. He even tells the dog where to lick. That's not funny - it's just disturbing."

b"We should all congratulate Uwe Boll. He's kind of like a movie cheap. No matter how small talent he has, and no matter how bad these films are, he can continue to do so. I know, he funds all of them himself through some kind of bizarre German fund, but even so, his ability to keep making movies despite absolute and complete failure is one of the great mysteries of the universe. It would not be so bad except that video game developers keep giving their best properties to this guy. I really enjoyed the Alone in the Dark series of games. Even the newest, the New Nightmare, was good for a few hours of gameplay. There was a good movie to be made from the adventures of Edward Carnby, but that's not it. Now Uwe Boll got his hands on Bloodrayne and Hunter: the Reckoning. What comes next, Silent Hill? Doom? I can only imagine the track that this guy will cut through adaptations from game to movie if he is not stopped. Someone needs to take out their line of credit, or these video game publishers need to understand and realize that when they make a bad movie of a game that kills the franchise, no one is more interested in that title. Think about it, is House of the Dead or Alone in the Dark a viable game title anymore? No way . A new House of the Dead game comes out on XBox and no one will mind. The title is dead and all because of Uwe Boll. So if any of you out there working for a game publisher, meeting a game publisher, or having access to a game publisher ... please let them know. This movie itself is not even worth reviewing. I can not separate what I did not like from this dung heap from the rest. Literally, all about it sucks. Writing, acting, music, CG effects, editing. I thought that if I waited until it came out on DVD and then rented with low expectations, I would not be disappointed. Even the $ 5 you spend on this DVD, if you buy it used by one of Amazon's sellers, is too much. You will regret it. This movie is just a bunch of Boll."

b'MAXIMUM OVERDRIVE is a fun, bloody, finale of the Stephen King world thriller (which directs for the first time from one of his published short stories). The story is about a comet flying across the Earth, and after that, machines from all over the world start to come to life and take on a life-force of their own (cars and trucks trample innocent people, electric knives cut off victims, soda machines shoot cans of refrigerant such as grenades, etc.). The main part of the story happens at a gas station where the machines have people trapped inside, struggling for their lives and finding a way to escape. The music in this movie is nothing short of memorable songs from the great rock band AC / DC.'

b'Harvey Pekar\'s comic book, American Splendor, pioneered a new genre: the autobiographical comic book. At first glance, the everyday happenings of a Cleveland archivist seem hardly the material for an interesting film. Fortunately, filmmakers Robert Pulcini and Shari Springer Berman are able to take what was funny, heart-wrenching and fascinating about Pekar\'s life and successfully adapt the page panes to the big screen. Like Ghost World, American Splendor is a champion of outsiders who do not fit into society. In a beautiful twist, a mini-comic comes with the DVD that briefly recounts Pekar\'s experience of having his story on film. The disc itself features an engaging audio commentary with the real Harvey Pekar, his wife Joyce, his daughter Danielle, his friend Toby Radloff, filmmakers Robert Pulcini and Shari Springer Berman, and actor Paul Giamatti. Everyone has a great time on this track as they play and reminisce about the film and its experiences. "Road to Splendor" is a brief update on what Harvey has been doing since the movie was made. The song "American Splendor" by Eytan Mirsky, which was presented in the film, can be heard in its entirety. . His vocals sound eerily like Evan Giving from the Lemonheads. Finally, there is a trailer for the movie. American Splendor has the same ironic and melancholic sense of humor as Ghost World, another excellent film adaptation of an independent comic book. American Splendor holds true to Pekar\'s vision - he refuses to sentimentalize his life, even in the emotional conclusion of the movie that is genuinely moving. It is one of the best comic book adaptations of all time because it remains true to its source material and wisely involves its creator in the process of transferring his story from page to screen.'

b'The film is a strange animal, alright, a work without genre, and sometimes Gordon seems to have overcome, seeking effects he is not able to achieve. The various styles, moods and genres give the film a slightly gaudy and amateurish feel, but in the end (perhaps consciously on Gordon\'s part), this embarrassment works in favor of the film. The Singing Detective is remarkably naive, fresh and daring, almost childish in its lack of pretentiousness and easily one of the most original American films of the last twenty years. Above all, it shows Robert Downey Jr.\'s infuriated and pulpy flesh writer, within whose head the whole (or so) movie takes place, and Downey makes a creative and powerful performance, which may be the apotheosis of his life. enormous talent. Despite praise for Downey, at its launch, Gordon\'s film found a wall of critical resistance, a veritable conspiracy of contempt. This may have been due in part (at least in the UK) to a fondness for Potter\'s original TV series; but perhaps it was due even more to the basic incompatibility of Potter\'s idiosyncratic and blunt vision with the main (critical) tastes. Whatever the case, the film once again failed tragically in finding its audience. With his earlier adaptations, Gordon respected the source material without reverencing him, and as a director, he has a rare gift: the ability to fuse his own sensibilities and talents. with your subject at a fundamental level. In The Singing Detective\'s case, it was a slightly less perfect merger; Potter\'s vision (his bizarre blend of musical fantasy and gloomy psychological realism) was so surprisingly original that it required another sensitivity at least as strong and eccentric to merge. Gordon does not (yet) have the surrealistic gifts to make Potter\'s vision his own, or to take it to the next level (David Lynch may be the only capable director). He is a proficient director in every way, and seems to be blessed with a natural relationship with the actors (perhaps why so many good people want to work with him). However, Gordon is not a visionary director, and this was a visionary script. Fortunately, he had a visionary actor at a career peak to take the slack, and Downey bears the day. The Canto Detective is not a masterpiece; is flawed and fractured and sometimes thin, even easy and occasionally redundant (more especially in pseudo-noir sequences). But it is an imaginative and fearless work of art, an admirably eccentric work that manages to do something like justice to a brilliant piece of writing. Filled with inventive delights and heartfelt touches, it leaves most other recent American films in the dust. However, it failed, both in the UK and the US, being so poorly revised that many people (myself included) let it pass, suspicious of the stench of failure. It turns out that the bad smells did not come from the film, but from critics very corrupt and tired of recognizing a work of art when they saw it. (Excerpt from "Faithful to the Muse: Life on the Edge of Keith Gordon" by DOGVILLE VS. HOLLYWOOD by Jake Horsley)'

b'Seeing this musical on a New York stage is an unforgettable experience and I went to see it four times. But watching him at the movies is a totally flat experience. It just does not work on the screen for me. Although you have a talented cast, the incredible energy and electricity that have crossed the stage are far from being found here. The musical is a brave story based on humid, village-filled environments filled with interesting locals. On the edge . Since I lived in New York for 30 years, I immediately felt at home with this hidden world that the average person can not imagine. But spending two hours in a movie theater, watching this depressing and depressing story, is a grim experience. The musical numbers seem all forced. The people are not very friendly. They are very dramatic and intense for the comfort zone and the reason the movie bombed, is that America in the middle probably could not understand why the people in this movie did not pay the damn rent - and avoid all the drama and problems! This movie went very well in the big cities, where there were people who identified with this bona fide story of tragedy and Aids. But even for someone like me who is very familiar with this world, which happens in the Village where I used to live, it is a gloomy and depressing experience with too little to feel optimistic about. I could not sympathize with the drug addicts and the prostheses nor any of the musical numbers electrified. They should have gotten a new cast for the film version and open it up more of the dark and ever-wet world that surrounds this cinematic treatment.'

b'"The Exorcist," by William Friedkin, is a landmark. The cultural psyche is still recovering from its arrival on the scene more than thirty years ago. It is a masterpiece that will continue to linger long after many of today\'s horror films are forgotten. The actress Chris MacNeil (Ellen Burstyn) seeks the help of Father Damien Karras (Jason Miller) after his daughter Regan (Linda Blair) begins to behave strangely. After realizing that something is terribly wrong with the young woman, Father Lankester Merrin (Max von Sydow) is summoned to perform an exorcism on her. A terrible battle between the forces of good and evil happens, then, pushing everyone involved to their physical and spiritual breakpoints. Words can not effectively convey the power of "The Exorcist." \'\' This is a movie that relentlessly attacks the senses and does not apologize for it. The ensuing genre entries had no choice but to follow suit, because, on their own, they redefined what the public understood to be cinematic terror. While Linda Blair deservedly deserves great attention for her fine work, Jason Miller\'s equally powerful performance as Father Karras should not be neglected. It gives the film an important human component that holds it firm. Without Karras\' bow, "The Exorcist" is just another screaming movie trying to make money fast, relying on cheap thrills. Truly groundbreaking, "The Exorcist" is a stunning work that dared to test the limits of cinema. No serious discussion about the great cinema is complete without mentioning it.'

b"There are those who criticize JFK, claiming that Oliver Stone disregarded the facts and rewrote the story. True or not, that loses the point completely. Stone himself said that his intention in making the film was to make his audience question authority and think for himself. The film is presented as a POSSIBLE explanation (a combination of two separate theories) for the unusual events leading up to the Kennedy assassination, and actually raises more questions than answers. The cast is phenomenal. The award-winning cinematography and editing are innovative to say the least. Despite his take on JFK's politics, the film is one of the few that I would say is perfect. It's the reason I'm a filmmaker and it's worth every second that you spend watching. You'll never forget that."

b'First of all, I want to inform you that I am a huge Recess fan. So this comes from the perspective of a fan. So you really want to know what that is? This is like the "Miracle On Third Street" DVD, with which the real stories are kept together. There are 4 real stories (3 have seen TV episodes) and only a new episode of 13 minutes. It starts when TJ and his gang return to the old abandoned playground at the back of the playground and are caught by the kindergarteners. They are held as "hostage" by the new boss named Chief Stinky and the gang tries to tell them stories about their experiences with the kindergarteners and then Gus tells when the gang was kindergarteners (the new episode.) The three episodes already seen are "The Legend of Big Kid", "Wild Child" and "The Kindergarten Derby". \'\' The bonus DVD episodes titled as \'\' Fans \'\' 3 favorite episodes \'\' are: The Challenge, The Whomps Story and One Got Clean. * I kind of doubt that they are the most favorite, because I know that `` The Experiment \'\' is very popular among fans, because that\'s when TJ and Spinelli kiss. Also if you wonder why Gus is on the cover when he supposedly came in. Third street in 4th grade. Well on the DVD, Gus went to Third Street during kindergarten, but only for a few weeks and only he remembers the kindergarten, while the rest of the class does not remember anything about the year that explains why Gus is on the cover. You will notice that the voices of TJ and Mikey are different (not too different or annoying, but it is noticeable) because the voices of the original voice actors have become very deep. Anyway, when I bought this DVD I thought it would be an adventure of an hour of history when TJ and his gang were kindergarteners ... but unfortunately it was not. It was really pathetic of Disney to do that and give such a careless bit of episodes "already seen on TV". I only gave 2 stars because of the new episode. If you bought `` Miracle on Third Street \'\' and were disappointed, I do not think you would want that. If you are a new fan, and you have not seen all the episodes ... then this is a great DVD for you to follow! If you are a parent and consider it a simple whimisical entertainment for your child, I HIGHLY suggest this, but the DVD and episodes are hilarious, but they can also have good messages of friendship and believe in yourself, and so on. I know most kids like this because my younger cousins \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8b(around 8-12 years old) like cartoons and can relate to the characters in school. Hope this helps you!'

b"Dumas's stories have been filmed so often, but it's still a joy to see them. This new version of the Count of Monte Christo is no exception. It has serious defects and errors, too many to list. None of these things really pissed me off. I just sat down and enjoyed it. The opening scene set the mood and the picture usually showed great settings. The ending was incredibly mellow, but since I had just watched a wonderful fight / fencing scene with a lush green backdrop, I did not care much. A loud complaint about most new movies: voices are almost inaudible compared for background music and noises.I hope you read the book if you have not already. No movie has ever made Dumas's story telling justice to power. The film version of the Three Musketeers with Michael York as D'Artagnan came close. If you're willing to have fun, this movie may fit your mood. I've seen this three times so far."

b"Robocop 2 is probably the most underrated and most harshly criticized sequel in history (tying with Predator 2, which came out the same year). Because of some missing elements of the first and a little more cartoon for the violence, critics and the public were not satisfied and the opinions and feelings about the franchise failed with the simply horrible Robocop 3. Make no mistake about a good movie though. Robocop 2 still has the same wild sense of humor, cynical social commentary and pathetic character of the first film. It is a hyper-realistic vision of an America populated by gun-loving psychopaths, a democracy owned by big business, and the miserable junkies who are trafficked to them by hawkers, believing it to be the second coming of Christ. be the typical way of describing it. Completely-over-the-top would be more appropriate. Empire Strikes Back director Irvin Kershner clashes with so much sadistic violence, deafening shots, endless destruction and loss of human lives that the film just begs you not to take it seriously. Some of the blame was put on writer Frank Miller for the film being more caricature than the original. I do not think that's very fair. I read Miller's original script when I was in high school and it's quite different and, I daresay, it's not applicable. Robocop 2 himself was not the Nuke Lord Caine, the hippie psycho with delirium of divinity. His name was Kong, a psychotic cop who practically killed everyone he encountered. Sergeant Reed and the Old Man died and there was not much humor. Screenwriter Walon Green has been hired to dictate the script and much of what appears on screen is actually his job. Frank Miller's original ideas are virtually left behind as the structure of the entire film and part of his story has been recycled to Robocop 3 (do not blame him for that either). Miller was obviously upset about this, but it was still a sport good enough to appear in the film (keep an eye on him playing Doctor Frank), although he promised not to work in Hollywood again for fear of being taken advantage of. Until Robert Rodriguez promised to make a success in his graphic novels Sin City.Verhoven may be gone, but Irvin Kershner struggles to deliver the same mix of joy and magic and really hit it. Basil Poledouris' ghastly score has also disappeared (he returns in Robocop 3), but the new composer Leonard Rosenman creates a wonderfully heroic and optimistic theme that fits the film more than the poisedour soundtrack of Poledouris in the first film.Filmado m\xc3\xa1s once in Texas, Houston this time, you really have to feel for Peter Weller walking in that Robosuit. It must have weighed a ton and it would be sweating inside loads. There is a particular scene in the film in which Murphy is tortured in near death / destruction which is very difficult to watch. But that leads him to get a brand new makeover and these crazy new directives placed in his head. The part where he gives a lecture to the Little League boys and reprimands the young people who play with the leak (after citing some very suspicious philosophies) is hilarious. Robocop 2 is a great movie. Despite the problems with the script, the story and some slightly dated stop motion effects, it's a brilliant sequence that meets expectations. Listen to the most talkative. I do not know what kind of movie they were expecting. And thanks for not smoking! The DVD is at 1.85: 1 widescreen anamorphic widescreen color (check out Robo's armor chrome) and Dolby 5.1 sound. I'm a little sad that there are no extras as a comment, because I really want to hear what Kershner has to say about the movie. And there are deleted scenes that I know of that made Murphy visit his grave and some more details about why Caine is so weird. We can only hope that in the future ..."

b'This 30-year anniversary edition takes the original Night of the Living Dead movie and launches a new soundtrack and new scenes. As far as I was concerned, the original film was perfect as it is and this was unnecessary, however I decided to be open-minded and give this edition a chance considering that the new material was written by John Russo (who co- original film) and has photography (and acting) by Hinzman (who also helped create the original). I was completely disappointed. The new scenes include a new introduction, varied scenes of zombies marching and being killed by hillbilly, and a new epilogue. The various scenes sometimes interfere with the flow of the film, the makeup is less effective and some of the new extras are terrible. They do a decent job of editing in the new scenes, but they are still remarkable (for example, the fashions are not quite right). The new introduction and epilogue are ridiculous. The introduction just states that the lead zombie (played by Hinzman) was a criminal when alive. This takes one of the movies the most effective elements: that zombies can be your neighbor or a close friend or relative, but they will still try to kill you. Hinzman is obviously older in the front photos (the profiles are fine). When he starts attacking two gravediggers, one of the "actors" starts to flee and realizes that Hinzman should catch him first, so he actually goes back to the coffin and leans so that Hinzman can catch him! ! ! The fact that they did not make a second attempt shows a lack of care. The epilogue is a "one year later" with an insane preacher of hell and sulfur who survived the carnage. He\'s stuck in the middle (spoiler warning) of the Duane Jones scene being killed and the final credits showing the rednecks eliminating his body! ! Talk about interfering with a very effective ending! You have the option to watch the original cut (in a great print), but you can only watch it with the new soundtrack! The old soundtrack was made up of library music, but it worked out great. At best, the new soundtrack is mediocre. Sometimes this does not even fit the mood of the scene, for example, being frenetic when the action is calmer and depressing. The booklet contains interviews consisting mostly of actors talking about how "flawless" new scenes have been added and how many old fans will love the new (wrong) version. There\'s a fun commentary track, but you get the same people (plus others, including Romero), giving you the same information in the comment bands of the much higher Elite Millennium Edition.'

b'I was very disappointed with how far this film departs from the real story! It\'s "more or less" Prince Caspian, but it lacks many important elements. First, they left Aslam almost entirely to the end. Those who are familiar with the book will remember that Aslan is the most important part of the strength and development of the story. It was he who called the children to Narnia for their purpose, a plan. Half the book is about Aslan and the kids, so the fact that they have let their importance out of the movie really spoils the story. Not Aslan, nor Narnia! There are a number of other aspects that are not about the book, but some of them could be more easily overlooked if they had not strayed from the true "Heart" of history. The other big disappointment for me was how they changed Peter\'s character. Your whole attitude has changed. You never get a chance to warm up with him, and in the end, he\'s almost glad he did not return to Narnia. (The same can be said of Susan.) The plot seemed very weak, and the relationship they tried to create between Caspian and Susan was totally unnecessary and I felt, it helped a lot in ruining the film as well. But if you\'re not interested in the story\'s fidelity, "Prince Caspian" by Andrew Adamson is an action-packed adventure with many wonderful visual and special effects. However, I recommend you read the story. The book has much more wealth and purpose. I wish they had stayed in this story, just like they had the "Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe." I hope they do better in "The Journey of the Dawn Treader." We will see ... ! These are just a few of my thoughts. Needless to say, I feel like they could have made this movie so much better.'

b"This is one of those rare movies that completely captures teenage girls in a funny and honest way. Enid and Rebecca are two misfits who have just graduated from high school. While Rebecca gets a job to try to fix her own apartment and move on into adulthood, Enid is still struggling to find her place in a new world. This is obvious from his reluctance to get a job and move on. After making a joke with an older, lonely man, she eventually becomes a friend of his as she walks away from Rebecca. Enid is a character who sometimes gets angry but at the same time understands that she is having trouble moving forward life and feel empathy for. She has a lot of talent, but she has no idea what exactly she wants to do. Then she turns to the outcasts like the crazy old man who sits waiting for a bus that never comes and the older Seymour. This movie is often sad but hilarious as well. You're always wondering where this movie is going to take you. By the end is the perfect touch, although some may not care about it. It's a great movie that is really real and honest. These are not cardboard characters, they are real girls. In conclusion, it deserves all the buzzing. You'll like this if you like intelligent, independent films that are not artificial and actually have some real meaning. Bright!"

b'Interview with a vampire was an excellent film, beautifully done based on an incredible idea. The Queen of the Damned illustrates, at the very least, that Anne Rice is a wonderfully creative author, but I discovered that this cinematic version of one of her books was very boring, with many fine characters. The vampire Lestat (beautifully played by Stuart Townsend) decides to get out of retirement, which is actually a sleep of several hundred years. He gives a great insight into the world of vampires - you know you hate light, garlic and all things sacred; loves dark, blood attractive young ladies necks and eerrr `` Nu-Metal! "But what bothers him the most is that he is immortal. I mean, he does not age, he seems to have unlimited financial resources - but he\'s so bored with life. Sounds like a kind of vampire brat, spoiled to me! So he thinks that if he can totally provoke all the other vampires, then maybe they\'ll be so enraged to get him out of this eternal misery - and who\'s better at work than the "Queen of the Damned"? or Aaliyah for us. As he teases them and she, well, he becomes the lead singer of the world\'s biggest and most controversial Nu-Metal band. Hey, I definitely would be with all the other vampires. There are interesting aspects in this film - how he became a vampire and how he dealt with it is quite fascinating. In addition, everything is filmed using typical gothic images and colors. The monologue of his thoughts is full of comic irony and is delivered wonderfully. Some of the subtle interactions between the characters are also hilarious. Aaliyah looks amazing in her role as the queen of all vampires, she really has a presence on screen and what tragedy her career as an actress and musician has been interrupted. The conflicts between vampires and vampires that happen during the film are also very original. Unfortunately, none of the effects is particularly spectacular. Overall, although the idea is good, the development and plot are too weak to make this movie truly memorable.'

b'This is a 1970s horror movie based on the bestselling book of the "true" story of a haunted house on Long Island. It was denied and proved to be a total farce, but the film spawned about ten sequels and even that necessary remake. The Lutz family buys the house of their dreams only to discover it is haunted, and also contains the passage to hell in the basement. Yes, it is completely and utterly overwhelming to think that if such a passage existed in something called Hell, it would be in Amityville, Long Island. James Brolin plays the husband, tough guy with lots of hair. Margot Kidder is the wife, who can react with big, wide eyes whenever she witnesses a ghost, hallucination, atrocities, etc. Most of the scares are really opening doors or something, looking at something, and then the music gets really loud, and then we see people\'s eyes, closer, and then, da da! A special cheese effect. Good for the value of nostalgia. The appearance of Rod Steiger as a crazed priest is a great advantage. Like a cheap exorcist. If these types of movies scare you, it may be worth it on a slow night. Good for some unintentional laughter too.'

Since the first film was made in 1997, it was incredibly disappointing that the CGI was so bad. Given the advancement of computer graphics technology, you'd think a movie would at least try to live up to the 1997 standards. No - it did not. There is no need to think about it any more.- The acting. Most of the performance was filled with poor actors and actresses. Overemphasized, not emphasized, not emphasized at all - I found very few of the actors to be worth watching. I could not help but shrink from the way some of them played their characters, and the way several of them were portrayed. Military men and women do not follow what we, as individuals, think they will do, police officers and officers order troops around in insane and absurd patterns, and soldiers throw themselves over exploding insects when they could simply retreat to the back of the room . . Value is not even a problem here - its stupidity that charges the price. - The cheese. Yes, I specifically mentioned the cheese, even though it is highly relevant in this film. b'This is one of my favorite noirs movies, a great movie in which Welles showed the world that he could make a classic Hollywood movie without going over budget and still produce a genuine and personal masterpiece. I own two more previously released releases of this public domain movie, none of which did justice to the film. They look like worn VHS tapes. They are so bad. Finally, though with no extras and at a relatively high price, MGM has released what appears to be a transfer of an original 35mm print, if not the original negative. The image looks very clean and sharp with deep blacks and finally I can enjoy the movie as Welles intended. Buy .'

b'Coleman Silk (Anthony Hopkins) is a highly respected faculty and professor. After an innocent comment is misconstrued as a racist comment, he is forced to leave his job in disgrace. Coleman begins a strange affair with a half-dead, unmarried woman (Nicole Kidman) who has had a tragic past and is not ready to reciprocate her love. To me, this weird little movie was doomed from the beginning, when the great finish is shown immediately. The rest of the story is shown in agitated and anticocyclical flashbacks (usually out of order), which did not allow any build-up of tension or sympathy for the main character, Coleman. As a young man from New Jersey, he is played by Wentworth Miller, who is quite charismatic and sympathetic, but he looked and looked nothing like the Welsh-accented adult Coleman (who sometimes appeared to channel a leper Hannibal Reader). Hopkins is so horribly miscast in this role that it is impossible to buy the racially charged plot. Kidman was also completely wrong for this movie; her innate grace and elegance could not be hidden by a messy hairstyle and I never bought her as an illiterate tutor. His graphic love scenes with Hopkins were more frightening than romantic. There is so much personal tragedy among the main characters - including Gary Sinise, who plays a troublesome writer and Ed Harris as a crazed Vietnam veteran - and the film fails completely and I did not feel connected with them or the whole premise of injustice. After that, I shook my head with this surprising movie clutter and was struck by the fact that so much talent could not save him.'

b'& quot; Coffy & quot; (1973) made Pam Grier a star, & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; (1974) clearly shows why Grier became a star. & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; simply distills Grier\'s stellar qualities and uses them to their full potential, and by stellar qualities, I am not referring only to his broad body. In & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; Grier is a crazy abused and raped, wanting revenge at all costs, not only chews the scene, it destroys it. But that\'s exactly why we love Grier. She is beautiful, sensual and can kick an entire ass! As far as I\'m concerned, she\'s the original screen action heroine and this best vehicle shows her talents as an action star. Unlike & quot; Coffy, & quot; & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; does not give Grier much of a chance to flex his acting muscles, but presents Grier low and dirty: Foxy lives in apartments, beat lesbian hostiles, plucks eyes, burns alive men, weakens (literally and figuratively) his perfectly combed afro. & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; it\'s shocking, wildly sadistic, absolutely exaggerated, and a cult classic for the same reasons. & quot; Coffy & quot; may be the best movie, but & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; is more enjoyable. So, how come & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; rate on DVD? Well, the record is an absolute revelation. Not since the theatrical debut of the movie, it looked so good. The previous full-frame transfer used for the videotape and the CD was atrocious, featuring jaundiced skin tones, overly saturated colors, dark and dark interiors, ruined compositions, and horribly overrated edges. The new improved widescreen transfer anamorically is luminous. The compositions are preserved correctly with a ratio of 1.85: 1 ratio, with no more room for distraction and a little bit of image information is added to the sides. The interiors now reveal wood paneling, earthy wallpaper and brown curtains, unlike the previous transfer, which left almost everything black or dark brown. The skin tones are finally natural and the colors of the film are reduced to a level of comprehensible saturation, but do not worry, the 70\'s fashion is still a brilliant kaleidoscope of tawdriness. The sharpness is pleasant; The edge enhancement never raises its ugly head and the movie skies are finally blue. No more olive and yellow sunshine. The grain of film is noticeable in some dark scenes and there are some defects of origin. Considering that this is a low budget exploration film made in 1974, the source element is almost untouched. The compression on the disk is not so pure, though. Some dark and dark areas and dissolutions are often subject to artifacts side by side, but for a retail price of only $ 14.95, who can complain? The supplements include the entertaining theatrical trailer ("Foxy\'s got guts: without ifs, ands or buts!") And an illuminating commentary by director Jack Hill that repeatedly describes the difficulties of working with AIP (American International Pictures) in this film, which he said was one of his worst experiences of making movies. The mono sound of the disc is recommended; the dialogue is always intelligible and the low level makes Willie Hutch\'s score sound as fun as it was 27 years ago. Jack Hill created Pam Grier his own subgenre with & quot; Coffy & quot; and & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; and when she left after 1976 it is bleak & quot; Friday Foster, & quot; no one took her place ... nobody ever got it. & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; is the best action vehicle Pam Grier, a classic blaxploitation and a great DVD! If you have only seen & quot; Foxy Brown & quot; on VCR or laserdisc, you did not see & quot; Foxy & quot; at all.'

b'This movie is about a million times better than the recent remake "Red Dragon". The real conflict in the film is Will\'s tenuous understanding of his sanity as he accompanies a killer who is about to attack while dealing with a killer he has already caught. While Brian Cox\'s Lecktor will make comparisons with Anthony Hopkin\'s version in subsequent films, Cox interprets the psychopath as a real threat - a killer who will kill. Hopkins is brilliant too but I always felt that his Reader was like an animal that would attack only with a strong provocation. We see Cox and Petersen as equals on different sides of the fence, with little separation between them, apart from Peterson\'s knowledge of right and wrong. This thriller is one of the best.'

b'I am a longtime follower of Smallville, and every year there are always fans (myself included) who point to the current year as "Jumping the shark". If you browse my profile, you\'ll find that my reviews of the older seasons get excited and become more critical as the years go by. While I\'m not going to comment on the current 8th screening season, the trend seems to be true when you compare Season 7 with the 6 that came before it - they are pure geniuses compared to this mess. There\'s a lot going on this year. Smallville always has great comic books, but lacks internal development and logic in his own world. Writers jump from plot to plot without any rhythm, so you get to seemingly dramatic life-changing events that are completely forgotten by the next episode. There is a shocking twist involving the new Daily Planet Editor, which was cut short when it became interesting; the return of Clark Lara\'s biological mother hardly lasts one episode; Bizzaro appears and is promptly defeated - twice; Clark travels through time and space to save his child in Krypton in five minutes. Sam Jones finally returns as Pete Ross and is wasted in the placement of horrible products. Supergirl is introduced and underdeveloped before being sealed with the clich\xc3\xa9 of amnesia and disappearing for most of the season. Why not settle on 2 or 3 stories and develop them properly? And I do not blame the writers\' strike, which cuts off this season in 2 episodes - the problems were obvious before the strike happened. Speaking of outside influences, some characters leave the show this year. The sudden departure of Kristen Kreuk to shoot Street Fighter leaves her weak character a pretty anemic farewell - luckily, she will return briefly in Season 8 to tie the loose ends. Another character that I will not ruin dies a noble death, and will be lost. It\'s Rosenbaum\'s departure that is the real kicker, though. Not only is the best actor in Smallville not coming back, but he continues with an ambiguous and unsatisfactory ending. Hardly a great success for 7 years of incredible work. There are some things Smallville does well this year - Brainiac\'s return and the \'Veritas\' plot bring a sense of continuity that the show has been extremely lacking. But overall, there is a lack of consistency that seasons 5 and 6 have tried to have, and the show does not have heart now that Kent\'s parents are gone. Whether or not you need this season depends on whether you bought the top six and want the complete collection.'

b"This movie made me cry so much and it was so sad that it's really hard to understand how I could recommend it so strongly. The chemistry between Nicholson and Freeman was incredible and they played beautifully. Humor was a welcome relief to the immense emotional subject. This movie really made me think about what is important in life. I've found several of the main themes of the film in which to think and consider in relation to my own life. I loved the questions of the pyramids: 1. Did you find joy in your life? 2 Have you brought joy to other lives? This movie is probably not the only one to look for when you're in the mood for something light and funny. However, if you want to regain some perspective on what is important in life, this movie does a good job of making you think about what you want to accomplish in life - particularly without being lazy."

b'`` Alias \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8b\'\' is one of my favorite shows - even at its weakest, it was excellent compared to almost every other television show. The fifth season, reinventing the show again, is very entertaining, exciting and thrilling, and I recommend everyone to watch. However, I have serious and serious issues with this DVD release. I really do not own it because I bought the complete collection of the Rambaldi box (all five seasons Alias \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bin one). But I saw the launch of the fifth season and it\'s terrible. Of all five DVD releases, it\'s the ugliest box. The promo photo is awful, the green cover does not go well with the other seasons, and the big words "FINAL SEASON" are simply cheesy. The box now is not sized for the other releases, it\'s what appears to be less than half an inch thick. This has been a big problem for me too, with Alias \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8b- Buena Vista changing the packaging for each season. It is very annoying. Also, the special features are nothing. Some interesting features, but in general the supplements are very weak for the final season. The whole thing seems rushed and spoiled, as if no one had realized that this was the last season of such a beloved series. If you can afford it, I recommend you invest in the complete collection. It is very well made and assembled (although it has flaws) and has a bonus disc of extras that are very informative and fun to watch. However, only 40,000 are being made so supplies are limited.'

b'I just recently started working on a regular basis. In the past I\'d start something and then get bored or just do not like it.
