b'"L\'Affaire du Collier" may be based on a true story, but it is also a fascinating historical novel, "The Necklace of the Queen" by Alexandre Dumas, who certainly had more than the "Three Musketeers". on the sleeve Dumas tells the identical story of Joseph Balsamo (also known as Count Cagliostro), Jeanne de la Motte Valois, the lascivious but lovely Cardinal de Rohan and the great diamond blow, although the filmmakers do not credit Dumas (note that the book is available at Amazon.com, and I highly recommend it!) The costume designer, Malena Canonero, deserves applause for silks, satins, and lace jabots that magnificently recreate the opulence of Louis XVI\'s 18th-century court. The settings are also splendid. However, I found much of the strident music in which the composer insisted on giving him a modern beat sometimes and also used a mix of Mozart\'s "Requiem" among other things. I find these cuts and rearrangements of a bar here; a bar there, to be lazy and a little cheater. On the featurette, the director explained that he wanted to make the period "accessible" to the modern public. This "accessibility" not only insults the intelligence of modern audiences, but also weakens the film. As the story is so strong, I still enjoyed the movie. I was particularly impressed by the performances of Jonathan Pryce as the suave cardinal, Adrien Brody as Jeanne\'s irresponsible husband, and Simon Baker, who is especially engaging as his love interest. They are all believable and move well in their silks. Although Hilary Swank is an excellent actress, I thought she was wrong in that role. She seems a bit uncomfortable in her costume and moves more like a woman than the twenty-first century, instead of one of the eighteenth century. Leaving aside these reservations, I will keep this film and, no doubt, I will watch again.'

b'I generally do not use the space provided for product reviews to comment on the condition of a particular piece of merchandise, or draw attention to a less reputable buyer. In this case, however, I shall make an exception. The DVD I received today, being sold by Amazon LLC, which is listed as `` Passport to Pimlico \'\' (Remastered Edition), is obviously a home-based job. The outer label is a color photocopy, the DVD itself is black and white, for God\'s sake. Flip the DVD and you can clearly see the band that the home recording makes on a recordable DVD. The manufacturer, A2ZCDs, seems to be a professional equipment, with a meaningful catalog, a good looking website, etc. But I do not know why this sale was not listed as coming from a third party vendor. (At least its coming from Amazon makes it easy to return.) But, more importantly, is not home-making DVDs simply, well, illegal? Does not this constitute piracy? My guess when I read the word "remastered" is that the print is made from an existing negative, or significantly cleaned; I certainly hope the studio, the filmmakers or at least the movie historians have some part in the album\'s production. Maybe whoever runs A2ZCDs has done some such work on household equipment, but that does not excuse the fact of fooling the general public. It may be that I have been away from the base and that the copyright to `` Passport to Pimlico \'\' has been running for years. Maybe no one owns the movie and we all have the right to photocopy it and sell it as the next guy. If so, my (saved) apologizes to the A2ZCDs. I think, however, that buyers should be aware that they are not getting merchandise that somehow reflect what most of us who collects movies have come to consider "remastered" or even professionally produced. I have a Panasonic DVD recorder and make my own movie DVDs that I recorded from TMC. In my craziest dreams, however, it would never occur to me to sell them. Maybe that makes me an idiot. If so, at least I\'m honest.'

b'Here\'s a riddle for all of you. What do you call ten gallons of ice cream and one scoop of dung? Ten gallons of manure. I do not care how much they wear the DVD version of this movie, it does not change the fact that it\'s terrible. I\'m just giving this star, but keep five or six Advil at hand. That should be enough to cover you for it. A couple of tips on this disaster: It\'s made by Uwe Boll, director of two of the WORST films I\'ve seen in \'House of the Dead\' and \'Alone in the Dark\'. In what was for me an impressive moment of brutal honesty, Boll himself admitted that he did not release the film until TWO WEEKS before the start of filming. What he ended up was a bunch of "names" who happened to have a hole in the agenda and appeared for a quick payment and a free trip to Romania. It also shows that the whole movie looks like they just skipped the essay and no one seems at all interested in making an honest effort. Will Sanderson and Michael Madsen may have discovered the only way to survive a Boll movie. They were completely intoxicated throughout the production. Ben Kingsley, who previously had to deal with Madsen in the movie "Species" refused to even be in the same set with him. In the harem scene with Meatloaf, these are HONEST TO GOD, 100% ROMAN PROSTITUTES WITH FULL-BLOODED. I swear you can not do these things. Apparently Boll could not play real actresses (his union fees made them very expensive), so he decided he could cut costs just by ordering for the real thing. This is a disaster from front to back. I\'ll give it, it\'s better than his last two movies. "Bloodrayne", at least, is a bit unintentionally funny. Even though I said that, I could never recommend anyone to see this. It will only encourage the man to continue. Uwe Boll, no doubt in my mind, is the most untalented filmmaker I\'ve ever seen. I\'m absolutely surprised this guy keeps finding his way behind a camera ...'

b"`` These are the continuous trips of the USS Enterprise '' on blu ray.Okay, we all know what Star Trek is about, so I will not go over the plot. I will say that the stories are very interesting, well thought out, well written and well interpreted. I really like how Star Trek plays 'Human Emotion' and 'Human Element'. I want to talk about blu-ray transfer, and it's great. The image is crystal clear and sharp like a razor. I was honestly without words watching. I grew up with ST: TNG, and it was like I was watching it all over again. The colors are very clear and I could not believe what I was seeing. I always surprise myself with just how colorful and vibrant the pictures are. When I was reading other reviews, there were many complaints about the sound. UPDATE: It seems like the more you get into the episodes, sometimes the worse it gets. One of the episodes looks like it was recorded in a bathroom, very echo and muffled. Even if it's not perfect, I'm still happy to have it. *** UPDATE 10/6: If you have the early set, you will have problems with the sound in some of the episodes. CBS / Paramount is having a disc exchange. Just send an email to: phe.stng @ bydeluxe.com. They ask for the code on the back of the disk on the right side. It may be hard to see, but it's there. It took about a week to send me the replacements for blu rays. *** Normally, I do not care about extras when it comes to DVD, but this has a lot of them, and they're fantastic. Now for the price. Yes, it's very expensive but expensive, it's worth it. I spent buying the dvd and waited for the blu ray, and dude, I'm glad I did. It was worth the wait. If you know someone who is a Star Trek fan, this is a must have for them. They do not regret receiving it, and neither did I when I bought it. I can not wait the rest of the seasons to get to blu ray."

b'This 1955 release is one of those smaller films by Akira Kurosawa that is overlooked in favor of his larger films as & quot; Rashomon & quot; and & quot; Seven Samurai & quot; but still worth seeing. The great Toshiro Mifune plays an industrialist in post-World War II Japan, who is slowly freaking out with the notion that a nuclear war is coming and tries to convince his family (and his lovers) to flee Japan with him. The obsessive portrait of Mifune is the stuff of a great tragedy, especially when he vainly asks his greedy family to leave and Takashi Shimura, the samurai leader in "Sete Samurai", is also effective as a counselor who tries The film captures Japanese fear about the atomic bomb, a subject that Kurosawa would also address in his masterpiece, "Ikiru", very well and with the greedy family approaching a delirious patriarch , brings to mind & quot; King Lear & quot ;, a tale that the director would return many years later in & quot; Ran & quot ;.This is a short film from one of the great directors of the world but very good.'

b'I was eager to see this cinematic version of HG Wells\'s classic novel as the producers claimed it would remain true to the original location and period of the late Victorian Britain. Initially, I had been delayed buying this film since its original release in 2005 due to initial, and significant amount of complaints of low production values, weak FX, under par and "endless walking scenes". Needless to say, my passion for romance and courage took me the best and I had to see this movie by myself. Basically, I was aware of the short films and had no great expectations regarding the production, so I can honestly say that I liked the film despite the flaws that are too numerous to list here and have already been covered by much more eloquent reviewers that I. The editing of scenes and events would confuse a viewer who has not read the original novel and they soon lose the plot as the film alternates between scenes of the narrator in Woking and his brother in London. at one point, the brother is allegedly on a London street and suddenly witnesses the attack on the Elfinstone ladies on a lane inland and runs on their rescue. The red herb of Mars appears soon after the attack on Woking and Shepperton without any explanation within the film Much has been said about the meeting between HMS Thunderchild and the Martians, since the brother escapes from England in a "paddestestearmer", enough to say that it is really horrible and that it would be better to be left out altogether. There is a much-anticipated scene in which the legs of a tripod move toward an artillery battery that is probably the best effect inside that movie and shows what could have happened. There is a truly terrible dialogue between the characters. For example, I challenge someone not to regret it when they see the exchange between the ladies Elfinstone and the brother while they \'discuss\' how they are going to escape England. I would also award the James Doohan award for the worst Scottish accent witnessed in the movies since Brigadoon, when the narrator talks to a soldier at Horsell Common. In contrast, when you observe the interaction with the actors trapped in the ruined house, also the meeting of the narrator of the dead woman on a London street, you are sadly remembered again of what might have been. film 2 stars that is generous and for the following reasons.The score is fantastic.It is refreshing that the film is faithful to the events of the book and had made the effort, albeit ill, to set the book in Victorian England and yet another updated version definite In the USA. Regrettably due to cost constraints, British style buildings are scanned and fix the Monty Python style inside a field in Washington state to represent Woking, Shepperton or London. I liked the design of the combat machines, also of the manipulators in the pit scenes. my 17-year-old daughter who watched this movie was not impressed, but was intrigued by the setting and location of the films. As a result, she struggled to read the novel and, to my surprise, read from cover to cover. The irony is that H. Wells won another young admirer despite the very poor quality of this film and for that I am very grateful. However, would I recommend this movie to a friend? Unfortunately, not if I wanted them to be friends.'

b"Anyone reading these reviews will see the TV production and know it from the inside out; therefore, I will limit my review to the quality of the DVD image - or rather, lack thereof. It's a shame that what used to be a beautiful and memorable TV movie has become a worn and faded shadow of your old self. It is painful to see something occupying a special place in your heart be treated so meanly. For years, the only version that millions saw on TV had colors so faded and low contrast that it almost seemed to have been filmed in black and white! If this is what you are accustomed to, & quot; restored & quot; The version of this DVD (and the one shown on TV in the last 3 or 4 years) looks a bit better, but it is hardly restored. Just look at a deleted music in the extras section to see how the original production was beautiful and bright: crisp, clear, immaculate, with highly saturated colors. Time and money must have been spent to bring the rest of the film to that standard. It is morally wrong to put a defective product on the market, so have the courage to charge money for it. As many of our parents probably told us when we were young, & quot; It pays to do anything worthwhile! & quot;"

b'COME THE FIRST MORNING You\'ve seen a movie and then thought to yourself that "the man is real," but not as a documentary, but just a piece of cinema that seems to have been ripped out of real life. If you\'ve ever felt that way then chances are you\'re watching this one. "Come Early Morning" is a wonderful little film made wonderfully by Joey Lauren Adams of Chasing Amy\'s fame and starring Ashley Judd and Jeffrey Donovan. This honestly looks like cameras were set up throughout the city and this is what was captured, it seems real. The film follows Lucy Fowler (Judd) on her journey through her thirties waking up every morning beside a useless guy after another. She is also dealing with a father with whom she is desperately trying to pass the time, although it seems that he could care less. So the story goes that she is a desperate and confused woman who is just looking for love and acceptance. Of course you could say that your problems with men emanate from your distant relationship with your father. Still, she ends up meeting at least one decent guy named Cal Percell (played so well by Donovan), who seems to want a relationship with her, despite her problem. It is this relationship here that is the driving force of the film, although the time spent with the father and roommate also adds an interesting dynamic. The great thing about all this is how it all ends. Director / Director Adams proves that all this time spent with Kevin Smith was worth it because this is a wonderful debut film. His direction is great, but it\'s his writing that really makes this movie so good. Like I said, this has to be one of the most real movies I\'ve seen in a while. I like the fact that she has not romanticized the main character and her problems, things do not end the way you want them to. This movie has an ending that is probably what would really happen, how big is that? Even those who did not grow up in a small town can relate to the things that are happening in this movie. Of course, Judd Judd is brilliant as the thirty-something girl who is trying to find her way. And you know Jeffery Donovan is great as the guy who should have been the one for her. Laura Prepon from "That 70\'s Show" is as good as Judd\'s roommate and best friend, she even finds love. Also Scott Wilson is brilliant as she finds father religion that looks as off her as she. In fact, the whole cast is great and deserves all the credit in the world. In addition to that the film was also filmed very well and for such a limited budget, it seems that the movie showed the whole city, even if it did not happen. I would have to say that this is one of the best movies that came out in a time and a wonderful debut for a filmmaker. For those who look like this, I say spread the word and review it now. And for those who have yet to see, I recommend this as a purchase, but I think you can try a rental. This is a wonderful movie with a great cast with real issues that everyone should be able to relate to. I would love to go on this movie, but anything can come is to watch it, if it\'s not your thing that\'s fine, but for those who enjoy these types of movies you will like this a lot.'

b"This is a typical quirky comedy from the sixties! Some may like it, and some may not. But if you are a fan of Mini Cooper, or just a car enthusiast (the opening scene with a Lamborghini Miura driving through the Italian Alps is amazing!), You have to see this movie! Mini Coopers are the real stars of this movie! The aforementioned Lamborghini Miura, a DB-4 Aston Martin, a Daimler, a pair of Jaguars type E, and a lot of Italian cars from the late 60's such as Alfa Romeos and FIATs, are the supporting stars! This is undoubtedly a movie of car enthusiasts! A must for lovers of the Mini Cooper!"

b"This is one that is definitely worth getting into Blu-Ray. The pictures are crisp and crystal clear, John Barry's famous soundtrack is in stereo and there are four extras that are very informative. I am a fan of this movement for decades, and own it on VHS and two DVD versions. But Blu-Ray is worth the money - a simply superb edition of one of the greatest action / adventure movies ever made."

b"Down right pathetic. It 's safe to say that this is and I'm going to mark it as Stephen Dorff (Cecil B. Demented, Blade, Entropy) and the worst Christian Slater movie (Pump Up The Volume, True Romance, Heathers) they've ever done. b"I was waiting so long to get this remastered movie on DVD. Here it is. Danny Kaye is such a talented singer and actor and this movie is brilliant for him. The jester is also very good and should be seen by everyone who liked Merry Andrew. I'm a big circus fan and also a circus performer. film shows what a real circus is. It's not a circus factory like today, it's not a family tradition. Colorful and funny!"

b'The Banks family needs a new nanny for Jane and Michael. Fortunately, it comes to the wind in the form of Mary Poppins. She is everything kids want, fun and magical. But while she takes them to paint the fields and tea parties on the ceiling, their father is less happy. Can it be made to see beyond the end of the nose? Ok, so this movie is really little more than an excuse for music and dance numbers. Still great! The plot is thin paper, and you miss his site in the midst of some of his fantastic scenes. Of course, part of this is because the film is based on a book that is nothing more than short stories. Still, this movie is more fun than anything else. And it has that in spades. What kid does not have fun imagining that they can do all the things that Jane and Michael do in this movie? They say that Walt Disney poured everything he learned to make this movie, and it shows. Many of the special effects remain remarkably well today. There were some that I had not even discovered until I attended this special edition. And the music! Any Disney fan knows these songs by heart. And you can not stop humming "A Spoonful of Sugar," "Jolly Holiday," "Let\'s Go to Kite," or "Chim Chim Cher-ee" for days after seeing it. Those who want to own a great DVD of this movie will not be disappointed with this two-disc set. Disc one presents the film in all its glory on wide screen. I can not see how that\'s better. The soundtrack has many different options, but the home theater mix will amaze you. It\'s fantastic . There is also a commentary track with Julie Andrews, Dick van Dyke, Karen Dubice (Jane) and Richard Sherman. Sprinkled are comments from other archives, including Disney himself. Also included are some pop-up facts to read along with while watching the movie. Disc two features a new documentary about the film, a deleted song, and more about music with Julie, Dick and the composers. And be sure to check out the animated cartoon "The Cat That Looked Like a King," a tale adapted from one of the later books in the series. One thing that comes out loud in this setting is how much everyone had fun doing and how much they respect Walt Disney. The fact that this film lasted 40 years is a testament to its genius. With this set, it will be appreciated by generations to come.'

b"I would not go as far as the previous reviewer in saying it's some kind of liberal conspiracy movie (and if it is, I hate listening to what people say about movies like Ferngully and Once Upon A Forest). I doubt that the fact that most humans care little about our impact on the environment is news to anyone, nor the fact that some of us kill other living creatures for a mirad of reasons ranging from fun to need real. That said, however, I can not give this movie a better rating. CG animation is * much * lower quality than the cover makes it look (more in line with a Saturday morning cartoon than a real feature film). I do not think I found a single funny joke in the whole movie, and more than a few scenes were so rude that I preferred to look away rather than watch them. The image is often dark and disturbing (the woman trying to behead a cat with a chainsaw comes to mind), and the peaceful outdoor scenes seem very fake. The animation has several parts that are remarkably poor when compared to a good CG movie (or even decent). In addition, humans are distorted almost beyond recognition. In short, there are many good CG titles, but that's certainly not one of them."

b"Gregory Peck magnificently plays the role of squadron commander of a precision bombing squadron during World War II. Playing & quot; Savage General & quot; Peck's role is that of an incoming commander with rigid military discipline beliefs to get the most out of his men and bring in what they lacked with their previous commander. The script itself is fun with philosophies and non-stop suspense. I would recommend this movie very strongly as a training video for people in professions where leadership is the key to success. Notice carefully how General Savage incorporates strict temperance discipline into his interactions with his men. With the gain of respect, he also gained the confidence of the troops. This form of leadership is almost non-existent today. However, it is literally, & quot; proven combat & quot; ."

b"I've seen this movie for many years and I know it's good. However, the DVD that Amazon sold me is HORRIBLE. I think it's a Chinese bootleg or something. I could not watch more than the first minute. If you buy, you will be disappointed."

b'This film begins with a simple question from Richard Lobb of the National Chicken Council: "In a way, we are not producing chickens, we are producing food. What this does is produce lots of food in a small amount of space at a very affordable price. Let someone explain to me what\'s wrong with that. "Well, this movie explains very well what\'s wrong with that. The first point is that it\'s not good to treat animals as if they were mere objects." You will see chickens and knee-high meat in their own excrement. You will also see chickens in their cages, not being able to carry their own weight. The animals are kept all the time in the dark, inclusive for us. It was very difficult for the filmmakers to get some footage from inside these chicken coops. The second point, connected in a way to the preceding one, is that our food can be easily contaminated with E-coli due to the excrement of the animals. continue your skin. This is how food poisoning can occur in the slaughterhouse. Barbara Kowalcyk, mother of a 2.5-year-old child, has experienced the most horrible experience anyone can suffer: the death of their child ... The reason: eating a hamburger ... ... `` We put faith in our government to be protected, but we are not being protected at the most basic level, \'\' she says. This is not an inconvenient truth - although this film was produced by the same company that brought us the documentary with the same title. This is an ugly truth. Can we do something about it? Absolutely. "You can change the world with every bite." Switch to organic. Better yet it would connect again with the source of your food, what you are eating, what you are putting in your mouth! The best thing to do would be to get involved with a local farmer that you know and can trust.'

b"The release of Alfred Hitchcock's Spellbound by Criterion has a small flaw. 74 minutes in the film, we have a picture of J.B. (Gregory Peck) holding a razor blade while listening to Brulov's screen (Michael Checkov): 'Is that you, Mr. Brown? 'We then cut to Brulov for the next line' Oh, I thought it was you. Simple, is not it? Well, the Criterion DVD cuts the blade very early, and then has the footage of Brulov singing his second line while overdubbing his! st Then we take the second line correctly. In other words, the filming of Brulov's line 'Oh, I thought it was you' is united twice! ! So far I do not know if the Criterion disk is the only version affected. If you do not mind the flaw, then the Spellbound version of Criterion is the version to be collected (great extras and image quality). And if you can still find it somewhere (since it 's now sold out) do not hesitate to buy it, it' s still a very good album and these extras really make this DVD a true collector 's item. Just do not throw away that old VHS tape!"

b"I love the Murder She Write Series and I really hoped the show was released on DVD. I have the 1st and 2nd season. I love watching episodes, but I'm very disappointed in the quality of the DVDs themselves. I understand that this is not happening with all DVDs, but many of the sets (including mine) have DVDs that skip and stop. I have to skip entire chapters of the shows just to get to the next episode. The problem is to use both sides of the DVD to store the episodes. If any research had been done on two-sided DVDs before putting this wonderful show into the cheaper two-sided format then we would not have as many sets of DVDs jumping. I really wish they had gone to the best quality route and not the cheapest route."

b"The Sons of Paradise, by Marcel Carne, succeed on so many levels that deservedly deserve to be called one of the greatest films of all time. Carne filmed the film gradually during the Nazi occupation of Paris. His film was officially supported despite the occupation, since the Nazis wanted to show that they were friends of the arts. This created the ironic situation in which Carne was receiving money from the government to support a film during the day and to tap aid to the French resistance at night. An actor was supposed to be a Nazi collaborator. He disappeared mysteriously during filming and had to be replaced. Despite all these obstacles, Carnival managed to recreate the Paris of the nineteenth century magnificently. In this way, the film itself is a triumph of the creative spirit. The title refers to the poor, who could only afford seats so high in the theater that they were almost on the rafters ... and yet these were the actual audiences. the actors performed for. The story is a series of cross-lives that, one way or another, revolve around the world's bohemian and tired Garance (played in the Mona Lisa style by Arletty). In addition, the film also revolves around the theatrical life of 1840 in Paris: the actors, the audience and all others. Garance is almost a courtesan: she moves conveniently between four men who love her, apparently unaffected by any of them ... in the end, she falls in love with the mimic Baptiste (Jean-Louis Barrault) ... but Baptiste is married to another woman after losing her chance with Garance years before. Are they going to be together? In the end, we, the viewers, are either the Sons of the Gods, or Sons of Paradise, that the title refers to the theatrical audiences of the film. In fact, opening and closing credits are played against a theater curtain. We are the spectators in the Gods, and the actors are presenting themselves to us living their lives: loving, living, dying ... feeling pain and joy. The Carne movie lasts more than three hours, but it's never late. The stories intersect and can not be adequately described in a simple review like this ... Four men love Garance and, in a way, all their lives intersect in and around the theater. The cinematography is incredible. There's a crowd scene at the end of the movie that resists anything ever filmed: it's simply magnificent. Batista is lost (in many ways) in a burgeoning mass of movement of mankind. Only this scene is reason enough to see the movie. I suspect this is a movie that people love or hate. The long duration can drive away many people, but this is a shame. The movie is not for those who want instant gratification. Instead, it is something to be enjoyed and enjoyed. If all this makes it look very serious, make sure it is not. Children of Paradise is a tragedy in some respects, but it is also a comedy in the Shakespearean sense. This was a movie made for a company like Criterion, and they do it justice in their DVD edition. The two halves of the film are presented on individual discs, so the film never experiences compression failures or other problems. The restoration is perfect: you would never know that this movie is almost sixty years old. The audio is mono, but very clean, no hiss or static. Criterion also included some supplements, inverviews, filmographies, trailers, etc., but the real treat is the movie itself. It is timeless."

b'I want to start by saying that this is the best Blu-Ray version I\'ve bought so far. The packaging is marvelous with its hard-shell "souvenir" aesthetic, and additional bonus features make it worth the meager asking price. Watching real scenes from Linda Blair (not less complete) on the set is invaluable and definitely outweighs any extras from previous releases. Regarding the important things .... THE MOVIE. I have to say that this has become my favorite movie of all the times. I am by no means a terror fan. I have some favorites of the genre ... but I opt more for the comic and / or fantastic. I like being raised with laughter, or drawn from reality completely. You ask, "So why on Earth would you consider the Exorcist your favorite movie? ? \'\'. It\'s a modern parable and it\'s one of those rare films that really produces the intended effect in every frame. Labeling "The Exorcist" as a horror movie is a bit myopic. It\'s a spiritual drama, a psychological thriller and a supernatural tale ... all together. A billion years later, it still retains its own and is as relevant today as it was then. The difference here is that we now live in a society that is, as Blatty states in the documentary "Fear Of God" "totally tired and depraved." Nothing here seems to shock and 14-year-olds now see this movie as "laughable." It\'s a shame, because there\'s so much more than pea soup and spinning heads here. It\'s really all about the terror of the unknown ... the fear and trepidation involved in all things metaphysical and spiritual. It is about the mystery of faith and your ability to succeed. Visions, sounds and history ... everything merges here. It\'s incredibly well written by Blatty. Friedkin\'s sense of documentary realism serves the plot well. The acting is top notch by a cast that could not have been more perfect. Dick Smith\'s makeup is groundbreaking, not only with Linda Blair, but with Max Von Sydow, who was in his mid-forties. Owen Roizman\'s use of varied light textures and, of course, his magisterial and iconic photo of Merrin\'s arrival is also noteworthy. I was fortunate enough to see the Fathom screening on Sept. 30 and while watching this movie a large screen with digital sound was fantastic, I still have to say that it plays better and provides more enervating sensations when watching at home ... in the dark. This is the truly scary angle within this movie ... it reminds us that no matter how safe we \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bthink we are (even in our own house with all the lights on), there is nothing that the real evil does not do nowhere do not go to manifest.'

b"Let me start by saying that I love & quot; Oh My Goddess & quot; and I was really looking forward to the DVD release of the series. It's very sweet, funny and easily one of the most charmingly romantic series I've ever seen. I am very happy to spend some time with Belldandy, Keichi, Skuld and Urd. That being said, I am shocked and disappointed to discover that they have split the series into two DVDs, each for separate sale. The episodes are very short, totaling just over an hour per DVD (I believe it's 82 minutes for Vol. 1 and 62 minutes for Vol. 2). No extra features included. Yikes! This is a lot for two and a half hours of viewing. I find it hard to believe that Animego could not do more justice to this excellent series, or provide more value to its customers. The six parts & quot; Moldiver & quot; OAV has managed to find a way to a DVD with good prices. How disappointing that & quot; Oh My Goddess & quot; could not do the same. I am sad to say that this is a great series for renting (but not for buying)."

b'Ripe is not an Lolita sex exploit film as supersaturated key art may suggest. Instead, it is a challenging and unusual exploration of feminine sexuality and maturity, with imagery directed and well represented by its three protagonists. The script sometimes becomes rocky and coarse as in many indie films (too many curses are a curse on independent scripts). , but the film is visually stunning, and the accumulation of little moments is delightful - when Violet discovers the adult magazines, for example, or when the stern man carrying the sisters has to explain the menstruation to her. And the final scene with the two sisters is devastating, a strange amalgam of suspense, family drama, and psychosocial implications. A wonderful soundtrack by Anton Sanko (ex-Suzanne Vega Band) extends this aesthetically excellent film, curiously moving and ultimately very somber. .'

b"The Iron Giant is a loose adaptation of a wonderful book of the same title, by Ted Hughes (written in the late sixties). In the book, the giant's origins are unknown, and he is initially buried under the ground before being attacked and finally being helped. The enemy in the book, who becomes a common enemy for both the humans and the giant and the cause of his alliance, was a gigantic dragon-like creature (as big as Australia !!) that the giant ends up overtaking. , set during the Cold War, and featuring a wonderful picture of the 1950s atmosphere, the enemy is the American - and our tendency to fear what is strange, and shoot first and ask questions later. I think this is, in the end, deeper. Of course the original author may have had some such allegory in mind when he wrote the original book, as the dragon from outer space ends up destroying and enveloping a large part of the planet in the darkness, almost like a world war. But in this case does his alliance with the giant supposedly signify an alliance with military technology to prevent a world war? In the movie, the robot is just a cool robot from outer space, that humans can choose to make a friend or establish as an enemy. Either way, this is easily one of the best animated films coming out of the UK. States in the last decade (and one of the others is from the same director, Brad Bird)."

b"I can not remember the last time I was so entertained by a movie I watched three times in 24 hours. STILL CRAZY took me out of my somber, somewhat starched middle-aged existence and carried me back to my college years in the seventies when I was in a disorganized part-time band. Make no mistake: this film unites the chaotic, weird, self-absorbed, arrogant and irresistibly dysfunctional behavior of rock musicians. The characters' antics - even in middle age, as they try to revive their careers - have brought back a multitude of memories. I can also remember shows that went awry; band members screaming chords with each other during a song; the frequent & quot; artistic & quot; disagreements; improvised improvisation sessions in barns, garages, empty high school bandrooms; and the thrill of connecting with an audience (usually a drunken audience). Buy this movie ... rent this movie ... watch this movie. It is more than just a comedy; there is a very real human component that transcends even the tumultuous world of the music industry. You will laugh, you will brush an occasional tear, and you will be completely entertained. The flame still burns. God bless rock 'n roll!"

b'At the end of this film, the character of Janet Jackson leads her to be ex-husband to death and ends up smiling at the end of the movie while looking at her next sexual perspective. This movie ended as a horror movie. It is a terrible example for any black woman who may be watching. This kind of aggressive and sadistic behavior is what you can read in the news, not in a romantic comedy or drama, or whatever that melodrama should be. I hope black women do not watch this movie and think the ending of the movie was good because it was quite sinister. Black men also seem unusually weak, while black women seem dominant. No man really wants a dominant woman with a loud mouth, no matter what Tyler Perry says. This movie gave me nightmares.'

b"I own a VHS copy of ALICE IN ACIDLAND, purchased from Something Weird years ago. I'm a big fan of the drug-trafficking films of the 60's and ALICE IN ACIDLAND has always been one of my favorites. I finally upgraded to DVD and was completely disappointed. This ALICE DVD is a clipped and censored version of the movie. Ten to fifteen second pieces were lifted here and there, leaving chopping heels in their places. And near the end of the movie, a whole scene was eliminated. Cropped images are all scenes containing full frontal nudity and / or the most brutal violence. The cuts are obvious - no attempt was made to make them flow with the movie ... the music and voice narration clipped awkwardly with each trimming instance The information about the runtime in the box is wrong ... in the box, the original ALICE runtime is listed: 62 minutes. But the DVD version only runs 53 minutes with all cuts. I've been a fan of Something Weird for years ... But now I'm disappointed with the company. They used to be a haven for unfiltered, non-PC, full-in-rave, horror, psychedelic exploration and simply a weird cinema ... things the masses would not want. So why cut a movie to (presumably) appeal to the masses? ? ? I will hesitate before buying another DVD Something Something Weird. I give this DVD 2 stars instead of one as the other material of this DVD is very good. But I do not think this DVD is worth your money."

b'This is just one of the questions asked and answered in this little gem of a movie. (btw, the answer is "Maybe because they fear death.") Both sweet and sour, it has just the right blend of humor, melancholy and true love.Char is at its best here as Loretta Castorini, a widow who falls in love with her brother the youngest of her fianc\xc3\xa9, Nicholas Case and Danny Aiello, respectively - both equally impressive in these roles - Olympia Dukakis and Vincent Gardenia complete the case as Loretta\'s parents - Feodor Chaliapin Jr. is invaluable as Loretta.It is my grandfather in love with dogs and I get John Mahoney before becoming the father of "Frasier." My favorite scene is where Loretta meets Johnny for the first time at the bakery.Nicholas Cage makes the funniest and sadest speech about his past.I know the whole scene by heart.'

b"For those of us who really like rock and heavy metal (the kind of guy who buys hundreds of CDs, who knows a bit about the history of a band, a band that knows the songs for their names, etc), film is sacrilege . This is totally bad. It has damaged the already biased image of rock. But the songs that STEEL DRAGON plays in the movie, as if it were his own, are not! ! There's a song from RAINBOW, another from DEF LEPPARD, it's absurd! Even as joke did not work, because it was not designed as a joke!"

b'Simplifying: Style over substance. There are some excellent sequences, but that\'s all this movie looks like, well planned and executed sequences - but without anything coherent, sticking it all together. The \'near-impact plane and the last-minute rescue\' is extremely impressive and the machine-gun ammunition crashing into Supe\'s chest, followed by the bullet in the eye, is magnificent. My chin was falling and I almost wanted to cheer. That\'s what Superman is about: seeing him defeat the bad guys in new, interesting ways - even fun. But that\'s when the fun ended. As Superman is not, it\'s children\'s love and ridiculous heroic jokes with kryptonite. I think both are so horribly implausible that both should be ridiculed. Like Brodie (skillfully played by Jason Lee in Kevin Smith\'s Mallrats), "It\'s impossible! Lois Lane could never have Superman\'s baby. Do you think your fallopian tubes could handle your sperm? I assure you that when he comes during sex, he probably blows a load like a shotgun blast ... across her back. "So, besides Lois Lane being alive after intercourse, you would have the impossibility of a human being conceiving and bringing the term of an alien\'s son to the term. Do not forget that just because Clark Kent looks and ostensibly acts like a human, he is an alien. He is a different species entirely. And totally different species can not mate. Just think of the chaos that would ensue in the animal kingdom if a lion falls in love and mates with a crocodile. Or a graffiti. The other issue that makes me shake with rage is the whole crappy concept of Superman being physically able to lift an entire continent of kryptonite into outer space. As the internet blogger dpogue21 speaks so proficiently (much better than I do - so thank you dpogue) in his review of imdb, "my next big complaint is that Superman raises a continent made of kryptonite into outer space. He does not get the Simpsons comic book guy to point out what\'s wrong with that. I do not know how many comic books Bryan Singer has read, but when Superman is exposed to a small amount of kryptonite he barely has the strength to stand. Whoever has had the idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bmaking him fly on a big island, made up of his greatest weakness in space, has no business being associated with any other Superman-related project. The concept is as ridiculous as making a Dracula movie, where the title character has a stake in his heart and still manages to pilot a spaceship made out of garlic in the sun. Why does not only Superman eat kryptonite? He can eat it and then brush his teeth with it and then sleep in kryptonite pajamas. This is no more absurd than having him hoisting a continent of kryptonite into space and then falling helplessly through the atmosphere without burning into re-entry or spreading throughout the central park when it hits the ground. \'\' Do I need to say more? I do not think so. ** [...]'

b'I was surprised that the editorial reviews of this movie treat as just another movie, which it definitely is not. I would describe this in several ways: like the movie that John Waters would give his left hand to do; like a tremendous drama of dramatic, intense and tear-drenched dance films, such as Red Shoes, which takes the hat from the concept of "field" without throwing the whole experience away just to maintain consistency with attitude; like a comedy that, if you understand the joke, will make you foolish to laugh sometimes. There are times when I was not sure which movie I was in, as the plot listed towards Flashdance and then Cinderella. But that\'s the kind of movie it is; embraces the operatic emotion and the high melodrama and, although it recognizes the common one, never becomes this way. And it beautifully communicates the essential madness of all inclusive and integrated subcultures. (The constant exhortations of the old guard so that the hero does not indulge in "movements pleasing to the crowd" are hilariously absurd and at the same time totally typical of such subcultures, where the most sensible question is always "Who on earth made these above these rules! ``) It\'s a strange and intense movie, which contantly you unbalance, and wondering whether to take it seriously or as an elaborate type of dream comedy filmed (think of Rocky Horror Show photo). is that you never have to decide, you can enjoy new aspects in several views.'

b"Ridley Scott's alien must be considered one of the best thrillers ever placed on celluloid. He is at the top with films like Hitchcock's Psycho and Tod Browning's Dracula (1931). Alien is basically a haunted classic movie, but instead of an old and scary Victorian mansion, we have a dirty old space freighter and the endless darkness of space. The stranger rises above his credentials in movie B - - this movie is actually a B movie in the heart - with a very tense and clever script, and exceptional direction by Ridley Scott. From the long opening sequence of the Nostromo filling the screen, audiences know they will be treated to an exceptionally filmed film. Ridley Scott has always been known for his art direction and the biomechanical appearance of the scenarios in Alien helps to heighten the sense of dread and horror. This helps that Scott and his team decided to hire the famous Swiss surrealist H.R. Giger to project the appearance of sets and creatures. Anyone who has seen Giger's work can easily see his influence on the scenario for the Alien. Giger's final design for the main creature will be one of the best creations in movie history. So far, everyone knows what to imagine when someone mentions the words Alien and films together. The group of actors chosen for the film is excellent from top to bottom. Tom Skerritt's Capt. Dallas is a solid base upon which the rest of the characters revolve around. The slow descent of Veronica Cartwright's character to hysteria - fully suited to the situation with which she and the rest of her teammates are confronted - is like a barometer for the growing fear that permeates the entire film from beginning to end. . The highlight of the cast has to be Sigourney Weaver. The fact that this was her first major role in the movies bodes well for what the public could expect of her as her career exploded. His character of Lieutenant Ellen Ripley is practically the antithesis of Cartwright's Lambert. Where Lambert slowly descended into a paralyzing hysteria, Ripley slowly took control of the situation and became the de facto leader after Dallas. The overall tone of the film owes much to the past scifi horror / thrillers. But instead of constant scares and red handcuffs, Scott slowly increased the tension and feared with long, slow strokes of empty hallways and cargo holds. For a movie that is considered one of the best horror movies ever made, Alien does not have many dark areas where the monster suddenly jumps. The monster will jump from well-lit and spacious areas. Scott also used Spielberg's trick to prevent the monster creature from appearing on the screen for just a few quick glimpses. It's not until near the end that we see the Alien creature of Giger in all its glory. This newest of the many editions of Alien DVD has finally come with re-edited scenes that add more shock and horror to the film. I have to agree with Scott's reasoning to exclude themsevles scenes. It slows down the roller coaster, accelerating pace in the latter part of the film. But in the comfort of the home theater itself, these re-edited scenes are easier to understand. The original director's and director's movie look has been remastered and looks great, especially when viewed on a progressive scan DVD player and a dedicated widescreen HDTV. Sound and music also received a 4-star remastering treatment to make better use of home theater systems that are growing in number. The alien is the most superior entry in the Foreign Quadrilogy, although Aliens is a more exciting film. Alien takes the horror scifi genre and sets a standard that many still need to achieve today."

b'The latest assault committed by a professional thief and his team goes terribly wrong, and the clean plan organizer gets more than he expected. Agents and mobsters chase after him, but he keeps his cool under pressure, thwarts the other party\'s plans, and can always get rid of the mud. This is a standard story format for the action movie. It looks clich\xc3\xa9. d predictable, but works well with good pace in action and the director\'s safe guidance. But `` 7 Seconds \'\' does not have them. Wesley Snipes plays the thief named Jack. Jack\'s unsuccessful robbery in Bucharest, Romania, leads to a new problem because his girlfriend / partner in the crime is abducted during the shootings. He holds a hostage by a NATO military police officer (Tamzin Outhwaite after his British accent) after the chaos (and saving her life too), and engages in the pursuit of urban cars with family scenarios. The story does not make much sense (why steal money from casinos in Romania?), But the earlier part of "7 Seconds" is fun with decent stunts on cars and a bit of humor. The actions are confusing, and you do not know where those cars are going, but at least the acrobatics themselves are not bad. Then in the middle part of the movie, boredom sets in, which interrupts the actions and begins to introduce superfluous characters, as well as an unnecessary plot or twist. We do not need to see Wesley Snipes walking in the station and putting a briefcase in the coin cabinet there. Or, in fact, we do not care what the folder actually contains; and we do not even want to know if anything in it (whatever it is) is real or not. We want excitement and action, or funny dialogues. Except for a few brief martial arts acrobatics and slightly amusing jokes between Snipes and Outhwaite, "7 Seconds" does not have much to show, particularly in its second part where the movie has another stunt sequence involving street cars but is hampered by unstable editing. We often hear complaints or criticisms about direct films, but in fact some of them are very good, offering 90 minutes like the films of Jean-Claude Van Damme and Dolph Lundgren. Unfortunately, despite all the good acting of the stars, "7 Seconds" by Wesley Snipes is not one of them.'

b'The Crucible, based on Arthur Miller\'s play, is a fun, though not always accurate, version of the 1692 events in Salem Village. Having read numerous books on the subject, I still can not say with certainty what led to the events that so many men and women were accused of witchcraft and so many young girls seemed to be afflicted. It may be questioned why it was only the Salem females, and not the males that seemed afflicted with shouting, catatonic states, hallucinations, etc ... Anyway, one conclusion I could not draw was that of a despised woman in this Case Abigail Williams played for Winona Ryder whose advances are declined by the married John Proctor (Daniel Day Lewis). The Proctors are also much younger in the film than in real life. John was sixty when he was hanged. Elizabeth would be in her forties at the time of the trials. Pregnancy saved her from hangman\'s tie. The film retains a good deal of precision in the treatment of the Tituba slave and her part anyway, as well as the accusations against some of the "trouble-makers" cities such as Good Nurse and Giles Corey who was pressed to death for refusing to witness. The courtroom scenes were the most dynamic and exciting, and brought to the attention those period paintings from old books, depicting trials with stern and puritan judges pointing to accusing fingers. The film also did a good job capturing that stifling and repressive scenario of the seventeenth century and the costumes were first-rate. The best performances for me came from those men who played the various ministers and judges, particularly Bruce Davison as Reverend Parris and Paul Scofield as Judge. Danforth. Although not a totally accurate film, it still does a good job of capturing one of the seminal events in American history. Reviewed by Tim Janson'

b'This movie starts quickly and quickly immerses the viewer into a very strange world, with dialogue and action that accelerates, hindering the accompaniment. The important thing is to stay there and the pieces will start to fit together. The film is based on a novel by Philip K. Dick, who is known for his highly original imagination and who came up with ideas for stories unlike any other person. This is one more of those original stories and takes the viewer to a wild ride. Fortunately, the pieces begin to fit together and do so with the dramatic use of the surround speakers and plenty of onscreen action. The basic premise of the film is a technology developed that allows the visualization of a crime before it actually happens so that the police can intervene and stop the crime before it occurs. Just as this crime prevention system is ready to happen all over the country, something happens and changes everything. The character of Tom Cruise, a police officer named John Anderton, is suddenly plunged into a situation that threatens his own life. He must now use the crime prevention system called Precrime to discover the truth and find out who is out to frame it. His quest for truth provides the basis for this exciting action movie. I encourage the viewer to give the film a chance because, although it may seem confusing at first, it quickly turns into a good science fiction movie.'

b'Some people in Germany have accused this film of trying to "make harmless" the crimes of the Third Reich. This could not be further from the truth, and I will explain why. Bruno Ganz plays Hitler as the man. Hitler, the man who loves his dog, who is cool to his secretary, who loves his friends and spits on the people he thinks betray him, who tells those he cares about saving himself as he prepares to take cyanide, if kill and then be burned. This is a guy who, as long as he is not talking about the Jews or the domination of the world, would not be so difficult to live with. WHO, this is still Hitler\'s monster. Being vegetarian does not exempt you from being directly responsible for the deaths of millions or for launching the whole world into war. Hitler, the two-dimensional monster, is inseparable from Hitler, the three-dimensional man, and that\'s what this movie reminds us every time it makes you feel sorry for him, even though he knows, and the movie recalls, that he was a monster. All the monsters in history - past, present and future - have been and are and will be human beings. We liked to imagine Hitler as a kind of inhuman monster, but he was only human. Very human. That\'s why this movie makes people uncomfortable; it reminds them that any leader of men who looks like a good companion can become a monster if the right questions are never asked or if ideas are never questioned. The warning is uncomfortable: you can not trust any ideologue about face value. Not one single, ever. And / or / is the real import of this movie, if `` Never Again \'\' is to have some kind of real. that is, next to a slogan. If I were a history teacher, I would show this film followed by Schindler \'s / List. Both are equally true and equally important sides of history: all this horror is of simple human beings born.'

b'I was and still am a faithful fan of Xena and Gabrielle. Let me remind those who liked the end of something. Real life is full of sadness, misery, loss and tragedy. We watch TV and movies to escape reality. Xena was a tragic figure early in her life. She killed for little or no reason. But she saw that she was wrong. She changed her ways and fought for justice. There is no way to bring the dead back to life. But Xena repented and dedicated her life to fighting for good. She risked her life many times to save the lives of countless others. (Let the sinless cast the first stone) We need a heroine like Xena. We want to see that "white hats" win and the bad ones of "black hats" lose. I know that reality does not work that many times. But Xena was different. She is special. I think it\'s more difficult, very tragic and pathetic that Xena has to die. And if dying was not enough, decapitating it made my stomach turn. I own the whole series. But I will never, ever watch the last episode again. I gave it two stars because Xena\'s tragic and unnecessary death puts a stain on the entire series.'

b"This is the greatest SPACE movie of all time, without any reasonable doubt. Tom Hanks, Kevin Bacon, Bill Paxton, Gary Sinise, Ed Harris and Kathleen Quinlan give superb performances. I really like the way they were able to make an exciting old story without having much dramatic license. This movie really makes you feel like you're with Jim Lovell, Fred Haise and Jack Swigert in their desperate battle to stay alive in their crippled spaceship 200,000 miles away, or with Lovell's wife and family as they sit close and wait for the best, or with Gene Kranz and other members of the mission control team struggling to bring them back home. This is still the best Ron Howard film as director. Anyone who wants to see a historical adventure movie should look no further than APOLLO 13. It will make you feel good, trust me! Note: A +"

b"From the myriad interpretations of this game I've seen on stage and screen, this is the best - a strong statement, considering the many excellent actors who have been drawn to powerful characters from Tennessee Williams (eg, Katherine Hepburn and Sam Waterston). John Malkovich seems to have been born to play Tom, the artist divided between family duties and desire to travel. The intense and percussive style of Malkovich is an ideal combination for the play of Williams, in which the text and its poetry dominate. His performance in this role is the most convincing of all I have ever seen, and he avoids the trap of allowing Tom to become too grumpy and selfish. Joanne Woodward is also perfect as Amanda, who, though deluded, narrow and even moronic, keeps her family together for her unique blend of courage and despair. Karen Allen and James Naughton also capture what I think Williams must have intended in the characters Laura Wingfield and the caller sirs, and the two generate real chemistry in the crucial scene with the glass unicorn. This is a must see for anyone interested in American theater."

b"The wooden box is a bit mushy, but it is the most important thing, and what is inside this wooden box is indispensable for all serious Morse fans. Kevin Whately, as the often naive and naive Lewis, is the perfect contrast to Morse's intellect and love of culture. The individual plots offer the usual plot of twists, twists and red jokes in order to keep you guessing, but the stories are not pretentious in their complexity. If you like solid detective dramas with a good dose of English culture, then this series is in its alley."

b'This is an excellent film in German (with English subtitles). The attempt is precisely to show the final days of the Third Reich through the eyes of the young secretary of Hitler, Traudl Junge. Bruno Ganz (a Swiss-born actor) makes an excellent rendition of the rampant Hitler - not a parody - but a very realistic interpretation of the megalomaniac who lives in a dream world of ghostly divisions of the army as the reign of "a thousand years" crumbles Eu I recommend for historical accuracy and excellent performance.'

b"It looks like good movies inspire remakes. As to whether they are & quot; inspired & quot; remakes are always open to questioning. Both versions of The Italian Job have unique features that make them interesting but for sheer acting and fun (with the exception of Ed Norton in the remake, which looks like he's stuck in a movie he does not like), 1969. s The Job Italian is my personal choice of the two. Mark Wahlberg can not hold a candle (and not a very frank actor) to Michael Caine in the original film. There are almost so many things that make this classic movie work like there are seconds on a clock. The plot focuses more on escape than the caper. This unique twist turned the shape on his head. The fantastic cast (including the late Noel Coward in his last screen appearance and, among all, Benny Hill!) Features the wonderful Michael Caine in the lead. He gives a great performance and helps the group prepare for the occasion. The late Peter Collinson directs with energy and intelligence bringing to life what might have been, despite his twists in the plot, a routine film. Collinson is a kind of cult director who died relatively young before fulfilling his promise as a director. I would also recommend his classic psychological thriller Straight On Till Morning, which became available last year on DVD. Although hampered by some visual and editorial conventions of the mid-1970s, Morning has more than her own with the explosion films of the time. The movie set-up is a track of comments that features the original producer of the film as well as number of enjoyable extras. It's great to have this secondary classic finally restored in its proper proportion. The transfer of the DVD is very good and although the print quality varies a bit, it is really good overall."

b'This is not the version of Christopher Reeve\'s Superman that we know and love, but it comes very close. What I liked most about this version of Superman is the deeper relationship between Lois Lane and Superman and how she\'s real. For me, HISTORY should be just as important as the "cool" graphics, and Singer Blind here. Lois Lane is Superman\'s love for her life, just as Lois\' ... the two are inseparable. Although it is gone and Lois moves to another man, love is definitely still there. So, of course, there\'s the ongoing battle between Lex Luthor and Superman, so it\'s like having two great stories in one movie! There is emotional chemistry in this film that is undeniable. You can really feel what superman is going through throughout the movie, both good and bad. I must have seen this movie 5 times since its release ... I give the director / writer Bryan Singer a big push for an engaging, emotional, well-written story.'

b'Director Jon Reiss and producer Tracy Wares take us on a graffiti world tour in "Bomb It". The film is more favorable to graphite than against it, but interviews individuals whose mission is to rid graffiti and graffiti quarters on 4 continents. There is a chain that questions who should decide what we look at in public spaces, a provocative question, but it is not really the focus of the film. "Bomb It" covers much of the history and scope of graffiti art, but with good results, since we are able to see that graffiti artists are not all the same. Graphite has evolved over time, and its purpose is different in different cultures and subcultures. "Bomb It" begins by interviewing Cornbread, a Philadelphia whose campaign to mark everything with his nickname in 1967 can make him the first modern graffiti artist. The film avoids the "who did what is first" debate, but follows the progression from simple marking to more elaborate lyrics that have led to the transformation of graffiti from a subclass counterculture movement to one that encompasses a broader artistic movement. New York graffiti artists in the 1970s and 1980s talk about their exploits before the city began to aggressively clean up graffiti on public property. Other cities whose artists are presented are: Paris, France; Amsterdam, The Netherlands; London, United Kingdom ; Berlin, Germany ; Barcelona, \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bSpain; Cape Town, South Africa; S\xc3\xa3o Paulo Brazil ; Tokyo, Japan ; and Los Angeles, USA. I always thought of graffiti as a frustrated, energetic, but mostly irresponsible youth medium that attacked what they perceived as the status quo. Now I\'ve learned that graffiti has different meanings in different cultures. In South Africa, graphite was a tool for political change. In Los Angeles, he is part of the Chicano movement and has taken the trap of a lifestyle in some sectors. In some cultures, the emphasis is more on putting works of art in public spaces than in counter-culture. Not surprisingly, these artists have a less contradictory relationship with communities and the law. The fact is that graffiti and vandalism have a profound effect on the rate of more serious crimes. And many of the artists interviewed are faced with extremely important people who inflict their spleen on others because their lives are not as they would like. On the other hand, it can not be denied that graphite is sometimes an improvement over discouraged, decadent buildings, or that artists are talented, or that some of the opponents of graphite are politically philistine. "Bomb It" provides an introduction to graffiti and its controversies, showing us the art, ideas and differences of opinion. The DVD (Docurama 2008): There are 3 featurettes and a feature commentary. In `` Behind the Scenes \'\' (14 min), director Jon Reiss talks about the genesis of the project, filming in different countries, setting the film and some themes. "Extended Time Lapse Sequences" (15 min) are 3 sequences, 5 minutes each in England, Brazil and Japan, where we can watch the art being created in an accelerated time. There are also "Extended Interviews" (26 min). The audio commentary by director Jon Reiss and producer Tracy Wares is constant and informative. They talk about what they did and did not include in the film, their intentions and more details about who and what we are seeing.'

b"Well, if you did not see it, you're in for something great. This is one of the funniest movies ever made - certainly abbot and best cost, and that's no small thing. Often imitated, never duplicated."

b"You will not regret ! If I had known how fun and clever this movie was, I would have taken my son to see when he was at the movies. b'For the plot outline, see the back of the DVD box: "Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) is a private investigator specializing in unexplained supernatural phenomena. Their cases plunge into the dark corners of the world, seeking the truth in the hidden remnants of ancient civilizations. Now the greatest mystery of his past is about to become the most dangerous case he has ever faced. With the help of his ex-girlfriend, archaeologist Aline Cedrac (Tara Reid), and his bitter rival, government agent Richard Burke (Stephen Dorff), Edward is about to learn this just because you do not believe in something that does not . t means it can not kill you! "According to the character of Carnby, the fear of the dark is what keeps us alive. Unfortunately, however, the fear of bad movies does not stop us from renting them. Despite the awful reviews, I decided to give in to the temptation to rent Alone In The Dark (I had a free lease, so I figured there could not be much loss). It was even worse than I expected ... On the one hand, creatures that are released from the depths of darkness - or whatever the clich\xc3\xa9 of horse feces is scattered throughout history - are pathetic CGI dinosaurs. Anything interesting, scary or just "cool" about them? Do not . Only nonsense computer-generated monsters that can not entertain the public in the simplest way. For two, the acting is horrendous. Seeing Tara Reid on the DVD\'s top credits made me roll my eyes, but seeing her trying to act as an archaeologist in a science fiction movie made me laugh. The only decent performance midway is given by Christian Slater, but still not enough to cover up the rest. And for three, the film is terribly boring, with few action scenes. Oh, of course, some unknown bumps here and there, some creatures flashing on the screen, and a little blood is included. But the real action? Very little . The small amounts of action he did include the reason why I gave this stinker two stars. I hate watching a movie suffer, but this one deserves it. In conclusion, do not make the same mistakes that most of these reviewers did by renting the movie, knowing how awful it should be. Just rely on the ratings of this one. You will save your money and your time.'

b"I bought this because I'm a big fan of cowboys and I thought it would be fun to learn some of the DCC routines. I also found that some of the girls' voices were particularly annoying. I did not feel energized or as if I had burned any calories. All in all, this product was a big disappointment to me."
