b"I can not tell a joke well. A bad joke is not funny, no matter who says it, but a person like me can make a bad joke. A story also needs to be told well and, in the case of a movie, filmed well, to be interesting. The problem with AntiTrust is that it is a tale that is not counted or filmed very well. It is lovely to look at, but it has no electricity or soul. Milo [Ryan Phillippe] is a computer genius. Outside of college, he plans to start a business with some friends out of a garage, just as his computer heroes did twenty years ago. They plan to make their mark on cyberspace. One day, seemingly out of nowhere, Milo and his best friend are approached by Gary Winston [Tim Robbins], who wants them to come and work for their giant multinational company. It seems that Winston is about to launch a computer program that will revolutionize communications, but he needs some good geeks to get him up and running. The friend, a wise young man, decides to keep his original plan, but Milo is sucked. Along with his girlfriend Alice [Claire Forlani], he packs up and moves to Portland, Oregon, home to the Nurve Corporation of Winston. It will not be long until Milo suspects that Winston will literally kill to get what he wants. Advances in the programming of the new product always seem to happen soon after the mysterious death of some brilliant programmer. One of the problems of the film is with part of the cast. Tim Robbins is just like Winston, making him look and act as much as Bill Gates which is a bit scary. Ryan Phillippe, however, I can not buy like any kind of genius. He has done a good job in the past, playing roles as a sociopath [Cruel Intentions], a psychopath [The Way of the Gun] and a party-goer [54]. But a computer whiz? I think not . Rachael Lee Cook is just as unbelievable as Lisa, a fellow programmer. Claire Forlani, who may be a star soon, is just as Alice is but a part that is below her capabilities. AntiTrust belongs to the paranoid suspense genre. This is the only one in which only the hero has discovered a diabolical plot. By the end of the movie, the rest of the characters are almost always blind to the truth and tend to believe that the hero is simply stressed. Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window is a classic example of this type of film. To succeed, the film must make the audience care for the protagonist. Must relate to him. This does not happen in AntiTrust. Milo is simply insipid and lame to keep our interest. It's one of those cases where, if we relate to anyone, it's for the villain, Winston. At least he's insightful and somehow humorous. You know a movie is in trouble when we start cheering on the villain."

b'This is a very well made and well filmed sequence. The opening sequence and the sequels with the sniper firing indiscriminately at the fleeing crowd were very memorable and well executed. However, I was completely undecided about how simple it was for the father to access his wife, who should be in some sort of quarantine. I know there are often lapses in logic and suspensions of disbelief in many movies and I am guilty of succumbing to some of them. But this was very glaring to me. By crying out loud, either the US Army was completely incompetent or the filmmakers did not think it would be so glaring to the public. Who in good conscience does not put the mother in quarantine with at least one guard at the door, let alone a nurse or a technician monitoring it? ? ? ? ? ? Instead, the installation was deserted. It was too simple for her father to access it with a pass card or not. If a person were still alive 28 weeks later without symptoms in a quarantine zone in the real world, that person would be locked and the video monitored 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, if not weeks, because they want to know how she survived and as she was "immune" to this virus. Such precautions would never be taken lightly, especially when you are dealing with a virus that has nearly wiped out a whole country! If they did not have strict protocals, we would have been eliminated like a race a long time ago. The suspension of disbelief in this film really prevented me from enjoying a movie well done.'

b'Clint Eastwood takes on the role of director and actor here, starring Walt Kowalski, an old grumpy racist who changes his mind in "Gran Torino." Walt\'s journey is just one of several that make up the film. It begins with the funeral of Walt\'s beloved wife, whom we never see, but somehow meet a kinder soul than Walt, and probably a positive influence in that it keeps his most unpleasant character traits at bay. In the days after the funeral, we see Walt alone and bitter, estranged from the rest of his family and seemingly unable to make emotional connections. One of the things that make it so bitter is that its neighborhood is becoming more and more Asian. North America is changing, and places that were once almost exclusively white are now more multi-racial or, in some cases, dominated by a particular ethnic group. This neighborhood has a growing number of Hmong (a Southeast Asian ethnic group), and it is safe to say that Walt was not too happy to see its increasing numbers over the years. At the beginning of the film, he is a racist, not just "old and defined in his ways", not just "narrow-minded" but also racist. The fact that the film does not try to sugarcoat makes the character transformation much more powerful. There are two main interpersonal \'pulls\' in the film - one is Walt being pulled against his will to the fabric of the neighborhood, the other is a Hmong kid of about 15 (I estimate), Thao (Bee Vang) - Walt is the neighbor on the side - being pulled against his will to a street gang dominated by Hmong. He is the cousin of one of the gang\'s bosses, and therefore, as the gang expands more and more from its traditional strongholds to the suburbs, Thao is invited to participate. In the classic gang style, it\'s an offer he can not refuse. Then, little by little, he is being sucked into that lifestyle he wants very much to avoid, but he seems powerless for that. His feat of initiation in the gang is stealing the classic car of the neighbor Walt, Gran Torino. When he is caught red-handed and the other members flee, his family decides that his punishment is to \'help\' Walt with yard work, housekeeping, etc. for a short time, as atonement. Walt is not interested and refuses the deal, but Thao is forced to try to make amends anyway. Shortly thereafter, an incident occurs in the neighborhood involving the gang, and Walt becomes the neighborhood hero by expelling some gang members. To Walt\'s horror, this seems to encourage the neighborhood\'s Hmong community to "adopt" him, arriving with gifts, baskets and food, always saluting him warmly, apparently oblivious to the fact that Walt does not like them much. . Of course, despite his hostility toward Asians, he never met anyone outside of his experiences in the Korean War where they were on opposite sides (he seems to have many memories of Koreans as enemies, but few of the South Koreans as allies on your side). As he is involuntarily drawn to the community, his feelings towards his Hmong neighbors slowly begin to change ... This may sound clich\xc3\xa9d or artificial, but absolutely nothing in the movie comes out that way. Each characterization and interaction - good or bad - seems very genuine. During this time, we see Walt trying and not reestablishing some kind of connection with his biological family; we also see him very shocked at himself for being so close to his \'new\' family, particularly Thao and his older sister Sue (Ahney Her), for whom he seems to be filling some sort of uncle. paternal role Meanwhile, the other pull is still happening - the gang\'s determination to recruit Thao, apparently motivated mainly by the fact that they are offended at the idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bsomeone refusing them. Thao is increasingly determined not to follow this path, but this seems only to make the gang more insistent. Gran Torino gives a good picture of the hard place that someone like Thao is when he is targeted for recruiting like this by a gang who can do anything if he does not agree with them. It\'s a situation your family sees, and that Walt also recognizes. The film becomes extremely intense in its final stages, building a tremendously powerful end. What is most unexpected is all the humor and, for want of a better word, "heat" that starts to get in about a third of the way. These elements do not clash with tension, but provide a counterpoint. And, as we see in the film, things can go from very "happy" to very, very somber. The ability to deal with seemingly disparate tones and universally excellent performances helps make Gran Torino a great movie at all levels. For a skillful blend of drama, tenderness and vicious suspense, you can not go better than this.'

b"This movie is mandatory - one that you can watch at least once a year. It's fun with great performances by Sig Weaver and Melanie Griffith. Although Melanie is a very average actress, her style works in this film. The type of character required, that is. Ditzy blonde, meant that she could be herself really. Also, your baby voice works for the role. Working Girl is a beauty comedy focused on an unlikely rise to the top, but when you think about it carefully, it shows that anyone can get anywhere, if you have determination and courage. This is a good message to convey, I feel. Working Girl might have made Melanie a big star, but she did not open the doors she thought it would be. She may have gotten more roles after that, but none of them were worth watching! I mean failures like Bonfire Vanities, Stormy Monday (simple, of course!), Shining Through, and one with ex-husband Don Johnson - the title escapes me. I think Melanie's inability to get rid of that baby voice really killed her career."

b'I think this is a horrible video. The first 57 minutes teaches things like: - what is vibrato - how to do hammer ons, pull offs, trills - A (G) major arpeggio (it plays - with no explanation as the root, then the 3rd, then the 5th, now I repeat it "or something like that, he just plays an arpeggio.) Big-boosted and chordless chords (he plays them with very little explanation other than one has a fifth plane and the other has a fifth stratified - no. he says that if you want to know more you should go buy a book!) -A George Van Eps lickOK, here\'s the thing ... These are all EXTREMELY BASIC.These are things that anyone who plays guitar there is more than one year or two should already know, most of the time.Maybe not in and out, but he does not teach in & for most of the above, he gives only one example with very little explanation. Gypsy jazz.Oh, but in the last 2 or 3 minutes he plays a Gyps jazz song He could have picked up exactly the same video and played a song from Yngwie Malmsteen at the end and called the video & quot; neoclassical flooring & quot; and would have been exactly like & quot; valid & quot; like calling it a gypsy jazz video! Now, I imagine someone who wants to join Gypsy Jazz already knows how to make hammers and pull them out. If they do not, they need to continue practicing for many years before attempting to tackle gypsy jazz. So who is this video for? Paul Mehling really know? There is no theory in this video at all. ANYTHING ! He does not tell you when to touch the scales and trills, etc. what it shows you, or how they relate to the chords, or anything. There is no rhythmic placement examination of notes when solos (that would be the SWING part of the guitar swing gypsy). There is no examination of which scales django prefers on which chords, none of that. Here are some basic techniques that any beginning guitar student should know, now see me playing a Django song without any explanation. & quot; There is no dissection or ripping of the Djangos style, as suggested by another reviewer. Nothing like that. Nor is it a primer on jazz improvisation in my opinion. The sad thing is that this video could have been so much more. Paul is obviously an excellent player and knows the style. He does not teach well though. There are many excellent guitarists who are not good teachers. Paul seems to be one of these. Someone should tell him! I am now going to eBay to sell my video to someone else. I HIGHLY recommend to anyone else who wants to get into that style on the hotclub site to get some basic information about the class, and the book by Stan Ayeroff & quot; The Music of Django Reinhardt 44 classic solos of the legendary guitarist with a thorough review & quot; Pub MelBay, ISBN: 0-7866-3388-3'

b'I was already using Jillian\'s `` 30 Day Shred \'\' DVD and wanted to change my routine. A friend told me about `` No More Trouble Zones \'\' and I decided to give it a try. NMTZ is definitely more difficult than 30 days of destruction! I like the variety of movements and that this workout requires more repetitions with lighter weights. It\'s also cool to be able to choose to play the entire exercise or select different segments from the menu. Each segment is about 5 to 7 minutes long and focuses on certain areas such as abs / chest or core. The biggest downside for me is that I\'ve been using this DVD 2-3 times a week for about a month, and I have not seen a noticeable difference in my "trouble spots." I\'m already in very good shape - I also run 3-4 times a week and I\'m careful with what I eat - but I was hoping that this workout would help me steady a little more. I will continue like this! I would also warn you that if you prefer a lower impact workout and no sweat, this DVD is not for you. When Jillian says "you should feel like you\'re going to die," she means ...'

"That\'s Rock And Roll, folks.'

b'I vaguely remember the game in which this movie was titled and was a fan of some of the old films of Christian Slater, so even after knowing that it was a horrible movie, I decided to rent it. Unfortunately, this movie was not fun in any way, form or form. Christian Slater is a good actor and the film seemed to have a decent budget for the creatures, which were very lively, but beyond these two points, this film did not even qualify for a direct channel for Sci-Fi. \'\' launch . There was no fun in this movie. The story made no sense at all, the supporting actors were very tough and none of the characters seemed to care about any of the other characters. At one point in the movie, Christian Slater mentions "I just killed my friend," just as you would say, "I just poured my coffee into a smeared pants I was about to throw away." . I think I could summarize the whole movie. The actors did not seem to care, the director did not seem to care, the editors did not seem to care, in fact the only prople that actually seemed to do decent work in the middle of the way were the entertainers who cheered the audience. After watching this movie I felt very sad for Christian Slater. Your career must be completely over now. I\'m depressed . Time to watch Madagascar and cheer up.'

b'As a parent, I really enjoy watching Thomas shows and movies. I prefer trains and Thomas is the standard for children\'s train movies. However, this film is a dramatic drift and has a thoughtless storyline decorated with absurdity. In short, Thomas accidentally descends to an island five miles off the coast of Brendam. Despite the FIVE MILE submarine tunnel linking Sodor to Misty Island and the proximity to the coast, none of them have seen Misty Island. Thomas meets new trains on the misty island (Dash, Bash and Ferdinand) who were sent into exile on the island for not being really useful and together work hard to exploit an endangered tree to build a rescue station. Everything works out in the end, but they waste valuable time in history, for logistical reasons, to find some of the people who were out finding Thomas before he rescues himself (if that makes sense). It must have at least made sense to the writers that this was a horrible story. Also introduced in this story is the captain (a boat) who is the only one who has an English accent as all the people who frequent the sea have English accents. Finally, Hit Entertainment, which brings together the films of Thomas, makes the film another logistical challenge, removing the function of the menu button, thus avoiding the previous ones, it is only possible to press the "jump" button a million times. I thought I was paying for the non-Hit Kingdom free movies to suffocate my son with previews of his other products.'

b"I really hoped that MLB & A & E would have learned from the 2004 experience that fans want the full set of games, including ALDS games. Instead, they give us a more incomplete product! This set does not include ALDS games 1 to 4. We lost the first game - a Beckett gem. And the excitement of games 2 to 4, when Cleveland proved they were real contenders! And while the 2004 set did not have the 3 ALDS games against the Angels, at least it was produced in HD. This set of World Series has been rushed to the market, so much that it is not in HD or widescreen, which are virtually automatic on all DVDs today. While I appreciate MLB's effort to get a product on time for the holidays, I really wish they would have postponed the offer until the entire post-season game series could be made available on 1 set - with all the advantages!"

b'We are a family of three generations of Mary Poppins. I saw it when I was a child - when it came up, I grew up with the MP books and repeated views of Mary Poppins. I ordered the VCR tape about 20 years ago at a premium price. I\'m still using it. My 3 children grew up with Mary Poppins, learning each line for the songs and script. They played "Mary Poppins". b'I bought this DVD because I was impressed by Ghislaine Thesmar\'s commentary on the documentary "Etoiles" about the Paris Opera Ballet, but I had never seen her dance. b'The third season had new directors and new writers. Only one episode was written by a returning writer. This seems to have completely changed the tone of the program. Seasons one and two are science fiction, the third season seems to have more resemblance to Gilligan\'s Island or Lost in Space. The approach seems to be to play on any fantastic character that writers could think of, regardless of how stupid or out of place. The third season features Medusa, a caveman, flying Dutchman, abominable snowman, a fire-breathing dinosaur, a two-headed dinosaur and a beetle whose bite makes you sick! Logic, continuity and characterization go out the window. Sleestak and Chaka talk, Enik does stupid things in the name of "logic." The only thing better this season is the acting. The only reason to watch this season is if you want to see all the episodes to complete. If you liked the first two seasons, you probably will not like it.'

b"After being greatly disappointed by Spirited Killer, I set my expectations much lower for this movie. Unfortunately, it's even worse than the Spirited Killer. The story is not worth going over. Basically, there's a guy who knows where a valuable stone is. An evil general and his men want the stone and are trying to get it. There is also a group of good guys trying to find the guy who knows where the stone is. This is the story. Tony Jaa plays one of the bad guys and looks very well in his two fight scenes, but all the other fights are very bad. Some of the acrobatics are good, but not on par with most of the other Panna Rittikrai films. The good guys have a Rambo guy on their side and he drags the movie because his moves are very slow. But overall the main reason for this movie being so bad is because there are not many fights. I can handle a bad story as long as the fights are good, but this movie does not predict that. Even the grand finale is not worth staying around. There are some decent blasts, but nothing to get excited about. This movie really makes you appreciate how much effort has been put into 2 Panna Born to Fight movies. The picture quality is surprisingly good (good, good for Videoasia). There is a HORRIBLE dubbing track in English, but fortunately there is also an original language track and subtitles. The only reason this 2 disc DVD gets more than 1 star is because of the special features.4 Minute interview with Tony Jaa talking about Tom Yum Goong. No new information here but while he is talking they show a very cool demonstration he did on some TV show.6 minute interview with Jaa talking about his inspiration to get into movies and some other interesting topics.10 minute interview in some comedy Thai TV show with Prachya Pinkaew, Jaa, Panna and Petchtai Wongkamlao. Demonstration and interview slightly fun.5 minutes Jaa did in Hong Kong. And there are some good action scenes mixed up in the interview.3 Tony Jaa interview. It looks like they're just trying to stack the special features with this. The only thing to talk about is a 1 minute demonstration that they show at the end of the interview. Last but not least, it's an interview with Christoph Kluppel, who is a great face of German Rambo who stars in Battle Warrior. He talks about his film career. I suppose that would be interesting if I were a fan of him."

b'The "Prisoner of Zenda" of 1922 is surely one of the best silent movies ever made. Its main actors knew better than to exaggerate and, obviously, had a very competent director in Rex Ingram. Even if the plot, the costumes and the scenario are taken from an operetta, the players generally appear natural, demonstrating that good acting was not something that somehow emerged with the advent of sound. Even Ramon Navarro as the villainous Rupert of Hentzau shows up much more than just a cute face as he turns his role into a fun, animated tour. The tour begins at the mansion of Englishman Rudolph Rassendyll, the camera zeroing in on the eyes extremely handsome Lewis Stone, now a 43-year veteran who, in most other respects, looks like a fairly normal middle-aged man in good physical condition. But of course, there is nothing in common with Stone\'s histrionic talent, and he has all the charm that made him as dear as Judge Hardy, about 15 years later, in the Andy Hardy series. Rassendyll decides to attend the coronation of his cousin, Rudolph of Ruritania [whose twin brother he could be] and thinks his relative is a dissipated mess. Lewis Stone plays the two parts, needless to say. The feeble future king has an ambitious but evil brother, Duke Michael, who plans to take the throne for himself and kill Rudolph in the process. On the eve of the coronation, the duke causes his brother to be drugged, so that he is not in a position to attend the ceremony. Therefore, the king\'s legalists persuade the British Rassendyll to take their place for a day and prevent Michael from doing so. The Ruritarian Rudolph has a beautiful bride played by the luminous Alice Terry. The couple does not have much use for each other, but she is a popular princess that would serve to reinforce the unstable position of Rudolph. Meanwhile, Rassendyll and the lovely girl meet at the same time, and sensing an unexpected change in their intention, the princess no longer sees her role as the future queen as a simple duty. Of course, the plot thickens and there is another woman involved, played by the seductive but less natural actress, Barbara La Marr. Rudolph Rassendyll can not go to England after the coronation, but must continue to help rescue his cousin in extinction. There is a lot of skull and sword play as well. Everyone makes a fascinating movie and it\'s a great revelation to see how effective a younger, more corollous version of old Judge Hardy is in the love scenes. Very sexy! Probably not by chance that the actor who played the double role in the next "Prisoner of Zenda", Ronald Colman, looked a lot like Lewis Stone.'

b"When I first saw the trailer for & quot; From Hell & quot; I was understandably ecstatic. Based on the graphic novel of the same name, written by Alan Moore, I had high hopes for this. Judging from previous ones, it seemed the Hughes brothers could do it justice. But unfortunately, when the film adaptations of the books usually go, they massacred it. Let's start with the character of Johnny Depp, Inspector Abberline. They transform him from an honest, hard-working detective who slowly develops some feelings for a young prostitute, into an opium-addicted clairvoyant who falls madly in love with the prostitute mentioned (Heather Graham). And speaking of Heather Graham, could they have made a more horrible choice for a 19th-century prostitute? The other prostitutes in the movie look, well, as they should (ugly), but Graham stands out like a sore thumb. As for the story, this carnage is typical of the great Hollywood movies. The book focused on the character of Jack the Ripper, more than any other in history. In fact, it was revealed in Chapter 2! That was what made it so fascinating: the book entered the murderer's head and tried to explain the motivations for his murders, in addition to the obvious ones presented in the film. He deconstructed and analyzed a truly distorted mind and attempted to convey how, in Alan Moore's words, & quot; The human experience was to the limit ... then it went beyond & quot; . The movie transforms into a typical whodunit, keeping you guessing until it is revealed at the end. Anyway, I remember long enough. Watch the movie if you want - for pure entertainment, you'll probably enjoy it. But if you want a richly textured and fascinating, yet fictional, story about one of the most notorious serial killers of all time, read the book."

b'While "Singin \'in the Rain" of 1952 is definitely the most complete musical film, I think this 1949 classic seems to be the best that MGM produced during the golden age of Hollywood when the talents were at their peak. Co-directed by Gene Kelly and 25-year-old Stanley Donen in his directorial debut, the film has a consistently propulsive energy thanks mainly to the remarkable choreography of Kelly and Donen, the perfect blend of Leonard Bernstein\'s familiar music with the original compositions of the studio Roger Edens, and the pure effervescence of the artists. Written by the esteemed team of Betty Comden and Adolph Green, the frayed storyline is simply about three sailors - Gabey, Chip and Ozzie - on a 24-hour license. New York and the women they know and romance. Based on a subway poster, Gabey, a womanizer, falls in love with Miss Turnstiles and spends her time looking for her. Phobia Ozzie finds romance with Claire anthropology student, while Chip, who is timid, is focused on sightseeing, despite the persistent attentions of hilarious taxi driver Hildy. The closest that the story comes of dramatic tension lies in the misunderstandings around Miss Turnstiles, who is not the big celebrity who Gabey assumes she is just an aspiring ballerina named Ivy, who has to work at night as an exotic dancer in Coney Island. is obviously at its best when focused on musical sequences - beginning with the actual locations used for "New York, New York" in establishing the energetic arrival of sailors, continuing with the elaborate "Prehistoric Man" number at the Museum of Natural History and jumping through the title set of songs with all six directors singing and dancing descending from the top of the Empire State Building. Everyone has the chance to shine, though like Gabey, Gene Kelly clearly dominates with his graceful athletic ability. Like Chip, Frank Sinatra mostly overshadowed singing to Betty Garrett, who admirably contains her subtlety as Hildy. Though hardly credible as an academic type, Ann Miller starts beating impressively during `` Prehistoric Man \'\', and Jules with rubber-faced Munshin mainly provides comedic relief as Ozzie. When she dances instead of acting to deceive Gabey, Vera-Ellen dazzles like Ivy, of "Miss Turnstiles Ballet" loaded with fantasy, for her superb duets with Kelly on "Main Street" and "A Day in New York Ballet". \'. The only bitter note is the paternalistic attitude toward Hildy\'s strident roommate Lucy (played with good sense by the original Gladys Kravitz of "Bewitched", Alice Pearce). Harold Rosson\'s saturated color cinematography was maintained quite well in the transfer of print on the 2000 DVD, although the only extra is the theatrical trailer that is now being attacked.'

b'My expectation from this film was that it would be more or less a compilation and reinforcement of information I had gathered from seeing the "Fast Food Nation" eye film several years ago and having just finished reading the excellent books. `Animal, Vegetable Miracle \'and` `In Defense of Food\' \'among others. However, this movie is more than the sum of these books and that movie. Food Inc. is an extremely well-made documentary, in part because of the personal stories told by the interviewees as well as hidden camera images. I was especially impressed with what is happening to the farmers. The material is so well researched and presented. Various aspects of food production, marketing and consumption are covered. There is no "time out" in this movie, it\'s one hit after another. All the shocking and important information that citizens need to worry about. Congratulations to all involved in making this incredibly important film. Thank you to those who have stretched their necks to tell you the truth. Yes, it\'s disturbing, but you have to watch it.'

b"This review is for the DVD edition of the Criterion DVD. The original title of the movie in French is & quot; Du Rifiif Chez les Hommes & quot; which translates to & quot; Problems with men & quot; The movie is very good and it is about several men who plan to break into a jewelry store, open the safe and escape - all without triggering the alarm. Several of the scenes were imitated in other films: notably Mission Impossible and the remake of Italain Job. Many scenes are quite exciting and the break-in scene is very exciting. This half-hour scene also does not contain any dialogue, making it one of the longest if not the longest elapsed time, without dialogue in a dialogue film. This is definitely one of the best break-in movies I've seen and is certainly worthy of a release from Criterion Collection. There are also several special features. There is also an optional English soundtrack for those bothered by foreign languages \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bwith subtitles. Anyway, this is a movie that no fan of assault movies should miss!"

b'This is a dark, scary, mysterious film in which the writer has not gone far with the plot. This film, on the other hand, is just complex enough to make it intriguing, while still at the top of the realism index. As much as I have enjoyed this movie, I will say that Sean Connery is one of the main reasons. Without it, the movie would probably lose a star. This is one of your best performances. F. Murray Abraham is also at his best, as the incredibly evil inquisitor. Christian Slater is not bad. The other actors in the film seem to have been found at an itinerant freak show or they had the best make-up artist of all time. What a strange-looking bunch! The film does not outnumber the blood and portrays little violence. Torture and murder usually happen off-screen. The Catholic church definitely has a black eye here. All monks and clerics (in addition to Sean C.) are shown to be at least 3 of the following: evil, active, sexually active (heterosexual and gay) and generally very dumb. However, I like to think that much of this is due to the century (14) in which the mystery takes place and, therefore, things were much more primitive. Still, Catholics may be offended if they are no longer desensitized by all the other films portrayed by the Catholic clergy. The mystery itself is a good example that should keep you guessing. Sean Connery is the only logical person in the movie and he is your guide to the solution. I liked the movie, as I think most will. Just manage your expectations, because this is a good movie, but not one of the best.'

b'`` Elvis: That\'s The It It Is \'\' captures King Presley at an interesting crossroads in his career. With his true talents largely wasted after many years in Hollywood, Elvis was usurped as the "King of Rock and Roll" by names like The Beatles and The Rolling Stones. This documentary, filmed in the summer of 1970 as he prepared for an engagement at the International Hotel in Las Vegas, finds Elvis ready and in prime condition to reclaim his throne! The documentary shows him at 35, in shape and taste, and having a great time! To see Elvis having fun - this in itself is a joy! Elvis had a good sense of muscianship and his craft. He expected a lot from the people he worked with; and he knew exactly how to get the best of them all. It\'s obvious here that Elvis loved working with his band and back-up singers; and they loved working with him. Elvis made criticisms in a kind and funny way. When his band struggles with the Midway section of Bridge Over Troubled Water, Elvis comments, "If that\'s the way it is, that\'s the way it is, but we need not emphasize that. `` The very recording of the show proves that Elvis may well have been the hardest working man in show business. It also proves that Elvis had "him" - that undefinable, often indescribable X-Factor (or, in his case, factors) that marks the difference between an artist and a superstar. Elvis was a superstar with an uppercase "S" - possessing a potent combination of charisma, sex appeal, musicality and charisma. The charisma of Elvis, in particular, burns the stage enough. Elvis does everything he can to please his audience. During a long rendition of "Love Me Tender," he goes out into the audience, kissing so many women and shaking hands with as many men as possible. He sings a Greatest Hits Medley largely for laughter (changing the lyrics to "forget the past, before I kick his a ##"). In the middle of the show, Elvis is just getting started, featuring powerful interpretations of "In The Ghetto," "You Lost That Loving Feeling," and "Polk Salad Annie." "Its extended, over-loaded, and super-sweaty version of` `Suspicious Minds \'\' is likely to leave viewers as exhausted as Elvis in the end. As the final credits roll, we see Elvis greeting other celebrities after the performance. Sammy Davis, Jr., clearly admiringly observes, "Dude, you evaluated and you never stopped! "When he is congratulated for a wonderful show, Elvis responds modestly:" Well, it was a sweaty show. \'\' The DVD Special Edition includes two versions, but stay with the most recent Restored Edition and skip the original 1970\'s theatrical version. The theatrical version of 1970 has fan testimonials that are unnecessary. The restored version has more images of Elvis in action. `` Elvis: That\'s The It Is Is \'\' is the way Elvis should always be remembered!'

b'If you\'ve never seen a movie coming out, this is the one to pick. One of the most critically acclaimed gay movies is a sensitive, caring, sweet, sweet story with a great Mama Cass track. The film was also acclaimed for being a good representation of the working class in British society. The film directed by Hettie McDonald and based on the script of gay writer Jonathan Harvey portrays the relationships of people in a large housing complex located in East London (I was physically there). Especially for low-income Brits, the film revolves around three families, all broken homes. Ste, coming from an abusive father and a family of brothers; Jaime, a mother and a family of boyfriends; and Leah, a British Black girl with her mother. The story is the development of a gay love relationship between two boys, Ste (played by Scott Neal) and Jaime (played by Glenn Berry). Both live side by side. They are both 16 (also in real life to maintain accuracy). It is also the story of Leah, sometimes drug user, troubled, abandoned teenager. She is a catalyst with her obsession with Mama Cass, constantly singing her songs and making a lot of noise around the apartments. I read messages in this chat room about her without understanding why she is the movie. His character contributes to the grandeur of the film. He is beaten several times by his father and brother. He takes refuge in Jaime\'s house. Jaime\'s mother, Sandra (superbly played by Linda Henry). She loves Jaime a lot and left her husband because of physical abuse. She is a strong, nonsense, caring and loving woman who runs the local bar / club in this apartment complex. She feels sorry for Ste and takes him in. Ste has to sleep on Jaime\'s bed or on a couch. Then one thing leads to another, Jaime kissing Ste.There is a trip to a local gay bar, more kisses in the woods. Sandra learns that her son has lied to her about her love for Ste. She is told by the school principal that Jaime is being teased and called "fagot." \'\' And the film comes to the last moments. Playing Mama Cass music late at night as she was high and almost falling off the balcony of the building, and Ste discovering that Sandra knows about them. While Sandra has been offered a better job managing a pub in another area of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bEast London, she says goodbye to her boyfriend and prepares to go out at night with the girls. Ste, Jaime and Leah getting ready to go to the gay bar again. The final scenes of the film show Ste and Jaime dancing (with a hint of Mama Cass\'s music) in an open area of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bapartment buildings, while tenants gather to watch every thing, some in bustle. Sandra steps out onto the porch next to Leah, watching what was happening below. One of the best scenes I\'ve ever seen in a movie of any kind is the extension of Leah\'s hand to Sandra (the symbolism is so powerful). By the way, Sandra and Leah fight like dogs and cats throughout the film, they mend in the closing moments. Both joined Ste and Jaime in the dance, and Sandra finally accepts the sexuality of her son. This is a very powerful film and the title is very appropriate. Both Glenn and Scott claimed in interviews that they received thousands of letters after the movie asking if they were gay. Glenn disappeared from the screen and Scott did some small things. The language is difficult to understand at times. There are websites with the slang dictionary used by the working class in Britain. Someone put a script for a sequel on the Internet, it\'s very good. This is a "great"'

b'They do not do that anymore. This is really despicable. In fact, sex far outstrips violence. And the many sex scenes are pretty graphic, bordering on hardcore. Stay tuned for the final scene, which also makes good use of the split-screen technique, which was very popular in the early 70\'s. As you probably guessed, this is not politically correct and because of that a lot of fun! The picture quality is very impressive. SWV did a great job with the transfer. As usual, the SWV DVD offers many extra features. There is, of course, the movie trailer, which includes images not shown in the movie. In all, there are a dozen trailers, both from US exploration and from old French crime films. My personal favorite among the trailers is THE GODSON, starring Uschi DIGARD (this movie will be released on DVD soon). An option `` play everything \'\' for the trailers would have been helpful. We also included five shorts, which I liked most about PROWLER. As a true crime fan, this 60s black and white instruction film for cops was a sight very appealing to me. Equally interesting is CRIME IN THE STREET, an instructional crime prevention documentary showing a young Chuck NORRIS (then a karate trainer). The movie is fun, but somehow pointless, because all the advice given is so well known and common sense. I did not like the other three short films. HARRY NOVAK, CRIME BUSTER is a kind of documentary, where a film crew visits movie producer Harry NOVAK. After playing with NOVAK (joking), he suggests that they visit a business partner, who paid with a missing check. NOVAK wields a samurai sword and a rifle to improve his arguments. Strange business customs ... Another short film is an extremely silly, boring sex beyond belief and due to the almost unwatchable horrible print quality. The last short feature is a black and white burlesque striptease. Boring, and by the way: You can not see something. Much better is Harry NOVAK\'s extensive film gallery. Buy the DVD, but it\'s best to skip the last three shorts on the extra features.'

b"This is a movie that is more about redemption than about purebred issues. Kowalski lives in a dilapidated part of Detroit, where he is a retired worker and a veteran of the Korean War. He is a grumpy old man who despises everything and apparently everyone. His nieghborhood is totally Hmong, with the only exception being him. We see him with his family, and interacting with his neighbors and then as you saw in the trailers, his dealings with the local youth. He begins a relationship with Thao and Sue, young Hmong neighbors that he creates an affinity for. Totally politically incorrect, Kowalski vomits racial and ethnic slurs in almost every sentence. He's a bit of a loaner, especially since he became a widower, but he likes his car and his house and wishes his world has not changed so much. Kowalski calls everyone's names on their faces and he really does not care what kind of climb up, leaves people. He basically offends evryone, whites, blacks, hispanics, asians. But you see young gangs from a variety of ethical perspectives and their own racism. Tao and Sue are like the ones you hear in the news, children who have problems come to them simply because they live in these areas. Kowalski knows the Hmong and they know him. He defends his home, his property and his friends. Realism, while surreal, has our senses impacted when you see the results of the fight. Sometimes it takes more of the same. Kowalski, although he is a figure of redemption, it impacts everyone who knows him eventually, but the biggest impact is in the viewer of Gran Torino. The extras on the DVD are good, more about cars than about society. I wish there were more on the inner city and gang issues to complement our love affair with the big muscle cars."

b"I bought this thought that I would be getting a portion of one of my childhood favorites, Hollywood and the Stars. That is not. (Ah, the dangers of online shopping ...) This disc contains three chapters (called episodes), consisting of World War II related news images, but the resemblance to Hollywood and the Stars ends there. Instead of narration by the inimitable Joseph Cotten, we are treated with occasional comments from Eric Sevareid. Certainly, Mr. Sevareid is a legend among journalists, but he simply does not cut it if someone is waiting for Joseph Cotten (not to mention the beautiful theme song by the late Elmer Bernstein). If you have to buy this, do it on your website. own risk and because its content is not 'Hollywood and the Stars'' is of interest to you, not the list (I bought quite cheaply from a third-party seller of Amazon, but any waste of money is painful for me). Why worth it, I noticed that it is playable in all regions, but I do not know if it will convert from NTSC to PAL. My advice is do not bother trying to figure it out."

b'"Lost Highway" is not so linear and therefore satisfies our narrative desire as "Mulholland Drive" because in fact it seems to be very difficult to be weird. But David Lynch is one of the only directors who understands how strangely dreamy cinema can be. Like Hitchcock, he exploits this situation with all his courage, but in the manner of the classic surrealists, and I think this film can be best experienced on the stage of a real theater. The terrain of this film is even more profoundly subconscious than \'Mulholland Drive\', because its ultimate theme seems to be the act of watching a narrative film itself as channeled through a model of truth in our society: crime. That\'s what makes it interesting. It is so open, however, that it allows each viewer their own personal interpretation because the "surface plot" is mixed with their own interpretive clues ... My opinion is that Fred Madison believes he was convicted of murdering his wife with based on the images contained in the last videotape that is delivered to him and Renee (Patricia Arquette); during the first act, the most crucial line is the statement that he does not like cameras because he prefers to remember things in his own way - not necessarily the way they happened. "This whole first section of the movie is how Fred remembers his life before being imprisoned, and it happens in the space of a second - after he is beaten in the face by the policeman who arrested him. Believing in the mysterious tapes that preceded the murder is his way of trying to convince himself that he did not do it - that the Mysterious Man (Robert Blake as a killer of women - ironic, huh?) Really did. The second part, less effective due to its lighter tone, is Madison\'s way of escaping the reality of the electric chair. The light above your cell glows and vibrates as presumably someone is running, which triggers your fantasy to escape, physically becoming another person. However, even in the life of this younger man, Renee returns (as a double ...?) And he is free to start a life with her without the memory of his marriage but learns the sordid truth about his life ... Mystery Man again appears, this time helping him commit the conscious murder of his ex-pimp - and allowing him to be filmed to convince himself that this murder (which Fred may have committed before the movie began) was right. But who the hell knows ... The plot? I mapped this movie after I saw it for the first time, and there are many doubles whose nature we, as spectators, can not trust as physical reality or mental projection. Each interpretation points to the other - like the Moebius track that Lynch claims the movie incorporates. It\'s more like a puzzle structured around themes, especially a subtext involving photography - the photo of the twins, the porn movies, the scary videos that show up on your doorstep as evil phone cards. Be sure to get a letterbox version of this movie; Lynch\'s visual compositions are based on horizontal angles all the time, and there are many extreme close-ups in which the tops of the heads are truncated (for some evil intent, I\'m sure). Cinematography is great, and the soundtrack (not the music, but the atmosphere that Lynch always does meticulously) is as important as the pictures, as in "Eraserhead". `` And after watching a particular scene in this movie, you will be very careful around glass tables with sharp edges for the rest of your life ...'

b'By the time this album came out, the Spice Girls were everywhere. They were on all magazine covers, they were in lollipops, books, they still had several sets of dolls as well as 5 # 1 hit songs. This album only added to it and until today has sold more than 15 million copies worldwide. Face it, they have sold more records than anyone since the Beatles and no one has yet to sell more than the Spice Girls. They are a milestone in pop music, a legacy and without them, there would be Britney or Christina. Spice Up Your Life (10/10) Yet another # 1 hit for girls, this song has great lyrics. And it was a smart way to market them. I was impressed with the video, it\'s very good. Great song. Stop (10/10) The only song that did not hit # 1 in the UK. I love this one . Geri\'s vocals are, in my opinion, the best part of this song. She looks so sweet and perfect in her verses. Captivating lyrics ... a perfect pop song. Too Much (10/10) One of my all time favorite songs. Just as 2 become 1. I love the message and the story behind this. When you have it, it\'s too much ... when you do not, it\'s not enough. LARGE letter. Saturday Night Divas (10/10) Another favorite of mine. I love the Melanie C piece on the bridge. Your voice here surprises me. Emma\'s verses are also perfect. Beautiful music with original and different verses. Love ! 05 Never give up the good times (10/10) Many fans agree that this would be a great single. This is great song with a great message for everyone. Especially for the girls. Be safe and do not get pregnant ... live young as long as you can. Move Over (8/10) Pepsi\'s music, but it\'s great overall. It\'s a kind of filler on this album, but its smooth rhythm and raw vocals make up for it. Although I prefer the other Pepsi song, "Step To Me," about that. It is available in the Japanese version of this album. Do It (9/10) Another song with a great message! My mom did not find out when the first album came out, but I agreed with everything they\'re saying and I still do. `` The rules should be broken, do what suites you, not what they want you to do. \'\' 08. Denying (10/10) Reminds me of my ex-boyfriend denying that he was really gay. This is one of my favorites. "You do not fool anyone but yourself. \'\' So true. Live Forever (10/10) Beautiful! Beautiful lyrics and melody. Saying goodbye to true love ... I can relate to it more deeply than many other songs here. This song really gives me shivers, it\'s amazing music. One of his best. The Lady Is A Vamp (7/10) Not one of my favorites, but it\'s different. And it\'s a great way to end the album as a concert ... "Ladies and gentlemen, we hope you enjoyed the show! "Overall, this album is as good as the original, with as much seasoning as the previous one. Geri, Emma, \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bMel C, Mel B and Victoria all have equal vocals in this one and they all sound incredible, however. In fact, this album is probably my favorite among the three, and I love all three. So if you do not already have it, buy used or something. It\'s fun . It makes you dance, cry and think a lot. Not just a soundtrack, this is an ALBUM. Take it !'

b'I have a stubborn girl who has resisted the potty since she was 2 years old too. I felt like she knew how to do it, but she was purposely being difficult - some sort of power struggle or something. She loves the DVD! She watched every day for about two weeks, but she would not do it alone. A combination of perseverance and PANTIES - not PULLUPS along with the DVD really helped. She\'s still saying ... \'\' I can do this as Potty Power! ! ! \'\' She\'s so excited and so are we. No more diapers OR Pull ups OR accidents only 3 weeks after she decided to take it seriously .. Good luck .. I highly recommend it. I might add that I think the "power" behind this little movie is that it uses some positive influences. You see all these cute and happy children wearing the potty and being proud of themselves, playing diapers, etc. Great idea ... because the next best thing is to have your child around another child who started the potty train.'

b"The five-star review here should be for the DVD of the Warner Brothers Archives Collection, The Prisoner of Zenda. '' If it was for the Grapevine Video release, I'm sure I would have mentioned the abysmal quality of the DVD. The transfer of Grapevine to DVD was made from an extremely poor print of the film, with absolutely no attempt to restore. Many of the title cards are so dark that they are unreadable; It would certainly have been a simple matter to create new titles for this release - unless the Grapevine folks could not read them either. The contrast in a section of the movie is so high that the characters and objects are reduced to blank blobs on the screen. I completely agree with the other critic's comments on the film's acting and film qualities of 1922. I'll return the Grapvine DVD, and I'm willing to try out the Warner Brothers release, but in the meantime I'll stick with Ronald Coleman's version of 1937."

b'IT\'S OK ; Let\'s be clear on something. This is a work of fiction. It is well crafted, slippery and attractive in its message. But it\'s fiction. However, let\'s make clear a few other things. First, many of the points that are made here are true. Which are ? Well, I\'m going to avoid spoilers, but suffice it to say that people always ask me if I\'m an atheist. No, I say, I do not deny the possibility of a higher being. But I deny the church. This story clearly shows how organized religion has routinely destroyed the best messages but corrupting them with greed, desire for power, and cruelty. Groups of men made human choices and wrote human words to describe a system that would keep them in power, and that story goes deeper into that. He investigates the little-known facts about the so-called "holy" Bible ... the idea that what we now know as the Bible differed greatly from what it once was. And so on . I do not seek to destroy faith, nor this history. What it does is, hopefully, entice the viewer / reader to think for himself. This is a fun story, well-represented and well photographed from a well written and enjoyable work of modern fiction. I hope you at least create THOUGHTS about it, and maybe, just maybe, people begin to see formal religious institutions, like Christianity, as they are ...'

b'I\'ve never written a review before, but after trying this video I felt compelled to warn others about how the title of the video is misleading. This video is very intense for anyone with neck or shoulder pain. I have a lot of pain in the neck and shoulders and this video only gets worse. Anyone with severe muscle tension needs yoga with a lot of stretching for those tight areas - this video is not it! The video starts with push ups and various weight poses, putting a lot of stress on the neck and shoulders (like plank and dog down). This is a very fast video - it\'s more a flow of yoga, definitely not something that will "rescue your neck and shoulders"! ! ! ! ! It alternates between weight poses and very, very quickly and there is almost no stretching in this video! She does not explain the poses and moves too fast. This video is for advanced yogis and definitely not for beginners or for anyone who has any kind of pain. I\'m not a beginner, but I have a lot of neck / shoulder pain and this video is completely inappropriate. There are other reasons also because this video is annoying (but these are of much lesser importance): the song is annoying. of voodoo music), the background scene is nauseating and it is very false. If you\'re looking for a good neck and shoulder support video, try "Yoga for Stress Relief" with Barbara Benagh, it\'s great! This video allows you to choose from several sequences, depending on the type of pain you have, and you can choose whether you want an active stream or a more passive stream.'

b'Every year, when Christmas rolls around, I like to have some friends to enjoy a cup of joy (a potent Egg Nog recipe available on request), put on a nice Christmas song, light some candles, prepare some delicious and golden, and gather around my humble but enough cinema and watch a wonderful holiday favorite. This year I\'m going to watch Die Hard and for me Christmas would not be complete without it. John McTiernan\'s classic action (Predator and The Hunt for Red October) that has spawned three explosive sequels never seems to age. , no matter how dated the hair, clothes and portrait of California cocaine addicts. Die Hard follows John McClane (Bruce Willis) to his quasi-wife\'s Christmas party (Bonnie Bedelia) in a skyscraper on the west coast. He is a New York cop whose wife and children have moved west while she seizes a great opportunity and fits. Of course, they are having some wedding problems but it is underestimated just enough. The building is empty except for the group that is having the Christmas party on one of the higher floors. "Terrorists" led by Hans Gruber (Alan Rickman) take over the building and chaos sets in. Gruber\'s plan would have worked very well if John had not fled and slowly began to take out each of his minions while warning local authorities. The feds soon arrive and the movie explodes in an action classic ... and also a Christmas classic. He has such a nice and compelling hero as you can get into John McClane and Bruce Willis behind the scenes of all the other action heroes making John not only clever and entertaining but easy to relate to with very little drama. It\'s an effortless performance that I can only compare to Harrison Ford as Indiana Jones. Just little fearless remarks, coupled with a cynical look on his face, make John go from typical good boy to what every kid dreams they could become under these circumstances. It\'s fantastic and it\'s kitsch, but this is forgivable because it\'s a holiday movie and even more importantly, action is still the priority at Die Hard. On the other side of the coin, the grandeur of Die Hard is complete. by his formidable and accessible antagonist, Hans Gruber. Even after we discover that Hans is not there as a political terrorist, but simply as a thief, he does not lose any credibility when he responds to Holly McClane\'s criticism by saying, "I am an exceptional thief, Mrs. McClane and since I am I am moving to kidnap you, you should be more educated.Although we know that Hans is capable of devious acts, he views them as merely means to a greater and somehow justifiable purpose.Your disposition is almost humanitarian and you could imagine it as a gentleman out of the context of the crimes he committed in the arch of the Duro de Matar.In the end, however, Hans is a pure sociopath who even the public is led to sympathize with.I wanted him to escape if his opposition was Van Damme , Segal or Stallone ... maybe even Arnold .The supporting cast is another great force and it helps to highlight the humorous tone of the film.The cops and feds are all fun and rich characters, especially Reggie VelJohnson as Sgt. Al-Powell. Villains are purely chaotic thugs with enough variety to make them a little more than just John\'s body count. The performance of William Atherton as a reporter is also noteworthy, as is John\'s limousine driver, Argyle. Even the edited versions for television are worth it when the curse is replaced by wonderfully light little curses like * slug of the ditch *, * melon farmer * and * bad mother crusher *. These, of course, make it fun and affordable for all ages and Die Hard is one of the best examples of hilariously edited television movies. But that\'s not clear what makes it a great movie. I would actually say that Die Hard is the biggest pure action movie ever made. Yippie-ki-yay * muddy funster * ... and happy holidays.'

b'Putting in my two cents: The girl who went through time was on my watch list for a while, but I never had time to check until yesterday. I (like most of the other reviewers) was not expecting much, but after seeing his new movie "Summer Wars" I decided to give it a try. I have to say that despite being a slightly older film, it overcomes the Summer Wars in almost every respect (except perhaps computer animation). There is literally no weakness in this movie. The quality of the animation remains high throughout. The characters are beautifully drawn by hand and the backgrounds are meticulously rendered (mostly hand-drawn as well). The use of computer animation is kept to a minimum and occurs mainly when we see a \'jump\'. The characters are strong and nice. Makoto is his typical awkward teenager. A chance encounter followed by an (almost) horrible accident allows her to "jump" in time. Instead of using this ability for the so-called \'evil\' (I would be jumping back and investing heavily in certain actions ...), Makoto uses the ability to improve her life and that of her friends. However, this begins to cause unforeseen and terrible circumstances. And that\'s about the point where the film changes from light and somewhat comical to totally dramatic and overwhelming. I do not divulge any event or damage any plot for you, but let\'s say I was moved by the end of the movie (though not with tears in the eyes!). The dubbing in Japanese is strong, especially considering at least 2/3 of the main characters are dubbed by a first voice actor. It shows how in Japan they take the voice seriously and make a good cast (instead of most American dubbing companies that have a core of 5 or 6 full-time actors that need to match a main character in each series. film - often not getting the best game for the character). So the story is strong with a bit of science fiction, the characters are nice and well portrayed, the dubbing is wonderful, the animation is beautiful ... why Have not you seen it yet? If you are not an anime fan, this might be a good movie to help change your mind.'

b"The classic tale of demonic possession of all time, based on William Peter Blatty's bestseller. Linda Blair is Regan MacNeil, a twelve-year-old girl who manifests herself in a truly evil spirit. His mother, Chris MacNeil (Ellen Burstyn), an agnostic, seeks the help of a young Jesuit psychiatrist, Father Damien Karras (Jason Miller, God rest his Irish soul!) Who has his own demons, and is plagued by his recent death. of his mother, and his loss in faith that he sought refuge. After confronting the demon within the girl (and himself), Karras, though skeptical of demonic possession, is given permission from the church to assist during the exorcism. The priest chosen to perform the ritual is a mysterious and elderly Jesuit, Father Lankaster Merrin (Max Von Sydow), who has seen such devilish work. While the two clerics confront the devil, a police detective, Lieutenant William F. Kinderman (Lee J. Cobb) finds some links connecting the girl with a cryptic death and desecration in the local Catholic church. William Friedkin brilliantly directed, and Blatty adapted the script (receiving an Oscar for his efforts) and produced. The cast gives extraordinary and sensitive performances (Burstyn, Miller and Blair all nominated for the Oscars) and the special effects are breathtaking and still bring a punch, with veteran Mercedes McCambridge providing the voice of the evil entity. (The movie also won for Best Achievement in Sound). The underlying theme of much of Blatty's work is self-evident, his philosophy being, if there is all this evil out there, why is there so much good? Metaphorically, everyone fights their own demons, and even in their last moment of self-sacrifice, Karras finds his faith again and heroically gives his life to save this innocent child. How much more significant can it be? A truly terrifying, captivating, and ultimately moving, film that deals with human faith and frailty."

b"This story caught my eye immediately and kept it all through the movie. The film is based on the life of John Nash. He was a brilliant mathematician who became famous as a young man for his work in economics. The film spans several decades and begins when John Nash arrives at Princeton University. Russell Crowe does an excellent job in the role of Nash. The part demanded Nash's transformation from a healthy young man to an aged schizophrenic. Alicia, Nash's wife is played by Jennifer Connelly. She is very convincing as a smart and strong woman who comes to realize that her brilliant husband is very upset and lives in another world. A particularly lovely scene stands out in my mind, where Nash and his future wife are staring at the stars. He tells her to think of different shapes or animals and he is able to look at the night sky with its millions of stars, and link them in whatever form she mentions. I wish there were more such scenes and maybe a little insight into Nash's family and childhood. John Nash was finally awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, which is a consolation, but the tragedy of his talented mind is being assaulted by delusions was something I do not forget. I came out of this movie with tremendous compassion for John Nash. Schizophrenia is really a horrible mental illness. This movie is worth seeing and I believe it will stand the test of time."

b'I felt compelled to write a review of this movie for several reasons. Firstly, because this is one of my favorite movies of all time. I never get tired of watching this movie several times and sharing with others who have not yet had the pleasure of watching it. I also wanted to write this review because many younger movie fans immediately discard old movies and especially black and white movies. And finally, I wanted to put my two cents after reading the critical `` professional criticism \'\' ... mis-cast? ? ? How could there be a more perfect and better movie? ? ? Gregory Peck, whom I came to revere as Atticus Finch in `` To Kill A Mockingbird \'\' (he is the reason why I wanted to become a lawyer when I was a child), and Audrey Hepburn has the perfect blend of innocence and fearlessness for his role as the rebel princess. Even Eddie Albert as the comedy kick was ideal. This film follows a princess who, at first glance, lives an enviable life of wealth and fame and glamor. I\'ve always found it hard to find any sympathy for similar people\'s complaints, either in real life or in the movie, but somehow Audrey Hepburn does it and it\'s not hard to cheer her up because she experiences such basic things as deciding how her hair should look be cut and eat an ice cream. While Gregory Peck is undeniably suave as the American journalist, he is also able to remove the weakness necessary to make his paper acceptable. You have to be able to understand that your initial motivation does NOT come from a "good place", but merely from greed and selfishness. but then you also have to believe in your change of heart and your subtlety. And this works. He does not wake up suddenly and has a change of heart. You can see its transformation or relevancy in the course of the movie. As a romantic closet I have to say that I always secretly hope there is a better ending (and by "better" I do not mean in terms of movie quality. I mean in terms of a classic "happy ending"). The final scene is to cut the heart, but the only plausible way it can end. I\'m always wondering what happened next, even though I know the answer very well ... and it\'s not necessarily what we\'d all like to imagine. But I respect the fact that the film does not spell it and does not involve everything in a lovely bow. Still a sad ending, but exactly as it should be. Please watch this movie. You\'ll want to own it later, I promise. And do not be fooled, it\'s not just an old-fashioned movie. \'\' It\'s just good. Oh yes, and that * sigh factor * ... HUGE! Enjoy and share with the younger crowd, so this classic is never lost to modern blockbusters.'

b'I must agree with the reviewers who say that the production of this concert footage is very poor. If you are looking to watch Evanescence live, chances are you will not find it here. This looks more like any video clip than a show. It has been edited to a nth degree and rarely focuses on a single shot for more than two seconds. Fortunately, the DVD has a few redeeming factors, including the exciting videos from "Bring Me to Life," "Going Under," "My Immortal," and "Everybody\'s Fool." The backstage bits are a little bit fun, if nothing else. It is good to be shown that this band has a lot of fun on the road, giving the impression that they will not leave the business anytime soon. While the video aspect of the DVD is poorly done, the audio is much better, which is why, if it were possible, I recommend you buy the concert CD instead of the DVD. Anyway, Amy\'s voice is pretty familiar in concert, which I was not sure; Do you know how some singers sound completely different live than on a recording? Well, she does not. Her voice falters during some of the fast-paced songs, but this is expected when she is running and jumping on stage. I was particularly impressed with the ballads; his powerful vocals combined with his beautiful piano playing were chilling, especially during Breathe No More and the band\'s hit My Immortal. I was surprised to find that I really liked `` Thoughtless \'\', the band\'s cover of a KoRn song. I\'ve never been a KoRn person, or an alternative rock heavy metal person of any kind, but I was impressed by how this song was performed by Evanescence. The audio CD also includes an unreleased track called `` Absence of \'\'. Much like the other ballads of the band, this song is smooth, with good vocals and painful and beautiful lyrics. In conclusion, Evanescence sounds very, very good on this CD. It is a real pleasure to hear; it\'s just the DVD that, well, sucks.'

However, I was informed in an e-mail newsletter: '' Please note - Peter still receives money from the Last Unicorn movie sales ONLY through Conlan Press. That goes for this new Blu-ray edition as well. If you buy it anywhere else, Peter does not get anything. What really sucks when you consider that 1.8 million DVDs of the last Unicorn have been sold in America since 2004, and only 6,000 of them went through Conlan Press. None of the other copies earned a penny for Peter. So, please encourage everyone you know to support you by buying the combination package through Conlan Press, and nowhere else. Thank you ! `'I do not know if this is also true of Amazon sales, but either way Amazon should address the problem directly and clarify that. I do not feel comfortable putting something like this into an Amazon review - essentially a plug-in for another vendor - but I think it's an important piece of information.PREATED AND UPDATED (2012): Peter Beagle has reached a rights agreement that is very satisfactory for all parties He is now in full possession of the rights to this film and is duly paid for the sales. Disregard the above!"

b"Finally, I delivered all the advertisement and actually went to watch the Minority Report. The question I have left now that I've seen is: what was all the hype about? Although I have to admit that some of the special effects generated by computer were impressive, the performance lacked any kind of substance. However, what bothered me the most was the incredible amount of product placement throughout the film. Mr. Spielberg was not sure he would make enough money at the box office to announce Aquafina, Pepsi, Gap, Lexus and Nokia throughout the film? Overall, I spent two and a half hours in the movie, during which I wondered more than once if all the people who were walking in the movies during the movie were as bored as I was. The bottom line is, good special effects for free and some interesting scenes like the chase in the car factory, other than that I can watch home commercials on my TV for free."

b"& quot; Return of the Living Dead & quot; is a hilarious horror / comedy inspired by the classic George A. Romero & quot; Live dead & quot; movies. Two workers at a medical supply depot find one of these drums, drill the accident and release a gas that brings the dead close to life. Luckily, the warehouse is right next to a graveyard. The rest is written, and the movie has some of the funniest moments in horror movie history: A corpse running in the warehouse, a zombie head being thrown out of the park with a baseball bat, a zombie ordering & quot; more paramedics & quot; like he's asking for pizza. And above all, a hard rock soundtrack from the '80s. This is one of my favorite party movies because it makes everyone (even non-terror fans) howl. It's a bit bloody, but comedy dazzles the elements of terror. The DVD in question is a bit light on the extras except for a documentary that is fun but warm. But the great privilege is the best picture and sound quality I've ever seen in this movie. The DVD really makes a difference. Grab a copy and see what I mean, you will not regret it."

b"Since this movie is sold out, it took me a few weeks to locate a copy. However, once I did, it seemed that I had found the holy grail of the horror film. The story revolves around a scandalous case had for a bored housewife (Julia Cotton) and her brother-in-law (Frank Cotton). Julia and her husband move to Frank's former home after Frank's sudden disappearance. Of course, Frank did not really disappear. Instead, the pervert brother-in-law has found a cube-shaped puzzle. The puzzle, when opened, opens a portal to the world of Cenobites. The Cenobites offer the greatest pleasure, but at a high cost. To escape the world of the Cenobites, once a drop of his brother's blood has been spilled on the floor of the house, Frank returns as a walking corpse, needing body parts. of living beings to be completed again. Frank uses his previous relationship with Julia to persuade her to bring him new victims. With each victim, Frank becomes more complete, but also more impatient. There are several prefigurations, praises the mantis with Julia when she goes to bars and picks random men for slaughter. Of course, eventually her actions bring suspicion on her stepdaughter and her husband ... The film introduces the introduction of Cenobites, which are some of the scariest cats in horror since the Alien Xenomorphs. As the movie progresses, we learn more about these beings, their origin and purpose. Of course, the ending leaves everything open, which leads to several sequences. I highly recommend this movie to those who enjoy watching old horror movies made by those who are now considered masters of the genre."

b'For the big fans of Manhunter, I advise you to avoid this DVD if you plan to own ... What was advertised as & quot; Theatrical & quot; version is actually a poorly mended version that awkwardly edits two scenes that had been in the theatrical version, including one of the most crucial scenes, and still has in it some of the most banal scenes restored from the cutting room floor. These cuts are poorly made and do not make sense to them, since they do not represent the theatrical release and destroy what was a finely edited film. I do not know if it was ignorance or arrogance, but this is the worst hacker job I\'ve ever seen trying to get by product. Whoever was in charge at Anchor Bay was an idiot, and if I were Michael Mann, I would call my lawyers. & Quot; Director\'s Cut & quot; is even worse in that it includes & quot; Non-Theatrical & quot; launch and so-called & quot; Director\'s Cut & quot; - a compilation of some interesting and not so interesting takes. As a companion to a true theatrical release, this would have been a fascinating addition; But here again, Anchor Bay finds a way to ruin what should be a good product. The entire film that has not gone through video post-production is stained and foggy, as if it had been transferred from a VHS tape - and a worn tape. "It\'s simply amazing that someone might have the audacity to offer this kind of price for the hard earned money. I saw this movie when it first came out in the movies and considered it one of the best of that year; and I ran to buy the LaserDisc version when it came out. When DVD Director\'s Cut was released by Anchor Bay this year, I was on the waiting list - ready to receive the enhanced THX widescreen version. Being intimately aware of the film, imagine my disappointment. Do not waste your time. Wait for a better version to leave. As for those people who want to compare the Silence of the Lambs to Manhunter, they usually favor one over the other and their minds are very well made right now. I\'m good at the Hunters\' Camp. For me, I liked Silence, but I could never take it seriously since I found Reader\'s portayal both caricaturedly superhuman and therefore unreal and unsuspended. However, Manhunter\'s Reader is a creepy but more realistic portrait that surprises me every time I see this in how an evil genius manages to manipulate events out of his cell through the simple apparatus of a telephone. This Reader is surely behind steralized bars - and yet it manages to be a strong presence for TBE told with.I hope every fan and future fan of Manhunter gets to see it the way it first appeared, a beautiful piece of handicraft which was slim and elegant, and yet it flowed elegantly. Siskel and Ebert rated it as one of the best films of all time, years after he left. But for now, I\'ll hold my LaserDisc.'

b"I saw and loved all three of those movies, so I did not roll to read the reviews. I should have .
