b"All 3 movies are well seated at the tip of your seat, but most people already know the story lines. The first of three films, The Bourne Identity, has excellent video and very discreet audio channel tracking. The sound mixers did a great job of using all the surround channels and did not let the soundtrack hide the various foley effects on any of the front or rear channels. Of course, in all the excitement, your subwoofer will have a good workout. The video transfer is very good with no video noise, aliasing or artifacts. This movie started the whole franchise and was a super start. My only question was how Bourne being shot in the back brought his amnesia in the first place. This was never really answered, since amnesia usually originated from severe head trauma and not from two bullets in the back. The Bourne Supremacy, the second film in the trilogy, made much more use of the portable camera, and while that was happening, it did not bother me, I remember a friend and professional photographer mentioning that he got seasick. The video transfer on Blu-ray was excellent in all respects, but I also noticed much less use of directional audio. Rather than putting money into a more understated sound editing, the producers augmented the soundtrack that enveloped the entire sound stage, front and back. It's not that the soundtrack does not fit the film, it certainly does, and it creates the excitement that the Bourne movie requires, but a greater focus on the 5.1 sound stage for foley purposes would have been good. The last of the Trilogy, the Bourne Ultimatum, completes the pack with the same force in the video transfer. I did not see any weakness in any of the video downloads for the 3 movies, but again, in the Bourne Ultimatum, you'd think with all the excitement going on, that using the front and back sides would be more prominent. I was disappointed that, like the Bourne Supremacy, they simply increased the audio levels of the soundtrack that would obfuscate any foley effects. I'm not saying that there is no use of discrete in either of the last two movies, but not where as much as what might have been or how it was used in the first Bourne Identity. To save $, they just raise the soundtrack level and that's a shame. During the fight scene, there are things being played, glass breaking and all sorts of chaos that could easily have been directed left or right, forward or backward. So, in this respect, I was disappointed. Nevertheless, this is a great collection to have, and the excitement and rhythm of the three films is simply outstanding. There are many deleted scenes and other short 'making of' scenes, as well as comments, with no wasted space for previews and announcements from other films. It's worth the cost. I hope this review has been helpful and if so, please check the 'Helpful' button so I know I'm on the right path with my reviews for you. Thank you ."

b'Every once in a while a film comes up that has had almost no publicity, not even a decent release for the general public, but the purgatory of limited films and art films. However, in the case of Equilibrium, I am more impressed that it has never received a wider release. Upon seeing the film, I honestly did not have high expectations, other than seeing some cool shootings and martial arts as the star of the movie. Although this factor has been fun, the real star belongs to the finely crafted script that honors such novels as "Brave New World", "1984" and "Fahrenheit 451". History puts the viewer in the post-apocalyptic world of the future. Having suffered the consequences of World War III, the survivors were banished together to form a new society that would rid them of humanity\'s greatest faults and emotions. Controlled by a drug that nullifies such meanings, the future is a war-free utopia, but enslaved by those who hold power and the created establishment. Art, music, literature, all this is forbidden and the penalty for committing such mental crimes is death. The most feared of the establishment guards is the Cleric. A group of men trained in mind and body to be the perfect killing machines and the hindquarters of their ideals. One such cleric, who even executed his own partner to read a book of poems, begins to see the world in a new light when he loses his regular dose and experiences a barrage of emotions he had never felt before. In attempting to maintain his duty, he finds the cruel sadism of his assigned task almost more than he can bear. In a desperate search, he tries to find resistance and put an end to the madness he has safeguarded. Christian Bale, playing the Cleric, is incredible giving depth and excitement to a role that required none. In this he makes the film even deeper. Film style and editing, borrowed from filmmakers like John Woo and Tsui Hark, bring enough freshness while adapting these styles. The art direction fits into creating a claustrophobic world of dark lies. Although the city scenarios are not so impressive and are obviously CG effects. Music that is sometimes obscure and tied to a conflict of foreboding and then is a fast-paced techno that sets the pace of the shooting without losing the rhythm. In all Equilibrium is a dream of science fiction fans, but it is also a movie that can be enjoyed by fans of classical literature as well. While the ending may seem simplified, I actually found it to have a deeper meaning as well as an interesting commentary on mankind in general. But most will be thrilled by the ten-minute shootout with an impressive sword duel. Balance contains strong violence and language and is recommended for people over 17 years. For once the style and substance collide on the celluloid.'

b"I can not rave about this DVD anymore! ! ! ! I think they did the best they could with incorporating music with phonetics. I swear, my 6-year-old son in first grade has had a dramatic improvement in reading and spelling after watching this video. At the beginning of the school year, she had an average of 3 out of 8 on her spelling and her first report card, the teacher said she needed more help with reading. I called this video a few times during the week for a few weeks for her to watch and every time I started in a different chapter. There was a dramatic improvement in his reading and spelling. Now she got an 8/8 in her spelling. She started coming home with stickers every day from school, which she said she managed to do a good job of reading. She said that this phonic video taught her to read! ! ! Just a few weeks ago, we were barely going through Dora's phonetics series and now she's reading books for me that she picked up in the library that are on a second level. Awesome video! ! ! ! I think all kindergarten and first grade teachers should use this video to supplement teaching. Students relate to this much better than a standing teacher trying to teach him."

b"It's been fun reading these posts from people who have been so moved and entertained by this movie. I saw it when it first came out and I've had Cat Stevens songs in my head ever since. It's one of those that personally affect the movies that drive fans to quote them, and my favorite moment after all those years is (as it is for some of those other writers) Maude casting Harold's charm into the river because now she ' ll & quot; I always know where it is. & quot; This was my first experience with the depth of the film, and I never lost it. If you have not seen the movie yet, you can probably read some of those posts and not have it ruined for you. There is so much to laugh at and marvel at, and of course, these songs. . . ."

b"This is one of the films most loved by the affictionados of the scene of the foreign cinema. Tati provided a brilliant connection between the better than the silent film era and modern cinema had to offer. It is a relatively simple tale of a clumsy man on vacation off the coast of France. But repeated visions, especially over the years, increasingly open up treasures that have not been recognized until now, like a classic novel. I'd be surprised if anyone gets excited about this movie the first time they watch it. I certainly did not. But repeated views over the years will give you an appreciation of this cult-serving film. Every member of my extended family loves this movie, and everyone has a particular reason. Some love their ability to perfectly capture a foreign time and place, allowing them to feel as if they themselves had escaped to the French coast during the afternoon. Some adore Hulot's awkward but enjoyable attempts at the best novel. Many love the bright jokes that are funny, no matter how many times you've seen them. But regardless of what the viewer loves most, everyone will feel a bond with the character of Hulot (and, in turn, M. Tati), who will last a lifetime. With this DVD, I can finally feel safe to borrow my beloved and grainy copy on VHS. A classic film by all the meanings of the term."

b"When I was ten years old, my mother's uncle gave me his copy of Cornelius Ryan's book A Bridge Too Far. This was a very special gift from him since he was deported to Germany to work for the Reich during World War II and never mentally recovered from what had happened to him. By the time I got the book, he lived in a small village a few miles west of Arnhem on the south bank of the River Rijn. Obviously, I was young to read the book back then. Over the years, my interest in World War II and Operation Market Garden began to grow, and every time A Bridge Too Far was broadcast, I watched. The scenes depicting the parachute falls and the Waal River assault were the most remembered. That, and the great musical score of John Addison. I finally bought the DVD and watched it a few times since. I must say that every time I watch, the movie gets better and better. Especially with subtitles: first those that specify where we are. Without this, it can be confused where the viewer was brought from one scene to another. Secondly, since English is not my native language, I have been able to better understand some of the dialogues. (Finally I understood what Liv was trying to say in Dutch =) The widescreen option is fantastic. You actually enter the battle scenes and see all the extra images ... for example, when John Frost's battalion is entering Arnhem, you see people riding a bicycle in the background, you do not see in the pan and But with a great like the DVD, and also with the 25th anniversary of the movies last year, MGM and United Artists missed a big chance. It's a shame that the only extra is the original theatrical trailer. I would really like to see more behind the scene images included in a second disc. The Dutch Broadcasting Company (NOS) must have a lot of filming, I remember the news often spending time filming the film, such as re-enacted excrement. Also, the studio should have extra pictures as well. They could even produce a new documantary in the filming of this film, including interviews with leading actors and Sir Richard Attenborough. What about the original footage and notes about the battle how it happened? Despite this lack, it is still a must buy if you are into war and / or classic movies. After 25 years, it still holds its own, and it's still a thrill to watch. Buy it, and meanwhile keep waiting for a special DVD edition. I give this DVD 4 stars, but if they had included the extra stuff, it would easily get 5 stars!"

b'This movie has always been one of my favorites. I own three copies on VHS (two back-ups just incase the one I usually watch wear out). I make all my friends watch it, and most of them love it as much as I do. It\'s stupid, completely inept and totally hilarious. I put it there with `` Forbidden Zone \'\' by Richard Elfman and `` Crimewave \'\' by John Paiz (AKA. `` The Big Crimewave \'\') as one of the three biggest cult movies of all time.Only problem is that no one Never heard of this movie. So I could not believe my luck when I came across the DVD! ! ! I thought I was dreaming. I was tempted to buy three copies ... just in case. First, I watched the deleted scenes and extras, which were cool. It seemed strange because I had seen many of the deleted scenes (they are part of my VHS versions). So when I settled in to watch the movie, my heart broke. Someone, in his infinite wisdom, has decided to censor almost all nudity, and many other scenes have either been shortened, or are entirely lacking. I suppose this version of the movie may seem a bit more complex because the missing scenes may have slowed down the movie a bit, but the most recent scenes were all PRICELESS. The ineptitude of this film is what made it special, and editing it as "professional version" is a limited blasphemy. After seeing this edited and censored version, I wish I had never bought it. I wish it did not even exist. Thank God for my copies on VHS. Whoever decided to censor and edit this movie should feel good. Thank you so much for destroying one of my favorite movies. I only give two stars because some of the extras are cool.'

b'I am just writing this review so this movie does not have the regrettably misleading 3-star rating of the only other reviewer. There are a handful of truly great Vietnam war films, and they usually cover their own solo. Full Metal Jacket is a kind of exception in that it covers the other three all do separately. Platoon covers the real combat, the sensation of hell that produced in an individual experiencing the fight, the jungle, the trauma at the moment the O deer hunter covers the post-war trauma, the long-range effect on a veteran\'s psyche. Apocalypse Now covers the psychological (and poetic) heart of war, that is, the heart of what war means, which is hate, fear and the merciless nature of the universe. After all, it\'s based on \'Heart of Darkness\'. Overall, it may be the most terrifying and irresistible of all. In turn, Heart of Darkness and this film are based on a long line of literary background called "katabasis" in Greek, that is, the descent into the underworld. It is epic, punctuated by scene after scene that becomes somber and distorted, and the protagonist is self-compelled, advancing to hell without knowing why - because, as evil exists, he feels attracted to him, or if he can not, become part of it. Transitively, ask him to try to understand the evil. If I no longer owned this, I would definitely buy it instantly for $ 6, as anyone who sees this page and has not seen the movie should do.'

b"I never got a chance to go see this movie when it hit the theaters. I rented it without knowing what to expect. After watching it on DVD, I can say that I would not have minded paying the price of the movie ticket to watch this movie. It's not all that glamorous, but what a good and respectable good movie. Gabrielle Union does a good job of playing a rude, hateful, hateful sister by the name of Eva. Sometimes she takes it to the top, but that's acting and that's what she's paid to do. Eva is keen to take care of her little sister, who leans to her for advice instead of her men. Sister Eva love and hear her as if her word was the gospel. Men, on the other hand, hate their courage and want nothing more than to see her leave town. She often interferes with her sisters' relationships and insists on leaving the men of her sisters crazy. Thus, in order to bring the proper order to their respected relationships, men plan to take Eve out of their lives. So, the need for Ray (LL Cool J). Ray is a soft-spoken player with a serious game. The men tell Ray to date Eve to get her out of their lives. Ray agrees, and so the story begins with two people falling in love with each other who should not fall in love. That's when things get confusing for Ray and Eva. Some parts of the movie were a bit outrageous and the ending was not the best, but after all, it was a really good movie. I read some of the comments about this movie and other movies as well. My thing is, if you want real life situations, go watch a drama or a real life story. This is comedy ... the comedy should not be real. It is really an escape from reality. Do not we all need it now? Anyway, in addition to the ending, this movie was well done with the supporting actors doing a great job in playing their respected roles. Also, the women in this movie are fine. Also, LL did a great job playing Ray. I have a lot of respect for him as an actor. He did not play his part anymore, but he made that believable. All in all, I give this movie a B +. The ending was a little clich\xc3\xa9."

b"This is a little-known but absolutely wonderful film that, no matter how tacky it may seem, deserves to be shared by many. A little film about a family and the small trials and tribulations of the day to day life they go through. It is very realistic and deals with the most ordinary everyday things. What makes this movie so amazing is how it is able to present this window to the lives of this group of people with such acumen and insight, sadness and honesty; ultimately resulting in a film that is tender and uplifting and hopeful. The acting is simply incredible. No other words to put. Everyone from Brenda Blethyn to Timothy Spall to Marianna Jean Baptiste to Claire Rushbrook all take turns in robbery scenes in such natural performances and to the point that sometimes it does not even seem like they're acting. This is the true performance that cuts right to the heart. The screenplay is wonderful as it provides so many little details that no one would think of including in a movie. Just the smallest things that somehow bring the characters to life. A wonderful movie that will never be acclaimed because that's all about the actors. No special effects or sex scenes. No way - this is an actor's movie. And they steal the show. If you have taste in REAL cinema, do not miss this gem of a movie. IT IS SIMPLY WONDERFUL."

b'As other reviewers have said, I was eager to watch an authentic adaptation of H.G. Wells\'s classic Romance. At the same time, I was aware that this film was made on a modest budget with the expected results. Well, this movie was worse than I expected. The special effects seemed quite caricatured, especially compared to the state of the art (Spielberg). Worse, the use of colored filters in many scenes came to be extremely annoying after some time. Even the overall quality of the print was, at best, mediocre, with saturated color and only sharpness. And the acting receives no Oscar nomination. Also, I\'m wondering if the original 3-hour version would be better for watching the storywise. In this 125 minute version, there are many jumps from one subframe to another without proper scene development in my opinion. The Martian "red weed" appears briefly in some scenes without any explanation. On the plus side, I thought the tripods and manipulation machines looked really cool, the sound effects are very good, and the music score is beautiful. Unfortunately, this is not enough to overcome the poorly executed production. If only CGI were the state of the art and color filters were eliminated, it would be a good movie, but not great. If only ... ..'

b"G.D really is almost perfect. I never get tired of it. At the same time, I think most people miss the point. (By the way, I have not seen the special edition.) I'm fascinated every time watching the totally self-centered Bill Murray captured in this wonderful time paradox, living the same day over and over. It goes through different phases: fear and confusion; euphoria, when he realizes that he can do anything without consequence; despair, when he realizes that life has no meaning if the person pursues selfish pleasures without goals; and finally a peaceful self-realization when he engages in self-improvement and the humanitarian goals that his situation gives him the opportunity to pursue. It takes a pause to consider what each would do in a similar circumstance. Oh, it's really funny, too."

b'This film is in English and its main star is American. However, it is a Japanese collaborative effort. As essentially a Japanese horror film, it has some things in common with "The Grudge". "Here, once again, we have a haunting that conveys shivers as his face is cut with his hair hanging. I do not know why hiding an apparition behind hair strands is such a scary effect - but it is. In addition, the premise of driving down a lonely road at night is sinister by itself. And when you have a dead body in the trunk of your car - the ride becomes doubly fraught with danger. The acting is usually made of wood. The actress who plays one of the main love interests is Japanese, with a very limited mastery of the English language. With so many actors eagerly available to appear in movies, I do not know why they do not find better talent. So this movie is not memorable. But it is not a complete waste of time. This will make you think twice the next time you put a corpse in your car and head towards the nearest lake to discard it. You will realize that you may have some night terrors along the way.'

b'This small, bizarre cinematic exercise from low-budget schlockmeister Bill Zebub owes much of his inspiration, I imagine, to the South Park team\'s (vastly superior) team epic. After a long comic "confrontation" at the beginning of the film, the "plot" essentially tries to parody many Hollywood, political and religious, and inject as many disturbing images of sexually mutilated Barbi dolls as possible. Actiing is provided by a variety of \'action figure\' toys that are manipulated (awkwardly) by hand and through overlays of green screens. A little of that is fun, but ultimately the concept runs out of gas, and Zebub\'s macabre preoccupation with the voracious images of sadomasochism perpetuated on female dolls is kind of scary. Still, there is some intelligence in the basic concept that makes this satirical flik more enveloping than many of Zebub\'s seemingly most serious efforts. I would recommend just buying this (if at all) at a discounted (discounted) minimum price, as the content probably would not support multiple views.'

b'Ah, Gargoyles, finally getting a well-deserved DVD release. This series is really excellent and has the honor of being one of the most animated animated series of Disney until today. The series revolves around a group of live gargoyles, which are stones during the day and meat at night. Due to a curse on them, a small group of these creatures are frozen in stone for a thousand years before being awakened in Manhattan in 1994. Like all supernatural beings in Manhattan, they naturally decide to fight crime. It may sound cheesy, but in the hands of a splendid team of writers, the series becomes much more than just another story of "non-human crimes fighting superheroes." Instead, Gargoyles becomes an interesting story with engaging storyline and good characters. This series is aided by its ability to take risks - the first episode ends even with what is essentially a mass murder. The program also addresses issues such as gun control in a very mature and realistic manner, while at the same time not being overly moralistic or prejudiced. For example, the episode of Gun Control \'Deadly Force\' (shamefully omitted by Toon Disney in its series due to the presence of weapons and shootings, despite its strong message against the inexperienced game with such weapons and fortunately restored uncut at launch of the DVD) conveys his message without having the characters standing up saying "weapons are bad, mm\'kay?" The series also has a stiffness of continuity rarely seen in American cartoons; actions in earlier episodes later affect the episodes have a well-defined order - unlike some other Disney toons at the time, Gargoyles episodes usually had to be displayed in the correct order to make sense. episode of the second season contains, of all things, a joke of Kafka that I did not get for * years *.) Gargoyles is actually one of the cartoon series more interesting and original in the Disney safe. This DVD is a great buy for longtime fans and highly recommended to new curious people about what it all is. The first season beautifully creates the rest of the series and gives the viewer an idea of \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bwhat this series is all about. I\'m already looking forward to future releases of the rest of the series.'

b'If anyone doubts the temporal quality of fame, think of Douglas Fairbanks to bring the matter home. In its time, the fame of Douglas Fairbanks was unpublished. He and his wife, Mary Pickford, were considered the royal family of America. Today, his wonderful action movies are not watched except by moviegoers, and his face and name are lost to the younger generation (if Jay Leno\'s interviews are indicative, our younger Americans seem proud not to know the name "The Mark of Zorro" is a good example of the kind of film that Fairbanks specialized in at the end of the era. from the silent movies, and was very popular because of the dynamic presence of his star. watch Fairbanks jump on the tables, jump on the walls of the chest to ride a horse, jump from a table to a cornice near a tee to, etc. And it was not only because he was able to do these feats, it was that he did them effortlessly. The pure grace of man was truly moving. He never seemed to strive for anything. I sensed this as I watched the Mark of the Zorro during a scene where Fairbanks lifts one leg and dismounts a horse running at full gallop to land as easily as it was coming out of the ladder. He made it seem so easy, I came back and watched the scene again to make sure I saw what I thought I\'d seen. Yes, he had done it - smooth as silk. Then there is his acting. In this film, Fairbanks plays a dueling role: Don Diego, a young noble fanatic, and his masked colleague, Zorro. His interpretation of Don Diego is subtle and effective. Your body looks formless and soft. Her manner is distracted and indecisive and vaguely lost. He hates fencing and is constantly wiping his face because of his great "fatigue". "When his love interest declares" He is not a man - he is a fish! \'\' it hits the nail on the head. However, when he wears the mask, his body and his manner are reborn. His body looks agile and full of movement, and his smile, that tremendous radiant smile that radiates pure happiness, is almost as devastating as his sword. Finally, there is the artistic design and sets of this film. Fairbanks loved these pieces of the period and spared no expense of research and detail. Their care, financial investment and dedication to craftsmanship really show. Everything has a beautiful, deep feel. As a side note, this review is based on the Kino DVD release of this movie, and as with all Kino releases, this edition looks just great. God bless Kino for being one of the best companies that preserves and markets silent films. If you bothered to read this review, please purchase this movie. If you do, Douglas Fairbanks will be popular and famous again, at least in your heart.-Mykal Banta'

b'MILL CREEK ENTERTAINMENT multi-movie packages are very reasonable and of good quality. These twenty unrestored transfers of films in the public domain range from very good to sometimes fair - none is ever unattainable. The "legendary detectives" in this DVD package are all series of derivative films of the 1930s and 40s. "The Shadow" was a half-hour radio series broadcast for the first time on 7/31/30. Originally only the narrator of mystery stories, in 1937, "Shadow" Lamont Cranston (now played by a young Orson Welles) has become an integral character in each episode shown. The 24-year program ended the day after Christmas in 1954. The three Shadow films were first seen in 1937 at the height of the radio program\'s popularity. The `` Bulldog Drummond \'\' was created in 1920 by the British writer Herman McNeile, who published under the pseudonym `` Sapper. Drummond\'s stories were directly influenced by noir detectives, then popular in American fiction, and are considered the forerunners of James Bond. The half-dozen movies in this set that characterize this character are all from the late 1930s. "Dick Tracy" was a comic book fighter brought to life by the pen and imagination of Detroit artist Chester Gould in October 1931. Gould worked on the strips until retiring in 1977. Other artists are still producing the stories 76 years after the series began. In comics, Detective Tracy courted future wife Tess Trueheart for 18 years, finally marrying her on Christmas Day 1949. During that time, Tracy\'s square chin faced legendary bad guys like BB Eyes, Jones Flattop, Pruneface, Haf and Haf, 88 Keys, Mr, Crime, Sphinx, Pear-shape and Faceless Redrum. Dick Tracy\'s radio program aired from 1935 to \'48. In the films Tracy was portrayed mainly by Ralph Byrd (from 1937). Byrd stayed with the series until it ended after a brief run at the start of the television. "Sherlock Holmes", the most famous detective of all fiction, was the creation of the Scottish writer and doctor Arthur Conan Doyle. Holmes\'s stories have been published in several British magazines since 1887. Over the years, Conan Doyle has tried more than once to kill the character, but public outcry has made him reconsider. Doyle wrote four novels and fifty-six tales starring Holmes and Dr. John Watson, his friend and adventure cohort, until the death of the knight-author in 1930. SUSPENSE OF MILL CREEK! 20 Movie Pack would be a great complement to this set of DVDs. Pre-title numbers are from 1 to 10 ratings from viewer searches found on a movie features site. Bulldog Drummond Comes Back (1937) - John Barrymore / John Howard (5.7) Bulldog Drummond Escapes (1937) - Ray Milland / Guy Standing (5.9) Bulldog Drummond in Africa John Barrymore / John Howard (6.4) The Secret Police (2006) - John Barrymore / John Howard (6.4) - John Barrymore / John Howard Dick Tracy, Detective - / Anne Jeffreys (5,9) Dilemma Morgan Conway\'s Dick Tracy (1947) - Ralph Byrd / Lyle Latell / Kay Christopher Dick Tracy vs. Cueball (1946) - Morgan Conway / Anne Jeffreys (7.0) Sherlock Holmes (1946) - Dick Tracy Meets Gruesome (1947) - Boris Karloff / Ralph Byrd (1937) - Rod La Roque / Agnes Anderson (6.5) - Cast and crew Name Character / Surname ) The Shadow: The Invisible Avenger (1958) - R ichard Derr / Jeanne Neher / Dan Mullin (6,8) Sherlock Holmes and the Secret Weapon (1943) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce / Lionel Atwill (6.0) The Sign of the Four (`` Sherlock Holmes \'\') (1932) - Arthur Wontner / Ian Hunter (6.4) A Study in Scarlet (1933) - Reginald Owen / Warburton Gamble (7.0) Terror at Night ("Sherlock Holmes") (1946) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce / Alan Mowbray (6.1) A Triumph Of Sherlock Holmes (1935) - Arthur Wontner / Ian Fleming (as Dr. Watson) (6.9) The Woman In Green (1945) - Basil Rathbone / Nigel Bruce / Hillary Brooke'

b'This is an interesting movie to stumble while the channel sails, but not a DVD to rent or own. What can you say about a movie where the hero kills hundreds, but does not save his wife or (later) his love interest? be burned to death and still be able to rescue a fluffy cub. This is not so much a science fiction movement about a futuristic "Orwellian Dystopia" as it is a recipe for how to make a science fiction movie about a futuristic "Orwellian Dystopia." \'Watching this movie was like playing Trivial Pursuit.It was more fun trying to pick out the various ingredients of the recipe than actually watching the movie.Take Fahrenheit 451, add a big help from 1984, just a dash of Brave New World (injections of drugs), mix a lot of special Matrix effects, add wide-ranging action with a variety of weapons (to add flavor to a samurai sword fight), and just a slice of beefcake with a scene from Christian Bale without Mix well and bake in a crematorium (this future society will incinerate not only books, but works of art and social maladjustments) at 451 degrees until a cover is made orosa of existential depth (there are a lot of characters staring at each other out of the corners of their eyes and two of the characters quote Yeats\' `He wishes for the cloths of heaven. ``) Top with a maraschino cherry for a happy ending (visually as the Fight Club) and you have Equilibrium. The premise of the film is that, after an apocalyptic war, all mankind is governed by a single government, in which a Big Brother figure retains complete mind control and compliance. To avoid conflict, all feelings and feelings are suppressed by constant monitoring and injecting drugs. People who violate the dictated rule are hunted by "clergymen" and eliminated by incineration. The character Christian Bales is one of the "clergymen". "He is a single father of two children whose wife was burned. He is a top cleric, but as the film progresses, he begins to have doubts about what he is doing. Ultimately, he seeks underground resistance leaders who are literally clandestine, forced to live in a secret room. full of a mix of paintings, books, antique toys and bric a brac (not unlike a modern teenager\'s room). Inspired by a young girl he has in custody and a cute puppy, he joins the resistance. After a career of killing and incinerating people, they will remain emotionless and will not kill themselves and blow things up, Bale said. The character kills people and blows things up so that society can express their emotions and everyone starts to kill themselves and blow things up.'

b"In the 1960s, when filmmaking was still an art form, master puppeteer manipulator George Pal created what was considered a true classic, The Time Machine. Selecting as his hero, handsome and courageous Austrian actor Rod Taylor, playing Herbert George Wells, the director accurately portrays the adventurous but moody, Victorian as a gentleman, who plays with inventions and yearns for a more peaceful century to live . . Using what has been hailed as the best special effects of that date, Pal launches Taylor in the future. Stopping only to observe the changing eras where war is waged with better and more sophisticated weapons, Wells finally arrives at Eloi's land. Here he meets the beautiful and sensual Weena (Yvette Mimieux) and his people. During their brief time together, Weena lets Wells know that despite her idyllic paradise, it is not without perils. In this future, it is the Morlocks who have become the masters of the world and have stolen the Wells time machine. Condemned to spend eternity in the future, Taylor engages in battle with the Morlocks, resulting in a story that he later will relate to David Filby (Alan Young) and his Victorian friends. The film is superb and although it has been redone several times, it has never been matched. Mr Wells would have approved. *****"

b"The Italian work of the 1960s is well known to the British public, for whom the film is as common on the Christmas TV show as the James Bond films The Great Escape and the Queen's speech. Negative reviews of American viewers result both from the lack of a cultural context and from the ignorance of many people in the cast. The film has aged well and offers a fun snapshot of the British culture of the 1960s. The cast includes Noel Coward as Mr. Bridger, the crime leader, and Michael Caine as the failed Charlie Croker. The British public will recognize a number of well-known actors in special roles, including Benny Hill and John Le Mesurier. The stars of the film are undoubtedly the cars. Curiously, the 1960s supercar variety, including a Lamborghini Muira, E-Type Jaguars and Charlie's Aston Martin, are being overshadowed by the three Mini Coopers who lead the Italian police in an incredible car race in Turin. Remy Julienne and his stunt team produced one of the most incredible and known, at least for the British public, car chases in the movies. Undoubtedly, it is still considered one of the best car chase sequences and even more so because acrobatics were actually filmed in Turin (and Coventry in the case of sewage scenes) and in cars with minimal modifications. There are many memorable moments. in the film beyond the sequence of the Mini Cooper. Caine's 'blew the doors', Benny Hill's obsessed woman, Professor Peach, on the tram in Turin, and the end of the 'hanging', in my mind. The DVD's extra features are good, but not truly remarkable. The documentary 'Making Of' provides several interesting insights about the film. The track of comment overlays is a bit flamboyant, but worth listening to. There is only one scene deleted, the incredible ballet 'Blue Danube' on the ice. In summary, this is a true British classic with a great cast, soundtrack and plot. A good snapshot of London from the 60's, a fantastic (at least for the UK public) and the superb car chase scene make this the first to buy. The remake of Hollywood, although not a bad movie in its own right, shares only the title, a plot based on a gold theft and the BMW Mini updated with the original. And for anyone asking about the original of the Mini, they really are small and lots of fun to drive."

b'28 Days Later is a film so well treated in terms of suspense, acting and meaning, that every time I watch it I become more convinced that it will become a classic in the horror-science fiction genre. It is not so with the "sequence," which Fresnadillo may well be directing, but is not well structured as narrative, and does not lend any valuable "message" to the public. 28 Weeks Later often incurs the error of insulting our intelligence. How can you explain that the survivor\'s husband who is detained in a security health facility can gain access to the room without finding a guard, no doctors, no soldiers, no surveillance personnel at the scene? There are no cameras even in a situation where the reappearance of the virus is feared and it is possible after the diagnosis made by the medical staff of the female survivor. In fact, this is the main event that causes virus violation. In addition, the film is so focused on bloodshed, bites and vampire races that no meaningful dialogue is possible, preventing anyone from making any sense of the chaos. And what can you say about the helicopter used as a deadly saw to decapitate dozens of vampire zombies? The least I can say is that the scene is the height of sensationalism. And insisting on the meaning of the film, why such a valuable element in the story as the possibility that the female survivor or her children hold the key to curing the virus is just a waste in favor of leaving the public with a final terrible, pessimistic and fatal? Is this the bait for another sequel, parallel to the "Alien" series? Meanwhile, we get a "sequel" that does not properly honor 28 Days Later, no matter the fact that Boyle is among the producers.'

b"I had no idea that Ganz had in him to be so great until I saw him here as Hitler. Alexandra Maria Lara as her naive young secretary is also very good. The cast is excellent. Director Oliver Hirschbieger cleverly pulls everything together and will keep you on the edge of your seat all the way through - though we all know how the tale has ended. The film gets under your skin and it pokes at your psyche long after you've seen it - and this is some trick. How did the creators of this movie achieve this? By avoiding the usual approach of making Hitler and his thugs SS thugs as two-dimensional cartoon characters, instead, they show their lot to be what they were: humans. Mass murderers mixed up, misguided, fanatical, barbarian, cold-blooded - and all in search of power (which they never attained), but humans nonetheless. What is sad here, as far as I am concerned, instead of encouraging your nation to concentrate all this energy on making the world a better place, because the Germans, the German people, gave us much more than good cars and excellent lenses of beer and camera ... Hitler and his henchmen had their people squandering all this potential in causing destruction and chaos, misery and pain ... for nothing. I realize that some Germans did not care about Hitler and his crazy notions ... but there was not much they could do about (once he came to power and they saw where he was actually taking them ... straight to hell ). Any German who opposed the dreaded SS and the Gestapo ended up dead or somewhere in the country somewhere to suffer the consequences. I've always wondered what it must have been like for Hitler and his people in that bunker during the last months / weeks / days. .. This powerful movie shows what happened - and then some."

b"Werner Herzog is the perfect and unique personification of the always concerned, irreverent, dissatisfied and nonconformist director who likes to walk on the razor's edge and delights in exposing limit situations on the eve of reaching the boiling point. its cinematography was signed by novelty and original proposals, characterized by unexplored territories and unthinkable stages. In this case, we help the clash of two distinctly different civilizations, the aboriginal ancestry and the Western way of life, where myth and progress collide as the inevitable collision of two trains shifting each one in opposite directions. A company will set up in the middle of the Australian desert to explore and exploit uranium reserves. But they will be confronted by ancestral tribes who oppose them, for they will interrupt the dream of the green ants. A film dedicated to Herzog's mother, with intriguing and clear reflections all the time, when this case is discussed in the Supreme Court. through a very interesting essay, where the happy ending will be absent. The final sequence will invite you to think and reflect."

b'For starters, I\'m a lifelong bodybuilder and fan of Arnold Schwarzenegger, so even though he\'s strictly a co-star on that, I\'m obviously partial. That said, however, I absolutely love this whole movie! One of my favorite parts is the way some of the best advice I\'ve heard about friendships and relationships in general is dispensed with throughout the movie, sometimes you did not even realize that you were learning something. b'I saw this movie about a month ago at the local cinematheque. About eighty minutes I looked discreetly at my watch and was disappointed with the realization that the film was not even halfway. Celine and Julie go by boat? There was not a body of water, much less a boat, in sight so far. Where was this bizarre story with scenes being repeated several times, and when would it end? I am a patient movie viewer, but that was too much. A number of film critics, whose opinions I usually respect, have practically built religions around their appreciation of this film. I wondered if this could just be a case of the "emperor\'s new clothes"? Almost two hours later, it was all over and I left the theater thinking I might have seen two real cinematographic masterpieces in the time I wasted on the Rivette movie ... But somehow, it was not really over. The effect of the film remained. It was not just an intellectual conundrum I needed to deal with, the movie had affected me. Scenes kept repeating in my head like a strange dream. Her pace was unlike anything I\'d encountered before. Celine and Julie have never adapted to any of my expectations - and neither does Jacques Rivette. In two separate scenes in the film, Celine and Julie introduce themselves to the men, who unconsciously think they are meeting the other woman. In each case, the two women completely subvert the worlds of men, opening gaps in their rigid conventionality. Throughout the movie, Rivette was doing the same thing to me. Everything about the movie, from the "plot" to the subtle manipulation of reality to the beat, forces you to abandon your expectations (or to feel unhappy in trying to hold them). You have to relate to the movie on your own level, as you would with a child. Only then can you have fun. I do not know exactly why the movie had such an effect on me, but it says something about its power that, over a month later, I\'m still thinking about it. In recent days, I\'ve had this growing need to see `` Celine and Julie Go Boating \'\' again. The ideal circumstance for a first date with him is definitely in a theater or you might end up hanging up. Now that I\'ve gone through Rubicon, I\'d like it to be available in a region of 0 or 1 DVD so that I could lose another three hours.'

b"& quot; Back to the Future & quot; it can be the most charming comedy / adventure that exists. The film is a science fiction tale about a young man traveling accidentally in the age of 30 until the 1950s. While sci-fi films less focused on the ideas of time and hardware paradoxes, & quot; & quot; Back to the Future & quot; focuses on wonder with open eyes, charming characters and very good humor.The story begins with Marty McFly in the year 1985. Marty is a hopeless lazy with two idiot parents and a mad scientist friend. Marty's friend, Doc Brown, perfected a pluto-powered time machine made from a DeLorean sports car. After a successful test, Marty is accidentally transplanted to the year 1955 and abandoned there, he left his extra plutonium in 1985. What happens next is a series of wonderful surprises when Marty interacts with the people of the city of 1950 while looking for the younger version of Doc Brown, but what's even more surprising and magical is Marty's relationship with his parents as teenagers. The film takes the perspective of a young man from his loser parents and makes him realize that his parents were as hopeful and fearful as he was. He finally meets his parents for the first time. The film also suggests the hopeful notion that you can go back in time and help your parents when they need it most, as Marty certainly does. While the film is a light hearted joke, there is plenty of action as Doc Brown devises an exciting scheme to bring Marty back into the future involving lightning, many visual effects and a high-tech race. & quot; Back to the Future & quot; is the most perfectly balanced blend of science fiction, comedy and adventure. It is a movie suitable for children from the 80s and 50s."

b'"I Know Who Killed Me" is a vile little horror game that was conceived as a kind of "comeback" vehicle for Lindsay Lohan in early 2007. Needless to say, the movie was unsuccessful in that effort. Anything but.Lohan plays Aubrey Fleming, an attractive but relatively naive high school student who is the victim of a serial killer crazy for tortures that manages to cut off some of her limbs before she miraculously escapes her claws. When she wakes up at the hospital, she believes she\'s a girl named Dakota Moss, a sort of fictional alter ego with a life of soft-porn dating - which provides us with ample opportunity for Lohan to wear lightly as she squirms in slow motion performing pole dances on a sloppy striper joint. It is Aubrey, herself a fiction writer, simply a victim of repression, a wild, free spirit so obsessed with being a "good girl" that she allowed her true nature to remain buried in her subconscious. years? And the trauma she has suffered is simply the vehicle through which this true nature can now surface? Or is there another explanation less purely psychological - say, symbiotic twins? - by this sudden change of identity? It does not really matter what the answers to these questions are, for this depressing incursion into sadism, dismemberment and supernatural spells is poorly written, amateurish, and utterly devoid of emotion or common sense. In fact, the story itself might have some validity if it had not forced the audience to dive into as many free wear as it. But as it is, whenever we begin to develop even the slightest interest in what is happening, we are subject to another round of sangria revving the stomach. Disgusting .'

b'Having grown up with the original Thunderbirds on TV (even on B & W), I was hoping for something better. I suppose, since I\'m starting a little, pubescent teen angst does not appeal much anymore. I wanted to see the machines, the drama, the tension of the people dealing with disasters that took them beyond them, the triumph of decent people over the impersonal malevolence of nature and all those good things that the original had in abundance, along with a campiness and humor that does not take itself too seriously. b'Carole Lombard was a beautiful intelligent natural blonde, the highest female comedian of Screwball, the highest paid actress, wife of Clark Gable and one of Hollywood\'s most powerful women during the 1930s until her untimely death in 1942. This beautifully restored DVD gives us a taste of Carole Lombard and the effect she had on the audience of the 1930s. This was her only Technicolor film she ever made. So sit back and watch your natural beauty and your genius evolve on the screen. Fredric March, as his co-star, adds to this adorably humorous film. In summary: A Vermont girl, Hazel Flagg (Lombard), diagnosed to have radio poisoning (terminal). A hot shot from the New York Jounalist (March) reads about it in a newspaper and wants to use this event to increase the popularity of their magazines by sponsoring Hazel. Bringing her to New York City and presenting her with the "Keys to the City" and VIP status enhances public awareness. All the time using the public sympathy to increase magazine sales. Hazel discovers that she has been misdiagnosed and reluctantly continues with the fraud. In the meantime, March begins to fall in love with Hazel and he wants her to rest and be comfortable until the end of it arrives. As you can see, this has a strange twist on events, which is the main ingredient of the 1930\'s "SCREWBALL COMBS" proving `` nothing is sacred! \'\' ! ! Extras include: 2 early Lombard movies and Gable & Lombard home movies. This is a `` LIMITED EDITION \'\' collectible DVD.'

b'Spoilers ahead, but again, who is not familiar with Casablanca, even if he has not seen it? I have been to \'Casablanca\' several times since I bought the Special Edition DVD, and is there a movie out there that you can watch over and over without ever getting tired of it? And does any movie appeal to a wider audience? Just about everything seems to be as close to perfection as it can be. But what exactly is so special about it? Is it your great mix of genres, never matched by another movie? When we think of \'Casablanca\' first, we remember it as a romantic movie (well, most of us). But again, it\'s also a drama involving terror, murder, and flight. One can call this character study, focusing on Rick. And there are a few moments of comic delight, just think of the pickpocket ("This place is full of vultures, vultures everywhere!") Or the elderly couple the last night before their emigration to the US ("What to watch \'\'.). But \'Casablanca\' is not only great overall, it\'s still at the top if we break it down and look at simple lines of dialogue, scenes or performances by themselves. Is there any other film that has a more quoteable dialogue? that \'Casablanca\'? \'Pulp Fiction\' is on my mind here, and \'All About Eve\' and \'Sunset Blvd.\' Come close too, but I still think \'Casablanca\' is at the top of everything. just the great dialogue, is inexhaustibly delivered, especially by Humphrey Bogart ("I was misinformed") and Claude Rains ("I\'m shocked, shocked to discover that the game is going on here.") Many of the scenes have become part of the Die Wacht am Rhein \'and\' La Marseillaise \'is probably and one of the biggest scenes ever filmed (the only one I can think of that would rival him for the first place is Hynkel and Chaplin\'s world). Great Dictator \'), and the last scene is probably familiar to the few people who have never seen\' Casablanca \'. Am I the only one who is absolutely convinced that the movie would not have become what it is today if Rick and Ilsa had ended up as the lucky couple? On the performances: Much has been said about the uniqueness of the chemistry of Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman as Rick and Ilsa, about the incredible turn of Claude Rains as Renault, about the performances of stealing the scene of Peter Lorre (one of the 10 greatest actors of all time) like Ugarte and Sydney Greenstreet like Ferrari and about Dooley Wilson stopping the show like Sam. I would love to emphasize here two other performances, one that is not mentioned so many times and one that is shamelessly ignored: Conrad Veidt as Major Strasser had a really difficult task here, since his character is the only evil but yet Strasser is not a character and it took more than 50 years until another actor gave a similar (perhaps even more) impressive performance than a Nazi, Ralph Fiennes on Schindler\'s List. But why does no one mention S. K. Sakall, who plays Carl, the cheery waiter at Rick\'s Caf? I am Ricain is beyond me. He definitely has more time on the screen than Lorre, Greenstreet and Wilson, and probably as much as Veidt, and he\'s a joy whenever he\'s on the screen. I simply love his reaction when the "Vultures everywhere!" Accidentally comes up against him, or the reaction to the "What watch" dialogue. Or as he says he gave Strasser the best table, "being a German, he would have taken it anyway." His performance is simply forgotten criminally. So, is there a weaker link in \'Casablanca\'? Each film, no matter how close to perfection, has a small flaw or two, so one can find them in \'Casablanca\' too if one really strives. So, yes, one might ask how much sense all the nonsense about the traffic bills does. It may be noted that Paul Henreid, though his performance is certainly good, does not come close to the grandeur of any of his co-stars. However, the film is so close to perfection that I\'m almost embarrassed to be desperately trying to find less than perfect elements. So any movies that will come, how many sequences will overflow on the screen, and how much trash we\'ll have to sit, one thing is certain if we\'re desperate to see a great movie: we\'ll always have Casablanca!'

b'Sites that track positive and negative critics of top critics record a positive rating of at least 95 percent for Ratatouille, putting it clearly at the top of the 2007 films. Is it the best movie of the year? No, but it is the one that has the biggest appeal, since almost everyone will consider it a positive experience. Ratatouille follows Remy, a curious rat who aspires to be more than a thief. The keen sense of smell and appreciation for Remy\'s food lure him into the culinary arts. By stealing what he can from an appreciation of elderly owners for cooking programs and books, Remy becomes a devotee of one of France\'s most famous chefs, Auguste Gusteau. After Remy discovers that Gusteau died years ago and he was watching reruns of his television show, the mouse begins to be guided by Ben Kenobi by the spirit of the dead chef. Following the spirit eventually leads him to the old restaurant of Gusteau, which was taken over by an artless capitalist who uses the image of Gusteau to sell frozen burritos and corndogs. By using a young kitchen worker as a medium, Remy attempts to rebuild Gusteau\'s reputation and return his restaurant to his glory. The resulting action is an often charming tale of a mouse that is dedicated as much to meet as to reach its goal. Many laughs are found when his family comes looking for handouts, and the main antagonists (the owner and a food critic) create real dramatic moments of danger. Remy is truly a "hero" movie, someone dedicated to a cause that he believes will make the world a better place. Despite not having the heart of the Toy Story movies or the comedic brilliance of the first Shrek, Ratatouille continues the trend of revival of animation that provided some of the best films of the last decade.'

b'Originally released for Christmas in 1935, this splendidly produced, atmospheric and magnificently acclaimed film showed the M-G-M\'s talent for filming literary classics - DAVID COPPERFIELD was released earlier that year - without cost savings; The assault on the Bastille sequel employed thousands of extras and was filmed on one of the biggest Hollywood sets of all time. Ronald Colman was initially reluctant to play the role of Sidney Carlton, that charming but dissolute lawyer who commits the ultimate self - sacrifice ... ... It took a lot of persuasion to make Colman shave his trademark mustache for the role of Carlton, but he delivered more than likely his best performance. (Later in his life, Colman admitted that this was his favorite of all his roles.) Charles Dicken\'s seething 17th-century classic of Paris and London and the events surrounding the French Revolution were filmed as silences on four different occasions - twice in Britain and America - and this remains the definitive masterpiece. Under the meticulous direction of Jack Conway, TALE OF TWO CITIES offers memorable performances from an outstanding cast including the wonderful Hammie Blanche Yurka, the scary Lucille LaVerne, the Edna May Oliver Vinegar, the despicable Basil Rathbone, the eloquent Henry B Walthall (he was the "Little Colonel" in BIRTH OF A NATION) and, in a radical change of pace, the tiny Isabel Jewell, as the pathetic seamstress who accompanies Colman to the place of his execution.'

b'I was just beginning my long passion with music in 1967 when I ran to Buckley. His early albums mesmerized me and I\'ve never been without an incarnation of the top three ever since, whether LP or CD. When LORCA left I went with it to some extent, but I admit that I totally lost the thread from where Buckley was going through STARSAILOR. This DVD, which features a very good range of clips throughout his career, gives a new appreciation to all phases of an artist who pushed hard the creative envelope (achieving a quasi-commercial suicide in the attempt). When I watched the performances of the later era, I felt guilty for abandoning Buckley in its later stages, but it takes a maturity to appreciate this material that I did not have at the time. Now I find this inspiring, magical, transcendent. The DVD is a "must have" for anyone who has an interest in this incredible talent, and it\'s great to finally see these performances in high quality.'

b'What can I say about this uninspired "account" of Bret\'s first novel? The film adaptation does not contain the scenes and the tone I thought made the book so scary and memorable. (The dead boy in the alley scene, the snuff movie with the underage girl ...) This movie really can not be claimed that it\'s based on the book - it\'s more that it\'s inspired by the novel. Despite this downfall, it\'s worth watching the movie for any fan of Bret Easton Ellis - even if it\'s to satisfy someone\'s curiosity. The film does not contain the one-sided phrases or the small characters that make the book so interesting and engaging (Sisters of Clay, Spin) The movie made it seem like Julian was the protagonist while I always felt the novel was about seeing the events unfolding through Clay\'s eyes. One of the most engaging parts of the novel is Clay\'s flashbacks of a better time before he goes to school. The film only talks about it at first, and the flashback is about Blair, not about his parents, who were the flashbacks I found most interesting. The lunch scene between Clay and his father is pure genius. The distance between father and son made me shudder physically. This scene is not included in the movie. The unfortunate thing about adapting movies from books is that you almost always miss something in the \'translation\'. \'American Psycho\' is really the only one of the films adapted from his books that I feel captures the tone of the book while simultaneously the compact in a watchable narrative without losing the style of Bret, and this is due to the fact that Bateman himself is the storyteller. Everyone and everyone, \'Less Than Zero\' is not a bad movie, actually. Just a bad adaptation. It captures what was both incredible and forgettable about the popular 1980s movie, and fits into any teenage drama of the era (including the extravagant use of cocaine by minors, New Wave, the future star of Where Are They? Now, James Spader). There are some exciting moments, but it seems that the film tried to find a conclusion that the book did not (and had a reason not to). After all, Julian does not die in the novel, and Blair certainly does not return to Camden with Clay (Morrissey would not be proud). What is so melancholic about the novel is what the movie did not get. also alludes to: how upset, apathetic, nd lost Clay is now that he has changed and gained a new perspective, while his friends, unfortunately, have not.A serious complaint: Where is the outdoor Disappear Here? It is an integral part of the pictures of the novel, and is absent in the film (unless I have lost it). Everything and everyone: If you are a fan of Bret\'s books, give this movie a chance. Worth watching once, but do not get upset if you hardly try to capture the mood or purpose of the novel.'

Mayer [MGM]. She appeared in a number of B-grade films (perhaps C), often without credits. I still carry a torch for her. In fact she would be as old as my grandmother. On the screen, however, it holds a regal appeal. Beatrice Roberts has finally disappeared into obscurity and is apparently buried in Plymouth, Massachusetts, near my hometown. b'When I came across Across the Universe for the first time, it seemed a bit esoteric, even with the Beatles\' musical pedigree. But from the first minute, when Jim Sturgess sings "Girl" - it all makes sense. You have to really respect how well the Beatles\' musical legacy has been entwined in this effort. Lennon, McCartney, Harrison and Starr made some of the best songs of the 20th century and besides being a good movie, Across the Universe really puts that in focus. The power of the songs comes to life at every turn. Vividly imagined with art direction and cinematography, Across the Universe cleverly weaves the Beatles into the socio-political context of the times when the songs were written. Let\'s take the hat off to director Julie Taymor and the crew who clearly found it very well, and the excellent cast that everyone sings better than anyone could expect. This is a great feat considering it could have been complimentary or badly done. The actor Sturgess reminds me of a young Paul McCartney, but that\'s where the resemblance to anything from the Beatles ends. It\'s a shame Across the Universe has not been successful in theaters as well, but I suspect the treatment was very clever. to the audience today. It is a movie that comes from the heart that every fan of the Beatles must watch and the curious about the music can check.'

b'First of all, I want to thank all the reviewers here. It\'s the reviews of this beautiful film that tried to buy me (this and the fact that the director also did "Breaker Morant" - one of my favorites). I\'m a big fan of that genre. I loved `` Dances with Wolves \'\' and `` Jeremiah Johnson, \'\' and I really enjoyed `` The Last of the Mohicans \'\' and `` Last of the Dogmen, \'\' but none of these great movies compares with absolute. realism depicted in "Black Robe". This is a simple story set in the early seventeenth century ... a story of a French Jesuit priest who was accused by his canoe superiors to an outpost of Huron to 1,500 miles away help of Indian scouts and an interpreter) and help to convert the Huronian Indians to Christianity, thus saving their souls. In this film the protagonist is not a superhero who does not make mistakes, shows no weaknesses, can shoot and leave in any man alive. On the contrary, he is just a young priest full of self-righteousness, ignorance, fear and doubt. But despite this (or because of this), his bravery is truly incomparable. This is a story of real people fighting for their lives every day against the harshness of nature and against other Indian tribes. This is also a story about the confrontation between two very varied cultures. This is shown with an unusual subtlety, but the effects are devastating. `` Black Robe \'\' goes where few movies have gone before, or ever since. It\'s a movie as Oscar-worthy as any I\'ve ever seen. Cinematography is dark, cold, and relentless, as is history. Between 1 and 10, I give this landmark a solid movie 9. It is truly one of my favorites.'

b'Lewis Gilbert\'s 1983 masterpiece, a sensitive and emotionally satisfying adaptation of Willy Russel\'s intelligent and insightful two-character set. Gilbert and Russell would team up again for the wonderful & quot; Shirley Valentine, & quot; but their work in this film remains unparalleled. Michael Caine makes one of the most memorable performances of an illustrious career, disappearing into his Frank character, and Julie Walters is magnificent as Rita / Susan. David Hentschel\'s music is perfectly appropriate, Frank Watts\'s cinematography is inspired, the script is both touching and honest, but the magic of this film lies in the interaction between the two main characters. This film captures the journey towards self-consciousness embedded in education, as the character Rita / Susan develops from hairdresser to student, intellectual, dilitante and, finally, in someone very different than at the beginning of the film, but still undeniably and solely "Rita "The greatest gift one person can give to another is the love of learning, and so I feel this is one of the greatest love stories ever made for celluloid.The ending may be" as inevitable as tragedy, "in the words of Willy Russel, but the relationship between Frank and Rita has made their emotional journey worthwhile, and we are all richer for their journey.'

b"If Daniel Barenboim is not the greatest living classical musician in the world, he is certainly the most versatile. In a career spanning more than 50 years, his name is linked to many of the celebrated recordings of opera, symphony, small ensemble and piano solo. With the later half of his career marked by the distinction on the podium, it may be forgotten that he is still an accomplished concert pianist. Here we are treated with both talents as Barenboim leads to Staatskapelle Berlin and plays all five Beethoven piano concerts. From the accompanying booklet, we find that Barenboim recorded these works for the first time in 1967 at the age of twenty-four, under Otto Klemperer. Now he is revisiting them 40 years later, on the occasion of his 65th birthday. The challenges of serving as conductor and soloist are undoubtedly considerable, but Barenboim, acting entirely from memory and without punctuation, makes it look easy and natural. Even when fully engaged in his role as a soloist, Barenboim never loses control of the orchestra. Sometimes his direction is in the momentary freedom of a broad gesture from his left hand. At other times, it is the subtlety of his nod or the quickness of his eyes. The Staatskapelle is perfectly attuned to these nuances and their game is always on time and never hesitant. Among the many highlights: the wonderful interchange between piano and clarinet in the Largo of the first concert, an exciting account of Rondo Vivace in the final movement. the room and all the beauty and majesty of the Emperor. The performance was recorded before a live audience during a three-day piano festival in Bochum, Germany, in 2007. The concerts took place at the Jahrhunderthalle, which features an architectural design of a converted steel mill. The minimalist interior, with high ceiling and exposed steel beams, renounces the traditional elegance that adorns many concert halls (and the false pretense that accompanies it). Aesthetically, the Jahrhunderthalle is a place that emphasizes comfort and clean lines of vision above all else. The exhausted audience is appreciative and respectful of music. They are often viewed, but rarely heard (even between movements) until the applause at the end of each job. They are smart (if not formally) dressed people who know good classical music when they hear it. Some of the presentations happened during the day allowing the large back windows to project stunning natural light to the audience as well as to the performers. illuminated even more by the soft lighting of the stage that highlights the musicians and their instruments when necessary and without shadows. The Blu-ray 1080i picture is almost perfect. The skin tones are natural and attractive. The color of the instruments and the suit of the audience are precise without bleeding. The ivory keyboard is properly exposed and balanced with great resolution to see the distinction between the keys. The black levels are strong without losing any detail in the folds of the musicians. Close-ups reveal the polished brass of the French horns as well as the fine grain on the bass and violins. Barenboim is appropriately the center of attention and we can see the delicate strands of his hair and the beads of sweat that begin to shine on his forehead by the third movement of each concert. The PCM 2.0 audio track is clean, but the piano sounds a little. in contrast to the high C. In contrast, the DTS HD-MA 5.1 range, opening the rear channel environment and a wider sound stage, provides a beautiful sound that is warm and spacious and devoid of any mismatch in the upper register. The piano is properly centered, while the sound integrity of each orchestral instrument is presented with distinction according to its location on the stage. The full program runs at approximately 3:20. There are no supplements except some trailers from other Medici Arts releases. An interview with Barenboim, some rehearsal footage and a brief history of the place would have been good, but unfortunately the opportunities were missed. In the end, it's the only thing missing, because it is, in any case, a very welcome release and another great achievement for one of the most distinguished artists of classical music."

b'A Better Way To Die is a dark comedy about a former Chicago cop named "Boomer," who leaves the force after his partner is killed in a secret drug disguise by ruthless thugs, and wants to climb north to turn things around with his estranged girlfriend, but along the way he is robbed, shot, framed and his girlfriend dead in the process, and is mistakenly identified as a missing FBI agent. The Chicago mob and corrupt FBI agents are trying to track down what drives Boomer to a bloodshed and revenge mission. A Better Way to Die is the best action-packed movie of the year 2000, and its dark humor and hilarious gunfights and do not leave viewers disappointed. I recommend a better way to die.'

b'This is an unusual Merchant / Ivory film that focuses on the Indian community of Trinidad from 1943 to about 1954. It focuses in particular on a young teacher who takes a wife, outwits her cunning and greedy father and lives in the countryside , just wanting to write books. Still, he has to make a living, so he becomes a masseuse, who is not a masseur, but a healer. He also writes books about Hinduism, which he publishes himself. He becomes known as the Mystic Masseuse and develops a great repercussion throughout the country. His book and the books that follow are quickly bought by a now worshiped audience that reveres him as a Pundit. A brief career in politics soon follows, only for him to discover that a public he loves can become fickle. The film snakes, as does the life of this scholar. With top-notch cinematography and stellar performances from the entire cast, this is a very good movie, though unusual. Those who are interested in other cultures will find this film of some interest. If you are not so inclined, deduce a star from my review.'

b'I admit I\'ve never seen Mario Bava movies. I just recently joined the Italian cinema with the films of Dario Argento and other Giallo took my interest. So far I\'ve never tried any Bava. So by listening to this movie and being intrigued by the premise, I got the DVD. The premise of the film is that four criminals steal a payroll from pharmaceutical companies during which the escape driver is killed. The three remaining killers flee to a parking lot taking hostages, one of whom they kill to escape. Then, in order not to be seen by the police in a family car, they remove more hostages and this time a middle-aged man and a sick child. At this point, the films were a violent crime film. When it enters the car, the film is basically centered in the movement of the criminals and their hostages. What is good about the film despite the minor flaws is that even in its form (neither Rabid Dogs nor the reissued Kidnapped was completed with Bava\'s support due to circumstances that gained their "lost" status until recently), it is actually a very good thriller of mounted suspense building its tension slowly. As the tensions in the car increase and victims plead for their lives, even the criminals begin to turn against each other. One wants to rape the woman as a hostage, while another goes along with what happens while the leader is more concerned about just reaching his destination. There are moments in the movie that to me have been great, in a transgressive way, that the latest movies do not even come close to the top. And in the end, I do not want to ruin this, but if you get into the plot as much as I do, it will definitely amaze you. I was totally impressed with the movie. One thing is also the feeling of anger that infiltrates every picture. This is a brutal movie to watch at times with your portrayal of a world that is arrogant and rather brutal in considering the situation of the hostages (especially the child). For me, it\'s a film that can almost be compared to one of my favorites, Kurosawa\'s Ran. Unfortunately I only saw the cut Rabid Dogs on the new album from Anchor Bay. It also contains the version of Lamberto Bava Kidnapped more according to the intentions of his father, which I will watch in the future, but was deactivated for the soundtrack of the synthesizer (I love the harpsichord and organs playing in Rabid Dogs, despite admitting that the score is incessant) and did not want to watch the film as soon after seeing it. This is still a definite recommendation from me, worth seeing.'

The actors move in slow motion as if they have no coordination. I'm guessing this is due to a low budget fight choreographer. And the blood! This movie has to have the fluffiest look of blood I've ever seen ... Difficult I'm giving this movie two stars for its violence. The beheadings and such are so exaggerated and 'funny' looking like they are beyond comic. Think Kill Bill multiplied 20 times ... In short, this is a very 'bad' movie from start to finish. There is virtually nothing in this that I would recommend."

b'As many critics say, this is definitely a lightweight, irresistible, funny and simply wonderful movie to watch. No sex, no violence, just a funny story about a salaried man who thinks dancing is the key to freeing himself from his bored existence. The music soundtrack was simply wonderful - every song matched perfectly with every scene. I was fortunate to get a copy of the soundtrack during a trip abroad. Anyway, I found the plot much more engaging and clever than your normal Hollywood movies. Instead of having Sugiyama fall in love with the original girl who brought him to the dance hall, he discovers the pure joy of dancing and his liberating power that brought him closer to his family, encouraging him to show his affection and love more openly and directly . No clich\xc3\xa9s or well-used plots, just a beautiful story.'

b'While it is true that the once-brilliant "Soap" suffers major creative terminal problems in its fourth and final season (why Burt is suddenly the holiest member of the family?), He overcomes virtually every comedy in the air nowadays. his daring mix of comedy, drama, romance, suspense and pathos. The fourth season features many memorable TV moments, if less than the previous three seasons, including Burt\'s crisis of faith, El Puerco and his hilarious introduction to the family, Chester\'s touch and the belated perception that he loves Jessica, marriage Dutch and Eunice cheeky, and Mary struggles to maintain her sanity amid a real insanity. No show today comes close to the "Soap," even in this weaker season. What Sony did with the fourth season is shocking and a mystery. Although their presentations from the first to the fourth period have been technically unnoticed, many of them due to sources, at least the episodes remained intact and were presented as they were originally on ABC and the VHS series release by Columbia House in the 1990s "For some reason, Sony chose to edit the fourth season of` `Soap \'\' by cutting most of the pre-episode recaps (` `In the last episode of \'Soap\' ...` `), some of which were quite smart and none of which consumed more than 40 seconds or more. Worse still, Sony edited the last five one-hour episodes of the season in ten and a half hours, omitting entire scenes and essentially including syndicated versions of the opening portion of the show. (I do not know if these are in fact syndicated versions of these episodes, but they are significantly different from the episodes that appeared on the Columbia House tapes, which featured entire episodes when they appeared on ABC in 1981). full and complete versions of Seasons 1-3, this incomplete and poor season 4 pack is a puzzle, a disappointment and of value only to fans who just need to have the entire series on DVD. Otherwise, the true fans of the unedited full-length series must hold - or find - the last year of the Soap on VHS and suffer the inferior quality until Sony considers it wrong.'

b"This is a great film that portrays the events of the seizure of Air France Flight 139 and Operation Thunderbolt (later called Operation Yonatan) accurately and in great detail. The movie keeps you on the edge of your seat and as events unfold. I saw this movie on the History Channel, in Real to Reel, presented by Steve Gitland, and I enjoyed it so much I went to buy the DVD here on Amazon. I received the 2007 remastered version distributed by WHAM! USA. The picture quality is poor on this disc, but my biggest disappointment is that there are a lot of memorable scenes missing. There is at least one perceptible cut in the film. Some of the scenes I've seen on television, but not on this DVD, are as follows: - The part where they took their passports from the hostages. - When Daniel Cooper's son is informed by a French airport officer about the fate of his father's flight. - An exchange between two hostages over trying to watch the television cameras during one of Idi Amin's visits. - All the scenes showing the release. non-Israeli hostages returning home.- A Catholic nun insisted on staying with the rest of the hostages. All these memorable scenes, which I was eager to see again, are GONE! Although the attack itself seems almost intact, but the scenes are so dark, I had to rely on the memory of the TV version of the movie to know what was going on. All in all, great movie, Bad DVD! I will avoid all of WHAM's products! US in the future."
