b"Currently, this is the only version of Nobody's Fool available on DVD. The fact that you have a Paul Newman doubleheader for the same price as a single title is just a bonus. Nobody's fool is one of my favorite dramas and one of the last great roles of Newman, since his luck is Sully. . The whole cast shines; Without a doubt, this is the best work you've ever seen from Melanie Griffith and Bruce Willis. Add to that a young, pre-Oscar-nominated Philip Seymour Hoffman and the final role of Jessica Tandy and you have a must-see movie and a treasure of its own. I like Richard Russo's books. I really like Mohawk, Nobody's Fool, and the Pulitzer Prize-winning Empire Falls. The last book was translated into an HBO miniseries, Empire Falls, which surprisingly also includes performances by Paul Newman and Philip Seymour Hoffman. However, Newman won only an Oscar, Best Actor for his role in The Color of Money in 1986. However, Newman exudes such casual charm as Sully in Nobody's Fool, which remains my favorite of the two. Classification: Five stars.P.S. I'm not a big fan of `` Fat Man & Little Boy ''. Unlike Nobody 's Fool, the historical drama does not have the charm and humor that I prefer for repeated visions."

b"This workout was great. I completed 15 minutes ago and I can definitely feel it now. The workout is divided into 5 segments of 10 minutes which is a format that I love as it means that you can divide it for a shorter workout and even if you do the whole thing it does not feel like an eternity because of the change segments. The general idea is to do strengthening exercises followed by stretches to lengthen the muscles. Overview of segments: Arms: This was probably my least favorite segment. I prefer the arm segment in 10 minute pilates perfect body solutions. There were about 6-7 minutes of arms work and then 3-4 stretching of the arms. He felt rushed and the signal seemed a little wrong. Besides, I did not find it too difficult. For this segment, you need light hand weights. Thighs: This segment was excellent. They claim that you need a chair to do these exercises, however, if you have reasonably strong thighs and good balance, it is not necessary. These exercises make you feel your thighs, mine started to tremble like crazy at one point and are really effective. Glutes: I think this was the hardest segment on the DVD. I really like that they have a segment especially dedicated to buttocks, much video through them with thighs and I do not think they work too hard. In this segment, the glutes will work hard and a chair is an absolute necessity. I've had to do several breaks during this, but I'm looking forward to working up the complete segment.Abs: I'm glad that this segment was short because despite having been good work for the abs, it was a bit annoying. You put your feet on the wall and sit in a sitting position (do not you think that sounds difficult? I have not tried it for about 8 minutes) and then I make variations from there. It's not my favorite ab workout, but effective, I definitely felt my abdomen overwork. Stretch: I really like when DVDs have a specific long stretch dedicated to stretching. That being said, this was not my favorite stretch segment. I wish the passages had been kept a little less long and there were more different passages. It was over and I still felt the need to do some other stretches to really feel stretched out. But the stretches they did were good, and there is something to be said to keep them for so long and really make your body relax in stretching. Overall, I would definitely recommend buying this video. It's a very effective exercise and I certainly enjoyed all the segments enough to keep doing, even if they were not my favorites. I also really enjoyed having two instructors, one man and one woman, and they showed simpler variations on many of the movements, including when it was best to rest if you needed to. One con I have not mentioned yet (and this is a personal preference thing) is that the instruction is voice-over, which is not my favorite and sometimes I felt like the cueing was not right. Final thoughts: for $ 15 it's worth it!"

b'Every year as a child I expected to see Rudolph, the Red-Nosed Reindeer, during the holidays. In fact, I was eager to see it on TV even as an adult! Wanting to share this great classic with my 7 year old son, I bought it for him a few weeks ago. Of course, I had recorded on a VHS along with other Christmas classics, but the quality was not so good and we had to endure commercials. The DVD version seems to be clean from the TV version in terms of quality. I remember more background fuzzies when I was on TV (maybe the DVD was remastered?) Desinty\'s Child\'s claymation video is basically useless, in my opinion, unless you have a little fan of that kind. of music (and I do not). With a run time of 65 minutes, this DVD has almost no extras. There\'s a lost scene that originally aired in place of the song "Why Am I Such Misfit?" \'\' (an optimistic tone about eliminating and finding his fortune). You can also watch the DVD in Spanish, and my son has fun doing it once in a while. The `` previews \'\' of other DVD\'s - including an annoying promo for one on Peter Rabbit / Easter - seems endless. It\'s a shame that they advertise to death on DVD\'s for young people! And as far as Rudolph\'s story goes: well, I\'ve always been bothered because Rudolph\'s father rejected him for being different - just like Santa Claus himself! Very disappointing, but it\'s not like life - where do people judge on the basis of appearances? Still, I love Rudolph\'s songs, the Red Nose Reindeer, and Hermie, the dentist, Yukon Cornelius and Bumble bring festive nostalgia to our house. And my 7-year-old son plays this DVD at least once a day! What else can you ask for ? (except maybe some fun extras).'

b'After the first year of college, the class meets to relax and have fun. After a party in Stiflers, which almost looks like the first movie, the gang decides to take their adventures to a beach house and spend the summer there. While they are trying to find work and partying on the beach, the boys have some of their own dilemmas they have to deal with. Jim discovers that Nadia is back in the United States after she was expelled from them after the internet disaster. Jim only had sex once and a half since that incident. So, to try to prepare for Nadia, he has the help of Michelle, the band nerd that rocked his world a year ago. As she begins to teach him the ways of sexual behavior, they themselves begin to realize that they may be more than they think they are to each other. Kevin, after separating himself from Vicky, has to overcome his feelings for her once she shows up in the house to have fun. Because to her, they are just friends, and that is why she now has a new boy in her life. Oz has to deal with a long-distance relationship with Heather since she left for the summer. It does not help, however, that his best friend Stifler is constantly trying to get him to have sex with any girl within a three meter radius of them. Speaking of Stifler, he\'s still dealing with the fact that Finch had sex with his mother last year. And Finch is having withdrawals from not being with Stifler\'s mother. For a long time I thought Part 1 was the best of them. I seriously think I\'ve been wrong all this time. After watching it back back last night, I can honestly say that I laughed a lot more with Part 2. The jokes are better and even bolder. The constraints that Jim goes through are hilarious (good God, the super glue scene). The girls are hotter. And choke maybe just a little over the top, but still much better in part 2. When he grabs the vibrator and shakes it while running through the house, I can not stop laughing. And when he says he forgot where he found it, because of all the excitement of when he thought it was just hilarious. The lesbian scene was just laughing out loud funny as well. In the end, I definitely would own it. Just remember, though, if you\'re not into sassy comedy, just stay away.P.S. "There\'s no way a single straight man could have left that house of light without doing something with Nadia. Just not at all.'

b"Alice Walker is a great pioneer. She is one of those African-American women who deserves all our love and adoration. She explores in this film, and behind it in the book, the slow and progressive liberation of black women from their auxiliary slavery. Everything must start in their heads. They must find the courage to develop their own personalities and freedom in the closed chain of their skulls, and then, little by little, they find the strength and power to resist men, and then society, and then stand out. Liberatiion is a mental process that finds its full power when it becomes public and looks at society as the natural field of its achievement. The film is touching, poignant, sensitive, intelligent, sentimental and tremendously powerful, if it is not yet pregnant with the most universal language we can imagine, the language of women's liberation seen as the first step of the liberation of humanity. Alice Walker is universal in this story and deals with the whole world and with all humans. What's more, no one is lost, no one is left on the side of the road, no one is wasted forever with the cause of liberation. Even the worst tyrant will discover in his moral depth the idea and initiative that will make him free along with others, along with those he or she has taught for decades. The husband pays for the immigration of his wife's sister's husband and African family. And he does it for nothing, because he stays on the side and does not claim what he deserves. Salvation is for all or it will not be. Dr. Jacques COULARDEAU, Universities of Paris II and IX."

b'First, I have to clean up. I first saw the Full Metal Jacket in its original movie release. About all that was left with me was the scene in the head that ends the second third of the movie. I bought it at the recommendation of my son, a second lieutenant newly commissioned from the Marines. He calls the FMJ "Marine Film". He also calls the time period a shameful chapter in the history of the Marine Corps. "The routine abuse of recruits described in the film does not happen anymore. Even so, the film hits in both ways. Maritime training, even thirty years later, is as demanding as Kubrick portrays. It has the same goal: the creation of "indestructible men (and now women)" who can kill as many enemies as possible. The experience of the Marines in combat, especially in Vietnam, is as the film demonstrates. By undergoing training that will qualify you to lead a platoon, I asked my son about the incident that led to the second cold-blooded murder. Could it have happened that the Marines would become so lost that they would be at the mercy of a sniper? Absolutely, he replied, adding that Marines see the prospect of urban warfare with anxiety: "There are an infinite number of places where the enemy could be. "In addition, he said, Cowboy made the right choice, although it resulted in the deaths of three Marines. Even though I was on the streets in a different way during Vietnam (and could not have seen the fight anyway - I\'m blind in my right eye and right handed), I\'m convinced Semper Fi is real. "Semper Fi, do or die, gung ho, gung, ho, gung ho." The Marines are in fact the best we have, the inspiration for the Army and Delta Force Rangers and the Navy SEALS. the bar in ways I did not enjoy. Run, do not walk, to see this movie.'

b'No one can soak a book in a frightening, muffled atmosphere like Neil Gaiman, infused with humor and more than a little horror. Fortunately, this flavor is kept alive in the film adaptation of "Coraline", brought to life by the talented Henry Selick. It\'s a scary little fairy tale full of decadent apartments, dancing mice and soulless doppelgangers, as well as a brave heroine who finds herself in this "other" sinister world. Newly moved to an old apartment, Coraline (Dakota Fanning) is bored . Her parents are too busy to do anything with her, and her neighbors are crazy or boring. The only exception is Wybie, a boy who irritates her endlessly. It\'s the relentlessly tedious kind of world any little girl would want to escape-to Coraline. She finds a towed door and a wormhole colored, leading to a new home. In fact, it is so similar that she has a "other mother" with button eyes (Teri Hatcher) and another "father" (John Hodgman), plus good food, games, a glittering magical garden. , a choir of circus rodents and magical toys. At first Coraline is fascinated by the other world, especially since her other parents are as attentive as their true ones are not. Then she finds her true parents sealed inside a mirror. With the help of a sarcastic cat, Coraline ventures back into the next world. But with her parents and a trio of dead children held hostage, Coraline\'s only hope is to bet on her own freedom - and she\'ll be stuck forever if she fails. Neil Gaiman\'s book "Coraline" is a brilliant, dark fairy tale vibration - decadent apartments, dead children, cobwebs, beetles, hands without body, button eyes and a woman with insect button eyes that wants to claim Coraline for herself. It\'s a fairy tale world that turns into a nightmare realm where souls are lost and horrible things hide in the shadows. Most directors would turn the story into a courteous and shameless affair ... but not the director of "The Nightmare Before Christmas." "and" James and the giant peach. "Instead, Selick gives a dark atmosphere full of cobwebs, bright colors and surreal details (the button eclipsing the moon). And it\'s full of charming details that could have been silly (the scary claw), but they work brilliantly. The story begins as merely surreal, but it becomes more ghastly and sinister as the film unfolds - and in the last third, the slow story suddenly turns into a completely scary territory, and a truly terrifying climax, where the Other Mother shows her true self. And along the way, there are plenty of wonderfully scary moments - the three ghosts in a rotten bedroom / mirror, the supply of knobs and thick black wire, strange circus acts and more. The horror is subtle, the delicious shiver is not.Coralina - Alice in this Notsowonderland - is a wonderful little heroine: strong, sensible, self-sufficient but still quite frightened by what is happening around her. Normally I\'m not crazy about Dakota Fanning, but only with voice is she very good at this role. The sarcastic cat is a wonderful counterpoint, and the original character of the movie, Wybie, makes a good (though odd) companion. And the other mother is the stuff of nightmares - she\'s totally inhuman and ruthless, and by the climax of the movie she becomes a nightmare. Oh, and French and Saunders make a couple of funny appearances like crazy neighbors. `` Coraline \'\' is a brilliantly dark little movie full of dark magic and strange creatures - definitely for Gaiman fans, somber fantasies and really scary stuff.'

b"In my review of the Fallen album I quoted Lemmy of Motorhead saying that the album was above and beyond the call of duty. The rest of the quote was that he felt he could not do it live. Well, I have to disagree with Mr. Kilminster as having seen the 'World Domination' tour on his Australian leg, I have to say the band sounded good. And this CD shows that they can really fill the sound mix as well as in their groundbreaking album. This is actually a bit of no frills in terms of audio. The sound is good, the band is fine, which is interesting, considering the personal dramas of the time. The noise of the crowd seems to have been gradual and gradual, although this is a fairly regular situation. The main difference between these Fallen songs and their live versions here is that the sound sounds a little empty. This really is a lucrative job in your fame. Putting a live album when you have no catalog back is a bit cheeky. It also fills the gap between the albums - the aforementioned staff revolts undoubtedly played their part. Not that filling the time between albums with live releases and curiosities is a new idea (G'n'R Lies, anyone?). For fans of this band, this is probably an essential listening. The songs sound good, the audience is adoring and they are a nice project. Three stars for the strength of the songs and because there did not seem to be massive overdubs. The fourth star of the extra DVD that shows the band putting in value. They also sold the DVD separately for some time. Be sure to get this version with the DVD already present as it is worth viewing."

b"4.6 stars I love this movie, and I think both the script and Ford do justice to the original and justifiably beloved TV series. I do not think this blu-ray transfer does much justice to the original impression; Although it is a good and clear image, it is not a big improvement over my DVD. The film itself is an excellent adaptation of the series, and Big Pharma's conspiracy angle is an excellent update that works well. There are thrills in abundance, with a minimum of violence, which I enjoy most every year, when idiot directors and writers rely on guns and blood to fill the holes in their ill-conceived conspiracies. There is more intelligence than this at work here, and director Andrew Davis does everything in a firm and suspenseful way. The ending is a bit weak: I do not buy the scene at the conference, but it works to the extent it should, and that's good enough. Add Ford and Jones at the top of their games and it's a movie worth watching many times, whenever someone needs to be reminded of what a truly good thriller can be. It's too bad they have not prepared it enough for it to be a blu-ray worthy of the description in high definition."

b'The problem with New Moon is that it takes itself very seriously while giving the public many reasons to consider it a joke. I try not to read much in movies, and I believe that individuals are responsible for their own actions, but I agree that this film has influence on girls, and yes, older women as well. I was in the gym once, and a lot of the dialogue reminded me of what I remember hearing from boyfriends and girlfriends. You know, the day you had a great passion and they were the love of your life? Then, 3 weeks later, you move on to another "love of your life". "That\'s how the dialogue sounds. It\'s extravagant, exaggerated, and I\'m sorry for teenagers who think this is what it should be. Edward and Bella have an obsessive and codependent relationship. Discharged by a vampire, so you\'re feeling suicidal? Same ? If you take things from vampire, everything else is still wrong. Bella is an imbecile girl, without emotion, without humor, without notion, completely empty of personality. It\'s very difficult to understand why these guys find her attractive. What does she do ? For her or for someone else? She\'s a big jerk and she treats her father like crap. It\'s simply not credible that two guys are willing to die (one again) for it. She offers nothing in return. She is abandoned by Ed and only consumes the attention that Jacob gives her, with no intention of never repaying her feelings. We call it leadership. Everything is about her to the fullest. What I find particularly amusing is that she asks Jacob if he could just stop being a wolf ... but that same girl would never ask Edward that. It makes no sense . Lautner did the best acting of the three and made me feel for Jake. I read the Wiki page for the book Breaking Dawn and the result for your character sounds like a movie recipe for disaster. At this point, producers need to stop leading girls. He honestly saved the movie. As an adult, I can only deal with so much teen angst and the fact that he broke some smiles prevented me from turning him off. When the werewolf left the forest before chasing Victoria, OK, yes, I thought it was a bear. But still, the werewolf scenes were the best parts. The vampire makeup was terrible and the contacts were distracting. Pattinson was better in the first movie. Stewart was the same non-entity. She was so unreliable. Even if it\'s not in the dialogue, mannerisms, facial expressions and actions can convey a lot about a character. It\'s hard to believe that Bella is not a robot. Even on the DVD cover, it just does not try. Compared with both male leads. Actors must be able to sell the motivations of their characters. Stanley in `Bonde \'was totally reprehensible, but Brando sold it. Stewart does not, and therefore Bella comes out as one of the most unworthy "heroines" that have ever appeared on screen. Wow, I will not stop here.'

b"Good movies about & quot; Great War & quot; (as WWI was known before there was a second) are few and far between. Then & quot; All the silence on the western front & quot; and & quot; Paths of Glory the list is very short. This movie does not meet these standards, but it's still an excellent movie. Overall, the film is quite accurate in terms of its description of the World War I combat. Battle scenes come close to & quot; Saving Private Ryan & quot; level of realism as you can get into commercial television. Be warned that some scenes, especially the & quot; friendly fire & quot; artillery attack, are not for scruples. The supporting cast is a colorful and original collection of characters, devoid of most of the clich\xc3\xa9s of usual war films. You can not look at a character and tell him if he would be dead by the end of the movie. It was easy to imagine that these characters had been ripped off a New York street around 1918. Rick Schroeder gives a first-class performance as the deeply conflicted major Whittlesey, torn between performing his duty and the well-being of his men. There are some moments where the movie hits a fake note. Whittlesey's car at first probably was not built for 15 years after the end of the Great War. The scene in which the major receives his orders seems to ignore the military protocol. And in a major flaw of continuity, Whittlesey's executive office talks about the wandering artillery barrage that happened on that day, when it happened the day before. These are just smaller holes in an otherwise first-class effort."

b"Yes, Keanu Reeves actually plays the villain in this wonderful and magical film of romance, jealousy, romance, betrayal and honor set in Renaissance Italy. Created and starring Kenneth Branagh, this remake of one of Shakespeare's comedies is probably the most enjoyable and entertaining film based on one of the Bard's plays. The cast includes many big names from both sides of the Atlantic, such as Denzel Washington, Emma Thompson and Michael Keaton, and heroine is Kate Beckinsale's first big attraction. The dialogue in the film remains true to the original play and the setting is probably as close as possible to what Shakespeare imagined. The best of all is the music; classic in style, but original in composition. I enjoyed watching this movie several times and so did you."

b"This DVD has my favorite soundtrack for this movie, however, it is out of sync with the video! (which basically ruins it) Chapter selection is also flawed: there are only 4 chapter selections to choose from; Chapter 2 is labeled Chapter 1, and so on ... so there is no selection for Chapter 1. The title menu is also extremely cheap by showing a small photo of the DVD case cover in a background that resembles very much the background image of Windows 95 'blue sky with clouds'. Last, and certainly not least, the quality of the video is terrible. This is probably not worth unless you are planning to remaster the dvd with the soundtrack in sync with the video for personal use, and with a decent chapter selection menu. I hope to find out that someone has already put a legal version along with this soundtrack on dvd (I know it exists in vhs)."

b"Nowadays, Uwe Boll has become a kind of joke among fans of the genre. With titles like Alone in the Dark and House of the Dead on his resume, the German director became synonymous with the picariados works. The weakest brands of the horror genre can be. I suppose it's a bit insensitive of us fans to like Boll's pursuit so much, but if the man has not tried vigorously to make excuses and defend his work. In interviews, I'd be much more willing to cut it. It's one thing to make a terrible movie and defend it by way of an illusory assumption that it's a good thing, but another is to try and cover yourself when you know you're succeeding. I wait patiently for Bloodyne Uwe's unenthusiastic defenses. As with all of these video game-based quicks, the plot is irrelevant. It's something I wrote in the tenth grade English class. All the clich\xc3\xa9s imaginable are on display. It's as if the screenwriter Guinevere Turner had an encyclopedia of banalities. But in spite of these anachronisms, the dialogue is nothing more than rigid and old-fashioned speech, with a humorous aversion to contractions in sentences. The various plotting machinations that provide the impetus for the characters' actions always remain vague and irrelevant. There is very little here for the actors to work. b'The Forbidden Planet is perhaps the pre-eminent work of the 1950s scientific fantasy. It is by no means a hard physical imagination, but it is a thoughtful and intelligent offer in its own way. Famously (but very loosely) based on Shakespeare\'s "The Tempest," this is a film in which there are as many potential layers of meaning as you want to find. With Morbus scaled as Prosper, and Prosper, in turn most likely based on the Elizabethan wizard Dr. John Dee, co-creator of Enochian magical language, is it really a co-incidence that Morbius himself is a linguist? There is much more I would like to say here, but I am holding back by those who are not yet familiar with the film. I do not want to give any spoilers. For those who have seen the film, and who feel inclined to such exercises, I just ask: to whom - or what - do you assign the respective roles of Ariel and Caliban? How would you fit your answers to the broader themes of the film? And what do their answers suggest about how matter and spirit were conceived respectively in the minds of the Elizabethans versus the Americans of the 1950s? Just something to think about. For those who have not yet seen the Forbidden Planet, I would first say that this is a wonderful movie that works perfectly well on the level of a direct adventure that a 10 year old could enjoy. As a work of science fiction, I only emphasize that the depths you will find are more of philosophy than of science; although the classic technological themes of science fiction in the 1950s are presented metaphorically. Fortunately, the reds under the bed / saucer in the sky metaphor that became a clich\xc3\xa9? in much of the day\'s science fiction is nowhere to be found. One thing I want to add before moving on is that this movie is worth being seen just for set design alone. Whether you consider it classic or dated, it is up to you; but by myself I will simply say that I have never seen the visual lexicon of 50s science fiction express itself more fully. Ok, so: so much for the movie. How about the DVD? Well, I\'m happy to say it\'s incredible! Image quality is beautiful, and there are many extras, and very good ones as well. We received loads of promotional material from the time, including in-depth backstage and even an extra bonus movie for kids that also used Robbie the Robot as support. Incidentally, because I\'ve seen some of the comments I\'ve written appear for different editions or releases of what I originally wrote for them, let me emphasize that I\'m writing everything about Forbidden Planet (Special Two-Disc Edition). If you check my profile reviewer, you\'ll see that I\'m not one of those reviewers who distributes five stars as candy. But if you have any interest in classical science fiction, this is a movie you MUST see. And if you\'re looking for the best possible DVD release, the best of my knowledge is this.'

b"Donald O'Connor plays Aladdin as the hero and comic relief in this fantasy of Arabian nights. Conspicuously American in a cast that looks largely European, Aladdin of O'Connor is of humble origins, but never allows his lack of means (or any concrete ideas to acquire any) cushion his dreams of greatness. When he discovers that his new lamp contains a genius that will grant him three wishes, his chance of greatness may finally come true. Nobody believes him, let alone the lovely Djalma, who spent years waiting for him to give up his dreams, settle down and marry her. Assured of his deepest desires, Aladdin travels to Basrah, a large nearby town, which already celebrates the impending marriage of the sultan's daughter with the young but wise Molook. Meanwhile, the prince's vicious Vizir conspires to slay Mollook and steal his crown and his bride and, without male Sultan heirs, the sultan's crown as well. In erring in the plan, Aladdin rides to an improbable rescue with the help of the astute prince and the population of fakirs and beggars of Basorah. This was a fun movie and for some reason ignored. It's okay for the kids, not too violent (except for two scenes, both involving a doll made to look like a real, exotic woman, and designed to crush to death those who get caught in their embrace) and manages to look a lot Hollywood and also very convincingly Arab at the same time. Donald O'Connor manages to steal all the scenes in which he is. This was the kind of movie that used to be on TNT every couple of months, but it has not been in years, so get that tape."

b'* \'\' The Defiant Ones \'\' is one of those rare movies that after being seen only once had the ability to stay with me for life! (Other such gems that have had a similar effect on me include Chaplin\'s first talkie, The Great Dictator, the original "Night of the Living Dead," the ugly and ugly science fiction cult, but fun flick `` Laserblast \'\' and \'\' Citizen Kane \'\' by Orson Welles.I just had the opportunity to buy the DVD and watch this movie for the second time, and it was as good and intense as I remember that first time! \'The Defiant Ones\' unites the legendary Tony Curtis and equally legendary and talented Sidney Poitier as convicted felons John `` Joker \'\' Jackson and Noah Cullen who, as a result of a racial physical confusion between the two, contribute in part to the The resulting crash gives these two chained prisoners an opportunity to get away on foot. But that\'s pre-1960s in the southern US, so when responsible law enforcement officers For tracking the prisi Oneiros discover that the two cons of escapes are of different racial origin, they become somewhat negligent in their quest, mistakenly assuming that the two fugitives will probably kill each other because of racial hatred before even getting five miles. Forced to cooperate despite racial tensions between them, Joker and Noah do not take the situation lightly and are constantly on the move to stay as far away from their pursuers as possible. In the days that follow, the two men form a kind of uneasy camaraderie, and the conversations between them seem to really help to soften some of the racial tensions they exhibit for each other, where each man earns a certain amount of respect for other . Joker is also made to confront some unpleasant realities such as being forced to admit in his heart that Noah is the more rational of the two and especially having to come to terms with the fact that his white skin is not a safety net when he is a fugitive fugitive criminal. There is also a "human interest" story in the film\'s subplot, some of them only slightly ahead of its time: the county sheriff becomes the catalyst that keeps the chase from becoming a carefree and disorderly "good-looking boy" . One of the city\'s people, portrayed by the legendary Lon Chaney Jr., prevents citizens of a city from becoming a mob of emotionally irrational lynching. Cinematography is great for a movie of its time, although some of the scenarios may have been better constructed and arranged (for example, there is a set where the lights of the city of Los Angeles shine in the background beyond the studio). It\'s also good to hear actors conversing with southern accents that do not sound like "Foghorn Leghorn" rejects. Even considering `` redoing \'\' this classic movie would not just be a terrible mistake but would also be a virtual impossibility ... so hopefully no one in Hollyweird, or anywhere else, would ever think of doing it. one thing, and so let this great piece of filmmaking history hold up and continue to stand the test of time. * * *'

b'I agree with everyone that the studios are stealing us again. TV movies should be made available to all fans who have already purchased the individual seasons. Regarding the "whole series" ; I think it\'s a good idea, but it\'s NOT an idea that really works at the moment. My main complaint is the amount of disks and non-standard (LARGE) boxes used for most series. Sure, it looks cool in the store and online, but it sure does not fit nicely on a shelf with the rest of your DVD collection. Try to put some `` full set \'\' box sets on a shelf and see how quickly it starts to look ridiculous! I prefer to buy individual seasons, which fit nicely on a shelf (with the rest of my collection) and usually have better packaging. Remember that some of the "whole season" sets have the disks placed one on top of the other (loose) or simply sliding into small cardboard grooves (which scratches the disks). The real answer to integer sets will be the increased capacity of the BLU-RAY format. Fewer discs, nicer box (standard size), etc. Until then, I intend to buy individual seasons.JM'

b"I'm very disappointed with this movie. Mainly because it looks like he's talking about two different subjects at the same time. On the one hand, the film interviews some experts in the field of philosophy and theology, who effectively trace the history and progression of postmodern thought. On the other hand, there are the two filmmakers who simply discuss their lack of help and sometimes irrelevant to the ideas of discussion. The Williamson brothers are asking questions that have little to do with postmodernism and more with their own personal dissatisfaction with the church. It's as if they make this movie to throw away their own ideas and announce it as a film about postmodernism. While some of the interviews with the experts are useful for clarifying the trends of postmodern thinking, this video as a whole is useless as a whole."

b'The White Hair Bride 2 quickly followed the success of the original film, taking on the tragic story of Cho Yi-Hang (Leslie Cheung) and her forbidden love Lien Ni-Chang (Brigitte Lin). In betraying his sacred oath that he would never doubt his beloved, Cho unleashed a monster. Ni-Chang\'s fury over Cho\'s betrayal drives her completely insane, turning her into a white-haired witch who lives only to destroy all living members of the Eight Clans, especially the Wu Tang clan to which Cho belongs. As for Cho, he retreated to Mount Shin Fung, guarding a mystical flower whose flower (and blooms only once every twenty years) can purify and restore the woman he still loves. Ten years have passed since the deadly night that Ni- Chang went mad and almost alone destroyed the Wu Tang clan. Only two members of the clan survive: Cho, who was guarded on Mount Shin Fung under blizzard conditions all these years, and Cho\'s nephew Kit (Sunny Chan). With Kit\'s impending marriage to Lyre (Joey Maan), the opportunity to promote the lineage exists - and this is how Ni-Chang breaks the party, kidnaps the young bride, and takes her back to her own private castle full of men. - mortal women. There, Lyre is indoctrinated in the philosophy "See a man, kill a man" of the witch and programmed to kill Kit with her own hands. The Eight Clans send their best warriors to try to kill the witch and rescue Lyre, but they are almost defenseless against Ni-Chang, who uses his mortal hair as a more effective weapon (sounds strange, I know, but it works very well). It soon becomes clear that the only person who may be able to defeat the white witch is Cho Yi-Hang, and this sets the stage for an unforgettable meeting between the two former lovers. This sequence is a more direct and action-oriented film. than the original The Bride With White Hair, and for that reason I actually found it nicer on the surface. Still, it lacks the depth and beauty of the original, largely because the two lovers do not meet face to face again until the final scene - although this encounter is worth waiting for. Of course, if you have seen and liked the original, you will want to try this sequel.'

b"I was really looking forward to Disney's epic animated dinosaur. After all, supposedly eight years and millions of people were in training. I do not know exactly what I expected. Did I think the recent explosion in computer graphics technology would result in a corresponding breakthrough in the film's narrative? If so, I must have been naive, for what the powers of Disney have decided to do is to use this dazzling technology and graft in it a story that is merely a repetition of those used in some of its past successes. The dinosaur proves that it is not always the best way to go. The opening is spectacular. A flock of dinosaurs are grazing peacefully. We see a mother taking care of an egg nest. Suddenly, a huge carnasour emerges from the forest looking for dinner. In the ensuing chaos, only one egg survives. What follows is a spectacular series of events in which this egg is transported to a distant island is populated by mammals rather than dinosaurs. A family of lemurs finds the egg, and this is where the movie begins to disintegrate. Lemurs begin to speak, and this is the first time words are used in the film. I did not expect Disney to make a film so profoundly different than any of the characters spoke, but I was surprised to find that they had been taken directly from King Leo and Tarzan. It is as if the jungles of Africa were primitive at Disney World, as if things had been millions of years ago are beyond anyone's imagination. I can not emphasize how beautiful this movie is to look at. This shows us that CGI technology continues to advance at a breathtaking speed. The camera flies through wonderful landscapes, dinosaurs are fanstastic to look at, and the colors are wonderful. One particular scene, in which the dinosaur world is almost destroyed by a spectacular meteor shower, is among the best animated sequences ever produced. As for the story, I wonder how many of the Disney bosses actually have kids of their own. . One wonders if they make decisions based on the children they see around them or focus groups. Has it ever occurred to you that everything that fascinates children is not necessarily cute and cuddly or even safe. When I was a child, for example, I fell in love with the ocean, not because I thought it was warm and safe, but for deeper reasons I could not express it. I'm not sure what the children of today think of as dinosaurs, but I doubt they see them as great puppies or as creatures of Judeo-Christian ethics. In this movie, the dinosaur that the lemurs save grows to be someone who teaches their companions that the survival of the fittest is wrong and that helping their dinosaur mate is everything. Somehow, I do not believe the average child will buy their argument, not when it comes to nature creatures. I think they'll find your preaching a bit boring. Assuming that children take everything and translate it into a fantasy world, Disney has underestimated the intelligence of its young audience and has shown that it may have become somewhat out of touch with its target market, at least when it comes to that. subject."

b"First of all, you can not watch this DVD if you're some kind of politically awkward stranger. All the stereotypes, the metal chiefs, the religious father, and the professor of gender studies, are reinforced and ruthlessly beaten with brutal sarcasm. So if you could be offended by it, DO NOT ASSIST! ! ! There, now, if you can take things with a grain of salt, and you enjoy extremely cruel comedy, then Dirtbags is the movie for you! You get a bunch of college burn-outs, each of them trying to achieve a specific goal in life (usually involving getting women's sexual favors), and engaging in crazy situations where there is usually no escape, just one more dive . in absolute degeneration. I'm sure there's some sort of thesis in this for all of you college students out there ... you may never be able to achieve your goals by dishonest means? Oh, I do not think so. It probably does not make sense, but it does not matter! And you have to love the characters, who are so colorful and strange that no fiction could ever create them completely. These are real images of life ... I've seen male gender studies teachers and Ogre-gym types, so this is stranger than fiction. Like I said, this movie is politically incorrect. No, I'll take it back; is the anti-political correctness. It's great to see that someone went to extremes and completely ridiculed the politically correct, exposing him for the absurdity to which he was brought. If there are no other redeeming qualities of this film in the eyes of the wider public, at least it's the social critique that makes South Park look as tame as Sesame Street. The computer generated randomly and coarsely (the skeleton during the pizza). the man's play across the campus, the bee flying into the soda can, the drowning baby several times in the river) add a nice touch of quirkiness to B movies, and prove the ingenuity of home movies. I personally find these things great. The scenes of random nudity are, in my humble opinion, more out of pure randomness than gratifying drooling on the part of the viewer. Why is there a scene of a naked woman for several minutes? Because it is random and so completely stupid that it becomes quite funny. I need, however, to subtract a star for two reasons: one, the fact that this DVD does not have chapters selections (you can only watch the movie all the time)) and two, the sound. With the sound, there is always music playing, and sometimes it overcomes the dialogue (extremely annoying!), And because of the low budget, some of the dialogues are not cleverly recorded, so it's low on the mix. Once I watched this, I did not really get it, but when I watched it a second time, I was hitting it hysterically. Play a special Peter Steele appearance of Type O Negative, a fantastic soundtrack including Immolation, Candlemass, and a bunch of various funny songs, and you will have a real surprise! ... That is, if you are not afraid of not taking this seriously."

b'I was very disappointed with the Sneiders Perfect Rebounding Workout. I bought it because I wanted an alternative to the Urban Rebounding Compilation DVDs.The first sign of trouble was in the interview beginning on tape, which showed the host, presumably Dr. Sneider, with a gigantic belly. This is not the model I was looking for. To be honest, if you do the training in this video, you will have a good general workout. But the video is so repetitive, completely devoid of enthusiasm, downright boring and unprofessional. For the part in rebound, it makes the same movements, not very imaginative, repeatedly. By switching from one movement to another, the camera is almost never focused on the teacher\'s feet to see what he is doing, so you can only guess. The "class" consists of a group of people totally out of shape and challenged with pace on the front lawn of the Royal Hawaiian hotel. They do not exercise in unison, and the camera is usually in them, not in the teacher. You must have hand weights to make the program. For the abs part of the show, for most of it the cameraman forgot to focus the camera. The two people are just blots. Also, there is absolutely no point in doing your abs or yoga or pilates moves in a rebounder. It is quite uncomfortable doing it, and you can do a much better workout by doing them on a treadmill without getting hurt on the hard rebound frame. While the exercises in the abdominal and yoga parts were good, I highly recommend you get a different DVD, such as Candlelight Yoga (excellent) with Sara Ivanhoe. That has many of the same movements as the yoga part of this workout, but safe, well taught, professionally photographed, and most of all, ENTHUSIASM.This was just a very, very annoying, repetitive exercise video. Urban Rebounding builds are not perfect, but they are MUCH better.'

b'An amazing movie made under almost impossible circumstances. Set in Paris in the 1840s along a lower-class theater district (the "Boulevard of Crime"), the main story is about a mime (played by Jean-Louis Barrault) who falls in love with "a woman of experience ". \'\' - played brilliantly by Arletty. In an incredibly pungent and delicate scene, Arletty almost begs Barrault to make love to her, but he does not seize the moment and he leaves her. She finds lust in the arms of others. Other leading characters include a degenerate philosopher / writer; a Shakespearean actor; a rich score that "holds" Arletty; and the woman who loves Barrault and ends up marrying him. But the love between Barrault and Arletty remains true over the years, although in the end, after spending a glorious night together, she leaves him forever. The acting is superb everywhere, although what makes the film a masterpiece is the writing of Jacques Prevert: the dialogue is simply brilliant. The film was filmed during the Nazi occupation and many of the actors left the set to go out and fight in the resistance. Sets were constantly moved to avoid bombardments and Nazi interference when possible. The film is about 190 minutes long; the Nazis had a law that no film could exceed 90 minutes, so this was done as TWO independent films. The film is not only a testament to love in all its passionate intensity (after all, it\'s a French film), it\'s also about the survival of a country and a big city, Paris - a whole civilization, actually - suffering under the bootheel of a fierce oppressor: it is on the light of love and culture and memory always shining from the darkness of hell. An impressive achievement in all phases of the film production process, from the message of history to the scenes, through acting to photography: it\'s a film of all time.'

b'I have been practicing yoga regularly for about a year. I am familiar with the flow of Vinyasa and with Hatha Yoga and enjoy both. Sadly, Sybel\'s Yoga was a disappointment. I kept thinking she did not know what kind of yoga she was doing: it was focused pose as Hatha, but the pace was extremely fast (faster than most of Vinyasa I did) and there really was no flow to the movements. She jumped directly into poses without any focus of breathing before, and instead of making some movement to warm the body, she began with stretching poses. This confusing pattern continued throughout the dvd, while she alternated between strength, stretching, and relaxation, seemingly at random. Each pose was held for just 2-3 seconds before moving on, and the "inhale, exhale" reminders were too quick for a good soothing yoga breath. Although Sybel mentions in the opening that his yoga is for people at any level of fitness, many of the poses included in this dvd are very advanced for beginners and would need a lot of modification for someone who is not at the peak of fitness.'

b"Well, I saw this at Costco yesterday and I picked it up as it is one of my favorite movies from my childhood. Me and my younger brother usually rent this on VHS from our local rental location every year around the first of the summer vacation. The movie itself is great for a TV movie, it's as good as better than the animated series. The show itself is five stars, so why did I only give two stars? . . Quality is a drug. If you put it on a computer and check the size is only 3.7 GB, not even an entire DVD of 8 GB, then they went to the cheapest way and used a single layer DVD. You can tell this when you play, because it is a DVD interlaced, google interlaced DVD for more information. Basically, this is to play on old TVs and not the current HDTV. It also seems that they used an old VHS to rip rather than using original sources or even a LaserDisc, those huge record-sized DVD discs, they had a much higher quality than VHS and did not degrade over time like VHS . If they pulled from one of them, it would be much better. They also did not need much time to create menus, when you watch trailers and language exchange, it's a simple and muted menu. I could have done a better job with free software on the menus. In addition, the discs were made in Mexico, they could not even spend enough to have the made in the USA. I'm glad it's on DVD now, but for something I've waited so long for I'm upset about it. is of low quality. I can improve the quality a bit by ripping it and running a decomb filter to get rid of the interlaced, but why the hell could they just not put a higher quality product? I also know some people with LaserDisc readers, I can buy the LaserDisc and have them ready for me, burn it to DVD and put it in this case. The case is cool and looks good with my other DVDs and Blurays."

b'For the plot outline, see the back of the DVD box: "Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) is a private investigator specializing in unexplained supernatural phenomena. Their cases plunge into the dark corners of the world, seeking the truth in the hidden remnants of ancient civilizations. Now the greatest mystery of his past is about to become the most dangerous case he has ever faced. With the help of his ex-girlfriend, archaeologist Aline Cedrac (Tara Reid), and his bitter rival, government agent Richard Burke (Stephen Dorff), Edward is about to learn this just because you do not believe in something that does not . t means it can not kill you! "According to the character of Carnby, the fear of the dark is what keeps us alive. Unfortunately, however, the fear of bad movies does not stop us from renting them. Despite the awful reviews, I decided to give in to the temptation to rent Alone In The Dark (I had a free lease, so I figured there could not be much loss). It was even worse than I expected ... On the one hand, creatures that are released from the depths of darkness - or whatever the clich\xc3\xa9 of horse feces is scattered throughout history - are pathetic CGI dinosaurs. Anything interesting, scary or just "cool" about them? Do not . Only nonsense computer-generated monsters that can not entertain the public in the simplest way. For two, the acting is horrendous. Seeing Tara Reid on the DVD\'s top credits made me roll my eyes, but seeing her trying to act as an archaeologist in a science fiction movie made me laugh. The only decent performance midway is given by Christian Slater, but still not enough to cover up the rest. And for three, the film is terribly boring, with few action scenes. Oh, of course, some unknown bumps here and there, some creatures flashing on the screen, and a little blood is included. But the real action? Very little . The small amounts of action he did include the reason why I gave this stinker two stars. I hate watching a movie suffer, but this one deserves it. In conclusion, do not make the same mistakes that most of these reviewers did by renting the movie, knowing how awful it should be. Just rely on the ratings of this one. You will save your money and your time.'

b'In 1879, a British column was almost annihilated by a large "impi" of Zulus warriors near Isandhlwana. Then a small British force camped nearby Rorke\'s Drift (a trading and mission station), made up of 104 shaped soldiers and a number of invalids in a makeshift hospital became the next target. For two days the station was attacked by waves of Zulus warriors. The total number of intruders was about 4500. In the end, almost 400 Zulus were killed compared to only about 20 of the defenders, the hospital was burned to the ground, and 11 Victoria Crosses were awarded to the survivors. The film itself is a reasonably faithful re-creation of events. in Rorke\'s Drift, with good acting by Michael Caine, Stanley Baker and a great support cast of Zulus. The ferocity of the attack, the stubborn and desperate defense of the small garrison, and the chaos of melee combat on the barricades can be felt by cinematography. One wonderful aspect of this film is that the battle scenes were filmed using a large number of actors in the role of Zulu warriors, who were obviously able to re-create the tactics and movements of the royal army of 1879. Their war cries synchronized the spear movements against the shield and the advance of the formation created the sensation of a real army moving to attack the apparently doomed garrison. This is one of the few films that gives the viewer a notion of what combat must have been like in the days before the emergence of mechanized armies.'

b"That's what you expect from the Monty Python guys. It's silly, irreverent and totally weird. Erik the Viking is a comedy of dark humor, and even if that sounds weird, those of you who have seen Monty Python and the Holy Grail or Brian's Life will understand. This will never be called the masterpiece of cinematography, acting or special effects. Then again, it is not for. The film does what it sets out to do. The charm of the film is all about performing some rather silly situations. From Vikings flying across the ends of the Earth to Erik fighting against enemies who think he is invisible. The special effect hardly rivals that of other Python films made in the 1970s, and this was done in 1989. Monty Python's cast performances are not the best, but they are fun and satisfying. The thing is, none of this is really important. Erik the Viking is a good, fun story with some subtle reflections on the human condition and religion. Even the dark stuff turns out not to be so bad in the end. This DVD is really hard to find and to make matters worse, Sony has set up the Director's Cut, but so far never bothered to release it in the United States. If you have a free DVD from the region, there is a 'Son's Cut' from the director available in the UK so there is hope. If you happen to find the rare US-less release for any reasonable price, I'd recommend getting it without question, as Sony has not made any announcements for reissues. If you're a Monty Python fan, see Erik the Viking. Those of you who do not understand the whole mood of Python do not appreciate that either. If you like humor mixed with some decent Norse mythical stories (and it's not critical of low production budgets), then this movie should be a nice drift from reality."

b'We all know Clint Eastwood through his work. The countless Western TV shows and movies that he starred presented to us. His role has changed from Star to Superstar in his epic portrayals of "Dirty Harry," the tough homicide inspector. Since those days, we have seen his excellence as a director in many more excellent dramas and westerns. Although controversial, we investigate their morality and sense of care above and beyond the cultural meanings of morality in Million Dollar Baby. old age when you\'d think Dirty Harry would just be resting in retirement, sipping his beer and smoking his cigarettes on a front porch, Clint Eastwood directs and stars in a movie in which he\'s retired drinking beer and smoking cigarettes on the front porch, growling at everyone, their neighbors, their war experiences, and their own family! In Gran Torino, it shows that it is possible to teach an old dog new tricks. Always immersed in hate, intolerance and racial stereotypes, it is slowly transformed by its neighboring Hmong immigrants. While he takes the young teenager Hmong under his wing (although in the beginning he was made to protect the one thing he really loves, his 1972 mint condition, Gran Torino), he takes the young Thao away from the gang bangers without goal. "Mans" Thao up. (As he has learned, he has inherited flawed standards.) As he does this, he discovers that on the human emotional side he really has much more in common with the Immigrant Ethic than with his own relatives! As \'\' Walt \'\' softens and learns to appreciate the Immigrant\'s generosity and hospitality, we see the true heart of our \'\' Dirty Harry \'\'. "He has more purpose in life now than simply hating everyone and loving his Gran Torino. When young Thao is "man enough" to go on a date, Walt even lets the young man (who has tried to steal his True Love) use his Gran Torino to take her to a date in style! And when the neighborhood gang threatens and attempts to kill the immigrant family, Walt releases Dirty Harry into himself, and sacrifices himself to protect the people who have adopted the "old, crunchy bastard" as one of them! Walt\'s last request was to give Thao his Gran Torino. In the last scene, when we see Thao driving Walt\'s old Gran Torino, the car with the ugly grille as Walt used to do, the joy in Thao\'s face reveals that Thao is not just driving Walt\'s soul. but Walt\'s soul was transplanted into the young Thao! If something that Clint Eastwood did in this worthwhile film is this: show how, in a changing America, by embracing and celebrating diversity in this country, we all strengthen what this country is in the first place! "One among many"'

b"When a nuclear submarine descends unexpectedly in the Pacific Ocean and a hurricane prevents the military from sending a crew into it, they subcontract an oil drilling team under the area headed by Bud Brigman (Ed Harris). To help the probe team, the military sends a group of Navy SEALs, led by Lieutenant Coffey (Michael Biehn), accompanied by the undersea designer and Bud, again wife Lindsey Brigman (Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio). But as they scour the nuclear submarine, they realize there may be more to sink the submarine than they thought, and while Lieutenant Coffey believes the Russians are responsible, the crews believe there may be something more ... supernatural. There are a few directors who really know how to overcome with each of the efforts the way James Cameron does. His first film, Terminator, set a precedent for action movies in the 1980s, and he only surpassed that achievement with the Terminator 2. With Aliens he made a film that was at least equal to that of Ridley Scott's Alien , making a sequence that changed the mood and style, respecting the original. In 1989, James Cameron directed The Abyss, a film that occurred mostly underwater, and was filmed in the largest underwater set of the time. The set, built on a semi-finished nuclear reactor facility, included 7 million gallons of water. So, among Cameron's other achievements, how does The Abyss stand? The Abyss is definitely Cameron's most underrated film. Looking at movies like Avatar, Aliens, Terminator 2 and Terminator 2, it's easy to see how a movie like The Abyss can be overlooked, but on closer inspection, the Abyss fits right next to the others. Like the other Cameron films, he shows great attention to detail with incredible special effects. On a technical scale, the film looks like real life, something that is always great when it comes to a Cameron movie. But like the other Cameron films, it's not about the special effects, but about the human element. Cameron does a great job of humanizing his characters and embodying their relationships. The acting was phenomenal, of course I would expect nothing less from a movie that includes Michael Biehn (The Terminator, Aliens) and Ed Harris (The Truman Show, The Rock). Biehn does very well as a military man who has lost communication with the outside world and has to call himself alone for his next step, and that drives him crazy. Ed Harris is great as the team leader who begs for his ex-wife who continues to run away in different jobs without him, and Marry Elizabeth Mastrantonio is great as the aforementioned wife who thinks getting stuck with Bud and his team is repulsive but grows near the husband she left behind and the staff he administers. If you have not seen this movie but like the other Cameron movies, I recommend you give it a try. I would say that this movie is possibly better than Terminator, and since I think Aliens is better than Terminator, I think this is the same as Aliens. Take a shot, this is definitely a classic that deserves more exposure than the one obtained."

b'(5/3/12, 1 star for this Blu-ray release, 5 stars for the movie) I have the regular DVD with English subtitles, which StudioCanal inexplicably omitted from its Blu-ray version. b"It was the franchise's slugfest that fans thought would never happen except in the form of comic books. After years and years of failed attempts and false beginnings, the powers that finally came together. Hoping to capitalize on the surprise success of the merger of two successful horror franchises with Freddy vs. Jaso, two of the most popular science fiction creatures go all the way in Alien Vs. Predator with those pesky humans caught in the middle. It's not a clich\xc3\xa9; that this movie does not like. Disposable characters are broadly outlined. For example, a bottle cap worn around a character's neck is considered a defining feature. The film even manages to include the old chestnut where the characters surpass the fireball blast. Fans who expect the two alien races to start waiting for over an hour until the first battle, but it is quite impressive when they play around. like something out of a comic book. Of course, the fight scenes are pretty cool in all their CGI-assisted glory, but that's hardly an endorsement. Poor Lance Henriksen is playing here as a selfish businessman who provides the only human connection with the other Alien movies (it is hinted that he is the inspiration for the android bishop in Aliens). It is in only a quarter of the movie before being shipped quickly. There is an audio commentary by screenwriter / director Paul W.S. Anderson and the actors Lance Henriksen and Sanaa Lathan. They connect at the same time seemingly oblivious to the narrative mess that is this movie. Also includes an audio commentary by visual effects supervisor John Bruno and creator effects creators Alec Gillis and Tom Woodruff Jr. Anyone who likes to hear these details will find this track informative. There are three deleted scenes totaling two minutes and include a bit of Predator humor that was properly cut. Also included are two trailers and a gallery of comic book covers. for Alien from Dark Horse Vs. Series Predator.Alien vs. Predator was not worth waiting for and comic book fans will feel cheated. The movie begins slowly but once the Aliens and Predators start hitting each other, the weak script and awkward plot mercifully become the background. It's a shame because both alien races are poised for countless story ideas that subsequent sequences have not been able to capitalize on effectively. All we have left is a beautiful, numbered movie."

b"I was terribly excited to find that one of my favorite classic films, the 1963 Peter Brooks & quot; Lord of the flies was on the dvd. I was even more excited when I saw that I had been offered a luxury treatment by a studio called Criterion. & quot; Lord of the Flies was the first DVD I bought and introduced me to the phenomenal Criterion Collection. Every extra on this DVD is fantastic and interesting, there is no filling or tasteless compliments. Just the comment is worth the price of this DVD, gives a magnificent view on how this film was made: for example, the film was one of the first independent productions ever produced. This is one of those rare remarks that enhances your appreciation and understanding of the film, I rate it alongside & quot; Seven Samurai & quot; and & quot; Great illusion & quot; (also both Criterion dvds reviews) as among the best I've heard. The movie itself seems abitlessly fantastic, worlds better than any vhs or laserdisc editing I've seen previously; The criterion has produced an incredible and clean image that will be outstanding in any video setting. _Lord of the Flies_ is one of my favorite romances; Golding masterfully touched on many themes and concepts about society and managed to capture the essence of mankind in the boy caricatures he created. In most cases, these themes and ideas appear very faithfully in the film. As pointed out in the dvd comment; there is no credit for script, because there was no script, the production team worked directly from the novel, using it as the only source of the story. The result is a remarkably clear and coherent adaptation of the original novel, brought to life with great faith and astonishing dexterity for a filmmaker for the first time. Some technical limitations can still be seen in the final product, but they do little to lessen the pleasure of the film. In short: a fantastic, dark and compelling story is brilliantly brought to life in such a harsh way that it seems to the viewer at times as a documentary unfolding. Finally, the film received a real DVD treatment that perfectly complements and improves the film itself; in everything, the price of admission is worth a lot."

b"Okay, I read the book back in high school and I fell in love with it! I must have read it several times. I recommend it to all my friends. When years later I heard they were making a movie, I was so excited! I was literally jumping up and down. I could not wait to see a new werewolf movie and my least favorite book. I thought this would be great, it would be # 1 at the box office! So I dragged my friends to see them at the opening meeting. What I noticed was that for an opening date, the theater was not very crowded. I thought `` oh, well, maybe people did not understand the title. '' Less than half the way played the movie my mouth just opened in disbelief! It was an abomination! They massacre him with his misinterpretation of the book and use horrible effects! They did not go from humans directly to the wolves in the flash of a bright light! And I almost cried when I saw the end! It was the complete opposite of the book! What the hell he used a silver knife to stab her! ! ! ! This whole movie lost the torment, the feelings and the pain that Vivian was going through at the end of the book. I suggest people who watched this movie read the book! I wanted to get out of the theater so many times if it was not for my friends. I cursed all the time I watched this horrible movie! He made my favorite book so cheesy and fake that it was awful! If there was a rating lower than a star, I would have put it! I really hope that someone comes a lot and make this book get into the movie it could have been! Hell, it could have been as good as Twilight, or rather, if they had followed the BOOK!"

b'Ghost World is a maturing story that defines the character of a generation that is one of the most illusive of modern memory. Enid (Thora Birch) is trapped in a small town with her peers and adults going nowhere. Only Norman, the passenger on a bus, is trustworthy in his opinion - perhaps because he is at least trying to get out of town - though this is not something that is thrown into the audience, but something to think about. a thoughtful film with engaging characters, sharp wit and gentle warmth. The composition, including the use of color in the ensemble and in the clothing, is exuberant and clear; highly expressive editing and camera. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who likes to better understand the lives and problems of middle-class youth struggling with identity-seeking in the late twentieth century.'
b'My 2 year old son did not learn much from this, but this DVD definitely entertains him and keeps him on his feet ... he loves to dance to the music! It pays to buy it!'

b'As a former Navy and Vietnam veteran, I have to disagree with Mr. Brennan\'s portrayal of the second half of this film. The war scenes were marginal at best and they could not grasp the "realism" of the war ... The platoon was much better at it. Especially since Oliver Stone was a veteran himself. However, the scenes from the training camp at the FMJ were accurate. R. Lee Ermey played the Drill Instructor perfectly, as it should have, having been the same in real life. I had several D.I. It\'s like that in the camp and I can assure you, it was like this during the Vietnam war. I can laugh at the movie now, but while at boot camp it was no laughing matter, we were there to learn how to fight and go to war, other skills were learned, but they were secondary. We had to be tough and they were sure we were. The part of the camp was almost like a documentary to me! Having said all this, the movie was like two parts to me. The first half and the second half. With one being killed and the other just so and completely based on a Hollywood perception of what the war was like. For those who were not there, trust me ... It was very different from this version. Overall, because of the performance of R. Lee Ermey and Vincent D\'Onofrio I gave 4 stars.'
